To Greg and Caroline—

致格雷格和卡罗琳——

I couldn’t ask for more.

我别无所求。

#↩

INTRODUCTION

介绍

We make our world significant by the courage of our questions and by the depth of our answers.

—CARL SAGAN

我们凭借提问的勇气和答案的深度，赋予世界意义。——卡尔·萨根

What made you pick up this book?

是什么让你拿起这本书的？

Perhaps you want to negotiate more or feel more comfortable doing it. You’d like to negotiate for a promotion or a raise—or both. You want to feel confident asking for what you’re worth.

或许你想提高谈判技巧，或者希望在谈判时更加得心应手。你想争取升职加薪——或者两者兼而有之。你想自信地提出自己应得的待遇。

Perhaps you’re an entrepreneur and want to grow your business. You’d like to create more loyal clients and get more value from your deals. Maybe you’re contemplating a career transition and want to find your calling.

或许您是一位企业家，想要拓展业务。您希望培养更多忠实客户，并从交易中获得更多价值。或许您正在考虑职业转型，想要找到自己的真正使命。

Or perhaps the reason you picked this book up has nothing to do with work. You’ve been in conflict with someone, and it’s eating up your mental energy. You’d like more understanding in your relationships.

或许你拿起这本书的原因与工作无关。你和某人发生了冲突，这让你精疲力竭。你渴望在人际关系中获得更多理解。

Whatever you’re facing, you now hold in your hands the tool to help you break through: Ten questions that will help you negotiate anything.

无论你面临什么，你现在都掌握了帮助你突破困境的工具：十个问题可以帮助你协商任何事情。

It might seem counterintuitive to learn how to negotiate by asking questions. Twenty years ago, before I first studied conflict resolution, I assumed that negotiation meant winning points, or making demands. But two decades later, I’ve learned something remarkably simple from having resolved hundreds of conflicts as a trained mediator: you get more value in negotiation by asking than you do from arguing.

通过提问来学习谈判技巧，这听起来似乎有悖常理。二十年前，在我第一次学习冲突解决之前，我以为谈判就是为了赢取利益或提出要求。但二十年后，作为一名训练有素的调解员，我处理过数百起冲突，从中我领悟到了一个非常简单的道理：在谈判中，提问比争论更有价值。

When you ask the right questions, of yourself and others, you open a window to create value far beyond what you can imagine. Leading your negotiation with questions not only helps your bottom line, but it helps you connect to people in a way that can transform relationships, personally and professionally.

当你向自己和他人提出正确的问题时，你便打开了一扇创造价值的窗口，其价值远超你的想象。以提问的方式引导谈判，不仅有助于提升你的最终收益，还能帮助你与他人建立联系，从而改善个人和职业关系。

When you change your questions, you change the conversation. In this book, we’ll discuss the power of questions—and not just any questions, but open questions. An open question can become your new negotiation tool to unlock deals and possibilities.

当你改变提问方式，就能改变对话走向。本书将探讨提问的力量——而且不仅仅是任何问题，而是开放式问题。开放式问题可以成为你谈判的新利器，助你达成交易，开启无限可能。

Asking for more also means you start negotiations at the beginning—with you. The first negotiation in any situation is the one you have with yourself. When you spend time asking yourself questions first, before sitting down with someone else, you’ll get more value and more enjoyment from the negotiation process and be more prepared. I’ll walk you through the questions to ask yourself so that you can walk into any negotiation with confidence.

要求更多也意味着你要从一开始就和自己谈判。在任何情况下，第一次谈判都是你和自己的谈判。在与他人谈判之前，先花时间问自己一些问题，你就能从谈判过程中获得更多价值和乐趣，也能做好更充分的准备。我会引导你思考应该问自己的问题，让你自信地应对任何谈判。

Finally, this book will change the way you think about negotiation itself. Ever read a negotiation book and think, That’s not me ? Think again. I’m going to give you a new definition of what it means to negotiate, one that takes negotiation beyond corporate boardrooms and politicians trading soundbites and into everyday life—where we work, live, and dream. One that’s more about listening than performing. One that allows you to be yourself while also creating more value out of every interaction you have. One that takes you far beyond a handshake and helps you create a lifetime of value.

最后，这本书将彻底改变你对谈判本身的认知。你是否曾经读过一些谈判书籍，然后心想：“这不适合我？”再想想。我将为你重新定义谈判的意义，它将谈判的范畴从公司董事会和政客们的空谈延伸到我们日常生活的方方面面——我们工作、生活和梦想的场所。它更注重倾听而非表现。它让你能够展现真我，同时在每一次互动中创造更多价值。它超越了简单的握手，助你创造终身价值。

Asking for More from Negotiation

在谈判中争取更多

Too often, we are taught that negotiation means talking instead of asking. Making your arguments. Controlling the conversation. That negotiation means having all the answers and getting your way to prevent the other person from getting their way. And if we do ask questions, we should only ask questions to which we already know the answer.

我们常常被灌输一种观念：谈判就是滔滔不绝地讲，而不是提问；就是阐述自己的观点，掌控对话；就是掌握所有答案，并坚持己见，阻止对方得逞；即便要提问，也应该只问那些我们已经知道答案的问题。

This performative concept of negotiation not only turns a lot of people off, leading them to avoid it, but it’s also ineffective. You don’t prepare to become an expert negotiator by looking in the mirror and rehearsing your arguments. That’s not negotiation—that’s public speaking. And when you sit down with someone else and lead with those arguments, the other person is less likely to hear you, and prone to give what you say much less credit.

这种表演式的谈判理念不仅让很多人反感，导致他们避而远之，而且也根本无效。你不可能对着镜子练习你的论点就成为谈判专家。那不是谈判，那是公开演讲。当你坐下来和别人交谈时，如果一开始就抛出这些论点，对方就更不愿意听你说话，也更容易对你的观点不以为然。

Having worked with thousands of negotiators over the course of my career, I can tell immediately who the experts in the room are. Expert negotiators know that their greatest source of strength in negotiation is not bluster but knowledge . Expert negotiation requires you to understand yourself and someone else well enough to conduct a conversation that produces value for both parties. But most people don’t ask the right questions to acquire that knowledge. Research shows that only 7 percent of people ask good questions in negotiation—even when sharing information about themselves, or getting the right information about their counterpart, could greatly benefit them. If you start negotiating by launching into your arguments, or asking the wrong questions, you not only miss the chance to create understanding across the table, you may end up settling for less.

在我的职业生涯中，我曾与数千名谈判者共事，因此我能一眼看出谁是谈判高手。谈判专家深知，谈判中最强大的力量并非虚张声势，而是丰富的知识。专业的谈判技巧要求你充分了解自己和对方，从而展开一场对双方都有价值的对话。然而，大多数人并没有提出正确的问题来获取这些知识。研究表明，只有7%的人在谈判中会提出好问题——即使分享自身信息或获取对方的正确信息对他们大有裨益。如果你一开始就急于阐述自己的观点，或者问错了问题，你不仅会错失建立共识的机会，最终可能还会被迫接受更低的条件。

But it doesn’t have to be that way.

但事情并非一定要如此。

What Is Negotiation?

什么是谈判？

When I set out to write this book, I surveyed hundreds of people from many professions and more than a dozen countries about their definition of negotiation, with a sneaking suspicion that most would have negative connotations around the word. In fact, many of the people who answered the survey defined it as something akin to “a back-and-forth discussion to get to an agreement,” with half using the words “compromise” or “concession”—which mean, in effect, a loss . For the people we surveyed, negotiation was analogous to giving up or giving in.

在着手撰写本书时，我调查了来自十几个国家、各行各业的数百人，了解他们对“谈判”的定义。我当时隐隐觉得，大多数人对这个词会有负面的理解。事实上，许多受访者将谈判定义为“为了达成协议而进行的反复讨论”，其中一半人使用了“妥协”或“让步”等词语——这些词语实际上意味着损失。对于我们调查的对象而言，谈判就等同于放弃或让步。

In other words, most people see negotiation as something you do only when you’re trying to get a specific result. And that you have to lose something when you do it.

换句话说，大多数人认为谈判只有在试图获得特定结果时才需要进行，而且谈判过程中你必须有所损失。

Everywhere we turn, whether in a dictionary or a book or on a television show, you get a similar picture. People arguing politics or trading numbers, to try and reach an agreement. For example, some dictionary definitions include:

无论我们翻阅字典、书籍还是电视节目，看到的都是类似的画面：人们争论政治或交换数据，试图达成共识。例如，一些字典定义包括：

  • Formal discussions in which people or groups try to reach an agreement, especially in a business or political situation. ( Macmillan )
    正式的讨论，指人们或团体试图达成协议的场合，尤其指商业或政治场合。（麦克米伦出版社）
  • A formal discussion between people who have different aims or intentions, especially in business and politics, during which they try to reach an agreement. ( Collins )
    谈判是指目标或意图不同的人在商业和政治领域之间进行的正式讨论，旨在达成共识。（柯林斯）

As a result, we are taught to think about negotiation in a limited way that excludes most people and problems. Is it really only negotiation if you’re trading numbers or political positions? Is negotiation really just the back-and-forth immediately preceding an agreement or contract?

因此，我们被教导以一种狭隘的方式看待谈判，这种方式将大多数人和问题排除在外。难道只有在交换数字或政治立场时才算是谈判吗？谈判真的只是达成协议或合同之前的来回磋商吗？

Negotiation: A New Definition

谈判：一种新的定义

When I teach people to negotiate, I start by putting up a point-of-view picture of a kayak going through a series of sea caves. You see the front of the boat, the paddle, some clear blue water, and several caves ahead. I ask: “What does this have to do with negotiation?” Most people look at the picture and say things like, “Negotiation is about strategic decisions. You need to pick which cave you want,” or “Negotiation means choosing the best of the options in front of you.” “Negotiation is advocating for the result you want.”

当我教别人谈判时，我首先会展示一张皮划艇穿过一系列海蚀洞的视角图片。图片上可以看到船头、桨、清澈的蓝色海水，以及前方几个海蚀洞。我会问：“这和谈判有什么关系？” 大多数人看着图片会说：“谈判是关于战略决策的。你需要选择你想进入哪个海蚀洞。”或者“谈判意味着在摆在你面前的选项中选择最佳方案。”“谈判就是争取你想要的结果。”

This is a pretty narrow, outcome-focused way to talk about negotiation. My conception of negotiation comes from a different definition, the one that’s way down the list when you open the dictionary:

这种谈论谈判的方式相当狭隘，只关注结果。我对谈判的理解则来自另一个定义，也就是你在字典里找到的那个定义：

Negotiate /v/: to successfully travel along or over ( Merriam-Webster )

协商 /v/：成功地沿着或越过（韦氏词典）

When you negotiate a kayak through sea caves, or negotiate your way along a hiking trail—in other words, when you successfully travel in the direction you need to go—what are you doing? You’re steering . In my work, I teach that negotiation is any conversation in which you are steering a relationship .

当你划着皮划艇穿过海蚀洞，或者沿着徒步小径行进——换句话说，当你成功地朝着目标方向前进时——你在做什么？你在掌舵。在我的教学中，我强调谈判就是任何你在引导关系走向的对话。

I love the kayak metaphor because it illustrates so many things about negotiation. How do you steer in a kayak? You have to paddle consistently. Even if all you want to do is continue on the course you’ve set, you still need a steady rhythm, left and right, in order to continue traveling the way you want to go. What happens to a kayak if we stop steering? We keep moving, but maybe not in the direction we want. Outside forces like the wind and water will carry us away. And the kayak metaphor tells us one more thing about negotiation: You need the right information to steer with accuracy. You can’t close your eyes and ears and expect to arrive at your destination. You need to watch the waves and feel the direction of the wind. Everything you see, hear, and feel helps you steer with accuracy toward your goal.

我喜欢用皮划艇来比喻谈判，因为它生动地阐释了谈判的诸多要点。皮划艇如何控制方向？你需要持续不断地划桨。即使你只想沿着既定路线前进，也需要保持稳定的节奏，左右划桨，才能继续朝着你想要的方向前进。如果我们停止划桨会发生什么？我们会继续前进，但可能并非朝着我们想要的方向。风和水等外力会将我们带走。皮划艇的比喻还告诉我们谈判的另一个重要方面：你需要掌握正确的信息才能精准地控制方向。你不能闭上眼睛和耳朵，就指望到达目的地。你需要观察波浪，感受风向。你所看到、听到和感受到的一切，都能帮助你精准地朝着目标前进。

All of us can benefit from steering more consistently, and with better information—but too often we don’t. Because we’ve been taught that negotiation is only when you’re talking about money, or that it’s for politicians or businesspeople, we often quit steering. We put the paddle down and wait until our once-a-year salary negotiation, or until we feel like we’re in crisis. And sometimes we are steering, but we steer haphazardly because we don’t have the right information to help us plot our destination.

我们都能从更稳健、更充分的信息掌控中获益——但我们往往没有这样做。因为我们从小就被灌输谈判只适用于谈钱，或者谈判是政客或商人的专属，所以我们常常放弃掌控局面。我们放下手中的桨，等到一年一度的薪资谈判，或者等到感觉自己身处危机时才想起谈判。有时我们确实在掌控局面，但却因为缺乏正确的信息来规划方向而显得漫无目的。

So what happens when you treat negotiation like steering a kayak? First, it means you don’t wait until the contract comes up to negotiate with your boss or client. You don’t wait until your relationship feels like it is in crisis to have a conversation. Instead, you are continuously piloting those relationships in every conversation you have. And second, you take in the right information to help you steer toward your goal. You ask great questions. You use advanced listening skills to get information that helps you shape your deals. In sum, you approach those conversations intentionally. You treat them all as part of your negotiation of that relationship .

那么，当你把谈判比作驾驶皮划艇时会发生什么呢？首先，这意味着你不会等到合同到期才与老板或客户谈判，也不会等到关系出现危机才进行沟通。相反，你会在每一次对话中持续地维护和发展这些关系。其次，你会收集正确的信息来帮助你朝着目标前进。你会提出好的问题，运用高超的倾听技巧来获取有助于你达成交易的信息。总之，你会有意识地进行每一次对话，并将它们都视为你维系这段关系的谈判的一部分。

When you’ve been steering your relationship consistently, you’ll get even better results when you do need to talk about money, or clients, or who forgot to sign the kids up for summer camp. The result is not only more deals—and more advantageous deals—but stronger relationships that produce value far beyond money.

当你持续有效地维护和维护人际关系时，当你需要谈论金钱、客户，或者谁忘了给孩子报名夏令营之类的事情时，你会获得更好的结果。最终不仅能达成更多交易——而且是更有利的交易——还能建立更牢固的关系，创造远超金钱的价值。

A Different Approach to Negotiation

一种不同的谈判方法

If this doesn’t sound like your typical approach to negotiation, you’re right. I’ve always thought about negotiation differently, and I think it goes back to the way I first learned it. While a student at Columbia Law School, I learned negotiation backward—meaning I studied mediation first. What’s the difference between the two? While negotiation involves advocating for what you want, mediation is a process in which an outside third person helps two or more people negotiate with each other in order to reach a mutually beneficial goal. The mediator doesn’t take anyone’s side or feed the negotiating parties the right answer. Instead, she helps people raise the right questions to see the bigger picture of their situation more clearly; in doing so, she helps them negotiate with more accuracy and find more hidden value than they might on their own. Most people in my field study mediation after negotiation (if they study mediation at all), so they miss out on the mediation skills that could make them even better negotiators.

如果这听起来不像你通常的谈判方式，那你说得对。我一直以来对谈判的思考方式都与众不同，我想这要追溯到我最初学习谈判的方式。在哥伦比亚法学院读书时，我学习谈判的方式很特别——我先学习了调解。这两者有什么区别呢？谈判是争取自己想要的东西，而调解则是一个由外部第三方帮助两个或多个人进行谈判，以达成互惠互利目标的过程。调解员不偏袒任何一方，也不会给谈判各方提供“正确答案”。相反，她帮助人们提出正确的问题，从而更清晰地了解自身处境的全貌；通过这种方式，她帮助他们更精准地进行谈判，并发现他们独自谈判时可能忽略的潜在价值。我所在领域的大多数人都是在学习谈判之后才学习调解（如果他们学习调解的话），因此他们错过了那些能够让他们成为更优秀谈判者的调解技巧。

Over the last fifteen years, I have been that mediator, that outside third person for thousands of people, helping them negotiate toward their goals. From that neutral chair, I’ve seen clearly how the me-first, argumentative approach many people took to negotiation repeatedly backfired in the sessions playing out in front of me. I also started to see a negotiation approach that really worked. Much of what I did as a mediator was listening and asking good questions of both people in the room—and when the negotiators learned how to do that for themselves, they achieved the best results.

过去十五年里，我一直担任调解员，作为局外人，帮助成千上万的人达成谈判目标。站在中立的立场上，我清楚地看到，许多人在谈判中采取的以自我为中心、争辩式的做法，在一次又一次的谈判中都适得其反。我也开始发现一种真正有效的谈判方法。作为调解员，我的大部分工作是倾听，并向谈判双方提出有见地的问题——当谈判者学会如何做到这一点时，他们就能取得最佳结果。

So when I teach negotiation, my goal is to teach it in a way that helps everyone—not just businesspeople and politicians—know that they, too, are negotiators. Whoever you are, and whatever you do, the questions in this book will help you negotiate anything. And you’ll learn to do it in a way that takes you far beyond one handshake to experience some of the magic—the added value, clarity, understanding, personal transformation—I’ve helped thousands of people achieve in mediation.

所以，当我教授谈判技巧时，我的目标是让每个人——不仅仅是商界人士和政界人士——都能意识到自己也是谈判者。无论你是谁，无论你从事什么职业，本书中的问题都能帮助你应对任何谈判。你将学会如何超越简单的握手，体验我在调解中帮助成千上万人获得的奇妙效果——增值、清晰的思路、深刻的理解和个人的转变。

This is the more in Ask for More .

这是《Axue for More》中的“更多”。

What’s the Best Way to Steer?

最佳的驾驶方式是什么？

To steer effectively, you need to see, hear, and understand where you’re going. One of the most senior diplomats at the United Nations, Assistant Secretary-General Nikhil Seth, shared with me that the old tools of negotiation and diplomacy—where you hold your cards to the vest and then try to spring a surprise on your adversary—no longer work. In this age, where so much information can travel around the world with the stroke of a keyboard, it’s much harder to surprise an adversary. Instead, he finds the key to negotiation is transparency: getting and sharing the right information.

要想有效掌舵，你需要看清、听清并理解你的方向。联合国资深外交官、助理秘书长尼基尔·塞思曾告诉我，过去那种把底牌藏在胸前，试图出其不意地给对手一个措手不及的谈判和外交手段已经不再奏效。在这个信息只需轻敲键盘就能传遍全球的时代，想要出其不意地击败对手变得更加困难。他认为，谈判的关键在于透明：获取并分享正确的信息。

Recent research on negotiation and leadership bears that out. The best negotiators and leaders are the ones who ask the right questions and therefore get the right information to help them make better deals.

近期关于谈判和领导力的研究证实了这一点。最优秀的谈判者和领导者都善于提出正确的问题，从而获得正确的信息，最终达成更有利的交易。

But achieving transparency is a lot harder than it seems in this age of information overload. We struggle to tune out internet chatter, other people’s opinions, even our own expectations, and truly see ourselves for who we are and what we need. And when we struggle to see ourselves, we inevitably fail to see the people around us—our clients, colleagues, spouses, and adversaries. This lack of perspective leads to all kinds of challenges, including failed negotiations, fractured or distant relationships, and client-service stagnation.

但在信息过载的时代，实现透明远比想象中困难得多。我们难以屏蔽网络上的各种议论、他人的意见，甚至自身的期望，真正看清自己，了解自己的需求。而当我们难以看清自己时，也必然会忽略身边的人——客户、同事、伴侣，甚至是对手。这种视角上的缺失会导致各种各样的挑战，包括谈判失败、关系破裂或疏远，以及客户服务停滞不前。

Asking for more in negotiation involves asking the right questions—both of yourself and someone else. What are the questions that hold us back, and which ones help us pave the way forward?

谈判中要想争取更多，就需要提出正确的问题——既要问自己，也要问对方。哪些问题会阻碍我们前进，哪些问题又能帮助我们铺平道路？

Fishing with a Net: The Power of Open Questions

用网捕鱼：开放式问题的力量

It’s true that most people in negotiation don’t ask enough questions. But even when they do, their questions tend to move them further away, not closer to their goal.

的确，大多数谈判者问的问题不够多。但即便他们问了，他们的问题往往也只会让他们离目标更远，而不是更近。

I became interested in studying questions early on in my career as a professor and mediator. In the second year of my tenure at Columbia Law School, I was invited to teach in a seaside city in Brazil called Fortaleza. One morning during that trip, prior to one of my mediation lectures at the university, I left my hotel room around sunrise for a walk on nearby Mucuripe Beach.

在我作为教授和调解员的职业生涯早期，我就对研究问题产生了兴趣。在哥伦比亚法学院任教的第二年，我受邀前往巴西海滨城市福塔莱萨授课。那次行程中的一天清晨，在大学进行调解讲座之前，我日出时分离开酒店房间，前往附近的穆库里佩海滩散步。

On the beach I saw the traditional fishing boats called jangadas , or rafts, pulling up to the shore, heavy with their stores. Fishermen spread nets on the sand to reveal a rainbow of catch for sale: bacalhau, tuna, shrimp, even pancake stingrays.

在海滩上，我看到被称为“jangadas”的传统渔船，也就是木筏，满载着渔获物，缓缓靠岸。渔民们在沙滩上撒网，露出五彩缤纷的渔获物待售：鳕鱼、金枪鱼、虾，甚至还有薄片鳐鱼。

Standing on the beach, I thought of my grandmother’s waterfront house in Copiague, New York, where as kids we would stand on the dock for hours, holding a fishing line in the bay waters, in hopes of catching one fish to toss back.

站在海滩上，我想起了我祖母在纽约州科皮亚格的海滨别墅，小时候我们常常站在码头上几个小时，在海湾水中拿着鱼线，希望能钓到一条鱼放生。

With a sudden thought, I rushed back to my hotel room to revise the slides for my lecture.

我突然想到什么，赶紧跑回酒店房间修改讲义幻灯片。

Standing on the beach in Fortaleza that morning, I realized one of the reasons people tend to feel so stuck when asking questions is because, when we ask questions, we are fishing with a line rather than with a net—meaning, we are asking closed questions that give us very little and often unhelpful information.

那天早上站在福塔莱萨的海滩上，我意识到人们在提问时常常感到束手无策的原因之一是，当我们提问时，我们是在用鱼线而不是渔网捕鱼——也就是说，我们问的是封闭式问题，这些问题给我们提供的信息很少，而且往往没有帮助。

Closed questions sound like:

封闭式问题听起来像是：

  • Can I convince this client to upgrade his package with my company?
    我能说服这位客户升级他使用我们公司的套餐吗？
  • Should I go back to work full-time and commute, or continue to stay home and feel unfulfilled?
    我应该回去全职工作并通勤，还是继续待在家里，忍受这种空虚感？
  • Don’t you understand we need to save money this year?
    你难道不明白我们今年需要省钱吗？
  • Will my boss give me a $10,000 raise to my base salary?
    老板会给我加薪1万美元吗？

So how can you tell when you’re asking a closed question? Let me give you an example. Imagine asking me about my most recent business trip—let’s say to India. What would you ask me?

那么，如何判断你问的是否是封闭式问题呢？我举个例子。假设你问我最近一次出差——比如说去印度——你会怎么问？

When I conduct this interview exercise in negotiation workshops, most people tend to ask questions like, “Did you like India?” “What city were you in?” “Was the food spicy?” Those seem like open questions, right? Wrong. Each one of those is a closed question, meaning it invites a yes/no or one-word answer. Every time you ask a closed question, you’re fishing with a line.

我在谈判工作坊里进行面试练习时，大多数人倾向于问一些类似这样的问题：“你喜欢印度吗？”“你当时在哪个城市？”“食物辣吗？”这些问题看起来像是开放式问题，对吧？错。这些都是封闭式问题，也就是说，它们只能得到“是/否”或一个词的回答。每次你问封闭式问题，就像是在钓鱼一样。

Want to know an easy way to avoid asking many closed questions? Here it is:

想知道避免问太多封闭式问题的简单方法吗？方法如下：

Don’t ask a question that starts with a non-action verb (like variations on “be” and “do”). “Was India hot?” “Did the training go well?” “Were you jet-lagged?” “Should I get a guide for the Taj Mahal?” Most of the time, when you start a question with a verb, you are asking a closed question.

不要问以非动作动词（例如“be”和“do”的各种变体）开头的问题。“印度热吗？”“培训进行得顺利吗？”“你时差反应严重吗？”“我应该请个导游去参观泰姬陵吗？”大多数情况下，以动词开头的问题都是封闭式问题。

Often, we don’t realize we are doing this. When you’re talking with your best friend and ask a closed question like “Did you like India?,” your friend might share more than your question requires. “Yes, I loved India! One of the most interesting things was…” But if you’re talking to an acquaintance, or someone with whom you’re having a conflict? You’re likely to get a simple yes .

我们常常意识不到自己正在这样做。当你和最好的朋友聊天，问一个封闭式问题，比如“你喜欢印度吗？”，你的朋友可能会分享比你问题本身更多的内容。“是的，我太喜欢印度了！其中最有趣的事情之一是……”但如果你是在和一位泛泛之交，或者和你关系紧张的人聊天呢？你很可能只会得到一个简单的“是”。

Now that you know this information, you’re going to be shocked at the number of closed questions you are asking in your everyday life, both of yourself and others. When you ask closed questions, you are fishing with a line. At most, you will end up with one fish—at worst, you’ll leave empty-handed.

现在你了解了这些信息，你一定会惊讶于自己在日常生活中问了多少封闭式问题，无论是问自己还是问别人。问封闭式问题就像钓鱼，最多钓到一条鱼，最坏的情况是空手而归。

What Is an Open Question?

什么是开放性问题？

A truly open question is one that invites a broad answer about a number of topics. It prompts the speaker to give you factual information, insight into her feelings, details about her activities, and greater understanding of how she sees herself. As I told my students that first day in Fortaleza, fishing with a net gets you a host of information both good and challenging. You might recover a ton of live fish, as well as some carcasses, or a bunch of kelp that weighs down your net. But you’re light-years ahead of the person with one line in the water.

一个真正开放的问题，能够引发关于诸多话题的广泛讨论。它促使说话者提供事实信息、分享感受、详细描述活动，并加深对自我的理解。正如我在福塔莱萨第一天告诉学生们的那样，用网捕鱼能让你获得大量信息，既有有益的，也有挑战性的。你可能会捞到很多活鱼，也可能捞到一些鱼尸，或者一堆压在网里的海带。但你比那些只在水里放一根鱼线的人领先太多了。

You might be interested to know that this distinction between “open” and “closed” applies beyond the field of negotiation. Lizzie Assa, an expert on childhood play, shared with me that even children’s toys can be open-ended or close-ended. What’s the difference? With open-ended toys, like a block set of different basic shapes, children (or adults) can build anything. One day it could be a wall to climb, the next day a tree, and the following day a village of people. Open-ended toys promote language, social connection with others, and creativity. (Sound familiar?) Whereas a block set that becomes a firehouse means you can build only one thing: the firehouse. Close-ended toys are better for children who are learning how to pay attention and follow a task to completion.

您或许会感兴趣，这种“开放式”和“封闭式”的区别并不仅限于谈判领域。儿童游戏专家莉齐·阿萨 (Lizzie Assa) 告诉我，就连儿童玩具也分为开放式和封闭式两种。它们之间有什么区别呢？对于开放式玩具，例如一套不同基本形状的积木，孩子们（或成年人）可以搭建任何东西。今天它可以是一堵可以攀爬的墙，明天可以是一棵树，后天可以是一座村庄。开放式玩具能够促进语言发展、社交互动和创造力。（听起来是不是很熟悉？）而一套可以搭建成消防站的积木，则只能搭建一个东西：消防站。封闭式玩具更适合正在学习如何集中注意力并完成任务的孩子。

Likewise, if all we want is to finish a simple task, and do it quickly, a closed question will do the trick. But if we want to solve a challenging problem, see it better, connect better with others and unleash our creativity, we need an open question.

同样，如果我们只想快速完成一项简单的任务，封闭式问题就足够了。但如果我们想解决一个具有挑战性的问题，更深入地了解问题，更好地与他人沟通，并释放我们的创造力，我们就需要一个开放式问题。

Back to India: The Most Open Question There Is (Hint: It Doesn’t Have a Question Mark)

重返印度：最开放的问题（提示：它没有问号）

So, you’re probably wondering: What’s the most open question you can ask about my trip to India? The answer is tricky, because this question doesn’t even have a question mark on the end. Here it is: Tell me about your trip to India!

所以，你可能在想：关于我的印度之旅，你能问的最开放的问题是什么？答案有点巧妙，因为这个问题后面甚至没有问号。答案是：跟我说说你的印度之旅吧！

This question casts a very wide net. In answering this question, I might tell you that this was my first time in India. That I felt nervous to go because I was recovering from extensive foot surgery and still had a limp. I might tell you how excited I was that our mediation workshop for the Delhi High Court had attracted such a large and engaged audience. How surprised I was at the warm, family-oriented work culture that prompted the chief justice to invite us to a home-cooked meal with her own mother. I might describe my awe at seeing the Taj Mahal at sunrise, my pride at my students’ outstanding work, my guilt that my young daughter was missing me, or my love for onion kulcha. And I might tell you how optimistic I was that I’d go back. “Tell me” is a magic question that opens up an entire world to your view. You’ll find it later in this book.

这个问题涵盖面非常广。在回答这个问题时，我可能会告诉你，这是我第一次来印度。我当时很紧张，因为我刚做完一次大型足部手术，走路还有些跛。我可能会告诉你，我们为德里高等法院举办的调解研讨会吸引了如此众多且积极参与的听众，这让我多么兴奋。首席大法官邀请我们和她的母亲一起享用家常菜，让我对这里温暖如家的工作氛围感到多么惊讶。我可能会描述在日出时分看到泰姬陵时的震撼，为学生们的出色表现感到多么自豪，因为年幼的女儿想念我而感到多么内疚，或者我对洋葱烤饼的喜爱。我可能会告诉你，我多么乐观地认为我还会再来。“告诉我”是一个神奇的问题，它能为你打开一个全新的世界。你会在本书的后面部分找到答案。

Ten Open Questions: The Ask for More Framework

十个开放式问题：提出更多要求的框架

Ask for More contains ten questions that have the power to transform almost any negotiation, business issue, or relationship conflict. In this book, you’ll learn how to ask these ten questions in a way that will change the way you negotiate, make deals, maintain relationships, and pursue your dreams.

《争取更多》一书包含十个问题，这些问题能够彻底改变几乎任何谈判、商业问题或人际冲突。本书将教你如何提出这十个问题，从而改变你的谈判方式、达成交易的方式、维护人际关系的方式以及实现梦想的方式。

These will not be safe questions—the closed questions we amateur fishermen are used to when we leave the house with a pole and a bucket. Instead, we will ask courageous questions. Open questions. Questions that will uncover a depth of hidden treasure you never expected.

这些问题不会是那种安全无害的封闭式问题——我们这些业余钓鱼爱好者出门带上鱼竿和水桶时常问的那种问题。相反，我们会提出一些大胆的问题，一些开放式的问题。一些能够揭示你从未预料到的深层宝藏的问题。

The Mirror: Getting Clear on Yourself

镜子：认清自己

When people study negotiation, they tend to immediately focus on what happens when you sit down with (or call, or email) the other side. Should you make the first offer? Should you assess their strategy and then decide on yours? How do you frame your demand?

人们在学习谈判时，往往首先关注的是与对方坐下来（或打电话、发邮件）交谈时会发生什么。你应该先提出报价吗？你应该先评估对方的策略再决定自己的策略吗？你该如何表述你的要求？

Starting a study of negotiation by talking about the moment you sit down with someone feels like starting my grandma’s tomato sauce recipe from the moment it hits the pasta. You’ve missed most of what makes it work! Any negotiation, any steering conversation, has to begin with you. You need to steer from the very beginning, by asking yourself the right questions before you sit down with anyone else. The best negotiations, relationships, or client interactions start with you—a process of self-discovery that helps you get clarity on who you are and what you want to achieve.

如果一开始就从与人坐下来交谈的那一刻开始研究谈判，就好像从我奶奶的番茄酱配方开始讲解番茄酱入面的那一刻起一样。你错过了谈判成功的关键所在！任何谈判，任何引导性的对话，都必须从你自身开始。你需要从一开始就掌控局面，在与任何人坐下来之前，先问自己一些正确的问题。最好的谈判、人际关系或客户互动都始于你——一个自我发现的过程，帮助你清晰地了解自己是谁，以及你想要实现什么。

The first five questions in this book are ones to ask yourself. These open questions will first help you cast a broad net into the deepest recesses of your brain and hold up a mirror to yourself. Self-knowledge is critical to making deals and resolving conflict, while also discovering your purpose and finding happiness in life. These questions will help you get there.

本书的前五个问题是让你扪心自问的。这些开放式问题将帮助你深入探索大脑最深处，如同照镜子一般审视自己。自我认知对于达成交易、化解冲突至关重要，同时也是发现人生目标、获得幸福的关键。这些问题将助你达成目标。

Very often what initially brings people into my mediation office is not what they are most concerned with, deep down. They’ve never been able to ask themselves the questions that perhaps go beyond the money in dispute, the last argument they had with a spouse, or the four corners of the contract that brought them into the room. When I ask them these questions, we unearth what’s really driving these disputes—and everything makes a lot more sense, including what we’re looking for in the upcoming negotiation. This is what I call the “Mirror.”

很多时候，人们最初来我调解室的原因并非他们内心深处最关心的问题。他们从未有机会扪心自问，那些问题或许超越了争议的金额、与配偶的争吵，或是那份让他们走进房间的合同条款。当我问他们这些问题时，我们就能挖掘出真正驱动这些纠纷的根源——一切都会变得清晰明了，包括我们在接下来的谈判中要达成的目标。这就是我所说的“镜子”。

The Window: Getting Clear on Others

窗口：看清他人

After the Mirror questions are five questions to ask someone else in a negotiation. You will use these questions to unlock your window to the person across from you.

“镜像问题”之后是五个可以在谈判中向对方提出的问题。这些问题将帮助你打开了解对方的窗口。

Just as you used the Mirror questions to gain perspective on yourself, the Window questions will help you gain perspective on someone else. Never have we needed this ability more than now. Studies of the political and social climate in the United States show that we are more polarized than ever before. Research also demonstrates that people entering the workforce lack sufficient conflict-resolution skills. We can’t have the deep conversations that help us steer our families, companies, and society forward unless we engage people beyond our own vantage point. We need to have the courage—and the tools—to talk to one another.

正如你运用“镜子”问题来了解自己一样，“窗口”问题将帮助你了解他人。我们从未像现在这样需要这种能力。对美国政治和社会环境的研究表明，我们比以往任何时候都更加两极分化。研究还表明，新入职场的人缺乏足够的冲突解决技巧。如果我们不去与那些与我们观点相悖的人交流，我们就无法进行有助于我们推动家庭、公司和社会发展的深入对话。我们需要勇气——以及沟通的工具——来彼此交流。

Nikhil Seth made the same observation to me about the United Nations:

尼基尔·塞思也向我表达了对联合国的同样看法：

“It is easy to talk to people who are like-minded. We talk to ourselves much more than crossing the aisle. What really works in negotiation is when you have the courage to take that walk—to go and try and understand another person’s or group’s perspective. But you have to take that step.”

“和志同道合的人交谈很容易。我们更多的是在自说自话，而不是跨越分歧。谈判中真正有效的方法是鼓起勇气迈出那一步——去尝试理解另一个人或群体的观点。但你必须迈出这一步。”

In the process of asking these questions and listening to the answers, I will help you see the other person as clearly as you now see yourself. You will have an unvarnished view of your partner, your boss, your adversary—what makes them tick, what they believe, feel, and need. This kind of perspective is rare and has the power to unlock deals, strengthen relationships, and transform even the most challenging conflicts. That’s the “Window.”

在提出这些问题并聆听答案的过程中，我会帮助你像现在看清自己一样看清对方。你将对你的伴侣、老板、对手有一个最真实的了解——了解他们的动机、信念、感受和需求。这种视角非常难得，它能够促成交易、巩固关系，甚至化解最棘手的冲突。这就是“窗口”。

Bring It Home: Concluding Your Negotiation

谈判收尾：如何达成协议

By the end of this book, you will have changed the questions you are asking yourself and others. By asking better questions, you get better answers. These questions will expand your view of the world and your place in it. They will expand your view of the people around you. And they will prepare you to approach situations with a more positive, realistic, creative mind-set that will launch you into your next chapter and beyond.

读完本书，你会发现自己问自己和问别人的问题都发生了改变。提出更好的问题，才能得到更好的答案。这些问题将拓展你对世界和自身定位的认知，也将拓展你对周围人的理解。它们将帮助你以更积极、更务实、更具创造性的心态去应对各种情况，从而开启人生的新篇章，并走向更美好的未来。

But the journey doesn’t end with the questions themselves. Like the Carl Sagan quote at the beginning of this book suggests, asking courageous questions is the start of making our world significant, but it’s not the end. We make our world significant—whatever that word means to you—by the depth of our answers.

但这段旅程并非止于提出问题本身。正如本书开篇引用的卡尔·萨根的名言所说，提出勇敢的问题是赋予世界意义的开始，但这并非终点。我们赋予世界意义——无论“意义”一词对你而言意味着什么——取决于我们答案的深度。

#↩

PART 1 THE MIRROR

第一部分 镜子

Asking Ourselves the Right Questions

问自己正确的问题

You know the feeling. A potential client calls and says, “I’d like to retain you. What’s your fee?” Your partner or roommate fires off a text asking why a bill wasn’t paid. A recruiter asks you your desired salary. Your tween shows you a teacher’s note saying the homework wasn’t done again. The real estate agent emails and tells you it’s time to make an offer.

你肯定有过这种感觉。潜在客户打电话来说：“我想聘请你，你的收费是多少？”你的伴侣或室友发短信问你为什么账单还没付。招聘人员问你期望的薪资。你的孩子给你看老师的纸条，说作业又没做完。房产经纪人发邮件告诉你该出价了。

And you want to pick up your phone, keyboard—or voice—and respond right away .

你想拿起手机、键盘或语音工具，立即做出回应。

But hold it. In the Mirror section of this book, you’ll learn that by taking a short time—less than thirty minutes—to ask yourself (and answer) five good questions, you’ll get much better results, and feel more confident when negotiating with someone else.

但是，请稍等。在本书的“镜子”部分，您将了解到，只需花一小段时间——不到三十分钟——问自己（并回答）五个好问题，您就能获得更好的结果，并在与他人谈判时更有信心。

In an outward-oriented world in which so much of what we do is performative or focused on others, asking ourselves questions can feel unnatural. Many of us, across professions, have been taught that negotiation competence and leadership is about talking. Or even more than just about talking—that negotiation success means having all the answers.

在一个以外部为导向的世界里，我们所做的很多事情都带有表演性质或以他人为中心，因此，自我提问可能会让人感到不自然。许多人，无论从事什么职业，都被灌输了一种观念：谈判能力和领导力在于沟通。甚至不仅仅是沟通——谈判成功意味着拥有所有问题的答案。

What does asking ourselves questions have to do with negotiation and steering relationships effectively? Quite a bit, as it turns out. Recent research from organizational psychologist Dr. Tasha Eurich finds a decided link between self-awareness and effective leadership, including negotiation proficiency. But not all self-awareness is created equal. There actually are two different kinds of self-awareness: internal and external. Internal self-awareness is our ability to go deep within ourselves and truly see ourselves for who we are: our priorities, needs, emotions, goals, strengths, and weaknesses. External self-awareness is our ability to examine how others might see us. Guess which one many of us prioritize? When we focus on how others see us to the detriment of actually understanding ourselves—in other words, when we have high external self-awareness but low internal self-awareness—we are more likely to make choices that don’t line up with our values and priorities.

自问自答与谈判和有效处理人际关系有何关系？事实证明，关系非常密切。组织心理学家塔莎·尤里奇博士的最新研究发现，自我认知与有效领导力（包括谈判技巧）之间存在着显著联系。但并非所有的自我认知都具有相同的价值。实际上，自我认知分为两种：内在自我认知和外在自我认知。内在自我认知是指我们深入内心，真正了解自己的能力：包括我们的优先事项、需求、情绪、目标、优势和劣势。外在自我认知是指我们审视他人如何看待自己的能力。猜猜我们大多数人更看重哪一种？当我们过于关注他人如何看待自己而忽略了对自身的真正理解——换句话说，当我们拥有高度的外在自我认知而缺乏内在自我认知时——我们就更有可能做出与自身价值观和优先事项不符的选择。

Further, when Dr. Eurich and her team of researchers worked on discovering how to increase self-awareness, guess what they found? That accurate introspection depends on our asking ourselves questions—but not just any questions. In fact, they found that most of us ask ourselves exactly the wrong questions.

此外，当尤里奇博士和她的研究团队致力于探索如何提高自我意识时，你猜他们发现了什么？准确的内省取决于我们向自己提出问题——但并非任何问题都行。事实上，他们发现我们大多数人问自己的问题都恰恰是错误的问题。

One of the most ineffective questions people ask when trying to gain perspective on themselves is why. For example: “Why did that negotiation go so poorly?” “Why couldn’t I land any of my arguments?” Why is a question we tend to use when assigning blame, either to others or ourselves. Research shows that asking ourselves why puts us in a self-justifying mood and leads to distorted, self-serving answers. It’s so pervasive that I’ve seen it everywhere, often with potentially destructive results. In the days following the 2017 Las Vegas mass shooting, when more than fifty people were killed by a man firing assault rifles from a suite in the Mandalay Bay Hotel, I picked up the New York Times and read a piece alleging that in the wake of this tragedy, why was the question hanging heaviest over our country.

人们在试图了解自身时，最无效的问题之一就是“为什么”。例如：“为什么那次谈判进行得如此糟糕？”“为什么我的论点一个都没能奏效？”我们常常在归咎于他人或自己时使用“为什么”这个问题。研究表明，问自己“为什么”会让我们陷入自我辩解的情绪，导致扭曲的、自私的答案。这种现象如此普遍，我几乎随处可见，而且往往会造成潜在的破坏性后果。2017年拉斯维加斯枪击案发生后，一名男子在曼德勒海湾酒店的套房内用突击步枪扫射，造成五十多人死亡。事发后的几天里，我翻阅《纽约时报》，读到一篇文章，文章指出，在这场悲剧之后，“为什么”这个问题成了笼罩着我们国家最沉重的阴影。

But in challenging times, why isn’t the question we most need to ask.

但在充满挑战的时期，为什么并不是我们最需要问的问题。

Why looks backward, often seeking to particularize a problem to a perpetrator. But the even bigger problem with why is that it’s a distancer. When we feel we understand why someone did something, we can blame that why and understand how we are separate from it.

“为什么”往往着眼于过去，试图将问题归咎于某个肇事者。但“为什么”更大的问题在于它会拉开距离。当我们觉得自己理解了某人做某事的原因时，我们就可以把责任推卸给那个“为什么”，并认为自己与它无关。

You won’t find a why question in this book, and I don’t use why questions in negotiation, either. When we ask why of ourselves or others, we get self-serving, inaccurate answers. Instead I prefer to ask questions starting with what . For example, instead of asking, “Why did I do that?” I might ask, “What went into that decision for me?” Negotiators who ask themselves what questions obtain higher levels of internal self-awareness that leads to better business and relationship outcomes.

你不会在这本书里找到“为什么”的问题，我在谈判中也不会使用“为什么”的问题。当我们问自己或他人“为什么”时，我们得到的往往是自私自利、不准确的答案。相反，我更喜欢问“什么”的问题。例如，与其问“我为什么那样做？”，我可能会问“我做出这个决定是出于什么考虑？”。那些会问自己“什么”问题的谈判者，能够获得更高的自我认知，从而带来更好的商业成果和人际关系。

That most of us lack proficiency in asking ourselves questions makes sense. We have so little practice with talking to ourselves that when we do, we often don’t know the right questions to ask. Janet, a human resources executive, told me a story that illustrates this point. She was working with a senior manager, Deborah, who was very unhappy with an employee who’d recently transferred into her group. Deborah vented to Janet that this employee didn’t know how she liked things done and she didn’t have the time to train someone. She told Janet she needed someone else. She needed someone great.

我们大多数人都不擅长自问自答，这很正常。我们很少练习与自己对话，所以即使真的要自问，也常常不知道该问什么问题。人力资源主管珍妮特给我讲了一个故事，正好说明了这一点。她当时正在和一位名叫黛博拉的高级经理共事，黛博拉对最近调到她团队的一位员工非常不满。黛博拉向珍妮特抱怨说，这位员工不知道她喜欢的工作方式，而且她也没有时间去培训新人。她告诉珍妮特，她需要换个人，而且要找个优秀的人。

Janet asked Deborah, “What would a great employee look like?” and gave Deborah space to consider the question. Deborah thought for a minute and said, “Someone who is a good writer, poised and confident, someone with good attention to detail, a great attitude and judgment. Because those are things I can’t always teach…” And then Deborah’s voice trailed off. She paused again, and her eyes opened up. She looked at Janet. “Okay. I got it just now. He does have what I want. I just have to be patient and teach him the ropes.” Janet told me, “The magic of this question was that I didn’t have to say anything more. Deborah actually called later and said I was a genius because her new employee is such a quick learner!”

珍妮特问黛博拉：“你觉得一个优秀的员工应该具备哪些特质？”然后给了黛博拉一些时间思考。黛博拉想了一会儿，说道：“一个文笔好、举止沉稳自信、注重细节、态度积极、判断力强的人。因为这些品质我有时是教不来的……”说着，黛博拉的声音渐渐低了下去。她再次停顿，然后睁大了眼睛，看向珍妮特。“好了，我明白了。他确实具备我想要的那种特质。我只需要耐心一点，慢慢教他。”珍妮特告诉我：“这个问题妙就妙在，我什么都不用说。黛博拉后来打电话来说我真是个天才，因为她的新员工学得真快！”

As a result of that one Mirror question ( see chapter 2), Deborah heard her own words and learned something powerful that changed her entire view of the situation—and the situation itself: she had a great employee who needed a bit of investment. After that exchange, Deborah spent some time teaching him the ropes, and her entire team took off in a positive direction.

由于《镜子》杂志提出的那个问题（见第二章），黛博拉听出了自己的话，并从中领悟到了一些意义深远的道理，彻底改变了她对整个情况的看法——以及对情况本身的看法：她有一位非常优秀的员工，只是需要一些指导。在那次交流之后，黛博拉花了一些时间指导他，而她的整个团队也从此走上了积极的发展道路。

Your Turn in the Mirror

轮到你照镜子了

In the following five chapters, you will ask yourself five great questions that will help you in any negotiation. That work starts now. And I have prepared five simple tips to help you.

接下来的五章中，你将问自己五个关键问题，这些问题将帮助你应对任何谈判。现在就开始吧。我已经准备了五个简单的小技巧来帮助你。

TIP ONE: CREATE THE OCCASION. Oftentimes, the value I bring as a mediator is that I create the occasion for people in negotiation to tune out the noise and tune in to their issue. I provide a quiet, neutral space in which they can focus. I make them comfortable with drinks and snacks. And I give them as long as they need to talk things through. Do the same for yourself! Block time off. Make it a commitment as firm as a doctor’s appointment or a meeting with your boss.

秘诀一：创造合适的契机。我作为调解员的价值通常在于，我能为谈判双方创造一个契机，让他们能够屏蔽外界干扰，专注于问题本身。我会提供一个安静、中立的空间，让他们能够集中精力。我会准备饮料和小吃，让他们感到舒适。我会给他们足够的时间，让他们把事情说清楚。你也应该这样做！抽出时间，像预约医生或与老板开会一样，认真对待这件事。

TIP TWO: WRITE DOWN YOUR ANSWERS. Most of us, if we go into an important meeting where we need to listen to someone else’s ideas, bring some kind of notepad or device to write things down. Taking notes is not just a sign of respect; it’s been proven to help us remember things better. So why don’t we do this when we are listening to ourselves? Maybe you’re more mindful or organized than I am, but if I don’t write something down, I have a hard time remembering it the next day. Research also shows that writing down your goals means you’re more likely to achieve them—and that’s what you’re here to do. So treat this Mirror session like a meeting with yourself. Write down your answers to the questions as the thoughts arise.

技巧二：记下你的答案。我们大多数人在参加重要会议，需要聆听他人想法时，都会带上笔记本或其他电子设备来记录。记笔记不仅仅是一种尊重的表现；事实证明，它还能帮助我们更好地记忆。那么，为什么我们在倾听自己的想法时却不这样做呢？也许你比我更细心或更有条理，但如果我不把某些内容记下来，第二天就很难记住。研究还表明，写下你的目标意味着你更有可能实现它们——而这正是你来这里的目的。所以，把这次“镜像”练习当作一次与自己的对话。当想法涌现时，就把你对问题的答案写下来。

TIP THREE: WRITE DOWN THE THING YOU’RE THINKING. Not What You Wish You Were Thinking. As you’re writing out your answers, you might find yourself cringing as they hit the page. Or worse, you might censor yourself from ever writing them down at all. We are such a judgmental society—and we judge no one quite as harshly and relentlessly as we do ourselves. I can’t count the number of times someone has said to me, “Well, this probably wouldn’t work, but…” or “This is kind of a ridiculous point…” before saying something profound and useful. We have an extremely hard time separating ourselves from our internal critic.

建议三：写下你正在思考的事情，而不是你希望自己思考的事情。当你写下答案时，你可能会发现自己写在纸上时感到尴尬。更糟糕的是，你可能干脆选择不写下来。我们生活在一个如此爱评判他人的社会——而且我们对自己的评判比对别人的评判还要苛刻无情。我数不清有多少次，别人在说出一些深刻而有用的见解之前，先对我说：“嗯，这可能行不通，但是……”或者“这有点荒谬……”。我们很难摆脱内心的批评声音。

But I’m going to ask you to fight against your own judgment in this section. This is important work, for a couple of reasons: First, when we judge ourselves too harshly, we can’t see ourselves accurately. In my mediation work, I find one of the most common sources of disputes is people not seeing and presenting themselves as they are. It’s one thing to Facetune your online photos so that you look thinner or more awake—but trying to show up in conversation as some idealized, “conflict-tuned” version of yourself always leads to more problems. What happens, for example, when you’re feeling angry with someone but don’t want to acknowledge that to yourself? When you do sit down with the other person, the unfiltered you pops out from behind the curtain, leading to mixed messages, passive aggression, or harsh words you wish later you could take back. Seeing yourself clearly leads to better self-awareness, which in turn helps you to communicate much more clearly and accurately. Others, in turn, will respond to this authenticity—they’ll be more likely to share their true selves and react positively to your ideas.

但在这一部分，我要请你努力克服自己的评判。这很重要，原因有二：首先，当我们对自己过于苛刻时，就无法准确地认识自己。在我的调解工作中，我发现最常见的纠纷根源之一就是人们无法看清并展现真实的自我。用修图软件让自己看起来更瘦或更精神是一回事，但在对话中试图以某种理想化的、“迎合冲突”的形象出现，只会带来更多问题。例如，当你对某人感到生气，却又不想承认这一点时，会发生什么？当你真的坐下来与对方交谈时，未经修饰的你就会从幕后跳出来，导致信息混乱、消极攻击，或者说出一些事后后悔不已的伤人话语。清晰地认识自己能提升自我意识，进而帮助你更清晰、更准确地沟通。反过来，其他人也会对这种真诚做出回应——他们更有可能展现真实的自我，并对你的想法做出积极反应。

TIP FOUR: FOLLOW UP. In this Mirror section, I’m going to give you five great questions that will help you get to know yourself better than ever before. But we won’t stop there. I will also help you follow up each question to better understand the things you’re hearing about yourself. The follow-up doesn’t have to be complicated to be effective. Oftentimes I get the best information from parties after they have answered the first question you’ll see in this section, with one simple additional question. After they speak, I thank them, and then ask, “What else would you like us to know?” I can’t count the number of times that I then hear the thing that has been most on their minds, the thing they were waiting for permission to say. Give yourself that same space and permission.

技巧四：后续跟进。在本“自我反思”部分，我将提供五个绝佳的问题，帮助你比以往任何时候都更了解自己。但这还不是全部。我还会帮助你跟进每个问题，以便更好地理解你听到的关于自己的信息。有效的后续跟进并不需要复杂。通常，在对方回答完本部分的第一个问题后，我只需再问一个简单的问题，就能获得最有价值的信息。在他们回答之后，我会感谢他们，然后问：“还有什么想让我们知道的吗？” 我数不清有多少次，我随后听到了他们最想说的话，那些他们一直想说却还没说出口的话。给自己同样的空间和机会吧。

TIP FIVE: SUMMARIZE YOUR ANSWER. Read your words when you’ve finished answering each question. Then take a moment and think about what you’ve uncovered. How would you summarize this answer in a few lines if someone else had said it to you? Tell your story out loud as though you were explaining it to a trusted friend. (Or, if it works better, find an actual friend.) Then write your summary down below your original answer. When you summarize, make sure to look for patterns or words that seem to come up over and over again. Those have special meaning, so take note of them.

技巧五：总结你的答案。回答完每个问题后，读一遍你的回答。然后花点时间思考一下你发现了什么。如果别人这样告诉你，你会如何用几句话概括这个答案？大声地把你的故事讲出来，就像你在跟一位信任的朋友解释一样。（或者，如果效果更好，就找个真正的朋友。）然后把你的总结写在你最初的答案下方。总结的时候，注意寻找反复出现的模式或词语。这些往往有特殊的含义，所以一定要记下来。

Let’s get started.

我们开始吧。

#↩

ONE WHAT’S THE PROBLEM I WANT TO SOLVE?

第一，我想解决的问题是什么？

Albert Einstein reportedly said that if he had an hour to solve a problem, he would spend fifty-five minutes thinking about the problem and five minutes thinking about solutions.

据说阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦曾说过，如果他有一个小时来解决一个问题，他会花 55 分钟思考问题，5 分钟思考解决方案。

Another person who loved thinking about problems? Steve Jobs. In 2002, fresh off the success of the iPod, Steve Jobs watched as consumers took to it and used it wherever they went, listening to music. But as he watched (and experienced) this phenomenon, he became less and less satisfied with having created a device that simply added to the weight consumers had to lug around as they traveled. Those same consumers were also burdened with a bunch of other devices: their phone, a bulky laptop, and perhaps even a “personal digital assistant,” or PDA, like the Palm. At the time, smartphones and PDAs came with a permanent keyboard that could be difficult for consumers to use, or an attached stylus that sometimes didn’t work and was easy to lose.

还有谁喜欢思考问题？史蒂夫·乔布斯。2002年，iPod大获成功后，乔布斯眼看着消费者们纷纷购买并随身携带，随时随地听音乐。但随着他观察（并亲身经历）这一现象，他越来越不满意自己创造的这款设备，因为它只会增加消费者出行时的负重。这些消费者还背负着其他各种设备：手机、笨重的笔记本电脑，甚至可能还有像Palm这样的“个人数字助理”（PDA）。当时，智能手机和PDA要么配备固定键盘，使用起来可能不太方便，要么配备触控笔，但触控笔有时不好用，而且容易丢失。

Jobs saw what others did not: people needed one easy-to-use device for everything, including calls, computing, music, and organization. No keyboard, no stylus or other writing tool that could be lost. Just one device and the only accessory it needed: the human finger. He set Apple’s engineers to work on creating the one device that would solve this problem.

乔布斯看到了别人看不到的东西：人们需要一款简单易用的设备来完成所有事情，包括打电话、计算、听音乐和整理文件。不需要键盘，不需要触控笔或其他容易丢失的书写工具。只需要一款设备，以及它唯一需要的配件：人的手指。他让苹果的工程师们着手打造这款能够解决这个问题的设备。

Several years later, Jobs walked out of a meeting with AT&T, having negotiated a deal for their subsidiary Cingular Wireless to carry the first ever iPhone—which, remarkably, was still in development. AT&T would have exclusive distribution rights to the new iPhone, and in return, Apple would get approximately ten dollars from each customer’s wireless bill every month. Apple also retained control over the phone’s software, pricing, distribution, and branding. This type of deal had never been seen before in the wireless phone industry. Jobs brought AT&T on board by describing a problem he believed only Apple could solve, and articulating his vision for a groundbreaking solution.

几年后，乔布斯离开与AT&T的会议，此前他已与AT&T的子公司Cingular Wireless达成协议，由后者经销第一代iPhone——令人惊讶的是，当时iPhone仍在研发阶段。AT&T将拥有新款iPhone的独家经销权，作为回报，苹果公司每月将从每位用户的无线账单中抽取约10美元。苹果公司还保留了对手机软件、定价、分销和品牌推广的控制权。这种类型的交易在无线电话行业前所未见。乔布斯之所以能说服AT&T加入，是因为他描述了一个他认为只有苹果才能解决的问题，并阐述了他对突破性解决方案的愿景。

This negotiation was only part of a larger series of negotiations by Jobs to bring the iPhone to life. A consultant who worked with Jobs at the time, Raj Aggarwal, told Forbes magazine that the success of this one negotiation with AT&T resulted, in part, from the way Jobs steered his relationships with all the relevant players: “Jobs met with the CEOs of each carrier. I was struck by his hands-on nature and his desire to make his mark on everything the company was doing.” He steered every detail of the product with his engineers, testing and testing until the product worked the way he envisioned. He steered his relationships with consultants like Aggarwal, with his colleagues at Apple, with analysts in the market—and, most important, with his customers.

这次谈判只是乔布斯为打造iPhone而进行的一系列谈判中的一部分。当时与乔布斯共事的顾问拉杰·阿加瓦尔(Raj Aggarwal)告诉《福布斯》杂志，与AT&T的这次谈判之所以成功，部分原因在于乔布斯巧妙地处理了与所有相关方的关系：“乔布斯会见了每家运营商的CEO。他亲力亲为，力求在公司的一切事务中都留下自己的印记，这给我留下了深刻的印象。”他与工程师们一起把控产品的每一个细节，反复测试，直到产品完全符合他的设想。他精心维护着与阿加瓦尔这样的顾问、苹果公司的同事、市场分析师以及最重要的——他的客户之间的关系。

The Apple iPhone, released in 2007, quickly captured a sizable segment of the mobile market. What led to this transformative success for Jobs and Apple? As Kevin Ashton, a British technology entrepreneur who profiled Jobs, later described: “For Jobs and the iPhone, the critical point of departure was not finding a solution but seeing a problem: the problem of permanent keyboards making smarter phones harder to use. Everything else followed.”

2007年发布的苹果iPhone迅速占据了移动市场相当大的份额。是什么促成了乔布斯和苹果的这一变革性成功？正如曾为乔布斯撰写人物特写的英国科技企业家凯文·阿什顿后来所描述的那样：“对乔布斯和iPhone而言，关键的出发点并非找到解决方案，而是发现问题：固定键盘使得智能手机更难使用。其他一切都随之而来。”

The First Critical Step in Any Negotiation

任何谈判的第一步都是至关重要的

The first question to ask yourself in any negotiation is “What’s the problem I want to solve?”

在任何谈判中，首先要问自己的问题是“我想解决什么问题？”

Remember, to negotiate is to steer. Every decision, every turn you make in a negotiation stems from the problem or goal you have defined for yourself. In other words, if you’re going to be paddling your kayak, don’t you first want to know where you’re going? People who skip this step (and many do) run the risk of finding themselves having paddled all day through choppy waters, only to find themselves on the wrong island.

记住，谈判的本质在于掌控方向。谈判中你做出的每一个决定、每一个举动，都源于你为自己设定的问题或目标。换句话说，如果你要划皮划艇，难道你不想先知道自己要去哪里吗？很多人忽略了这一步，就可能白白在波涛汹涌的海面上划了一整天，最终却发现自己到了错误的岛屿。

Most people think that the fun part of negotiation is figuring out the solution. Nope. This—defining your problem—is the juicy work. Once you learn how to define a problem, you’ll find how incredibly satisfying, creative, and even fun it can be. For me as a negotiation coach, helping you find your what , your problem to solve, feels just as exhilarating as some people find jumping out of a plane or eating an incredibly fresh plate of pasta in Italy. (Don’t judge; we all like different things.) And that’s because I know what incredible things you might find or achieve on the other side of this question.

大多数人认为谈判的乐趣在于找到解决方案。错！真正精彩的部分在于——定义你的问题。一旦你学会如何定义问题，你就会发现这有多么令人满足、充满创意，甚至乐趣无穷。作为一名谈判教练，对我来说，帮助你找到你的问题所在，找到你需要解决的问题，这种感觉就像有些人觉得跳伞或在意大利吃到一盘无比新鲜的意面一样令人兴奋。（别评判我，我们喜欢的东西各不相同。）这是因为我知道，在解决这个问题之后，你可能会发现或取得多么了不起的成就。

Defining the problem helps you create the solution. And that’s the case for any negotiation, whether you’re facing a large diplomatic conflict or just trying to convince your toddler that ice cream is not dinner.

明确问题有助于找到解决方案。这一点适用于任何谈判，无论你面临的是重大外交冲突，还是仅仅想说服你的孩子冰淇淋不是正餐。

Spending Time to Save Time

花时间是为了节省时间

It takes a bit of time to accurately define your problem. But usually, the time you spend at the beginning comes back to you. One executive who took my negotiation course and completed this question told me, “I think in the space of fifteen minutes I have probably saved myself three days of spinning my wheels.” When you know where you want to steer, you save a lot of time that otherwise might be spent checking your map and doubling back.

准确定义问题需要一些时间。但通常来说，你最初投入的时间最终都会得到回报。一位参加过我的谈判课程并完成这个问题的高管告诉我：“我觉得这短短十五分钟，就相当于节省了三天原地打转的时间。” 当你明确目标方向时，就能节省大量原本可能浪费在查看路线图和走回头路上的时间。

Defining the Problem in Big Negotiations

在大谈判中界定问题

Defining your problem is critically important for big, long-standing, or complicated negotiations. Put another way: if someone came to my office and I were to immediately ask about the solution to their problem, I’d be asking them to describe something they can’t even see. Imagine that you are hiking up a mountain. The taller the mountain, the less you can see the top from where you stand at the base. You need to start at the bottom, working your way up step-by-step. With each rocky path you traverse, or stream you ford, you gain experience and confidence that helps you continue. And at some point, the summit becomes visible. You’re able to picture what it looks like and how you will get there.

对于大型、长期或复杂的谈判而言，明确问题至关重要。换句话说：如果有人来到我的办公室，我立刻询问他们的问题解决方案，就相当于让他们描述一个他们根本看不到的东西。想象一下，你正在攀登一座山。山越高，你从山脚下看到的山顶就越少。你需要从山脚开始，一步一步地向上攀登。每走过一条崎岖的小路，每渡过一条溪流，你都会积累经验和信心，从而继续前进。最终，山顶会出现在你的眼前。你能够想象出它的模样，以及到达山顶的路线。

As we hike up a mountain, so too do we negotiate. By asking yourself what problem you want to solve, you are starting where you need to start—with the problem you’re trying to solve—and generating information that will help you visualize and reach your goal, which is your solution.

就像登山一样，谈判也是一种过程。通过询问自己想要解决什么问题，你就找到了正确的起点——从你试图解决的问题本身出发——并由此获得信息，帮助你构思并最终达成目标，也就是找到解决方案。

Let’s take an example. One big problem the United States faces is the chronic absence of some children from school. Chronic absence, defined as missing 10 percent or more of school days due to absence for any reason, can translate into third graders unable to master reading, sixth graders failing subjects, and ninth graders dropping out of high school. According to non-profit Attendance Works, which helps schools and community partners work together to reduce chronic absence, every year more than eight million students in the United States miss so many days of school that they become academically at risk in the ways described above.

我们举个例子。美国面临的一大问题是部分儿童长期旷课。长期旷课，指的是因任何原因缺勤，缺课天数达到或超过总课时的10%。这会导致三年级学生无法掌握阅读，六年级学生成绩不及格，九年级学生甚至辍学。据非营利组织“出勤工作”（Attendance Works）称，该组织致力于帮助学校和社区伙伴共同努力减少长期旷课，每年美国有超过800万学生因旷课过多而面临上述学业风险。

Traditionally, people looking at the problem of chronic absence tended to focus only on what was called “truancy,” or unexcused absence from school—meaning days when students did not have a parental note excusing them from class. This one-sided definition of the problem assumed inappropriate student or family behavior, and often led to a knee-jerk, punitive solution: penalties for both students and parents in an effort to force better behavior. But the penalties didn’t work.

传统上，人们在探讨长期缺勤问题时，往往只关注所谓的“逃学”，也就是无故缺勤——指的是学生没有家长请假条而无法上课的日子。这种片面的定义假定学生或家庭存在不当行为，并常常导致一种仓促的惩罚性解决方案：对学生和家长进行处罚，试图以此来强制他们改正行为。但这种惩罚措施并没有奏效。

When Hedy Chang, executive director of Attendance Works, sat down to define the problem, she didn’t focus on unexcused absences and suspensions. Instead, she defined the problem as kids missing significant amounts of school for any reason. Indeed, in the early grades, she found that many at-risk students were accumulating excused absences, meaning that focusing on truancy wouldn’t catch the problem.

当“出勤工作”（Attendance Works）的执行主任海蒂·张（Hedy Chang）着手定义问题时，她并没有将重点放在无故缺勤和停学上。相反，她将问题定义为孩子因任何原因大量缺课。事实上，她发现，在低年级阶段，许多有辍学风险的学生累积了大量的请假缺勤，这意味着仅仅关注旷课并不能解决问题的根源。

With that problem definition guiding her, Hedy encourages schools to uncover the actual problems preventing kids from attending school by talking with kids and parents. These efforts have led to unexpected solutions. Once they opened lines of communication with their students and families, principals at a number of schools found something unexpected: sometimes, kids skipped school not to avoid the work, or because their parents didn’t prioritize learning, but because their clothes weren’t clean. Students who didn’t have a way to clean their clothes would stay home rather than feel embarrassed in front of their peers. Armed with this discovery, a growing number of schools partnered with local businesses or foundations to provide clothes-washing services at school. One school reported that the percentage of students attending school 90 percent of the time jumped from 46 percent to 84 percent after combining the clothes-washing program with check-ins from caring mentors. Broadly defining the problem of chronic absence helped Hedy, Attendance Works, educators and community partners from around the country design one innovative, effective solution that benefited families and districts alike.

在对问题进行明确界定后，海蒂鼓励学校通过与学生和家长沟通，找出导致孩子旷课的真正原因。这些努力带来了意想不到的解决方案。许多学校的校长在与学生和家长建立沟通渠道后，发现了一些意想不到的情况：有时，孩子旷课并非因为逃避作业或家长不重视孩子的学习，而是因为他们的衣服不干净。那些没有办法清洗衣服的学生宁愿待在家里，也不愿在同学面前感到尴尬。基于这一发现，越来越多的学校与当地企业或基金会合作，在校内提供洗衣服务。一所学校报告称，在将洗衣服务与热心导师的定期探访相结合后，学生出勤率达到90%的比例从46%跃升至84%。对长期旷课问题的广泛界定，帮助海蒂、Attendance Works组织、来自全国各地的教育工作者和社区合作伙伴设计出一个创新有效的解决方案，使家庭和学区都从中受益。

As this example shows, if you’re dealing with a big or complicated negotiation, it’s critical to define your problem. This is true of personal situations, too. Take Antonia, a financially successful insurance professional who, for the last five years, has been in conflict with her older sister, Carmen. Carmen repeatedly asks Antonia for financial help and then spends the money not on housing or food, but on luxury items that she can show off to her friends. To make things worse, Carmen speaks disdainfully about Antonia’s career success to the rest of their family. Antonia feels more and more resentful, and yet every time she tries to talk to Carmen, she has trouble articulating anything beyond her anger. The conversations never seem to move the situation forward, or give Antonia any relief. The reason? Antonia needs to define the problem she wants to solve. Is it asking Carmen to show appreciation for Antonia’s help? Setting boundaries around money? Finding a way to tactfully take a break from the relationship? Knowing the problem she wants to solve will give her a roadmap for the conversation she needs to have.

正如这个例子所示，如果你要处理一场规模庞大或错综复杂的谈判，明确问题至关重要。这在个人生活中也同样适用。以安东尼娅为例，她是一位事业有成的保险从业人员，过去五年里，她一直与姐姐卡门关系紧张。卡门不断向安东尼娅索要经济援助，却把钱花在了可以向朋友炫耀的奢侈品上，而不是住房或食物。更糟糕的是，卡门还向其他家人炫耀安东尼娅的事业成就，并以此表达轻蔑之情。安东尼娅越来越感到愤恨，但每次试图与卡门沟通时，她除了愤怒之外，几乎无法表达任何其他想法。这些对话似乎从未推动事态发展，也丝毫没有缓解安东尼娅的痛苦。原因何在？安东尼娅需要明确自己想要解决的问题。是要求卡门对她的帮助表示感谢？是设定金钱方面的界限？还是找到一种委婉的方式暂时结束这段关系？了解自己想要解决的问题，就能为她需要进行的对话提供方向。

Ever sit down with someone and find yourself having trouble organizing information or prioritizing what means the most to you? Or maybe you’re ten years into your career and throwing yourself into a variety of initiatives, but at the end of the day you’re not sure what you’re progressing toward? Like Antonia, you may have skipped the important step in which you define your problem.

你是否曾经和别人坐下来讨论问题，却发现自己难以整理信息或确定哪些事情对你来说最重要？或者，你可能已经工作十年，全身心投入到各种各样的项目中，但最终却不确定自己究竟在朝着哪个方向前进？就像安东尼娅一样，你可能忽略了定义问题这一重要步骤。

Defining the Problem in Simple Negotiations

在简单谈判中界定问题

Maybe you’re not trying to cure cancer or even determine the course of your career. You’re just preparing to talk to your contractor about what you’re doing with your bathroom, or trying to get your landlord’s attention to fix a leak. Seems like you should just be able to start talking solutions, yes?

也许你并不是想攻克癌症，甚至也不是想规划自己的职业生涯。你只是想和承包商谈谈浴室装修的事，或者想让房东重视一下漏水问题。看起来你应该可以直接开始讨论解决方案了，对吧？

Let’s take the bathroom example. You’re preparing to sit down with your contractor to go over a prospective renovation. Even here, it makes sense to ask what the problem is that you’re trying to solve. Are you selling your house? If so, maybe you’re trying to design a commercially appealing bathroom at a reasonable cost. Are you settling into your dream home, where if all goes well, you will be spending the next four decades of your life? If so, you might be trying to include all the cutting-edge features you will want to use during that time. Or are you redoing the bathroom in a hurry because your partner had an accident and is now confined to a wheelchair? If so, you have a whole other set of choices to consider.

我们以浴室改造为例。假设您正准备和承包商坐下来讨论翻新计划。即使在这种情况下，也应该先问问自己想要解决什么问题。您是要卖房子吗？如果是，您可能想设计一个既美观又经济实惠的浴室。您是要入住梦想中的房子吗？如果一切顺利，您将在这里度过未来四十年？如果是，您可能想把所有未来四十年里想要使用的尖端科技都融入其中。或者，您是因为伴侣意外受伤需要坐轮椅，所以才匆忙翻新浴室？如果是这样，您就需要考虑一系列不同的问题了。

Even in simple negotiations, you can’t design solutions until you understand the problem.

即使是简单的谈判，在了解问题之前也无法设计解决方案。

Defining a Problem No One Else Has Seen Yet: Innovation as Negotiation

定义一个前人未曾发现的问题：创新即谈判

Sometimes in negotiation we are steering our kayak by “picking a line” through the rapids carved out by the person in front of us. And sometimes, there’s no line to pick; we have to create it.

谈判中，我们有时就像划皮艇，需要在前面的人开辟出的湍急水域中“选择一条航线”。而有时，根本没有现成的航线可供选择，我们必须自己创造一条。

I started this chapter with a story about innovation that is also a negotiation story. How? Apple figured out where it needed to go and steered its important relationships—with its distributor, the market, and its customers—in that direction. And it all started with defining the problem.

本章开头我讲了一个关于创新的故事，同时也是一个关于谈判的故事。为什么呢？苹果公司明确了自身的发展方向，并引导其与分销商、市场和客户等重要关系朝着这个方向发展。而这一切都始于对问题的明确定义。

Most people think negotiation is mostly backward-looking, but negotiation is steering. It is creative. It is generative. Ultimately, negotiation is how we create our future. Sometimes we do that by solving a problem before anyone else even comprehends it. That creative place is where negotiation becomes innovation.

大多数人认为谈判主要是回顾过去，但谈判其实是一种引导。它具有创造性，能够带来变革。归根结底，谈判是我们创造未来的方式。有时，我们甚至能在其他人意识到问题之前就解决问题。这种创造性的境界正是谈判转化为创新的契机。

Steve Jobs recognized this. Jobs always sought to understand the next problem (recognizing that there is always a problem, even with products that consumers apparently love) and solve it—sometimes before anyone else in the market even recognized there was a problem. On Apple’s campus there is an inscription that reads INFINITE LOOP . What does that mean? It means that, as author Kevin Ashton described in studying Jobs, “Creating is not a result of genius, unconscious incubation, or aha! moments. It is a result of thinking: a series of mental steps consisting of problem, solution, repeat.”

史蒂夫·乔布斯深谙此道。他总是力求理解下一个问题（他明白，即使是消费者似乎非常喜爱的产品，也总会存在问题），并解决它——有时甚至在市场上其他人意识到问题之前就已着手解决。苹果公司园区内有一块刻着“无限循环”（INFINITE LOOP）的铭牌。这是什么意思呢？正如作家凯文·阿什顿在研究乔布斯时所描述的那样，它的意思是：“创造并非天才的产物，也非无意识的酝酿或灵光乍现。它是思考的结果：一系列由问题、解决方案、重复组成的思维步骤。”

Darrell Mann, a global innovation expert who formerly served as the chief engineer at Rolls-Royce, has spent decades studying innovation efforts by companies, and what makes them work—or not. He found that only 2 percent of companies’ innovation efforts succeeded. And of those, “Twenty-five percent of failures were due to people trying to solve the wrong problems.”

曾任劳斯莱斯首席工程师的全球创新专家达雷尔·曼恩，数十年来一直致力于研究企业的创新举措及其成败因素。他发现，只有2%的企业创新举措取得了成功。而在这2%的失败案例中，“25%的失败是由于人们试图解决错误的问题。”

How to Define Your Problem Completely: Getting the “Bigger Picture” Perspective

如何完整地定义你的问题：获得“全局”视角

“What’s the problem I want to solve?” is a broad question, one we often need to challenge ourselves to answer accurately. Neuroscience research from Thinking, Fast and Slow and similar works tells us that humans tend to avoid challenging questions in favor of answering narrower, easier questions instead. We do this to avoid dealing with things we’re not sure how to answer or which we’d rather not confront. But fishing with a net when solving a problem can lead to tremendous discoveries that change everything.

“我想解决什么问题？”这是一个宽泛的问题，我们常常需要挑战自己才能准确回答。神经科学研究，例如《思考，快与慢》等著作，告诉我们，人类倾向于回避具有挑战性的问题，而选择回答更具体、更容易的问题。我们这样做是为了避免处理那些我们不确定如何回答或我们宁愿不去面对的事情。但是，在解决问题时，用“撒网式”的方法可能会带来改变一切的重大发现。

Marcus, the head of a regional office for a nationwide company, sat down with his managers to solve a problem. An employee, Roger, had sought a promotion and been denied, causing him to make an internal complaint. When his managers initially called this meeting, they had decided the problem they wanted to solve was settling Roger’s complaint without going to court. But they ended up diagnosing a much larger problem.

马库斯是一家全国性公司区域办事处的负责人，他与经理们坐下来商讨一个问题。员工罗杰申请晋升被拒，因此向公司内部投诉。经理们最初召集这次会议的目的是为了解决罗杰的投诉，避免诉诸法庭。但最终，他们却发现了一个更大的问题。

In thinking about Roger’s claim, Marcus was confused about what was happening in this one city office under his jurisdiction. This used to be a happy team that appeared tight-knit. But in the last year, three employees had filed complaints that they were being treated unfairly, whether on work assignments, overtime, or with manager communication. Nothing about management had changed. Work assignments seemed to have been distributed as usual.

马库斯在思考罗杰的说法时，对辖区内这个市政办公室发生的事情感到困惑。这曾经是一个团结融洽、气氛融洽的团队。但在过去一年里，三名员工投诉称他们在工作安排、加班或与经理沟通方面受到了不公平对待。管理层没有任何改变。工作分配似乎也一切如常。

Marcus put Roger’s complaint to the side for a minute; instead, he zoomed out and asked his team to talk more broadly about how things were going in the office this year. His managers discussed current personnel numbers, the kinds of work they were tackling, and the status of their building reorganization—and that’s where things got interesting for Marcus. He remembered that in the last year, that office had been going through a space renovation and reorganization. Because of the construction, they had to relocate a third of their employees away from the others into a much older space. Marcus asked where Roger and the other two employees with complaints currently sat. All of them had been relocated.

马库斯暂时把罗杰的抱怨放在一边，转而让团队成员们更全面地谈谈今年办公室的运营情况。他的经理们讨论了目前的人员配置、正在处理的工作类型以及办公楼改造的进展——而这正是马库斯感兴趣的地方。他想起去年，这间办公室一直在进行空间翻新和重新布局。由于施工，他们不得不将三分之一的员工转移到一个更老旧的办公空间。马库斯问罗杰和其他两位抱怨的员工现在在哪里办公。他们都已经被调走了。

Marcus realized that his problem was not “How can we settle Roger’s complaint without going to court?” Instead, it was “How can we return our office to a cohesive and well-functioning unit?” Marcus spoke to Roger directly, and instead of just talking about the promotion, he asked Roger to talk more generally about life around the office. Roger had, in fact, felt shut out of office decisions recently. No one had told him why he was part of the group that had been moved. Communication among his team had suffered. Before, when they all worked in the same space, Roger used to be able to drop by his supervisors’ offices regularly, but that didn’t happen anymore. Even worse, no one had talked to Roger after the promotion decisions came down. Instead, he heard about them via email.

马库斯意识到，他的问题不是“如何才能在不诉诸法庭的情况下解决罗杰的投诉？”，而是“如何才能让办公室恢复团结高效？”马库斯直接和罗杰谈话，没有只谈晋升的事，而是请罗杰谈谈办公室里的其他事情。事实上，罗杰最近感觉自己被排除在办公室决策之外。没有人告诉他为什么他被调到了那个小组。团队内部的沟通也受到了影响。以前，大家都在同一个办公室工作时，罗杰可以经常去拜访他的主管，但现在这种情况已经不复存在了。更糟糕的是，晋升决定公布后，没有人跟罗杰沟通过。他只是通过电子邮件得知了结果。

Understanding this larger problem proved key to helping Marcus settle Roger’s promotion complaint and much more. Marcus and the management team met with all the employees in the office and took responsibility for not communicating effectively about the office and space decisions they had made. They brought the employees into the discussion about what was happening with the renovations. They engaged the entire office in finding ways to improve communication with employees across the two spaces. Marcus successfully resolved all three employee complaints and got the office back on track. Understanding a larger view of the problem posed by Roger’s case helped Marcus craft a negotiation strategy that worked not just for Roger but for the entire office.

理解这个更深层次的问题，对于帮助马库斯解决罗杰的晋升投诉以及其他诸多事宜至关重要。马库斯和管理团队与办公室所有员工会面，并承担了之前在办公室和空间决策方面沟通不畅的责任。他们让员工参与到关于装修进展的讨论中。他们动员整个办公室寻找改善两个办公空间员工沟通的方法。马库斯成功解决了所有三起员工投诉，使办公室重回正轨。对罗杰案例所引发问题的更宏观的理解，帮助马库斯制定了一套不仅对罗杰有效，而且对整个办公室都适用的谈判策略。

The goal of this chapter is to get you started on actually solving your problem, so you will need to take the time to cast a wide net in order to get the broadest possible view. This is what innovation experts call getting the “bigger picture” perspective. Once you’ve defined your problem, you will learn how to zoom out from it and see if there is a bigger picture you’re missing.

本章的目标是引导你着手解决问题，因此你需要花时间广泛撒网，以获得尽可能全面的视角。创新专家称之为“把握全局”。一旦你明确了问题所在，你将学会如何跳出问题本身，看看是否遗漏了什么更宏观的视角。

What Not to Do: The Usual Ways We Define a Problem

不该做的事：我们通常定义问题的方式

Many of us skip the critical negotiation step in which we define our problem. And I’ve seen people settle for less in negotiation because they defined their problem in a limited, unhelpful way. Let me give you an example:

我们很多人都忽略了谈判中至关重要的一步——定义问题。我见过很多人因为对问题的定义过于狭隘、无益，最终在谈判中妥协。我举个例子：

Rosana, a CEO, has just received employee survey results from her head of Human Resources. Seeing higher than usual turnover among her more junior employees, she asked HR to survey them and ask about their satisfaction at work. The survey results indicate that morale among junior employees is quite low. Imagine that Rosana sits down to define her problem to solve, and writes:

首席执行官罗莎娜刚刚收到人力资源主管发来的员工调查结果。她发现基层员工的离职率高于往常，于是要求人力资源部对他们进行调查，了解他们对工作的满意度。调查结果显示，基层员工的士气相当低落。想象一下，罗莎娜坐下来，试图明确她需要解决的问题，并写道：

Our junior employee satisfaction rating is extremely low.

我们初级员工的满意度评分非常低。

Any problem with this definition? Several, actually. First, it looks backward. Yes, we want to focus on the problem before jumping into designing solutions, but we also need to define our problem in a way that gives us a clear destination to steer toward. Nothing about this problem definition helps Rosana think about the future of her business. Second, it’s framed in the negative. It focuses on where she doesn’t want to be instead of where she does. We don’t want to get in the kayak, and when someone asks us where we are going, say, “Well, I know I don’t want to end up on the rocks.” Last, talking about the rating is a pretty narrow way to define the problem, like fishing with a line. Likely the rating is merely symbolic of a much larger issue Rosana will need to solve.

这个定义有什么问题吗？实际上，问题不少。首先，它有点本末倒置。没错，我们确实需要在着手设计解决方案之前先关注问题本身，但我们也需要以一种能够明确方向的方式来定义问题。这种问题定义对罗莎娜思考她企业的未来毫无帮助。其次，它的表述过于负面。它关注的是她不想去的地方，而不是她想去的地方。我们当然不想坐上皮划艇，当有人问我们要去哪里时，我们却说：“嗯，我知道我不想搁浅在礁石上。”最后，用评分来定义问题过于狭隘，就像用鱼线钓鱼一样。评分很可能只是罗莎娜需要解决的一个更大问题的象征。

Five Steps to Defining Your Problem Clearly and Completely

清晰完整定义问题的五个步骤

For the first step, take five minutes to consider and write down the problem you want to solve, whether that’s a major family challenge like Antonia’s, working with a contractor on your bathroom renovation, or trying to restore morale in your office. Include any issues you think may have contributed to the situation as it stands today, as well as the effects these issues are having on your life, career, company, or community. For example, Rosana might complete this section by talking about employee turnover, the survey, the results, and anything else that comes to mind as a part of this problem. Next, once you’re finished writing, I want you to take what you’ve written and summarize it in one sentence, as Rosana did above. Summarizing your problem in one sentence helps to give you the clearest, most concise picture possible. Rosana did this when she wrote, “Our junior employee satisfaction rating is extremely low.” For our bathroom contractor example, this could look like, “The total quote came in too high for my budget.” And for Antonia, that sentence may be “My sister disrespects me and doesn’t thank me for anything I’ve done.”

第一步，花五分钟时间思考并写下你想解决的问题，无论是像安东尼娅那样的家庭难题，还是与承包商合作进行浴室装修，亦或是努力重振办公室士气。把你认为可能导致目前状况的任何问题都写下来，以及这些问题对你的生活、事业、公司或社区的影响。例如，罗莎娜可能会在这一部分谈到员工流动率、调查、结果，以及任何你想到的与此问题相关的其他内容。接下来，写完之后，我希望你像罗莎娜那样，用一句话概括你写的内容。用一句话概括你的问题有助于你尽可能清晰简洁地描述问题。罗莎娜写道：“我们初级员工的满意度评分非常低。” 以我们之前提到的浴室承包商为例，你可以这样写：“总报价超出了我的预算。”而对于安东尼娅来说，这句话可能是“我的妹妹不尊重我，对我所做的一切也不表示感谢”。

Third, take anything that is negative and backward-looking in that sentence and reframe it to be positive and forward-looking. When we define a problem to solve, we need to spell out what we want in the future, not what we didn’t want in the past. For example, Rosana would change “Our junior employee satisfaction rating is extremely low” to “We need to achieve high junior employee satisfaction levels.” Our homeowner might move from “The total quote was too high” to “I need a bathroom that will work for my budget.” And Antonia would change “My sister disrespects me and doesn’t thank me for anything I’ve done” to “I need respect and acknowledgment from my sister.” When you’re steering your kayak, you achieve better results when you’re focused on the goal (the beach) instead of the obstacle (the rocks). By making this shift, we move from a place of fear or complaint to a positive problem-solving mind-set that carries us to our destination.

第三，将句子中所有消极的、回顾过去的内容重新表述为积极正面的、展望未来的内容。当我们定义一个需要解决的问题时，我们需要明确未来想要什么，而不是过去不想要什么。例如，罗莎娜会将“我们初级员工的满意度极低”改为“我们需要提高初级员工的满意度”。房主可能会将“总报价太高”改为“我需要一个符合我预算的浴室”。安东尼娅会将“我妹妹不尊重我，也不感谢我做的一切”改为“我需要得到妹妹的尊重和认可”。就像划皮划艇一样，专注于目标（沙滩）而不是障碍物（岩石）能带来更好的结果。通过这种转变，我们就能从恐惧或抱怨的心态转变为积极的解决问题的心态，从而抵达目的地。

Fourth, take your sentence and change it into a question starting with how , what , who , or when . Rosana would do this by asking, “What can we do to achieve high junior employee satisfaction levels?” or “How can we achieve high levels of junior employee satisfaction?” Our homeowner might ask, “How can I get a new bathroom that will work for my budget?” And Antonia would ask, “How can I feel respected and acknowledged by my sister?” A similar message, but phrased as a question, motivates you to seek more concrete information and to act on it. Yet again, questions are the answer when it comes to negotiation.

第四，将你的句子改成以“如何”、“什么”、“谁”或“何时”开头的问题。罗莎娜可能会问：“我们该如何提高初级员工的满意度？”或者“我们该如何提高初级员工的满意度？”房主可能会问：“我怎样才能在预算范围内装修一个新浴室？”安东尼娅则会问：“我怎样才能感受到姐姐的尊重和认可？”类似的信息，但以问题的形式表达，会促使你寻求更具体的信息并采取行动。再次强调，在谈判中，提问才是关键。

Last, we want to define your problem broadly and capture the full picture. If your initial problem definition was narrow, like Rosana’s, there’s a good reason why. Your brain is working against you, wanting to fish with a line instead of a net. Look at the question you just wrote and ask yourself, “What would happen if this came true?” Then write that answer down and consider revising your original question to reflect a larger picture. Here, Rosana would look at her question, “What can we do to achieve high junior employee satisfaction levels?” and ask herself, “What would happen if junior employee satisfaction rose?” She might conclude that with higher satisfaction levels, her company would attract and retain the best employees, and achieve even better results. Rosana’s revised question would then read: “What can we do to make this company a place where the best people in the industry want to apply, stay, and work their hardest toward our increased success?” In this way, Rosana has turned a conversation about the survey rating into a call to action that will help her steer her company and all those relationships forward. Our homeowner might look at her question and figure out that if she achieved a better budgetary result on her bathroom, she might be able to contribute more money to her 401K this year. So the revised question could be, “How can I achieve a budget on this bathroom that will allow me to save more toward retirement?” And Antonia might change, “How can I feel respected and acknowledged by my sister?” to “How can I achieve a relationship with my sister that feels emotionally healthy enough to sustain?” This question clarifies for Antonia that this isn’t just about money, or a disrespectful interaction; it’s evaluating what she needs in order to continue a relationship with Carmen.

最后，我们希望您能更全面地定义问题，把握全局。如果您最初对问题的定义过于狭隘，就像罗莎娜那样，那也是有原因的。您的思维方式可能存在偏差，只想用鱼线而不是渔网来捕鱼。请审视您刚刚提出的问题，并问问自己：“如果这种情况发生会怎样？” 然后把答案写下来，并考虑修改最初的问题，使其更贴近整体情况。例如，罗莎娜最初提出的问题“我们如何才能提高初级员工的满意度？”，她会问自己：“如果初级员工的满意度提高了会怎样？” 她可能会得出结论：更高的满意度能够帮助公司吸引并留住最优秀的员工，从而取得更好的业绩。因此，罗莎娜修改后的问题应该是：“我们如何才能让公司成为业内顶尖人才渴望加入、留下来并竭尽全力为我们取得更大成功而努力的地方？” 这样，罗莎娜就将关于调查评分的讨论转化为一项行动号召，这将帮助她引领公司发展，并推动所有相关关系向前迈进。我们的房主可能会审视自己的问题，并意识到如果她在浴室装修上能更好地控制预算，今年就能往她的401K退休账户里存更多钱。因此，修改后的问题可能是：“我怎样才能在浴室装修上控制预算，从而为退休储蓄更多？”安东尼娅可能会把“我怎样才能感受到姐姐的尊重和认可？”改成“我怎样才能和姐姐建立一段健康、足以维系的亲密关系？”这个问题让安东尼娅明白，这不仅仅是钱的问题，也不仅仅是缺乏尊重的问题；而是她需要评估自己需要什么才能继续和卡门保持亲密关系。

As the examples above show, too often we define our problems reactively, based on just one interaction or situation. Each of these revised questions allows for the person involved to move beyond an immediate triggering event—a survey, an outdated bathroom, a fight with a sibling—to consider the broader goals they’re seeking: a successful company, a robust retirement fund, or overall emotional health. That’s the bigger picture you need to define in order to ask for more in negotiation.

正如以上例子所示，我们常常会根据一次互动或情境，被动地定义问题。这些修改后的问题能够帮助当事人超越眼前的触发事件——比如调查问卷、老旧的浴室、与兄弟姐妹的争吵——去思考他们追求的更广泛的目标：公司的成功、稳健的退休基金，或是整体的心理健康。这才是谈判中提出更多诉求时需要明确的关键所在。

Troubleshooting Common Questions

常见问题故障排除

Here are a couple of common questions I get when discussing “What’s the problem I want to solve?”

以下是我在讨论“我想解决什么问题？”时经常被问到的一些问题。

What about the Problems That Can’t Be Solved?

那么，那些无法解决的问题呢？

Even conflict resolution experts recognize that some problems have no solution. Sometimes, the best we can do is simply manage . For example, as I write this book, I am working through what feels like an impossible set of choices about how best to care for my dying father. He needs twenty-four-hour assistance, and we must decide whether to place him in a skilled nursing unit where he will be safe but will miss his family greatly, or keep him at home, where he might hurt himself, and where my stepmother and his health aides are suffering stress. There is no perfect, or even happy, solution here. No negotiation strategies can change the fact that my father has an incurable, degenerative brain disease, and that he will continue to suffer in any living situation as the disease progresses. And yet, I’m still working through these questions to help me as we make these decisions. Even for problems that are unsolvable, understanding the problem helps us minimize the damaging effects it has on our lives, decrease the stress and anxiety we feel as a result of it, and may even help us discover new strategies.

即使是冲突解决专家也承认，有些问题无解。有时，我们所能做的最好的就是尽力应对。例如，在我写这本书的时候，我正在努力应对一系列看似不可能的选择：如何才能最好地照顾我即将离世的父亲。他需要24小时的照护，我们必须决定是把他送到专业的护理机构，在那里他会很安全，但会非常想念家人；还是让他待在家里，在那里他可能会伤害自己，而且我的继母和护理人员也会承受巨大的压力。这里没有完美的解决方案，甚至没有令人满意的方案。任何谈判策略都无法改变我父亲患有不治之症——一种退行性脑部疾病——的事实，而且随着病情发展，无论他身处何种生活环境，他都会继续遭受痛苦。然而，我仍然在思考这些问题，希望能帮助我们做出这些决定。即使是那些无法解决的问题，理解问题本身也能帮助我们最大限度地减少它对我们生活的负面影响，减轻我们因此而感受到的压力和焦虑，甚至可能帮助我们找到新的应对策略。

And even if you can’t solve the underlying problem (“How can we cure frontotemporal dementia?” left me nowhere), you can still find something to address. I worked through this question when making medical decisions for my dad, and my final problem definition turned out to be: “How can we care for Dad in a way that maximizes his comfort and dignity and also allows his family caregivers to feel supported?” Seeing the problem this way, and working through the rest of the questions in this section, made the decision clear: we transferred him to a memory care facility where he could receive expert treatment and also daily visits from family. We can’t cure my dad’s illness, but we can prioritize his comfort and dignity, as well as the family’s well-being. Often, having an achievable goal in the midst of an unsolvable problem can bring a sense of peace.

即使你无法解决根本问题（“我们该如何治愈额颞叶痴呆症？”这个问题让我束手无策），你仍然可以找到一些可以着手解决的问题。在为父亲做医疗决定时，我一直在思考这个问题，最终我将问题定义为：“我们如何才能在最大程度上保障父亲的舒适和尊严的同时，也让他的家人感到被支持？” 这样看待问题，并思考本节中的其他问题，让我做出了明确的决定：我们将他送到一家记忆护理机构，在那里他可以接受专家治疗，并且每天都能得到家人的探望。我们无法治愈父亲的疾病，但我们可以优先考虑他的舒适和尊严，以及家人的福祉。通常，在看似无法解决的问题中，拥有一个可实现的目标能够带来一丝慰藉。
