What If I’m Only Negotiating with Myself?

如果我只是在和自己谈判呢？

We know that negotiation also means steering the conversation you have with yourself. Should I speak up in management meetings? Is it time for me to go into business as an entrepreneur? How can I feel more confident when I advocate for myself in my personal relationships? This question, and the Mirror section of this book, can be very useful in any of these negotiations.

我们知道，谈判也意味着引导你与自己的对话。我应该在管理会议上发言吗？我是否应该创业？在人际关系中，我如何才能更有自信地为自己争取权益？这些问题，以及本书的“镜像”部分，在任何此类谈判中都非常有用。

Sometimes, people seek out negotiation coaching not because they’re ready to sit down with someone else, but because they’re feeling stuck and need clarity on a decision. That stuck feeling is usually an internal negotiation. What am I meant to do with my life? Which job should I take? Should I go back to work? How can I feel happier? Many people believe that it takes two to make a conflict, but you only need one car to have an accident!

有时，人们寻求谈判指导并非因为他们准备好与他人坐下来谈判，而是因为他们感到困惑，需要理清思路做出决定。这种困惑通常源于内心的挣扎。我的人生目标是什么？我应该选择哪份工作？我应该重返职场吗？我怎样才能更快乐？许多人认为冲突需要双方参与，但其实只需要一辆车就可能引发交通事故！

When you examine what brought you to this place, you’ll have better information to help you move through it. If you’re internally stuck, you can still go through both sides of the situation and look at the conflicting feelings, patterns, and facts that are leading to the stagnation you feel.

当你审视是什么把你带到这个境地时，你就能掌握更好的信息来帮助你走出困境。如果你内心陷入困境，你仍然可以从正反两方面来分析情况，审视那些导致你停滞不前的矛盾感受、模式和事实。

Self-Censoring: Too Many Cooks in Your Mental Kitchen

自我审查：你脑子里厨师太多了

One of the main problems I deal with in mediation or negotiation counseling is helping people combat their self-censorship and define their own goals for themselves. You might feel like your goal should be X, but really you’re yearning for Y.

我在调解或谈判咨询中处理的主要问题之一是帮助人们克服自我审查，并为自己设定目标。你可能觉得你的目标应该是X，但实际上你渴望的是Y。

I once had a student come to my office. He was one of the strongest performers in my class, and indeed had succeeded similarly in other classes. With a top academic record, he set a goal of getting into the best firm he could. (In this context, “best” means “highest ranked.” Lawyers love rankings.) In law school, students spend the summer interning at the law firm they hope to work for after graduation. If they nab a permanent job offer, they get to return for their last year at law school knowing they are set. This student, whom I’ll call David, succeeded in getting job offers at many of the best law firms in the country, and went to the top firm on his list for a summer internship. After spending a summer in their offices, the firm enthusiastically offered him a permanent job.

我曾经接待过一位学生。他是班上最优秀的学生之一，在其他课程中也同样表现出色。凭借着顶尖的学业成绩，他立志要进入最好的律师事务所。（这里的“最好”指的是“排名最高”。律师们都喜欢排名。）在法学院，学生们会在暑假期间到他们希望毕业后就职的律师事务所实习。如果他们成功获得正式聘用，就可以安心地回到学校完成最后一年的学业。这位学生，我姑且称他为大卫，成功地获得了全国多家顶尖律师事务所的聘用，并最终选择了他心仪的那家事务所进行暑期实习。在事务所度过一个夏天后，事务所热情地向他提供了一份正式工作。

David returned to school in September and asked me for a meeting. He arrived at my office, shut the door and looked around, as though worried someone might overhear him. In a quiet voice, he told me he’d had a great summer. Then he paused.

大卫九月份回学校，约我见面。他来到我的办公室，关上门，环顾四周，似乎担心有人会听到他说话。他轻声告诉我，他度过了一个美好的暑假。然后，他停顿了一下。

“But… ?” I asked.

“但是……？”我问道。

“But…” he said, “I don’t know. My original goal was just to go to the highest-ranked firm. And it’s a great place. I’m lucky to have a job there. If I’m being honest, though, I don’t know if that’s the life I want for myself. I want a family. I want to spend time with them. And… I also play in a band. I really want time to make music.”

“但是……”他说道，“我不知道。我最初的目标只是去排名最高的公司。那确实是个好地方。我很幸运能在那里工作。但说实话，我不知道那是不是我想要的生活。我想要一个家庭。我想和他们共度时光。而且……我还在乐队里演奏。我真的很想有时间做音乐。”

“Great,” I said. “So why do you look like you’re apologizing to me?”

“太好了，”我说。“那你为什么看起来像是在向我道歉呢？”

“Well,” he said, “because I feel like it’s not socially acceptable to… want a life.”

“嗯，”他说，“因为我觉得想要过上正常的生活在社会上是不被接受的。”

I laughed out loud, and after a moment he joined me. Sometimes, having a life feels like a revolutionary goal. That day, we talked more about this goal and ways he could achieve it, alongside his other career goals. I’m pleased to report that today, this former student works at a place where he has a life. He plays music, and is an active parent to his kids. These were worthy goals, and he’s achieved them.

我大笑起来，过了一会儿，他也跟着笑了。有时候，拥有自己的生活就像是一个革命性的目标。那天，我们更深入地探讨了这个目标以及他实现目标的方法，还有他其他的职业目标。我很高兴地告诉大家，如今，这位曾经的学生在一家让他拥有自己生活的地方工作。他演奏音乐，并且是一位尽职尽责的父亲。这些都是值得追求的目标，而他都实现了。

What do you do if someone else’s voice is in your head as you’re writing answers to this question? You might be getting confused by or preoccupied with what someone else thinks is the problem. Engage with that question: write down the different audiences to your issue—maybe your coworkers, clients, spouse, kids—and ask yourself what their views of the problem would be. Then study that. What seems right to you about what you wrote? What doesn’t resonate? Eventually, your goal will be to move that perspective to the side so that you can tune in to your own sense of your problem.

如果你在回答这个问题时，脑海中不断回响着别人的声音，该怎么办？你可能会被别人对问题的看法所困扰，甚至过度关注。不妨认真思考这个问题：写下你所讨论问题的不同受众——比如你的同事、客户、配偶、孩子——然后问问自己，他们会如何看待这个问题。接下来，仔细研究他们的看法。你觉得你写的内容哪些是正确的？哪些内容让你感到困惑？最终，你的目标是摆脱这种视角的影响，从而专注于你自身对问题的理解。

“I Don’t Know”

“我不知道”

What if you read this question and draw a blank? Maybe you aren’t sure what has brought you to the point of reading this book. You might be a negotiation avoider. Some people I know are so good at avoiding negotiation that they manage to forget they need to do it at all. This is the equivalent of not only putting down your kayak paddle but also then sticking your head between your knees and letting the current take you wherever.

如果你读到这个问题却一头雾水怎么办？也许你甚至不确定自己为什么会读到这本书。你可能是一个逃避谈判的人。我认识的一些人非常擅长逃避谈判，以至于他们完全忘记了自己需要谈判。这就像不仅放下皮划艇的桨，还把头埋在膝盖间，任由水流带着你漂流一样。

Or you might know you need to negotiate, but you’re not quite sure where to begin with thinking about your problem. Sometimes when we are in conflict or in the middle of an ongoing situation or challenging negotiation, we’re left feeling like everything is a big jumbled mess and we’re not sure where to start untangling it.

或许你知道自己需要谈判，但却不太确定该从何入手思考问题。有时，当我们身处冲突、陷入困境或面临棘手的谈判时，会感觉一切都乱成一团，不知从何下手。

If you see yourself in either of these paragraphs, try this:

如果你发现自己符合以上任何一段描述，不妨试试这个方法：

Ask yourself the last few times you felt dissatisfied, restless, unhappy, or fed up. What happened just before those moments? This may help you define the problem you want to solve.

问问自己，最近几次感到不满、烦躁、不快乐或厌倦的时候，在那些时刻之前发生了什么？这或许能帮助你明确想要解决的问题。

Or try the reverse: ask yourself the last few times you felt happy, satisfied, or like things were on the right track. What happened to produce those moments? This may lead you to discover your goal.

或者反过来：问问自己最近几次感到快乐、满足或觉得一切都在按计划进行的时候是什么时候。是什么让你有了这些感觉？这或许能帮助你找到自己的目标。

And if you’re still drawing a blank: take a break. Instead, I want you to focus on the next few moments in which you’re feeling unhappy/happy and notice what preceded that feeling. Now you’re getting close to discovering what’s brought you to the point of reading this book and taking action. Remember that defining your problem, or your goal, will be the foundation on which you build your solution.

如果你仍然一头雾水：那就休息一下。我希望你把注意力集中在接下来几分钟你感到不快乐/快乐的时刻，并留意这种感觉之前发生了什么。现在，你离发现是什么促使你阅读这本书并采取行动越来越近了。记住，明确你的问题或目标将是你构建解决方案的基础。

Wrapping Up

总结

Identifying the problem you want to solve is the first vital step to mastering negotiation. Now that you’ve thoroughly defined the problem, we’ll delve into some of what’s underlying your issue.

明确你想解决的问题是掌握谈判技巧的第一步。既然你已经彻底定义了问题，接下来我们将深入探讨问题的根本原因。

#↩

TWO WHAT DO I NEED?

二、我需要什么？

Lilia looked at the somber faces of her new staff members as they departed her office. It was 2013, and Lilia, a professor, lawyer, and researcher, had recently been promoted to vice president of the University of Fortaleza (UNIFOR), a private university in northeast Brazil. Her position put her in charge of all their graduate programs.

莉莉娅看着新员工们神情凝重地离开她的办公室。那是2013年，莉莉娅是一位教授、律师和研究员，最近被提拔为福塔莱萨大学（UNIFOR）的副校长。福塔莱萨大学是巴西东北部的一所私立大学，她的职位让她负责该校所有的研究生项目。

When she took over the vice presidency, Lilia had dreamed about taking UNIFOR’s graduate programs to a new level, raising the numbers of students enrolled as well as its national rankings. But that day, Lilia’s staff went to her to share their concerns. The overall health of their graduate school programs was poor. With Brazil’s economic situation unsteady and unemployment rates above 7 percent, UNIFOR struggled to attract graduate students. UNIFOR was a private graduate school that relied heavily on people to have jobs and the financial means to afford their tuition. Without jobs, people worried about investing in graduate education and spending substantial amounts of money on what they saw as an uncertain return. UNIFOR’s peer schools wouldn’t release their graduate school numbers, but Lilia’s staff heard that they were struggling, too. Her staff warned her to brace for impact, that the picture looked bleak and there seemed little they or anyone could do to change things until the overall economic climate improved. Their definition of the problem could have been summed up as follows: “We won’t be able to increase student enrollments, or our rankings, until Brazil is through this economic crisis and more people get jobs.”

莉莉娅就任副校长时，曾梦想着将巴西大学（UNIFOR）的研究生项目提升到一个新的水平，提高招生人数和全国排名。然而，就在那一天，莉莉娅的下属向她倾诉了他们的担忧。研究生项目的整体状况堪忧。由于巴西经济形势不稳定，失业率超过7%，巴西大学难以招到研究生。巴西大学是一所私立研究生院，严重依赖学生的就业和经济能力来支付学费。没有工作，人们担心投资研究生教育，担心在他们认为回报不确定的情况下花费大量资金。巴西大学的同类院校不愿公布研究生招生数据，但莉莉娅的下属听说他们也面临着同样的困境。她的下属警告她要做好应对冲击的准备，前景黯淡，在整体经济环境好转之前，他们或任何人似乎都无能为力。他们对问题的定义可以概括如下：“在巴西摆脱这场经济危机，更多的人找到工作之前，我们无法增加学生入学人数，也无法提高我们的排名。”

Lilia saw things differently. She wondered how UNIFOR could use its graduate programs to help people get through the crisis and find employment, thereby offering hope instead of cost. Lilia investigated what UNIFOR needed to solve this problem. She realized that they needed to offer not just an education in the substance of students’ chosen fields, like business, law, or urban planning, but management skills that would make them attractive to employers. She also knew that the university would need to find a way to connect people to jobs through the graduate programs themselves. Finally, Lilia thought about what she personally needed: “As a researcher, I was used to identifying problems and solving them. I got a high every time I managed to find an innovative way around something that seemed impossible. And I was also a professional woman who’d had my first child very early, before even finishing my education—so I was used to getting creative and persevering in my personal life, too. I realized that I couldn’t give up on the dream of expanding our graduate programs, for me as much as anyone else. It wouldn’t just hurt UNIFOR; it would hurt me. I needed this challenge as much as the institution did.”

莉莉娅的看法不同。她思考着，UNIFOR大学如何才能利用其研究生项目帮助人们渡过难关，找到工作，从而为他们带来希望，而不是增加经济负担。莉莉娅调查了UNIFOR大学需要做些什么才能解决这个问题。她意识到，大学不仅需要提供学生所选领域（如商业、法律或城市规划）的专业知识，还需要培养学生的管理技能，使他们更受雇主青睐。她也明白，大学需要找到一种方法，通过研究生项目本身将学生与工作机会联系起来。最后，莉莉娅思考着自己真正需要的是什么：“作为一名研究人员，我习惯于发现问题并解决问题。每当我找到看似不可能的创新方法时，我都会感到无比兴奋。而且，我同时也是一位职业女性，很早就生了第一个孩子，甚至在完成学业之前——所以我也习惯于在个人生活中发挥创造力并坚持不懈。我意识到，我不能放弃拓展研究生项目的梦想，这不仅对我自己，对其他人来说也是如此。这不仅会损害UNIFOR，也会损害我自己。我需要这个挑战，就像学校需要这个挑战一样。”

Based on this list of needs, Lilia restructured UNIFOR’s graduate programs to offer not only technical skills in each chosen field, but management skills like conflict resolution, complex problem-solving, creativity, and teamwork. She also devised a capstone component to every one of their graduate programs, whereby students were required to create a final project that would link their studies to the outside world in order to solve a problem, whether local or international. UNIFOR would then connect them with a company or government agency that needed that work. Lilia called this new model of graduate education “Leaders Who Transform,” and communicated directly with the public about how a UNIFOR graduate education could benefit them not despite, but because of the difficult economic climate. Indeed, unemployed students who enrolled in UNIFOR’s programs started to get jobs as a result of Lilia’s efforts to connect them to practice. The enrollment numbers began to turn around.

基于这份需求清单，莉莉娅重组了UNIFOR的研究生项目，不仅提供各专业领域的技术技能，还培养冲突解决、复杂问题解决、创造力和团队合作等管理技能。她还为每个研究生项目设计了毕业设计环节，要求学生完成一个最终项目，将所学知识与外部世界联系起来，以解决本地或国际问题。UNIFOR随后会将他们与需要这项工作的公司或政府机构对接。莉莉娅将这种新的研究生教育模式称为“变革型领导者”，并直接与公众沟通，阐述UNIFOR的研究生教育如何让他们受益——不是因为经济环境艰难，而是恰恰因为经济环境艰难。事实上，由于莉莉娅努力将学生与实践联系起来，许多失业学生开始在UNIFOR的项目中找到工作。招生人数也开始回升。

In 2019, Lilia sat down again to evaluate UNIFOR’s graduate programs. Brazil’s economic situation had indeed changed from when she started “Leaders Who Transform” back in 2013: it was worse. Unemployment had climbed to nearly 13 percent. And yet, the total number of students enrolled in her graduate programs had doubled . Moreover, the Brazilian agency regulating all graduate programs changed the standards by which it evaluated the quality of master’s programs and PhDs to include the “impact of the research/project on society”—a direct result of the work they saw being done at UNIFOR.

2019年，莉莉娅再次坐下来评估UNIFOR的研究生项目。巴西的经济形势确实与她2013年创办“变革型领导者”项目时截然不同：情况更加糟糕。失业率攀升至近13%。然而，她负责的研究生项目招生总人数却翻了一番。此外，负责监管所有研究生项目的巴西机构修改了硕士和博士项目质量评估标准，将“研究/项目对社会的影响”纳入考量——这正是UNIFOR项目所取得的成果。

Reframing the problem, and focusing on her personal and institutional needs, helped Lilia transform the entire graduate division of UNIFOR, as well as the lives of many people across Brazil.

莉莉娅重新审视问题，并专注于她个人和机构的需求，这不仅改变了 UNIFOR 的整个研究生院，也改变了巴西各地许多人的生活。

We Need, Therefore We Do (or Don’t)

我们有需要，所以我们做（或不做）

Needs motivate everything we do. They are our driving forces, the why behind all human behavior. You’ll know something is a need for you, as opposed to just a wish or a want, if the lack of it causes you some kind of suffering or adversity. Whether or not we think about or are even aware of our needs in any given moment, they exist—and they influence what we do or don’t do, every minute of our lives.

需求驱动着我们的一切行为。它们是我们的驱动力，是所有人类行为背后的根本原因。如果你缺乏某样东西会给你带来某种痛苦或逆境，那么你就知道它是你的必需品，而不仅仅是愿望或欲望。无论我们是否在任何特定时刻思考或意识到自己的需求，它们都存在——并且影响着我们生命中的每一分钟的所作所为。

People often prepare for negotiation by thinking about their “bottom line,” otherwise known as the worst-case scenario that could still result in a deal. But studies show that those who instead focus on identifying their goals, also called aspirations, get more from their negotiations—especially aspirations that are “optimistic, specific, and justifiable.” How do we find those aspirations? By identifying our needs. When we set goals based on our real needs, we negotiate from a place of clarity and conviction that helps us aspire to more. We steer more confidently and with more accuracy toward our goal. I am often asked: “How do you know when to walk away from a negotiation?” “How do you stand firm on your goal?” “How do you ask for more, and do it confidently?” My answer to these three questions is the same: you negotiate based on a thorough understanding of your deepest needs. Your needs are your clarity and your strength.

人们在谈判前常常会考虑自己的“底线”，也就是即便情况最坏但仍有可能达成交易的方案。但研究表明，那些专注于明确自身目标（也称愿望）的人，在谈判中往往能取得更大的成功——尤其是那些“乐观、具体且合理”的愿望。那么，我们如何找到这些愿望呢？答案是：认清自身的需求。当我们基于自身真正的需求设定目标时，我们就能以清晰的思路和坚定的信念进行谈判，从而更有动力去追求更高的目标。我们也能更加自信、更加精准地朝着目标前进。我经常被问到：“你如何判断何时应该结束谈判？”“你如何才能坚定地坚持自己的目标？”“你如何才能自信地提出更高的要求？”我对这三个问题的答案是一致的：谈判的基础在于对自身最深层需求的透彻理解。你的需求就是你的清晰思路和强大力量。

By contrast, when we go into negotiation, or even through life, without understanding our needs, we become rudderless. We are sitting in the kayak with a paddle in our lap, at the mercy of the wind and waves. We may feel scattered, disorganized, panicked. We never find our destination because we don’t know which way to steer.

相反，如果我们不了解自身需求就贸然进入谈判，甚至在生活中摸索前行，就会失去方向。我们就像坐在皮划艇里，桨放在腿上，任由风浪摆布。我们可能会感到迷茫、无所适从、惊慌失措。我们永远找不到目的地，因为我们不知道该往哪个方向走。

Even though our needs are critical to negotiation, we often don’t uncover them without asking ourselves the right questions. In this chapter, you’ll learn how to do just that.

尽管我们的需求对谈判至关重要，但如果我们不问自己正确的问题，往往无法发现这些需求。本章将教你如何做到这一点。

Identifying Your Needs

明确您的需求

“What do I need?” is an important question. It helps you get to the root of any problem or negotiation. And it takes practice and patience to answer it fully.

“我需要什么？”是一个重要的问题。它能帮助你找到任何问题或谈判的根源。而要全面回答这个问题，需要练习和耐心。

Here, you will ask yourself what you need and write down your response. I’m going to guide you through the different types of needs that can come up when people answer this question. And I will propose a couple of very important follow-up questions to ask yourself in order to make those needs concrete and actionable, so you can move forward with confidence toward your aspirations. We’ll also examine how to uncover the needs you’ve been hiding even from yourself, and what to do when you have needs that appear to conflict.

在这里，你需要问问自己需要什么，并写下你的答案。我会引导你了解人们在回答这个问题时可能产生的不同类型的需求。我还会提出几个非常重要的后续问题，帮助你将这些需求具体化、可操作化，从而让你更有信心地朝着目标前进。我们还会探讨如何发现你甚至对自己都未曾察觉的需求，以及当你的需求看似相互冲突时该如何应对。

Your Turn in the Mirror

轮到你照镜子了

I want you to begin this exercise by giving yourself time to contemplate the question of what you need. I suggest you write down your answers before we delve into the broader topic of human needs in general. Get into a comfortable place, turn off your phone, and devote yourself to looking in the Mirror. Set aside five minutes to write down whatever comes to mind. Remember, no self-censorship! If you think it, even for a fraction of a second, write it down, just as it is. And if you get nothing but silence to start, that’s fine. Sit quietly for a few minutes. Give yourself the gift of your patience and time (it’s only five minutes) to answer this question:

我希望你先花点时间思考一下自己真正需要什么。我建议你在深入探讨人类需求这个更广泛的话题之前，先把答案写下来。找个舒服的地方，关掉手机，专心照镜子。留出五分钟时间，写下你脑海中浮现的任何想法。记住，不要自我审查！只要你想到了，哪怕只有一瞬间，也要把它写下来，原原本本。如果你一开始什么也想不到，那也没关系。安静地坐几分钟。给自己一些耐心和时间（只有五分钟），来回答这个问题：

What do I need?

我需要什么？

If you write a few things and then feel stuck, imagine me asking you, “What else?” or “Can you say more about [what you’ve just written down]?” Keep going until five minutes are up.

如果你写了一些东西后感觉卡住了，就想象一下我问你：“还有什么要补充的吗？”或者“你能再详细说说你刚才写的内容吗？”继续写，直到五分钟结束。

To Have Needs Is Human; to Understand Them, Divine

拥有需求是人之常情；理解需求则是神圣之举。

I deliberately started this chapter with you, because I wanted to give you the freedom to answer this question for yourself before priming you with research on, and more examples of, other people’s needs.

我特意从你开始讲本章，因为我想让你在通过研究和更多其他人的需求示例来引导你之前，先自由地回答这个问题。

So now that you’ve given this some thought, let’s analyze needs more generally. What are they? How do we think about them? How can we make sense of what we need, and what those needs mean for our negotiation?

既然你已经思考过这个问题，那么让我们更广泛地分析一下需求。需求是什么？我们如何看待它们？我们如何理解我们的需求，以及这些需求对我们的谈判意味着什么？

The Problem: We Confuse Needs with Other Stuff

问题：我们把需求和其他东西混淆了

We have so little practice identifying our own needs that we can get them confused with other things. Needs are different from emotions, for example. If you’re feeling a certain way about a situation, generally it’s because you have a need that is (or isn’t) being met. We feel what we feel because we need what we need.

我们很少有机会去识别自己的需求，以至于常常会把它们和其他事物混淆。例如，需求和情绪是不同的。如果你对某种情况有某种感觉，通常是因为你的某种需求得到了满足（或没有得到满足）。我们之所以会有某种感觉，是因为我们需要它。

We also frequently confuse needs with our negotiation demands or positions. For example: “I’ve waited ten years for a promotion to VP; now it’s my turn. I should be the very next one from our division who gets promoted.” Or: “I always plan our outings with the kids—I’m not doing it today.” And in a legal case, demands are what’s contained in the case documents, such as: “He breached our contract, and I’m owed damages of fifty thousand dollars.”

我们也经常将需求与谈判要求或立场混淆。例如：“我等了十年才升任副总裁；现在轮到我了。我理应是我们部门下一个升职的人。”或者：“带孩子们出去玩都是我安排的——今天我不安排了。”而在法律案件中，诉求指的是案件文件中所载的内容，例如：“他违反了我们的合同，他应该赔偿我五万美元。”

The challenge in identifying our needs is that they aren’t always explicit. So we focus on our demands, which are easier to identify because they often relate to money or something tangible.

识别自身需求的难点在于，这些需求并非总是显而易见的。因此，我们往往关注自身的诉求，因为诉求更容易识别，它们通常与金钱或有形事物相关。

So what’s the difference between needs and demands? Needs are the reasons why we make demands. When you uncover your needs, you get valuable information that helps you and the other person have a more successful negotiation.

那么，需求和要求之间有什么区别呢？需求是我们提出要求的根本原因。当你明确了自己的需求，就能获得宝贵的信息，帮助你和对方更有效地进行谈判。

Human Needs in Negotiation

谈判中的人性需求

Having spent more than a decade mediating conflicts of every kind, I’ve seen many of the same basic human needs come up over and over again. But needs can also be as varied and diverse as humans themselves. Experts in many disciplines, from anthropology to psychology and law, have thought about and created ways to organize and think about needs.

十多年来，我调解过各种各样的冲突，发现许多基本的人类需求反复出现。但需求本身也如同人类一样，千差万别、千姿百态。从人类学到心理学再到法律，许多学科的专家都思考并创造了各种方法来组织和理解这些需求。

In this section I will highlight several categories of needs that human beings experience. Drawn from psychology research, they transcend gender, culture, and subject matter. We will talk about basic physical needs first and then move on to social, emotional, and other needs. Let’s take a brief look through these categories and see which of them resonates with you.

在本节中，我将重点介绍人类经历的几种需求类别。这些需求源于心理学研究，超越了性别、文化和学科的界限。我们将首先讨论基本的生理需求，然后再探讨社交需求、情感需求和其他需求。让我们简要了解一下这些类别，看看哪些与您产生共鸣。

Basic Biological Needs: First Things First

基本生理需求：首要之事

Our most fundamental needs as human beings are basic physical needs: food, clothing, shelter, sleep, sex, air, and water. For many of us, these needs come first; we must have our basic physical needs met before we can function well enough to turn our attention to any higher-order needs, like financial advancement or emotional satisfaction.

作为人类，我们最基本的需求是基本的生理需求：食物、衣物、住所、睡眠、性、空气和水。对我们许多人来说，这些需求至关重要；我们必须先满足这些基本的生理需求，才能正常运转，进而关注更高层次的需求，例如经济进步或情感满足。

I’ve seen how “physical needs first” rings true. I have encountered many cases in New York City Civil Court where one of the parties to a dispute is food insecure or homeless. I recall one case in which a landlord was suing a former tenant for back rent. The court asked us to have the parties negotiate. We brought both parties to our mediation room inside the courthouse, where the defendant sat silently on one side of the table, huddled up and shivering—even though the temperature inside the room was quite warm. When it was his turn to speak, he sheepishly asked us for a little time, saying he was having trouble formulating his thoughts. My students, reading the situation, called for a private session (a mediator move in which we talk to each party individually) so that he could talk to us without the pressure of having the other party present. Once we were alone, the former tenant opened up to us. He told us that he was homeless, and that even for some time before that, he had not had enough to eat. He said, “I don’t mean to be dramatic or whatever, but I swear… it’s hard to think when the fridge is empty.” I greatly admired this man’s efforts to participate in negotiation despite the fact that he was suffering and hungry. We ultimately decided that we could better use our time together to connect him with resources to help meet his basic physical needs. We left him our Mediation Clinic number to call when he was in a better place and ready to negotiate his case.

我亲眼见证了“优先满足基本需求”这句话的真谛。我在纽约市民事法庭遇到过很多这样的案例：纠纷中的一方面临食物短缺或无家可归的困境。我记得曾有一个案例，房东起诉前租客追讨拖欠的房租。法庭要求我们促成双方协商。我们把双方带到法院内的调解室，被告默默地坐在桌子的一侧，蜷缩着身子瑟瑟发抖——尽管房间里的温度相当温暖。轮到他发言时，他不好意思地请求给我们一点时间，说他一时语塞，不知如何组织语言。我的学生们察觉到他的情况，便要求进行单独会谈（调解员常用的技巧，即分别与双方交谈），这样他就可以在不受对方在场压力的情况下与我们交谈。单独会谈后，这位前租客敞开心扉。他告诉我们他无家可归，而且在此之前的一段时间里，他一直食不果腹。他说：“我不是想夸张什么的，但我发誓……冰箱空空如也的时候，真的很难思考。”我非常钦佩这位男士在忍受饥饿和痛苦的情况下仍然努力参与谈判。最终，我们决定与其浪费时间，不如帮助他联系相关资源，以满足他的基本生活需求。我们把调解诊所的电话号码留给了他，让他等身体状况好转、准备好协商案件时再联系我们。

This relationship between hunger and conflict also exists on the world stage. David Beasley, executive director of the World Food Programme, says, “The link between hunger and conflict is as strong as it is destructive. Conflict leads to food insecurity. And food insecurity can also stoke instability and tension, which trigger violence.” Globally, according to Beasley, 60 percent of the 815 million chronically food-insecure people live in conflict areas.

饥饿与冲突之间的这种关联也存在于世界范围内。世界粮食计划署执行主任戴维·比斯利表示：“饥饿与冲突之间的联系既紧密又极具破坏性。冲突会导致粮食不安全，而粮食不安全又会加剧不稳定和紧张局势，进而引发暴力。”比斯利指出，全球8.15亿长期面临粮食不安全问题的人口中，有60%生活在冲突地区。

Even if we are not dealing with food insecurity or the effects of war, we all share these basic human needs. Physiological needs are the reason that, when I mediate disputes, I make sure all parties have plenty of food, drinks, and time for breaks. We have a hard time focusing when those physical needs aren’t met. Don’t neglect food, water, and rest—for you and for others—when you negotiate.

即使我们不必面对粮食短缺或战争的影响，这些基本的人类需求我们所有人都有。生理需求正是我在调解纠纷时，确保各方都有充足的食物、饮水和休息时间的原因。如果这些生理需求得不到满足，我们就很难集中注意力。谈判时，不要忽视食物、水和休息——这不仅对你，也对他人。

Safety and Security Needs

安全保障需求

The next category of needs is safety, which includes security and economic stability. These interests often feel more urgent for human beings than the needs we’ll discuss after.

下一类需求是安全，包括保障和经济稳定。对人类而言，这些需求往往比我们接下来要讨论的需求更为迫切。

Safety, or the sense of protection from harm, is a fundamental need for all human beings. I once invited diplomats from Kosovo to come to Columbia Law School and talk about the peace process that gave birth to their nation. All of them said that their “freedom” or sovereignty did not begin until Kosovo’s citizens, who had been ravaged by famine and violence, were fed and safe; only as the fear subsided could they even begin to think about progress or political stature. If your list of needs includes basics like safety, you may have to focus on this need first, before addressing the secondary needs farther down in this section.

安全感，或者说免受伤害的保障感，是所有人类的基本需求。我曾邀请科索沃的外交官来哥伦比亚法学院，探讨促成他们国家诞生的和平进程。他们都表示，只有当饱受饥荒和暴力蹂躏的科索沃公民获得温饱和安全保障后，他们的“自由”或主权才真正开始；只有当恐惧消退，他们才能开始考虑发展或政治地位。如果你的需求清单中包含安全等基本需求，那么在本节后面讨论其他次要需求之前，你可能需要首先关注这一需求。

Our human need for security also affects many of our everyday choices and concerns. In the daily decisions we make, some of us are what I call “security negotiators”—meaning that we value certainty and lowering risk over saving money or other needs.

人类对安全的需求也影响着我们许多日常选择和考量。在日常决策中，有些人是我所谓的“安全谈判者”——这意味着我们更看重确定性和降低风险，而不是省钱或其他需求。

During a negotiation training workshop I held for U.S. government officials, one participant, Mikayla, described a frustrating interaction she had recently had with her husband over day-care arrangements for their son. Their agency was in the process of cutting down on telework, meaning that she and her husband would need to find new care arrangements. She found a beautiful, safe facility close to home that had a spot available. It was on the higher end of their price range, but it fit their needs, and she was ready to close the deal. Balking at the high price tag, he insisted that they try to look around for something a little cheaper. Exasperated, Mikayla discussed the situation with her colleagues.

在我为美国政府官员举办的谈判培训研讨会上，一位名叫米凯拉的学员讲述了她最近与丈夫就儿子日托安排发生的令人沮丧的争执。他们所在的机构正在缩减远程办公，这意味着她和丈夫需要寻找新的托儿安排。她在家附近找到了一家环境优美、安全可靠的托儿机构，而且还有空位。虽然价格略高于他们的预算，但符合他们的需求，她也准备敲定此事。然而，丈夫却对高昂的价格颇有微词，坚持要他们再找找更便宜的。米凯拉感到非常恼火，于是和同事们讨论了这件事。

I said, “It sounds like your need for security is trumping your need to maximize the economics of this situation.”

我说：“听起来你对安全的需求超过了你从这种情况中获得最大经济利益的需求。”

She said, “Yes, actually, that’s true! I’m big on security. For me, as long as a big decision is open, I worry. What if the day care fills up? What if nothing else turns out to be better? I’d rather have it settled. When we looked for houses, I was the same way. As soon as we found one that worked, I was done. Having it settled made me feel so relieved.”

她说：“是的，确实如此！我特别注重安全感。对我来说，只要一个重大决定悬而未决，我就会焦虑。万一托儿所满了怎么办？万一没有更好的选择怎么办？我宁愿尽快定下来。当初我们找房子的时候，我也是这样。一旦找到合适的房子，我就决定了。一切尘埃落定让我如释重负。”

This official prioritized the security of having a day-care spot secured. Meanwhile, her husband had a higher need for economic efficiency. They negotiated with the day care to give them some time to make a decision. And Mikayla and her husband agreed that if they couldn’t mutually settle on another, cheaper day care in that time, they would go with the facility she had found and find another way to save costs in their budget. Setting a timeline allowed Mikayla to feel secure, and gave her husband some assurance that either way, they’d be making efforts on the financial front.

这位官员优先考虑的是确保孩子能有个托儿所名额。与此同时，她的丈夫则更注重经济效益。他们与托儿所协商，希望他们能给些时间做决定。米凯拉和丈夫约定，如果在这段时间内他们无法找到另一家更便宜的托儿所，他们就选择米凯拉找到的那家，并想办法在预算中节省开支。设定时间期限让米凯拉感到安心，也让她的丈夫确信，无论结果如何，他们都会努力节省开支。

Financial security rounds out the list of these fundamental needs. Money allows us to buy the necessities of life. It means food, health insurance, childcare, and a safety net for emergencies. When people negotiate for their salary or the value of a contract, they may have in mind specific needs that will be fulfilled by that money. If a person’s economic needs are pressing, they may value economic stability above anything else, including title or quality of life. But, as you’ll see later in this chapter, money also connects to other, less concrete needs.

财务安全是这些基本需求中的最后一项。金钱使我们能够购买生活必需品，例如食物、医疗保险、托儿服务以及应对紧急情况的安全保障。人们在协商薪资或合同价值时，心中可能已经预设了需要用这笔钱来满足的具体需求。如果一个人的经济需求迫切，他们可能会将经济稳定置于一切之上，包括身份或生活质量。但是，正如你将在本章后面看到的那样，金钱也与其他一些不太具体的需求息息相关。

Psychological and Emotional Needs

心理和情感需求

Think you can take psychology and emotion out of negotiation? Think again. All negotiations, even those that center on finances, involve psychological and emotional needs. These can include:

认为谈判中可以忽略心理和情感因素？再想想。所有谈判，即使是围绕财务的谈判，都涉及心理和情感需求。这些需求可能包括：

Love and belonging needs, which include love, acceptance, social support, belonging, intimacy, affection, and affiliation (which is defined as feeling part of a group, whether at work or with friends or at home). That these needs come up in personal negotiations is not surprising. We need few things more than the love and support of those closest to us.

爱与归属的需求包括爱、接纳、社会支持、归属感、亲密感、情感和归属感（即感受到自己是某个群体的一份子，无论是在工作场所、朋友圈还是家庭中）。这些需求在人际交往中被提及并不奇怪。我们最需要的莫过于来自至亲之人的爱与支持。

Sometimes people read words like “love,” “belonging,” and “esteem,” and ask me if these needs actually come up in work-centered negotiations. The answer is: all the time. In my experience, people often ask or sue for money because they can’t contract for love, appreciation, or acceptance. We spend a lot of our lives at work, and studies show that whether we feel we belong, whether we have friendships and connections there, is a major determinant of both happiness and productivity.

有时人们看到“爱”、“归属感”和“尊重”这样的词语，会问我这些需求是否真的会在以工作为中心的谈判中出现。答案是：一直都在。以我的经验来看，人们常常因为无法用合同换取爱、欣赏或认可而要求赔偿或提起诉讼。我们一生中大部分时间都花在工作上，研究表明，我们是否感到归属，是否在工作中拥有友谊和人脉，是决定幸福感和工作效率的重要因素。

Esteem needs, both self-esteem-focused (dignity, pride, achievement, accomplishment) and those that focus on the esteem of others (like respect, reputation, recognition, or status). One of the things I love about assisting people in their negotiations is seeing the sense of pride and accomplishment radiating off them when they achieve a great result for themselves. In fact, self-esteem needs may be one of the things that drove you to pick up this book. You, too, may want more pride, achievement, and accomplishment from your life. If that’s you, stay tuned: later in this chapter, I’ll show you how to turn those powerful needs into an action plan that brings you closer to realizing them.

尊重需求包括以自我为中心的尊重需求（例如尊严、自豪感、成就感和满足感），以及以他人尊重为中心的尊重需求（例如尊重、声誉、认可或地位）。我喜欢帮助人们进行谈判的原因之一，就是看到他们在取得理想结果时，由衷地感到自豪和成就感。事实上，或许正是对自尊的需求促使你拿起这本书。你也可能渴望在生活中获得更多的自豪感、成就感和满足感。如果是这样，请继续阅读：在本章稍后部分，我将向你展示如何将这些强大的需求转化为行动计划，从而帮助你更接近目标。

Esteem needs underlie personal negotiations as well as business and diplomatic ones. Four major needs in this category are respect, dignity, recognition, and reputation.

尊重需求是个人谈判、商务谈判和外交谈判的基础。这一类别的四大主要需求是尊重、尊严、认可和声誉。

I have never yet seen a negotiation in which respect, which means admiration for someone or consideration for their feelings, rights, or wishes, was not critically important for success. Marriage researcher John Gottman has studied respect for decades and found that lack of respect in a partnership is one of the “Four Horsemen” that predicts divorce. Likewise, in business, research shows that when people receive respect, they are more likely to give it in return. Respect creates trust—and deals.

我从未见过任何谈判中，尊重——即对他人表示敬佩或体谅其感受、权利或愿望——不是成功的关键因素。婚姻研究专家约翰·戈特曼数十年来一直致力于研究尊重，他发现伴侣关系中缺乏尊重是导致离婚的“四大罪魁祸首”之一。同样，在商业领域，研究表明，当人们受到尊重时，他们更有可能给予尊重。尊重创造信任，并促成交易。

Dignity, which in some cultures is called “face,” is very important for people in all situations. From cradle to grave, every human being craves a sense of pride and worthiness in themselves—and whether that need is met is critical to their well-being, or even their will to live. When my father’s hospice agency helped my father make one final trip back to his home to spend time with his family, I was surprised and touched to see that even as he struggled to get out of the car, he had flowers in his hand. His hospice nurse, Patricia, had asked him whether he wanted to bring flowers to his wife, since he was going home for dinner. He was able to say yes, and so she took him to purchase some. She preserved his dignity even in the midst of great physical weakness.

尊严，在某些文化中被称为“面子”，对任何情况下的人来说都至关重要。从摇篮到坟墓，每个人都渴望获得一种自豪感和自我价值感——而这种需求是否得到满足，对他们的幸福，甚至他们的生存意志都至关重要。我父亲的临终关怀机构帮助他最后一次回家与家人团聚时，我惊讶又感动地看到，即使他挣扎着下车，手里仍然拿着鲜花。他的临终关怀护士帕特里夏问他是否想回家吃晚饭时带些花给妻子。他回答“是”，于是帕特里夏带他去买了花。即使在他身体极度虚弱的时候，她也维护了他的尊严。

Dignity also matters greatly in workplace situations. Senior diplomats tell me that if you challenge someone publicly, you challenge their dignity. The resulting embarrassment often results in intense anger and defensiveness that makes agreement challenging. Diplomats who are skilled in negotiation know that if they need to have a difficult conversation, they have it one-on-one. One diplomat described a major multinational negotiation that broke down in the middle of the night due to a leader feeling his dignity had been insulted: “He left the building in anger. I followed him to see what was happening and, away from the negotiation room, I told him I honored his need and wanted to help. Eventually he returned. Supporting his dignity saved a major policy initiative that would have affected the entire globe.”

尊严在职场中也至关重要。资深外交官告诉我，如果你公开质疑某人，就等于质疑他们的尊严。由此产生的尴尬往往会导致强烈的愤怒和防御心理，使得达成协议变得异常困难。擅长谈判的外交官深知，如果需要进行艰难的对话，他们会选择一对一的方式。一位外交官曾描述过一次重要的多边谈判，由于一位领导人感到自己的尊严受到侮辱，谈判在半夜破裂：“他愤怒地离开了大楼。我跟了过去，想看看发生了什么，然后在谈判室外告诉他，我理解他的需求，并愿意提供帮助。最终他回来了。维护他的尊严挽救了一项可能影响全球的重大政策举措。”

Recognition is another big need in this category. I have seen the need for recognition come up in almost every single one of the many hundreds of cases I have mediated over the course of my career. Many of the relationship cases I assist are, at their core, about each person’s need to be recognized for what they bring to the relationship. Likewise, in business situations, when people feel that they or their views are not recognized, negotiations and organizations break down. If one of the decision-makers sufficiently acknowledges each viewpoint, she may well get people on board even if all their views do not make it into the initiative under consideration.

认可也是此类需求中的一个重要方面。在我职业生涯中调解过的数百起案例中，几乎每一起都出现了对认可的需求。我协助处理的许多关系案例，其核心都是每个人都希望自己的付出得到认可。同样，在商业环境中，如果人们感到自己或自己的观点没有得到认可，谈判和组织就会崩溃。如果决策者能够充分肯定每个人的观点，即使并非所有人的意见最终都能被纳入到正在考虑的方案中，她也很有可能赢得大家的支持。

Finally, most people in negotiation care deeply about their reputation. Over the course of many negotiations, I’ve seen reputation come up over and over again as a critical need, one that often stays below the surface unless you recognize it. Many people who consult with me on negotiating their salary tell me that the money, in addition to providing the necessities of life, also helps to build their reputation. If the negotiation you’re approaching is the first of many similar ones you will need to tackle—for example, you’re starting to negotiate with clients over your new product or service—you may find yourself concerned about your reputation as a company leader, or your product’s reputation in the marketplace.

最后，大多数谈判者都非常重视自己的声誉。在多次谈判中，我反复看到声誉被提及，并被视为一项至关重要的需求，而这种需求往往隐藏在表面之下，除非你意识到它的存在。许多向我咨询薪资谈判的人告诉我，金钱除了满足生活必需之外，还有助于建立他们的声誉。如果你即将面临的谈判是众多类似谈判中的第一个——例如，你开始与客户就你的新产品或服务进行谈判——你可能会发现自己会担心作为公司领导者的声誉，或者你的产品在市场上的声誉。

A talent agent recalled a story of trying to negotiate terms for one of the first actors he ever represented. The agent was new, and realized he was showing inflexibility and exasperating the production company. But he pressed on. Why? He was just starting out and didn’t want to be known as a soft negotiator. If reputation seems like it might be a need for you in your negotiation (and it often is), take a moment to consider it now.

一位经纪人回忆起他第一次为一位他代理的演员谈判合约条款时的经历。这位经纪人当时刚入行，意识到自己态度僵硬，让制片公司很不耐烦。但他坚持不懈。为什么呢？因为他刚入行，不想落得个“谈判软弱”的名声。如果你觉得在谈判中维护声誉很重要（这种情况很常见），不妨现在就花点时间好好考虑一下。

Self-direction needs, including freedom or autonomy. People have a deep need to know that they are in charge of making their own decisions to the extent possible under law, or the rules of an organization (this includes families!). Even if someone you’re negotiating with, like a child, does not ultimately have decision-making power, consulting them and hearing them, or offering a menu of possible choices, can help satisfy these self-direction needs.

自主需求，包括自由和自主权。人们内心深处渴望在法律或组织规则允许的范围内（包括家庭！）能够自主做出决定。即使你协商的对象，比如孩子，最终没有决策权，咨询他们、倾听他们的意见，或者提供一系列可能的选择，都能帮助满足他们的自主需求。

Together, these psychological and emotional needs dominate many of the legal, business, family, neighborhood, and diplomatic negotiations we encounter every day.

这些心理和情感需求共同主导着我们每天遇到的许多法律、商业、家庭、邻里和外交谈判。

Other Needs

其他需求

Rounding out our categories of needs are the following:

我们的需求类别还包括以下几类：

  • TRANSCENDENCE. Values that transcend beyond the personal self (i.e., religious faith, mystical experiences and certain experiences with nature, service to others, aesthetic experiences, sexual experiences, the pursuit of science, etc.).
    超越。超越个人自我的价值观（例如，宗教信仰、神秘体验和与自然的某些体验、为他人服务、审美体验、性体验、追求科学等）。
  • COGNITIVE. Knowledge and understanding, curiosity, exploration, need for meaning, and predictability.
    认知方面：知识和理解力、好奇心、探索精神、对意义的需求以及可预测性。
  • AESTHETIC. Appreciation and search for beauty, balance, form, etc.
    美学。欣赏和追求美、平衡、形式等。
  • SELF-ACTUALIZATION. Realizing personal potential and self-fulfillment, seeking personal growth and transformative experiences.
    自我实现。发挥个人潜能，实现自我价值，追求个人成长和变革性体验。

Recognizing my self-actualization needs led to the book you are reading today. Eighteen years ago, when I was a student at Columbia Law School, I sat down in a dingy New York City court conference room and experienced one of those transformative moments you normally see in movies. I had enrolled in a course called the Mediation Clinic, on the advice of a law school friend who said little more than “It involves talking a lot—you’ll be great at it.” My professors gave me a short mediation training course and then sent me down to court to mediate my first case.

认识到自我实现的需求，促成了你今天正在阅读的这本书的诞生。十八年前，我还是哥伦比亚法学院的学生时，坐在纽约市一间昏暗的法院会议室里，经历了一次如同电影情节般改变人生的时刻。当时，我听从一位法学院朋友的建议，报名参加了一门名为“调解诊所”的课程。这位朋友只说了一句：“这门课需要大量沟通——你肯定能做得很好。”我的教授们给我安排了一个简短的调解培训课程，然后就派我去法院调解我的第一个案件。

That day, when the two parties sat down in front of me, and I started to help them resolve their dispute, I experienced a moment in which I realized, with perfect clarity, what I was put on this earth to achieve. I knew that when I was helping people negotiate better, I was realizing my highest potential. I felt more fulfilled than I’d ever felt before. The following semester, I went on to serve as a teaching assistant in the clinic and to help other students learn to mediate better. I absolutely loved it.

那天，当双方在我面前坐下，我开始帮助他们解决纠纷时，我突然无比清晰地意识到我来到这个世界的意义。我知道，当我帮助人们更好地谈判时，我就实现了我最大的潜能。我感到前所未有的满足。接下来的学期，我继续在诊所担任助教，帮助其他学生学习如何更好地进行调解。我非常喜欢这份工作。

After graduating from Columbia Law School, I went to work as a lawyer at one of the nation’s top law firms. I loved my work and my colleagues. I was well compensated. My parents were happy that I had found a stable job. But I yearned for more from my life. I thought back to that day in court and realized that I needed the fulfillment I had felt helping parties resolve their conflicts and students reach their own potential. I knew that returning to Columbia to teach mediation would allow me to grow. As I sit down to write this today, I know that recognizing my self-actualization needs led me to the best decision of my life—to leave a prestigious law firm job to teach and mediate. I wake up every day fulfilled by the work I’m doing.

从哥伦比亚法学院毕业后，我进入了美国顶尖律师事务所之一担任律师。我热爱我的工作和同事，收入也很丰厚。我的父母很高兴我找到了一份稳定的工作。但我渴望拥有更充实的生活。我回想起在法庭上的那一天，意识到我需要那种帮助当事人解决冲突、帮助学生发挥潜能所带来的成就感。我知道回到哥伦比亚大学教授调解课程能够让我获得成长。今天，当我坐下来写下这些文字时，我知道正是对自我实现需求的认知，让我做出了人生中最正确的决定——离开一家声名显赫的律师事务所，投身于教学和调解工作。每天醒来，我都因自己的工作而感到无比满足。

We Prioritize Needs Differently

我们对需求的优先顺序不同

Note that while people generally prioritize their basic physical and safety needs above all else, this is by no means universal. Human beings value things differently; if you negotiate enough, you’ll find, for example, some people who prioritize spiritual needs over economic security. I once mediated a legal case involving a religious organization. It was a breach of contract claim brought by the family of a deceased person against the religious organization to which he had belonged. The family alleged that the deceased, a loved one and a devoted member of this faith, had told them while he was alive that the organization had promised to bury him if he did not have enough money to cover his funeral expenses. When he died, the family contacted the organization to confirm that he was a congregant—but no one responded. Tearfully, the family told us that his body had sat in the morgue for a month until they could pull together the money to bury him.

请注意，虽然人们通常会将基本的生理和安全需求放在首位，但这绝非普遍现象。每个人对事物的价值判断都不同；例如，如果你进行足够的沟通，你会发现有些人会将精神需求置于经济保障之上。我曾调解过一起涉及宗教组织的法律案件。这是一起由一位已故人士的家属提起的违约诉讼，被告是死者生前所属的宗教组织。家属声称，死者是他们挚爱的亲人，也是该宗教的虔诚信徒，生前曾告诉他们，如果他没有足够的钱支付丧葬费用，该组织承诺会负责安葬他。死者去世后，家属联系该组织确认死者是否是其成员，但却无人回应。家属含泪告诉我们，死者的遗体在停尸房里存放了一个月，直到他们筹到足够的钱才得以安葬。

There was no written contract in this case. But the organization’s lawyer, herself a congregant of the same faith, told me from the beginning of the mediation that if what the family was alleging turned out to be true, the organization had a moral imperative to pay out a settlement no matter what the law said. The organization’s spiritual needs trumped their economic or legal ones.

本案中没有书面合同。但该组织的律师（她本人也是同一信仰的信徒）从调解一开始就告诉我，如果家属的指控属实，无论法律如何规定，该组织都有道义上的责任支付和解金。该组织的精神需求凌驾于经济或法律需求之上。

Going Further: Tangibles and Intangibles

更进一步：有形因素和无形因素

Now that you’ve read these categories, which of these resonates with you? Do any additional needs come to mind? If so, go ahead and write those down, too.

现在你已经了解了这些类别，其中哪些与你产生共鸣？你还有其他需求吗？如果有，也请写下来。

Once you’ve completed your list, we’ll take a closer look at what you’ve written down to help you achieve a deeper understanding of your needs. We’ll formulate actionable steps you can take to ensure those needs are met. The first step is to take a look at your needs and categorize them by dividing them into two buckets: tangibles and intangibles.

完成清单后，我们会仔细查看您写下的内容，帮助您更深入地了解自身需求。我们会制定切实可行的步骤，确保这些需求得到满足。第一步是审视您的需求，并将其分为两类：有形需求和无形需求。

Tangibles

有形资产

Let’s start with tangibles. Tangibles are things you can touch or feel or see or count: everything from clients, dollars, titles, or paintings to stores, scores, jobs, and units on a shelf. So if you ask yourself, “What do I need?” and start out by answering with tangible items, like “more money,” “a promotion to vice president,” or “new clients,” that’s a great place to start. Make sure you have covered all the tangibles you can identify.

我们先从有形事物说起。有形事物是指你可以触摸、感受、看到或计数的东西：从客户、金钱、头衔或画作，到商店、分数、工作和货架上的商品，无所不包。所以，如果你问自己“我需要什么？”，并首先从有形事物入手，比如“更多的钱”、“晋升为副总裁”或“新客户”，这是一个很好的起点。确保你已经涵盖了所有你能想到的有形事物。

But that’s not where our work ends today, because we want to go beyond the tangible when considering your needs. Look at the tangibles on your list and ask yourself these follow-up questions:

但我们今天的工作并未就此结束，因为我们希望在考虑您的需求时，超越那些看得见摸得着的层面。请审视您清单上的各项具体事项，并问自己以下几个后续问题：

  • “What makes this important?”
    “这件事为什么重要？”
  • “What does this represent for me?”
    “这对我来说意味着什么？”

These questions help you get at why you need the tangibles you’ve listed. Once we know the why , we can move on in subsequent chapters to tackle the how . For example, you might start with something concrete like, “I need five new clients this quarter.” When you ask yourself what makes this important, you might find yourself realizing “I need more clients because that means greater financial security,” or “I need a sense of challenge and advancement in my life.” That’s great. Once you’ve drilled down past the concrete, you uncover your deepest needs and values. We will use those to design your solution.

这些问题能帮助你弄清楚为什么你需要列出的这些具体需求。一旦我们了解了原因，就可以在后续章节中探讨如何实现。例如，你可以从一些具体的事情入手，比如“我这季度需要五个新客户”。当你问自己为什么这件事很重要时，你可能会意识到“我需要更多客户，因为这意味着更稳定的财务状况”，或者“我需要在生活中获得挑战和进步”。这很好。一旦你深入挖掘，超越了这些具体需求，你就能发现你内心深处的真正需求和价值观。我们将以此为基础，为你设计解决方案。

Tangibles often represent something else—something larger, of which the tangibles are just a part. We need to get underneath the tangibles to figure out the larger needs that lie underneath. For example, when I asked Walden, the CEO of a wellness consumer product start-up, about his needs for his company, one of the first things that came up was “achieve penetration into major chain stores and then achieve velocity (rate of customer consumption) in certain Midwest cities by 1Q2021.” When I followed up and asked him why this was important, he replied, “Everyone knows our product can succeed on the coasts. Many new wellness products do great in New York and LA. That’s a given. What distinguishes the products that succeed is high uptake in the rest of the country. If we achieve high velocity rates in cities like Des Moines, for example, our investors and the market will know we are here to stay, and we’ll set ourselves up for the next round of financing.” I summarized this back for him and asked him, “So what does the Midwest penetration number really mean for your needs?” He said, “Well, I hadn’t thought about this, but really, the Midwest number means investment—keeping the investors we have happy and attracting new ones.” We added “Investor Attraction/Satisfaction” to our list of needs, and put the “Midwest numbers” underneath it.

有形的事物往往代表着其他东西——某种更大的东西，而有形的事物只是其中的一部分。我们需要深入探究有形事物之下，才能找到隐藏的更深层次的需求。例如，当我问一家健康消费品初创公司的首席执行官沃尔登，他公司有哪些需求时，他首先提到的就是“打入大型连锁商店，然后在2021年第一季度之前，在某些中西部城市实现销售速度（客户消费率）。”当我追问他为什么这很重要时，他回答说：“大家都知道我们的产品在沿海地区可以成功。许多新的健康产品在纽约和洛杉矶都卖得很好。这是毋庸置疑的。真正成功的产品之所以能脱颖而出，是因为它们在其他地区的高接受度。如果我们能在像得梅因这样的城市实现高销售速度，我们的投资者和市场就会知道我们会长期发展，我们也能为下一轮融资做好准备。”我向他总结了一下，然后问他：“那么，中西部地区的渗透率对你们的需求究竟意味着什么？” 他说：“嗯，我之前没想过这个问题，但实际上，中西部地区的渗透率意味着投资——既要让现有投资者满意，又要吸引新投资者。” 我们将“吸引/满足投资者”添加到需求列表中，并将“中西部地区的渗透率”列在后面。

Like Walden, once you make those deeper needs explicit, you may end up expanding or refining the tangibles that go with it. After you identify why those are important to you, I want you to ask yourself, “How else might I fulfill my need for investor satisfaction?” In this way, you’ll both clarify the root need and generate a complete list of options to meet it.

就像瓦尔登湖一样，一旦你明确了那些深层次的需求，你最终可能会扩展或完善与之相关的具体方案。在你确定这些方案对你为何重要之后，我希望你问问自己：“我还能通过什么方式来满足我的投资满意度需求？” 这样，你既能明确根本需求，又能列出满足该需求的完整方案清单。

Intangibles

无形资产

Some of the needs on your list may be intangibles, which are ephemeral but important ideals that give our lives meaning—like many of the needs we discussed earlier in this chapter. When you listed your tangible needs above and then connected them to something deeper, those deeper needs are your intangibles. Some common intangibles include respect, reputation, acknowledgment, communication, success, progress, love, security, privacy, and freedom.

你清单上的一些需求可能是无形的，它们是转瞬即逝却又至关重要的理想，赋予我们生活意义——就像我们在本章前面讨论的许多需求一样。当你列出上面提到的有形需求，并将它们与更深层次的东西联系起来时，这些更深层次的需求就是你的无形需求。一些常见的无形需求包括尊重、声誉、认可、沟通、成功、进步、爱、安全感、隐私和自由。

Sometimes intangibles can feel fuzzy or soft because you can’t see or count them. But intangibles are important because they usually transcend any one particular issue and give meaning and purpose to our lives as a whole. Recognizing these intangible needs can help you chart a course for your entire professional or personal life. Remember that in this book we are steering your relationships and your future for the long haul, not just this one negotiation. You’re uncovering your personal needs in a way that will create value far beyond one handshake, contract, or hug.

有时，无形的东西会让人感觉模糊不清，因为它们看不见也数不清。但无形的东西之所以重要，是因为它们通常超越任何具体问题，赋予我们生活整体意义和目标。认识到这些无形的需求，可以帮助你规划整个职业生涯或个人生活。记住，本书旨在引导你建立长久的人际关系，并规划你的未来，而不仅仅是眼前的谈判。你将以一种全新的方式发掘自身的需求，这种价值远超一次握手、一份合同或一个拥抱。

So if you don’t yet have any intangibles on your list, take a moment and think about the needs you have listed. Do any of them connect to one of the intangibles you’ve seen in this chapter? Do any other intangibles occur to you as you’re reading this?

所以，如果你清单上还没有列出任何无形要素，请花点时间思考一下你列出的需求。其中是否有任何需求与本章中提到的某个无形要素相关？在阅读过程中，你是否想到了其他无形要素？

And if you already have intangibles, great. Now we want to do the second phase of our work: concretize them. We want to make those intangible needs actionable so that you can start the work of moving toward realizing them. So for each of these intangibles, you are going to ask yourself an important follow-up question:

如果你已经列出了无形需求，那就太好了。现在我们要进入第二阶段的工作：将它们具体化。我们要把这些无形需求转化为可执行的步骤，这样你才能开始着手实现它们。因此，对于每一项无形需求，你都要问自己一个重要的后续问题：

What would that look like?

那会是什么样子？

For example, when mediating business conflicts, I often hear people say, “I need a fair resolution to this issue.” They repeatedly bring up fairness. When I ask, “What would fairness look like for you here?” that’s where we start making progress toward a solution. Fairness can look vastly different for different people. When I have asked people this question, here is just a sampling of what I’ve heard in response:

例如，在调解商业冲突时，我经常听到人们说：“我需要一个公平的解决方案。”他们反复强调公平。当我问：“对您来说，公平意味着什么？”时，我们才能开始朝着解决方案迈进。公平对不同的人来说可能意义截然不同。以下是我问过人们这个问题后听到的一些回答：

  • $200,000
  • $2,000
  • a promotion
    促销
  • help setting up a child’s speech therapy appointments
    帮助安排孩子的语言治疗预约
  • mentorship from a C-suite executive
    来自高管的指导
  • an hour of television on weekend days
    周末每天看一小时电视
  • a discount on future dry cleaning
    下次干洗可享折扣
  • voting rights
    投票权
  • time off
    休假
  • time away without the kids
    没有孩子的假期
  • removal of six feral cats from a residential property (yes, really)
    从居民住宅中移除六只流浪猫（没错，是真的）
  • a better office location
    更佳的办公地点
  • an apology
    道歉

Getting the picture? Fairness may mean different things to you in different contexts, or at different times. You’ll never know until you ask. So for each of your intangibles, make sure you have asked yourself, “What would that look like?” Once you have your initial answers, make sure your list is complete by asking yourself, “How else might I achieve fairness (or whatever it is that I need) in this situation?” Keep going until you have what feels like a complete list.

明白了吗？公平在不同的情况下、不同时期对你来说可能意味着不同的东西。你不问就永远不会知道。所以，对于你列出的每一个无形要素，务必问问自己：“那会是什么样子？” 有了初步答案后，再问问自己：“在这种情况下，我还能通过什么方式来实现公平（或者我需要的任何东西）？” 继续这样做，直到你觉得列出了一个完整的清单。

As another example: Brett has been thinking about going back to work after ten years at home with her three boys, who are now nine, seven, and five years old. Formerly a management consultant and project manager, she has grown interested in nutrition consulting and has taken a few courses while at home raising her kids. She knows she wants to start her own business, and she’s generated a devoted social media following. But for some time, Brett has found herself torn about which direction to take, and now finds herself feeling stalled. She has decided to write down her needs in the hope that this will give her clarity about her work ambitions.

再举一个例子：布雷特在家照顾三个儿子（现在分别是九岁、七岁和五岁）十年后，一直在考虑重返职场。她以前是一名管理顾问和项目经理，后来对营养咨询产生了兴趣，并在家带孩子期间参加了一些相关课程。她知道自己想创业，并且在社交媒体上积累了一批忠实粉丝。但一段时间以来，布雷特一直犹豫不决，不知道该往哪个方向发展，现在感觉自己陷入了停滞。她决定把自己的需求写下来，希望这能帮助她理清自己的职业目标。

On her list she included “a sense of progress.” When I asked Brett what “a sense of progress” would look like, she answered, “Hmm, I think producing something tangible that people can consume. Maybe creating a PDF with tips that I could hand out. And seeing in-person clients. I don’t just want a social media platform. Having people actually work with me, in person or over Skype, would feel like progress.” Thanks to my question, we were able to identify more about her needs (as well as steps she could take to fulfill them): producing something tangible that people can see or hold in their hands, and finding clients to work with her.

她的清单里包括“取得进步的感觉”。当我问布雷特“取得进步的感觉”具体是什么样的，她回答说：“嗯，我想应该是做出一些人们可以实际体验的东西。比如制作一份包含技巧的PDF文件，可以分发给大家。还有就是能见到客户。我想要的不仅仅是一个社交媒体平台。能让人们真正地和我一起工作，无论是面对面还是通过Skype，都会让我感到有进步。” 多亏了我的问题，我们才能更清楚地了解她的需求（以及她可以采取哪些步骤来实现这些需求）：做出一些人们可以看到或拿到手的实物，以及找到愿意和她合作的客户。

What About Money?

钱怎么办？

Economic needs are real. Money counts as one of the basic, tangible human needs because it allows us to buy the necessities of life. But money also represents other things. In that way, it can also be an intangible; it is a proxy for respect, acknowledgment, progress, contribution, achievement, and even freedom.

经济需求是真实存在的。金钱是人类最基本、最实际的需求之一，因为它使我们能够购买生活必需品。但金钱也代表着其他东西。从这个意义上讲，它也可以是一种无形的东西；它是尊重、认可、进步、贡献、成就乃至自由的象征。

Over the years I’ve spoken to many people from different industries who have told me about financial negotiations they simply couldn’t close even when the terms they offered were objectively reasonable, or even great. Why does this happen? Because often the number isn’t tied to damages or economic realities as much as it symbolizes something else for that person. The need for recognition. A desire for fairness. Heartbreak over a failed relationship.

多年来，我与各行各业的许多人交流过，他们都曾告诉我，即使提出的条件客观上合理甚至优厚，他们也无法达成财务谈判。为什么会这样？因为很多时候，对方给出的数字并非真正基于损失或经济现实，而是象征着其他的东西。比如，渴望得到认可，追求公平，或是一段失败感情带来的伤痛。

So if money comes up as a tangible, explore what that money means to you. What value does it represent? And how else, in addition to money, might you achieve that value? If money comes up as an intangible, like “economic freedom,” ask yourself, “What would economic freedom look like?” This will help you place the money in its proper context and give you information on exactly what you need in order to achieve that value. Is it a flourishing retirement fund? One year’s salary in savings?

所以，如果金钱以有形事物的形式出现，那就探究一下金钱对你意味着什么。它代表着什么价值？除了金钱之外，你还能通过哪些方式实现这种价值？如果金钱以无形事物的形式出现，比如“经济自由”，那就问问自己：“经济自由是什么样的？”这将帮助你正确理解金钱的意义，并让你了解为了实现这种价值，你需要什么。是一笔丰厚的退休金？还是相当于一年工资的存款？

Knowing what you actually need will help you design your future in a way that goes far beyond the outcome of one individual negotiation.

了解自己真正需要什么，将有助于你规划未来，而这远远超出了一次谈判的结果。

Troubleshooting Common Problems

常见问题排查

Here are some additional tips to help you through a few possible issues when answering “What do I need?”:

以下是一些额外提示，可以帮助您解决在回答“我需要什么？”这个问题时可能出现的一些问题：

What If I’m Stuck?

如果我被困住了怎么办？

What if you’ve read this far and you’re still drawing a blank? If you’re having trouble identifying any needs, I have two tricks that often help. Here is the first:

如果你读到这里仍然一头雾水怎么办？如果你难以确定自己的需求，我有两个小技巧通常很有帮助。第一个技巧是：

TIP ONE: THINK ABOUT WHAT YOU ARE CURRENTLY FINDING INTOLERABLE ABOUT YOUR SITUATION OR WHAT’S UPSETTING YOU MOST, THEN FLIP IT AROUND AND WRITE DOWN ITS OPPOSITE. That’s your need. For example, if one of your main issues is feeling undervalued in your relationship, what you’re seeking might be appreciation, respect, or recognition. If you are sitting down with this book because of a job that doesn’t allow you a moment of rest or peace… well, now you can see what you need.

建议一：想想你目前处境中最让你难以忍受或最让你烦恼的是什么，然后反过来写下它的反面。这就是你的需求。例如，如果你的主要问题之一是感觉在感情关系中不被重视，那么你真正渴望的可能是欣赏、尊重或认可。如果你是因为工作压力太大，无法获得片刻休息或平静才来读这本书……那么，现在你应该明白自己需要什么了。

TIP TWO: SEPARATE YOURSELF FROM WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK OR BELIEVE YOU SHOULD NEED. It’s easy to get caught up in what other people have told us we need or what we think we should need based on what others have. If you’re stuck because you’re thinking about someone else and what they think you need, go ahead and address that. Make a list of everything that person thinks you should need—then literally put it aside. Having it written out in front of you will help you separate what you need versus what you’ve been told you should need.

建议二：不要受他人认为你应该需要的东西的影响。我们很容易被别人告诉我们需要什么，或者根据别人拥有的东西而认为自己应该需要什么所左右。如果你因为想着别人以及他们认为你需要什么而感到困惑，那就直接解决这个问题。把那个人认为你应该需要的所有东西都列出来——然后把它放在一边。把这些写下来放在你面前，可以帮助你区分你真正需要的和别人告诉你应该需要的。

How Do I Think about My Needs If I’m Negotiating on Behalf of Someone, or an Organization?

如果我代表某人或某个组织进行谈判，我应该如何考虑我的需求？

“What do I need?” can be used for companies or institutions, as well as people. Once we’ve done our initial brainstorming on needs, I like to get deeper by helping you break out your needs according to the different roles or identities you bring to the table—or what I call “hats.”

“我需要什么？”这个问题既可以用于公司或机构，也可以用于个人。在初步的需求头脑风暴之后，我喜欢更深入地探讨，帮助你根据你所扮演的不同角色或身份——或者我称之为“角色分工”——来细化你的需求。

How do we make sure we have accounted for all our different “hats” or roles? Think about your (1) responsibilities; (2) identities; and (3) roles, formal or informal. For example, Keisha, a teacher and the mother of a girl with autism, is negotiating with a school district over her daughter Imani’s IEP (an educational plan for children with disabilities). When she sits at the table, she’s thinking about her needs as (1) a parent to Imani, who can’t articulate her own needs; (2) a leader of the local special education parent-teacher organization, who works on behalf of all children in the town; and (3) an educator who values the role and expertise of teachers. Recognizing all these needs helped Keisha decide both what she wanted to advocate for (a personal aide for Imani and daily therapies) and how she needed to frame her arguments to resonate for the teachers in the room.

我们如何确保自己考虑到了所有不同的“角色”？想想你的（1）责任；（2）身份；以及（3）角色，无论正式还是非正式。例如，凯莎是一位教师，也是一位自闭症女孩的母亲。她正在与学区就女儿伊玛尼的个别化教育计划（IEP，一份为残疾儿童制定的教育计划）进行协商。当她坐在谈判桌旁时，她会考虑自己的需求：（1）作为伊玛尼的母亲，伊玛尼无法表达自己的需求；（2）作为当地特殊教育家长教师组织的领导者，她代表着镇上所有孩子的利益；以及（3）作为一位重视教师角色和专业知识的教育工作者。认识到所有这些需求，帮助凯莎决定了她想要争取的权益（为伊玛尼配备一名私人助理和日常治疗），以及她需要如何组织自己的论点才能引起在场教师的共鸣。

Likewise, if you are acting on behalf of an organization, you will have institutional needs as well as personal needs, as Lilia did in the story that began this chapter.

同样地，如果你代表某个组织行事，你就会像本章开头故事中的莉莉娅一样，既有机构的需求，也有个人的需求。

In summary, when we parse out all the identities that people bring to the table when they negotiate, it serves several purposes: first, it allows us to expand our list of needs so we can achieve the fullest possible picture of what we need from a negotiation. Second, it helps us identify the different roles we occupy as we negotiate, some that may not have even occurred to us. Last, it may help us pinpoint interests that appear to conflict—and I find that internally conflicting needs are a main cause of conflict and stagnation.

总而言之，当我们梳理谈判者在谈判中展现的各种身份时，它能带来以下几个好处：首先，它能帮助我们扩展需求清单，从而更全面地了解我们真正需要从谈判中获得什么。其次，它能帮助我们识别谈判过程中扮演的不同角色，其中一些角色我们可能之前从未想到过。最后，它或许能帮助我们找出看似冲突的利益——而我发现，内部冲突的需求是冲突和停滞的主要原因。

What If Some of My Needs Appear to Conflict?

如果我的一些需求看似相互冲突怎么办？

As you uncover your needs, you may find that some of them appear to conflict. For example, if you are considering changing jobs from a large, established company to a start-up, you might simultaneously need the professional growth that comes from bringing a new product to market and the need to maintain financial stability for your family. This is a great discovery! It might give you a clue as to why you’ve been unable to take steps toward the job decision. Write both needs down. Once we know that you have possibly conflicting needs—and many of us do—then we can figure out whether they actually conflict, or whether there’s a mutually satisfying path forward. Hint: there usually is.

当你逐渐了解自身需求时，你可能会发现其中一些需求看似相互冲突。例如，如果你正考虑从一家大型成熟公司跳槽到一家初创公司，你可能既需要通过推出新产品获得职业发展，又需要维持家庭的经济稳定。这是一个重要的发现！它或许能让你明白为什么自己迟迟无法做出职业决定。把这两种需求都写下来。一旦我们意识到你可能存在相互冲突的需求——而我们很多人都有这样的需求——我们就可以分析它们是否真的冲突，或者是否存在双方都能接受的解决方案。提示：通常情况下，答案是肯定的。

If you have opened this book because you feel a sense of personal or professional stagnation, look through your list of needs and ask yourself whether any of them appear to clash. If so, this can give rise to a sense of internal conflict that can result in (1) a stalled out feeling, and (2) conflicting feelings or behaviors. One way to tackle this is to look at the needs you think conflict and concretize them to see if that’s really the case.

如果你因为感到个人或职业发展停滞不前而翻开这本书，请审视一下你的需求清单，问问自己其中是否存在相互冲突的需求。如果存在冲突，就可能引发内心的矛盾，进而导致（1）停滞不前的感觉，以及（2）矛盾的感受或行为。解决这个问题的一个方法是，仔细审视你认为相互冲突的需求，并将它们具体化，看看是否真的如此。

Breaking out our needs into our roles, identities, or “hats” can also illuminate conflicts. Think back to Brett, who is considering going back to work after some time at home with her boys but has found herself torn about which direction to take. She feels as though she’s at odds with herself. When we talked about her “hats” and her needs, she broke it down as follows:

将我们的需求分解成不同的角色、身份或“角色”，也能帮助我们更好地理解冲突。想想布雷特，她在家陪伴儿子们一段时间后，正考虑重返职场，但她发现自己不知该何去何从。她感觉自己内心很矛盾。当我们讨论她的“角色”和需求时，她将其分解如下：

PARENT

父母

SPOUSE

配偶

FOR MYSELF

就我个人而言

Connection with my boys

与我的男孩们的联系

Financial balance with my husband

与丈夫的财务平衡

Connection with others

与他人建立联系

Help son with reading

帮儿子读书

Making house run smoothly

让家务顺利进行

Financial contribution

财务贡献

Invest in their development

投资于他们的发展

Peace in home

家中的平静

Sense of progress

进步感

Be there when they are little

在他们年幼的时候陪伴他们。

Connection with husband

与丈夫的关系

Adventure

冒险

After we laid it out this way, Brett took a look at her needs and said, “I’m concerned that my need for connection with my boys may conflict with my desire for travel and adventure.” We then took a look at each of these interests to see what they might look like in practice.

这样梳理之后，布雷特审视了自己的需求，说道：“我担心我对儿子们的感情需求可能会与我对旅行和冒险的渴望相冲突。” 然后，我们逐一分析了她的这些兴趣，看看它们在实践中会是什么样子。

When Brett asked herself what “connection with my boys” looked like, she discovered that for her it was:

当布雷特问自己“与儿子们的联系”是什么样子时，她发现对她而言，那是：

  • Having dedicated time that is devoted to each of them
    为他们每个人专门安排了时间
  • Saturday-morning snuggles before sports and activities
    周六早晨，在运动和活动之前，依偎在一起。
  • Family dinner twice a week with no screens
    每周两次家庭聚餐，全程不使用电子屏幕。

When we addressed her desire for “travel and adventure,” she defined this as:

当我们谈到她对“旅行和冒险”的渴望时，她这样定义：

  • A trip once a year that is “just for her,” without family
    每年一次“只属于她”的旅行，不带家人。
  • Hosting a workshop in another city that she runs for other women who also value travel and community
    她还在另一个城市举办工作坊，面向其他同样重视旅行和社群的女性。
  • Taking a French class
    上法语课
  • Doing something that takes her out of her comfort zone
    做一些让她走出舒适区的事情

When we look at these two lists, do these two interests actually conflict? Or are there ways for Brett to achieve both? When Brett and I looked at this list, we immediately saw that there were many ways in which she could satisfy both of these very important interests, at least most of the time. For example, she could take a weekly class and also find time to have a screen-free family dinner twice a week. She could cuddle with her boys, have date nights with her spouse, and also plan a personal trip or retreat that would fulfill her. Sometimes we might find ourselves with a hard conflict between interests—for example, a need for a new, updated kitchen might collide with a need to build up one’s savings and emergency fund—but very often if we drill down and examine what our needs actually look like in practice, we find there’s a way to achieve both of them.

当我们审视这两份清单时，这两个兴趣真的会冲突吗？或者布雷特能否找到兼顾两者的方法？我和布雷特一起查看这份清单后，立刻发现她有很多方法可以满足这两个非常重要的兴趣，至少大部分时间可以做到。例如，她可以每周上一节课，同时还能抽出时间每周两次与家人共进无电子屏幕的晚餐。她可以和儿子们依偎在一起，和伴侣享受浪漫的约会之夜，还可以计划一次让她感到充实的个人旅行或静修。有时，我们可能会发现自己的兴趣之间存在着难以调和的冲突——例如，想要一个崭新的厨房可能与积累储蓄和应急基金的需求相冲突——但很多时候，如果我们深入分析并审视这些需求在实践中的实际体现，就会发现总有办法能够兼顾两者。

(And get ready, you’re going to do this exercise of harmonizing needs all over again once you ask someone else about theirs, in the Window section.)

（做好准备，在“窗口”部分询问他人需求后，你还需要再次进行需求协调练习。）

A Final Note on Needs: Like Humans, They Evolve

关于需求的最后一点说明：它们和人类一样，会不断进化。

As Anaïs Nin tells us, “Life is a process of becoming.” Needs, like the people who own them, are never static: they are always shifting and changing. As we change, our identities and roles change, too. So our needs as sons, women, managers, doctors, and coaches will all evolve as we do.

正如阿娜伊斯·宁所说，“生命是一个不断成长的过程。”需求，如同拥有需求的人一样，并非一成不变：它们总是在不断变化。随着我们的改变，我们的身份和角色也会随之改变。因此，作为儿子、女人、管理者、医生和教练，我们的需求也会随着我们的成长而不断演变。

My needs as a faculty member are different now than they were when I started at Columbia twelve years ago. Walden’s needs as his company’s CEO will be different at the beginning, when he’s refining his product and seeking seed money, than when his company is doing its third round of financing and expanding nationwide. Brett’s needs as a parent, as a spouse, and as a person will change as she evolves and her children grow and develop.

我现在作为一名教员的需求，与十二年前刚到哥伦比亚大学时截然不同。沃尔登作为公司首席执行官的需求，在公司初期——他需要完善产品并寻求种子资金——与公司进行第三轮融资并拓展全国业务时的需求也会有所不同。布雷特作为母亲、妻子和个人的需求，也会随着她自身的成长和孩子们的成长而改变。

So if you have an ongoing issue that requires multiple negotiations, your needs may evolve during that time, too. If you’re meeting with the other person more than once, meet with yourself, then, too.

因此，如果你遇到需要多次协商的长期问题，你的需求也可能会在此期间发生变化。如果你要与对方多次会面，那么每次也别忘了与自己进行一次对话。

Wrap-Up… and One Final Question

总结……以及最后一个问题

Here is one more quick exercise for you. I want you to take a moment now to admit to what you haven’t yet acknowledged.

这里还有一个小练习。请你花点时间承认一下你还没有意识到的事情。

What does that mean? Sometimes the greatest needs we have are the ones we hide even from ourselves. We self-censor without even knowing it. So I want you to finish this chapter by pausing and asking yourself this question: What is the worst, least flattering thing (or things) I could possibly need in this situation?

那是什么意思呢？有时候，我们最大的需求反而是我们连自己都不愿承认的。我们会在不知不觉中进行自我审查。所以，我希望你在读完本章后停下来，问问自己这个问题：在这种情况下，我最需要的、最不讨喜的东西是什么？

When I asked Brett this question, after having heard her more “socially acceptable” needs to take care of her family and nourish her relationship with her husband, she paused, took a breath, and then unearthed some of her “secret” needs. Eventually, she admitted that she needs a feeling of achievement beyond the home. “I know I shouldn’t be focused on this so much… I’m a mom, right? My kids are the most important, of course. But I really miss feeling that I’m achieving something in the larger world.”

当我问布雷特这个问题时，在听完她那些更“符合社会规范”的需求——照顾家庭、维系与丈夫的关系——之后，她停顿了一下，深吸一口气，然后吐露了一些她“隐秘的”需求。最终，她承认自己需要一种超越家庭的成就感。“我知道我不应该这么执着于此……我是个妈妈，对吧？我的孩子当然是最重要的。但我真的很想体验在更广阔的世界里有所作为的感觉。”

This exercise in listing our “worst” possible needs is important for everyone. We often censor what we need. We think it’s not nice or appropriate to need a sense of achievement, attractiveness… or money. What is so wrong about these needs? Why does this feel hard to admit? When we ignore these needs, we end up denying a piece of who we are, limiting what we achieve in negotiation—and stifling who we could become.

列出我们“最糟糕的”需求对每个人都很重要。我们常常会压抑自己的需求。我们认为需要成就感、外貌吸引力……或者金钱是不体面或不合适的。这些需求到底错在哪里？为什么承认这些需求如此困难？当我们忽视这些需求时，最终会否定我们自身的一部分，限制我们在谈判中取得的成果，并扼杀我们成为理想自我的可能性。

Now that you’ve answered this question, tried on all your “hats,” listed your tangibles and intangibles, and followed up to go deep and get concrete, we’re going to wrap up by summarizing your needs. Review everything you’ve written and jot down a one-paragraph summary. Take note of any words or themes that keep coming up for you. You’ll use this summary as you move forward.

既然你已经回答了这个问题，尝试了各种不同的角色，列出了有形和无形的需求，并且深入思考、具体化了需求，那么接下来我们将总结你的需求。回顾你写下的所有内容，并简要概括一段话。记下反复出现的关键词或主题。在接下来的工作中，你会用到这份总结。

#↩

THREE WHAT DO I FEEL?

三、我的感受是什么？

Cara was a busy senior executive at a major international consumer products company, who was known for her dry sense of humor and no-nonsense personality. There for eighteen years, since she graduated college, she had advanced steadily up the ranks by selling household cleaners and personal care products to major drugstore chains and other stores.

卡拉是一家大型国际消费品公司的资深主管，工作繁忙，以其冷幽默和务实的性格而闻名。自大学毕业后，她在该公司工作了十八年，通过向大型连锁药店和其他商店销售家用清洁剂和个人护理产品，稳步晋升。

The job was fast-paced and stressful at times. But during Cara’s entire tenure at the company, even her closest colleagues and friends had never seen her get upset or shed a tear. She was often heard to say, “I don’t get upset. I don’t have time to get upset.” In her yearly reviews, the main constructive criticism she received was to “slow down.” As she grew in seniority at work, she married and saved rigorously, living on much less than her salary and taking very little financial risk in order to buy her dream home, with plenty of savings to spare. When it came time for her to purchase a home, she showed me the impressive Excel spreadsheet she had built of all her desired features and that analyzed which homes met which criteria. “I make a spreadsheet for everything,” she said. She chose the home with the most check marks on the sheet.

这份工作节奏快，有时压力也很大。但在卡拉在公司工作的整个期间，即使是她最亲密的同事和朋友也从未见过她生气或流泪。她经常说：“我不会生气。我没时间生气。”在她每年的绩效考核中，她收到的主要建设性批评是“放慢速度”。随着她在工作中资历的增长，她结婚了，并严格储蓄，生活水平远低于她的工资，并且尽量避免承担任何财务风险，最终买到了梦想中的房子，而且还剩下不少积蓄。到了买房的时候，她给我看了她精心制作的Excel表格，上面列出了她想要的所有房屋特征，并分析了哪些房子符合哪些条件。“我什么事都做表格，”她说。她最终选择了表格上勾选最多的房子。

Eventually Cara went on to have two boys. After they were born, she grew passionate about healthy living, and pursued a nutrition certification. As she turned her attention to feeding her family healthy meals, she also started thinking more about what kinds of household products she wanted to use with them, and started investigating more natural options. She compared the products she used at home to the products she was selling at work and saw a disconnect. She started to think it might be time to make a move.

最终，卡拉生了两个儿子。儿子出生后，她对健康生活产生了浓厚的兴趣，并考取了营养师资格证书。在致力于为家人烹制健康膳食的同时，她也开始思考应该使用哪些家用产品，并开始寻找更天然的选择。她将自己在家使用的产品与在工作中销售的产品进行比较，发现两者之间存在差异。她开始考虑或许是时候做出改变了。

For the last year, Cara had been looking at start-up companies in the natural cleaning products space, waiting for the right opportunity to present itself. Lots of companies were interested in hiring her. She consulted with me as a negotiation coach throughout her search—assessing market power, deal terms, and leadership team profiles for each potential company in an expansive Excel spreadsheet—only to reject each offer and move on. Finally, one offer came along that had some advantages over the others. The company was in the right market and stage of development, with the right title, but the financial package would represent a pay cut from her salary at the stable giant in her field. She went back and forth for several weeks, negotiating terms and debating whether to move. Finally, she reached a decision point: she had gotten as much as she could from the job negotiations, both in terms of money and information about the company’s future prospects, and now she needed to make a decision. But she felt paralyzed. “I’ve analyzed everything I possibly can,” she told me. “But for some reason I can’t bring myself to decide one way or the other.” The start-up told her she had one more week to let them know whether she was taking the job.

过去一年，卡拉一直在关注天然清洁产品领域的初创公司，等待合适的时机。很多公司都对她感兴趣。在整个求职过程中，她都咨询我的谈判指导——我用一份详尽的Excel表格评估每家潜在公司的市场实力、合同条款和领导团队情况——但最终都拒绝了，继续寻找下一个目标。最终，她收到了一份看似比其他公司更有优势的offer。这家公司处于合适的市场和发展阶段，职位名称也合适，但薪酬待遇却比她在业内那家稳定巨头公司的收入要低。她来回折腾了好几个星期，协商条款，权衡是否要跳槽。最终，她面临一个抉择：她已经从求职谈判中获得了尽可能多的信息，包括薪资和公司的未来发展前景，现在她必须做出决定。但她却感到不知所措。“我已经把所有能分析的都分析完了，”她告诉我。 “但不知为何，我始终无法做出决定。”这家创业公司告诉她，她还有一周时间考虑是否接受这份工作。

It was at this point that Cara mentioned in passing, during one of our consulting calls, that she hadn’t been able to get out of bed that morning. In fact, she’d needed to put her gym membership on hold; she’d been dealing with debilitating muscle pain for months, to the point of rendering her bedridden on several occasions. Her doctors had run every test they could think of, and all came up negative. And today, the pain prevented her from even making breakfast.

就在这时，卡拉在一次咨询电话中无意间提到，她那天早上根本起不了床。事实上，她不得不暂停健身房会员资格；几个月来，她一直饱受剧烈肌肉疼痛的折磨，有好几次都卧床不起。她的医生做了所有能想到的检查，结果都呈阴性。而今天，疼痛让她连早餐都做不了。

This was my opening. I took a breath and asked, “What are you feeling about this decision?” My no-nonsense client, who had run every comparative metric possible without once mentioning what I jokingly call “the F-word,” finally opened up and allowed herself to contemplate the feelings she was experiencing over this decision. She had known that moving to a start-up would involve a pay cut, and she had prepared for years in order to manage the hit to their finances. But she hadn’t anticipated how much anxiety she would feel about leaving the sure bet that had seen her through the last eighteen years, in exchange for a financial risk that could affect her family in the short term—though with hopes for a longer-term payout. She also couldn’t ignore the intense feeling of guilt that, at her current job, she wasn’t selling products she would use with her own kids. She told me that recently the company had developed a product she really didn’t believe in, and nonetheless, she had to get on the phone with potential buyers and sell it. She would hang up nauseated after every call.

这是我的开场白。我深吸一口气，问道：“你对这个决定有什么感受？”我这位务实的客户，之前已经把所有可能的比较指标都算了一遍，却始终没有提及我戏称为“那个F开头的词”——风险。最终，她敞开心扉，开始思考自己对这个决定的感受。她知道加入创业公司意味着降薪，也为此准备了多年，以应对经济上的冲击。但她没想到，离开过去十八年来让她安稳度日的稳定工作，去承担短期内可能影响家庭的经济风险——尽管她也希望从长远来看能获得回报——会让她如此焦虑。此外，她也无法忽视内心深处的愧疚感：在目前的工作中，她销售的产品并非自己会和孩子一起使用的。她告诉我，公司最近开发了一款她并不看好的产品，但她仍然不得不打电话给潜在客户推销。每次通话结束后，她都会感到恶心而挂断电话。

Writing these feelings down in her spreadsheet was clarifying for her. She examined her monetary anxiety against the numbers: she was able to remind herself that she was amply prepared for the short-term salary reduction and that through her research about the start-up, she had amassed solid evidence that she would end up making more money once it was acquired. She realized that this financial anxiety was natural but would likely be temporary. The anticipation of the hit might even be worse than the reality of it.

把这些感受写进电子表格让她思路清晰起来。她用数字分析了自己的经济焦虑：她提醒自己，她已经为短期减薪做好了充分准备，而且通过对这家初创公司的研究，她已经积累了确凿的证据，证明一旦公司被收购，她的收入最终会更高。她意识到，这种经济焦虑是人之常情，但很可能只是暂时的。对冲击的预期甚至可能比实际冲击更可怕。

Then she came to her guilt about the products she was currently selling. She knew that this guilt, unlike the financial anxiety, was likely to persist until she worked for a company that was more in line with her values. She realized that, in fact, this guilt had been growing within her for years. She couldn’t continue to sell products to families that she didn’t feel good about using with her own kids.

然后，她意识到自己对目前销售的产品感到内疚。她知道，这种内疚感，与经济上的焦虑不同，很可能会一直持续下去，直到她找到一家更符合自己价值观的公司。她意识到，事实上，这种内疚感已经在她心中滋生多年。她无法继续向那些她自己都不愿意让孩子使用的产品销售给其他家庭。

This executive, who prepared meticulously for this job negotiation and analyzed all the pieces of hard data available to her, hadn’t even realized she first needed to negotiate with herself over the feelings she was experiencing about the decision. Armed with this additional information about her feelings, she made the call: she took the job. The pain cleared up almost immediately. One year later, she was beating even the optimistic sales benchmarks her new company had set for her. She told me that she attributed this success in large part to her happiness at work. Her belief in the products led her to sell with a level of enthusiasm and energy she hadn’t experienced in years.

这位高管为这次工作谈判做了周密的准备，分析了所有可获得的确凿数据，却忽略了自己首先需要面对的内心感受。有了这些关于自身感受的信息，她最终做出了决定：她接受了这份工作。痛苦几乎立刻消散了。一年后，她的销售业绩甚至超过了新公司为她设定的乐观目标。她告诉我，她将这份成功很大程度上归功于工作中的快乐。她对产品的信心让她以多年未见的激情和活力投入销售。

“Feelings Are Facts”

“感觉即事实”

When I first studied negotiation, my mentor, Carol Liebman, taught me that feelings are facts. She did not mean to say that feelings are as objective a reality as time, weight or temperature, but rather that they are real, they exist, and they must be dealt with in any negotiation. Feelings shape our perception of reality and our decision-making at every turn.

我初学谈判时，我的导师卡罗尔·利布曼告诉我，感受也是事实。她并非指感受像时间、重量或温度一样客观存在，而是指感受是真实存在的，在任何谈判中都必须加以考虑。感受无时无刻不在影响着我们对现实的感知和决策。

We can’t prevent ourselves from experiencing feelings in negotiation. I once read an article that astutely compared human emotion to a volcano. Volcanoes are generative: they create islands that eventually bear plant and animal life. But they can also be destructive. Lava flow can destroy property and life itself. As with volcanoes, you can’t stop human emotions from erupting. But with preparation, you can direct the lava flow into the sea instead of the village, thereby maximizing the benefit and minimizing any damage.

在谈判中，我们无法控制自己的情绪。我曾读过一篇文章，它巧妙地将人类的情感比作火山。火山具有创造力：它们会形成岛屿，最终孕育动植物。但它们也具有破坏性。熔岩流会摧毁财产，甚至危及生命。正如火山一样，你无法阻止人类情感的爆发。但通过准备，你可以引导熔岩流流入大海而不是村庄，从而最大限度地发挥其作用，并将损失降到最低。

We often try to bury our feelings or deny that they exist, but I have always found (and research supports) that this practice tends to be more destructive than helpful, and that it can be more productive to face them. When we hold a Mirror to our feelings, two things happen: first, we clear away the fog or confusion that surrounds a conflict or important decision, leaving us feeling more organized and empowered; and second, we find information that helps us solve our issue.

我们常常试图压抑自己的感受，或者否认它们的存在，但我一直认为（研究也支持这一点），这种做法往往弊大于利，而直面它们反而更有成效。当我们正视自己的感受时，会发生两件事：首先，我们会拨开笼罩在冲突或重要决定上的迷雾和困惑，从而感到更有条理、更有力量；其次，我们会找到有助于解决问题的信息。

In this chapter, I will help you identify any feelings you are experiencing about your negotiation. Along the way, we’ll talk about why feelings are central to negotiation, and how identifying them can help you negotiate more effectively. I will help you listen to your internal voice non-judgmentally so that you can write down your actual feelings, not the ones your mother thinks you should be feeling. Together, we’ll follow up on your initial thoughts to make sure you’ve considered everything you might be feeling. And I will give you strategies for how to handle your feelings once you enter the Window phase and are talking face-to-face with someone else.

在本章中，我将帮助你识别你在谈判过程中产生的各种感受。我们会探讨感受在谈判中的重要性，以及识别感受如何帮助你更有效地进行谈判。我会帮助你以不带评判的眼光倾听内心的声音，从而记录下你真实的感受，而不是你母亲认为你应该有的感受。我们会一起回顾你最初的想法，确保你已经考虑到了所有可能的感受。我还会为你提供一些策略，帮助你在进入“窗口期”并与对方面对面交谈时，更好地应对自己的感受。

First, as always, the preparation starts at home, with you.

首先，和往常一样，准备工作要从家里开始，从你开始。

Your Turn in the Mirror

轮到你照镜子了

Now it’s your turn to look in the Mirror. Remember, you’ve already identified what’s brought you here, as well as your needs. You have a sense of the problem you want to solve and what you need from the situation. Now you’re going to get into your feelings. As you did in the other chapters, I want you to get into a physical space where you can think freely. For the next five minutes, think about and write down your answer to the question What do I feel?

现在轮到你照镜子了。记住，你已经明确了是什么把你带到这里，以及你的需求。你对想要解决的问题以及你希望从这种情况中获得什么有了大致的了解。现在，你要深入感受一下自己的情绪。就像你在其他章节中做的那样，我希望你找一个可以自由思考的空间。在接下来的五分钟里，思考并写下你对“我感觉如何？”这个问题的答案。

Dealing with the “F-Word” in Negotiation

谈判中如何应对“F”开头的那个词
