In this chapter, we will talk about feelings, or what I sometimes call “the other F-word,” in negotiation. Sometimes people are caught off-guard to talk about feelings while they’re on the job, or even in their personal negotiation.

本章我们将探讨谈判中的感受，或者我有时称之为“另一个F开头的词”。有时人们在工作中，甚至在个人谈判中，会措手不及地谈及感受。

This hesitation makes sense. For years, the conventional wisdom about feelings in negotiation was that feelings—whether positive or negative—are unproductive. We should just try not to have them, or if we do, we should stuff them down and negotiate on the facts.

这种犹豫不决是有道理的。多年来，关于谈判中感受的传统观点是，感受——无论是积极的还是消极的——都无益于谈判。我们应该尽量避免产生感受，或者如果产生了感受，就应该压抑住它们，只基于事实进行谈判。

But grappling with your feelings is the key to success in any negotiation. What makes feelings so essential? Two important factors:

但控制好自己的情绪是任何谈判成功的关键。为什么情绪如此重要？主要有两个因素：

  1. 1. FEELINGS ARE ALWAYS PRESENT IN NEGOTIATION

    Remember that any conversation in which you’re steering a relationship is a negotiation. You are constantly negotiating as you manage your relationships with colleagues, clients, managers, your spouse or partner, children, and the person who rear-ended your car on the road last week. A relationship is a moment (or longer) of connection between you and another human being or group. As a human being, you can also have a relationship with yourself.

    Any relationship or connection that involves humans, no matter how businesslike or brief, involves feelings. We’re used to thinking about feelings insofar as they affect our so-called personal lives, like in the context of our family relationships, but we often fail to appreciate that feelings are present in all negotiations. (If at some point we’re all replaced by computers, this may be a different story.) It doesn’t matter what kind of issue you’re facing, whether you are at the table negotiating on behalf of someone else or an institution, or whether you’re normally what one might call an “emotional person.” If your negotiation involves people (i.e. you), it’s personal, and feelings will be part of it.

    If feelings are always there, doesn’t it make sense to acknowledge and work with them?


    1. 情感始终存在于谈判之中 请记住，任何你试图掌控关系走向的对话都是一场谈判。当你与同事、客户、经理、配偶或伴侣、孩子，甚至上周在路上追尾你的人相处时，你都在不断地进行谈判。关系是你与另一个人或群体之间短暂（或更长时间）的联结。作为一个人，你也可以与自己建立关系。任何涉及人的关系或联结，无论多么公事公办或短暂，都包含情感。我们习惯于从情感对我们所谓的个人生活（例如家庭关系）的影响角度来思考情感，但我们常常忽略了情感在所有谈判中都扮演着重要角色。 （如果将来我们都被电脑取代，情况可能就不同了。）无论你面临的是什么问题，无论你是代表他人还是机构进行谈判，也无论你平时是否被认为是一个“感性的人”，只要你的谈判涉及人（也就是你自己），它就是私人的，而情感必然是其中的一部分。既然情感总是存在的，那么承认并利用它们难道不是理所当然的吗？
  2. 2. FEELINGS DIRECTLY IMPACT OUR DECISION-MAKING AND OTHER ABILITIES IN NEGOTIATION

    Feelings are important in negotiation because our feelings help us make decisions, big and small. Neuroscientist Antonio Damasio studied a number of patients whose right side of the brain (which controls emotions) was impaired, but who otherwise were cognitively intact, and found that they were unable to make decisions. They could talk through what they logically thought they should do, but couldn’t even decide what to eat for dinner. Without the ability to make decisions, we would be lost in negotiation.

    Emotions also affect innovation and creativity: psychology research has found that positive emotions, like compassion or gratitude, can enhance our ability to judge circumstances accurately, come up with creative solutions, and innovate—all of which are important for negotiation. Negative emotions, especially fear and anxiety (we’ll talk about each of these later in this chapter), can inhibit these abilities. Acknowledging our feelings and treating them like any other kind of data to consider in negotiation can help us make the most of this connection between emotion and action.


    2. 情绪直接影响我们的决策能力和其他谈判能力 情绪在谈判中至关重要，因为情绪有助于我们做出各种大小的决策。神经科学家安东尼奥·达马西奥研究了一些右脑（控制情绪）受损但认知功能正常的患者，发现他们无法做出决定。他们可以清晰地阐述自己逻辑上认为应该做什么，但甚至连晚饭吃什么都决定不了。如果没有决策能力，我们在谈判中就会束手无策。情绪还会影响创新和创造力：心理学研究发现，积极的情绪，例如同情或感恩，可以增强我们准确判断形势、提出创造性解决方案和进行创新的能力——所有这些对谈判都至关重要。消极的情绪，尤其是恐惧和焦虑（我们将在本章后面讨论这些情绪），会抑制这些能力。承认我们的感受，并像对待其他类型的数据一样对待它们，可以帮助我们在谈判中充分利用情感与行动之间的这种联系。

The Importance of Feelings in Professional Negotiations

专业谈判中情感的重要性

People sometimes express doubt that so-called professional negotiations—negotiations you do at work or maybe on behalf of an organization, like a company or a government—can involve feelings. But if you want to be a dealmaker in business, diplomacy, or any other field, you will need to understand and deal with feelings. Andra Shapiro, an executive vice president and general counsel for Cable Entertainment at NBCUniversal, negotiates deals in order to bring the very best programming to people all around the world. One of her most common negotiations involves making deals with people like writers and producers who create original content on any number of networks and platforms, to purchase or license their work.

人们有时会质疑，所谓的职业谈判——比如在工作中或代表公司、政府等组织进行的谈判——是否真的会涉及情感因素。但如果你想在商业、外交或其他任何领域成为一名优秀的交易撮合者，你就必须理解并处理情感问题。安德拉·夏皮罗是NBC环球有线娱乐部门的执行副总裁兼总法律顾问，她的工作就是通过谈判达成交易，为世界各地的观众带来最优质的节目。她最常见的谈判之一，就是与那些在众多电视网和平台上创作原创内容的编剧和制片人达成协议，购买或授权他们的作品。

Andra says that you’d think their negotiations only deal with money, and it’s true that economics are present in virtually every deal, but you’d be surprised at how often emotions are at the center of the negotiations, especially with content creators. “When we negotiate with someone over the things they’ve created, it’s as though they are handing over their baby to you,” she observes. “It’s extremely emotional and you have to respect that, understand that, or you will not do successful deals in this space.”

安德拉说，你可能会认为他们的谈判只涉及金钱，的确，经济因素几乎存在于每一笔交易中，但你或许会惊讶于情感在谈判中占据核心地位的程度，尤其是在与内容创作者谈判时。“当我们与别人就他们创作的作品进行谈判时，就好像他们把自己的孩子交给了你，”她观察到。“这其中蕴含着极大的情感，你必须尊重并理解这一点，否则你在这个领域就无法达成成功的交易。”

Likewise, when business deals go bad, a surprising percentage of those disputes arise because of unexamined feelings. One lawyer with mediation training told me about an experience he had as a partner at a major firm. His client, a large U.S. player in the health-care industry, was acquired by an even larger foreign giant. The acquisition process went smoothly until the two CEOs went to the closing dinner. There, they had an enormous fight fueled by cultural differences, wine, and insecurity over their future roles within the combined organization—which resulted in the American CEO calling his lawyer late at night on a Friday to say, “I want you to draft an arbitration complaint immediately. We’re going to sue the #@$% out of this $%@!”

同样，当商业交易失败时，相当一部分纠纷源于未经审视的情绪。一位接受过调解培训的律师向我讲述了他作为一家大型律师事务所合伙人的经历。他的客户是一家美国大型医疗保健企业，被一家规模更大的外国巨头收购。收购过程进展顺利，直到两家公司的首席执行官出席了最后的晚宴。晚宴上，他们爆发了一场激烈的争吵，起因是文化差异、酒精的作用以及对合并后公司未来角色的不安全感——最终，美国首席执行官在周五深夜打电话给他的律师，说道：“我要你立即起草一份仲裁诉状。我们要把这家公司告到倾家荡产！”

The lawyer listened to what his client had to say. But he also knew that the arbitration complaint would likely be both unsuccessful and expensive. So, remembering his mediation training and sensing the emotional issue at stake, he spent the weekend alternately drafting the complaint and talking to his client, asking him, “Okay, so tell me more about the dinner…” (Note: You’ll find that question in the Window section.) In the end, the lawyer helped his client get some emotional space and perspective on what happened at the closing dinner. The CEO ended up dropping his request for the arbitration complaint, instead refocusing his energy on making the combined company a success.

律师认真听取了客户的陈述。但他同时也明白，提起仲裁很可能既不成功又耗资巨大。于是，他想起自己接受过的调解培训，也意识到此事牵涉到客户的情绪，便利用周末时间，一边起草诉状，一边与客户交谈，反复询问：“好吧，那你再跟我说说晚宴的事吧……”（注：这个问题在“窗口”部分有详细介绍。）最终，律师帮助客户冷静下来，从更客观的角度看待那次告别晚宴。首席执行官最终放弃了仲裁请求，转而将精力集中在如何让合并后的公司取得成功上。

Looking in the Mirror: The Benefits of Considering Your Feelings

照镜子：关注自身感受的好处

The best way to prepare for and deal with feelings in negotiation is to identify your own. Thinking about your feelings helps you in several ways.

谈判中应对和处理情绪的最佳方法是认清自己的感受。思考自己的感受对你大有裨益。

First, it gives you important data you can use when you negotiate. Negotiation is not only driven by what we need or believe on a certain issue, but how strongly we feel about it. Knowing how you feel about an issue will help you understand how much you want to prioritize it in negotiation. Take a moment to look over your feelings and see what they tell you about how you should approach your Window conversation with the other person.

首先，它能为你提供谈判时可以使用的重要数据。谈判不仅取决于我们对某个问题的需求或信念，还取决于我们对该问题的感受强度。了解你对某个问题的感受，有助于你理解在谈判中该问题的优先级。花点时间审视一下你的感受，看看它们会告诉你，在与对方进行“窗口对话”时，应该如何进行。

Second, recognizing your feelings may help you to craft better solutions. One magic follow-up question can help you turn feelings into future-focused ideas. If you are feeling a negative emotion, I want you to ask yourself, “What would help eliminate or reduce my [ insert feeling ] in this situation?” For example, if you are a doctor going through this chapter and you discover that your overwhelming emotion is frustration about the way you are required to provide care to a certain patient population in your hospital, I want you to ask yourself, “What would help eliminate or reduce my frustration in this situation?” In this way, you can use your feelings to generate concrete ideas for how to move forward.

其次，觉察自己的感受有助于你找到更好的解决方案。一个神奇的后续问题就能帮助你将感受转化为面向未来的想法。如果你感到负面情绪，请问问自己：“在这种情况下，什么能帮助消除或减轻我的[此处填写感受]？” 例如，如果你是一名正在阅读本章的医生，发现自己最强烈的感受是对医院里为特定患者群体提供医疗服务的方式感到沮丧，请问问自己：“在这种情况下，什么能帮助消除或减轻我的沮丧？” 这样，你就可以利用自己的感受，产生切实可行的前进方向。

Last, acknowledging and expressing your feelings privately will help reduce the chance that you feel or express them in an uncontrollable way during the part of the negotiation where you sit down with another person. Research shows that if we stuff down our emotions, they may boomerang back at a moment or in a way that impedes our ability to make decisions, or clouds how we approach the decision. Again, you can’t keep that feelings volcano from erupting, but acknowledging your feelings and preparing yourself to handle them in a negotiation will help you harness their power and achieve great results.

最后，私下承认并表达自己的感受有助于降低在与对方谈判时情绪失控的可能性。研究表明，如果我们压抑自己的情绪，它们可能会在某个时刻以某种方式反弹回来，从而阻碍我们做出决策，或影响我们做出决定的方式。当然，你无法阻止情绪火山的爆发，但承认自己的感受并做好在谈判中应对它们的准备，将有助于你驾驭情绪的力量，并取得理想的结果。

Considering Your Feelings Brings Relief, and Results

顾及自身感受能带来慰藉和成效。

Stephen is a senior partner at a large U.S. law firm. As he has grown more established in his practice and closer to retirement, his firm has asked him to take on increased responsibility with recruiting new talent and mentoring them into partner positions. Eight years ago, he brought in a young real estate lawyer, Craig, who showed the promise of being a brilliant contributor to the firm. Stephen mentored Craig in a junior partner position, celebrating Craig’s strengths and also counseling him on areas to improve. What Stephen noticed, however, was that Craig, who was brilliant at generating new clients, sometimes moved too quickly and disregarded firm paperwork and protocol. One day, Stephen received a difficult call; his firm’s managing partner called him to say that Craig had brought in a new client with a real estate issue that required filing a lawsuit in court. Firm policy dictated that every complaint filed in court needed to include the name of, and be reviewed by, someone who was (1) a senior equity partner and (2) from the litigation department. Craig was not a litigator, nor was he a senior equity partner. He knew about this policy and yet he filed the complaint himself anyway.

斯蒂芬是美国一家大型律师事务所的高级合伙人。随着他业务的日益成熟以及退休临近，事务所要求他承担更多责任，包括招募新人才并指导他们晋升为合伙人。八年前，他招揽了一位年轻的房地产律师克雷格，克雷格展现出成为事务所杰出人才的潜力。斯蒂芬指导克雷格担任初级合伙人，赞扬他的优势，并就他需要改进的地方提出建议。然而，斯蒂芬注意到，克雷格虽然擅长开发新客户，但有时行事过于急躁，忽视了事务所的文书工作和规章制度。一天，斯蒂芬接到一个棘手的电话：事务所的管理合伙人告诉他，克雷格带来了一位新客户，该客户涉及房地产问题，需要提起诉讼。事务所规定，所有提交给法院的诉状都必须包含一位高级权益合伙人的姓名，并且必须由这两位人员审核。克雷格既不是诉讼律师，也不是高级权益合伙人。他明明知道这项政策，却还是亲自提起了诉讼。

Stephen reviewed the complaint. Craig’s work was very good. But had he consulted Stephen, or someone else in the litigation department, his work could have been slightly more comprehensive. And management was angry at what they saw as deliberate disregard of firm policy. Stephen pulled out the Mirror questions to start working through them. He knew what he needed: to ensure Craig followed firm policy from now on, while also keeping Craig at the firm and motivated to continue generating clients. Stephen also needed to preserve their good working relationship. Finally, as a litigator, Stephen felt a responsibility to make sure this client achieved a good result in court.

斯蒂芬审阅了投诉。克雷格的工作非常出色。但如果他咨询过斯蒂芬或诉讼部门的其他同事，他的工作本可以更加全面。管理层对克雷格的行为感到愤怒，认为他故意无视公司政策。斯蒂芬拿出《镜报》的问询，开始逐一分析。他知道自己需要做什么：既要确保克雷格今后遵守公司政策，又要留住克雷格，并激励他继续为公司拓展客户。斯蒂芬还需要维护他们良好的工作关系。最后，作为一名诉讼律师，斯蒂芬感到自己有责任确保这位客户在法庭上取得理想的结果。

When he got to “What do I feel?” things got interesting for Stephen. He listed a few emotions that felt relatively obvious:

当问到“我的感受是什么？”这个问题时，斯蒂芬的反应变得有趣起来。他列举了一些相对显而易见的感受：

  • Anxiety about the conversation
    对谈话感到焦虑
  • Fear of making things worse between Craig and management
    担心克雷格和管理层之间的关系会进一步恶化
  • Annoyance at Craig for not following the policy
    克雷格不遵守政策，令人恼火
  • Relief at the prospect of getting this sorted out
    看到这件事即将解决，我松了一口气。

But then, as he thought about it, he wrote down a couple more:

但后来，他仔细想了想，又写下了几个：

  • Empathy for Craig
    对克雷格的同情
  • Ambivalence about the policy
    对这项政策的矛盾态度

This surprised Stephen. Writing down his feelings made him realize two things. First, he realized that he could understand what happened here for Craig. Stephen, like Craig, was excellent at building relationships with new clients and solving their problems—fast. He could see himself in Craig, and deep down, he felt Craig’s intentions were to help, rather than to hurt the firm. He wrote all this down so he could include it when he spoke to Craig.

这让斯蒂芬感到惊讶。写下自己的感受后，他意识到两件事。首先，他意识到自己能理解克雷格在这里的遭遇。斯蒂芬和克雷格一样，非常擅长与新客户建立关系，并迅速解决他们的问题。他从克雷格身上看到了自己的影子，而且他内心深处觉得克雷格的本意是帮助公司，而不是损害公司。他把这一切都写下来，以便在和克雷格谈话时提及。

Second, Stephen discovered that he wasn’t sure the firm’s bright-line policy made sense. He realized that to fully solve the problem, he might need to pursue parallel tracks: one with Craig and one with management, to see whether they might build any flexibility into the policy, or be willing to brainstorm other ideas to help their junior partners.

其次，斯蒂芬发现公司一成不变的政策并不合理。他意识到，要彻底解决这个问题，他可能需要双管齐下：一条路跟克雷格走，另一条路跟管理层沟通，看看他们是否愿意在政策中加入一些灵活性，或者是否愿意集思广益，提出其他办法来帮助年轻合伙人。

Sometimes we fear that if we look in the Mirror to see our feelings, it might somehow make our situation worse. But far from hurting his negotiation, taking a few minutes to consider his feelings helped Stephen to connect with Craig, flesh out the actual problem(s) to be solved more fully, and craft some steps forward. If you work through this question the way Stephen did, you’ll likely find the same is true for you.

有时我们害怕，如果正视自己的感受，可能会让情况变得更糟。但斯蒂芬花几分钟思考自己的感受，非但没有影响谈判，反而帮助他与克雷格建立了联系，更全面地梳理了需要解决的实际问题，并制定了下一步行动方案。如果你像斯蒂芬那样思考这个问题，你很可能会发现，这对你同样适用。

Find the Fun

寻找乐趣

One final note about looking in the Mirror for feelings. Often, when prompted to consider their feelings in negotiation, people approach it with a bit of dread. It’s as though I’m asking, “What unpleasant things do you feel?” And they answer accordingly by writing down all the negative things that come to mind. So I want to follow up with a specific prompt: Have you written down positive feelings that come to mind? If not, do that now.

关于审视自身感受，最后一点需要说明。通常，当被要求在谈判中考虑自身感受时，人们会有些畏惧。就好像我在问：“你有什么不愉快的感觉？” 而他们往往会把所有想到的负面情绪都写下来。所以我想提出一个具体的问题：你有没有写下想到的积极感受？如果没有，现在就写下来。

I want to encourage you to get in touch with your positive feelings for every negotiation you encounter. Too often we allow our negative emotions to predominate over our negotiations, but underneath those feelings we also have some really positive feelings about the negotiations we encounter. Yes, you’re nervous about pitching a client or approaching a conversation with your partner. But couldn’t you also be excited to get this next phase of your career started? Might you be relieved at the prospect of getting off the mental hamster wheel of this conflict to clear the air with someone? I recently took a roomful of executives through this question. One participant, facing a major financial negotiation with an employee, wrote down “frustration that she is not realistic about the numbers,” and then “excited to push my skills as a negotiator.” “Finding the fun” (or joy, pride, excitement, or triumph) can help us consider the full picture of how we feel about our negotiation, and summon the energy to tackle it.

我想鼓励你，在每次谈判中，都要努力唤起自己积极的情绪。我们常常让负面情绪主导谈判，但其实在这些负面情绪之下，我们对谈判也抱有一些非常积极的感受。没错，你可能会因为要向客户推销方案或与伴侣交谈而感到紧张。但你难道不会也对开启职业生涯的下一个阶段感到兴奋吗？你难道不会因为终于可以摆脱这场冲突的困扰，与对方坦诚沟通而感到如释重负吗？我最近就这个问题，引导一群高管进行讨论。一位参与者在与员工进行重要的财务谈判时，写下了“她对数字不切实际的沮丧”，以及“很高兴能展现我的谈判技巧”。“找到乐趣”（或者喜悦、自豪、兴奋、胜利感）可以帮助我们全面了解自己对谈判的感受，并激发我们应对谈判的能量。

Following Up: Navigating Issues with Feelings

后续：如何处理情绪问题

We’ve established why it makes sense to consider feelings as part of any negotiation, and we’ve worked through the question itself. Next, we’ll troubleshoot any issues you might experience when thinking about your feelings. Let’s take a look at a few common speed bumps, and I’ll give you ways to overcome them.

我们已经阐明了在任何谈判中考虑感受的重要性，也探讨了这个问题本身。接下来，我们将解决你在考虑自身感受时可能遇到的任何问题。让我们来看看一些常见的障碍，我会告诉你如何克服它们。

  1. 1. “I CAN’T FEEL THINGS WHILE I’M WEARING A SUIT.”

    Are you asking yourself about your feelings in a place where you can be honest about the answers? The first time I ever previewed these questions at the United Nations, I was surprised by how many diplomats, male and female, teared up immediately upon my asking this question, and then had trouble allowing themselves to write anything down. One of them said, “I’m not used to asking myself about feelings while wearing a suit. What I feel at work is only what I want to allow myself to feel. The things I’m thinking about aren’t ‘suit feelings.’ ”

    I’ve come to understand that a lot of us really need to talk about our emotions, but don’t allow ourselves the opportunity. Instead, we try to shut off our feelings, especially in the workplace. It doesn’t matter whether you wear a suit, uniform, or the same pair of shorts every day to work. If you’re thinking about this question at work and are having trouble, try getting yourself to a place where you can explore your non-suit feelings.


    1.“穿西装的时候我感觉不到任何情绪。”你是否在一个可以坦诚面对自己感受的环境中审视过自己的情绪？我第一次在联合国预演这些问题时，惊讶地发现，很多外交官，无论男女，一听到这个问题就立刻热泪盈眶，然后难以开口写下任何想法。其中一位说：“我不习惯穿着西装思考自己的感受。我在工作中感受到的，只是我想让自己感受到的。我思考的并非‘西装带来的感受’。”我逐渐意识到，我们很多人都需要倾诉自己的情绪，但却往往不给自己这样的机会。相反，我们试图压抑自己的感受，尤其是在工作场所。无论你每天上班穿的是西装、制服，还是同一条短裤，都无关紧要。如果你在工作中思考这个问题并且遇到困难，试着让自己到一个可以探索你对西装不满意的感受的地方。
  2. 2. “I DON’T KNOW. I’M STUCK.”

    What if you’re stuck and can’t figure out what you feel at all? Perhaps you’ve asked yourself this question and now you’re drawing a blank.

    We have the ability to think about our emotions, but that doesn’t mean we always have an easy time identifying or expressing them. We are so used to suppressing our emotions—or on the flip side, feeling overwhelmed by them—that sometimes it can be difficult to identify with specificity what we are feeling. I’ve included several strategies here for identifying your emotions when you feel stuck.


    2. “我不知道。我卡住了。” 如果你感到困惑，完全搞不清楚自己的感受，该怎么办？也许你已经问过自己这个问题，但现在却一片空白。我们有能力思考自己的情绪，但这并不意味着我们总能轻易地识别或表达它们。我们太习惯于压抑自己的情绪——或者反过来，被情绪淹没——以至于有时很难准确地识别自己的感受。这里我列出了一些策略，可以帮助你在感到困惑时识别自己的情绪。

Common Human Emotions

人类的共同情感

If you’re stuck figuring out how you feel, take a look at the list below of the most common emotions. While human beings experience a broad range of feelings—a greater number than we can capture in this chapter—we also commonly experience some of the same emotions, especially in negotiation or conflict. Dr. Brené Brown and other psychology experts have worked on devising groups of core emotions that we can examine and use in our own lives. Below you will find a list of emotions that commonly arise in negotiations, some of which were identified by these experts, and some of which I have identified through my own experience coaching thousands of people through negotiations:

如果你难以分辨自己的感受，不妨看看下面列出的最常见情绪。虽然人类会体验到种类繁多的情感——远超本章所能涵盖的范围——但我们也常常会经历一些相同的情绪，尤其是在谈判或冲突中。布琳·布朗博士和其他心理学专家致力于研究核心情绪，我们可以审视这些情绪并将其运用到自己的生活中。以下列出了谈判中常见的几种情绪，其中一些是由这些专家提出的，另一些则是我通过指导数千人进行谈判的经验总结出来的：

  • Admiration
    钦佩
  • Anger
    愤怒
  • Anxiety
    焦虑
  • Appreciation
    欣赏
  • Belonging
    归属感
  • Betrayal
    背叛
  • Blame
    责备
  • Calm
    冷静的
  • Compassion
    同情
  • Confusion
    困惑
  • Contempt
    鄙视
  • Curiosity
    好奇心
  • Desire
    欲望
  • Disappointment
    失望
  • Disgust
    厌恶
  • Embarrassment
    尴尬
  • Empathy
    共情
  • Excitement
    激动
  • Fear
    害怕
  • Frustration
    挫折
  • Gratitude
    感激
  • Grief
    悲伤
  • Guilt
    有罪
  • Happiness
    幸福
  • Horror
    恐怖
  • Humiliation
    屈辱
  • Hurt
    伤害
  • Jealousy
    妒忌
  • Joy
    喜悦
  • Judgment
    判断
  • Loneliness
    孤独
  • Love
    爱
  • Pride
    自豪
  • Rage
    愤怒
  • Regret
    后悔
  • Rejection
    拒绝
  • Relief
    宽慰
  • Sadness
    悲伤
  • Satisfaction
    满意
  • Shame
    耻辱
  • Stress
    压力
  • Surprise
    惊喜
  • Sympathy
    同情
  • Triumph
    胜利
  • Vulnerability
    漏洞
  • Worry
    担心

Once you’ve reviewed this list, feel free to make any additions or adjustments you need to the one you generated earlier.

审阅完这份清单后，您可以根据需要对之前生成的清单进行任何补充或调整。

For Feelings, Go Back to Your Needs

对于感受，回归你的需求。

If you’re having trouble coming up with feelings, try going back to your needs. Often your needs and your feelings are flip sides of the same coin. Turn back to chapter 2 and look again at the intangible or tangible needs you discovered. Very often, what people are feeling conflicted about is the opposite of those needs. If you need a better compensation package from your job, you might be feeling insecure, undervalued, or even upset that you’re not getting what you feel you’re worth. If you need more appreciation in your relationship, you might be feeling sad, angry, or just plain unappreciated. If you feel a desperate need for forward progress on your client list, you may be feeling stuck or left behind.

如果你难以理清自己的感受，不妨回到你的需求上来。通常，你的需求和感受就像一枚硬币的两面。回到第二章，再次审视你发现的那些有形或无形的需求。很多时候，人们感到矛盾的根源恰恰与这些需求相反。如果你需要一份更好的薪酬待遇，你可能感到缺乏安全感、觉得自己被低估，甚至因为没有得到应有的回报而感到沮丧。如果你在感情关系中需要更多的认可，你可能感到悲伤、愤怒，或者只是单纯地不被重视。如果你迫切希望在客户名单上取得进展，你可能感到停滞不前或被落下。

Identifying “the Worst Feeling”: Combating Self-Censorship

识别“最糟糕的感觉”：对抗自我审查

Sometimes when I ask people what they are feeling, it turns out they are experiencing some feelings they are trying to hide, even from themselves. If you’re having trouble coming up with how you feel, ask yourself, “What’s the worst thing I could be feeling right now?” I love this follow-up question because a lot of the time we suppress our feelings to avoid shame or self-judgment. We don’t want to be feeling them. We wish they were something else. So we detach from those feelings. Except, stuffing them down or denying them doesn’t make them go away. Shining a light on our “worst” feelings (which I place in quotes because feelings are not bad or good, they just are ), even if they seem unattractive, reduces their effect on us and helps lighten our emotional load. Once we hold up a Mirror to some of these feelings, we’re in a much clearer place from which to move forward.

有时当我问别人他们的感受时，结果发现他们正在经历一些他们试图隐藏的情绪，甚至连自己都不愿面对。如果你难以描述自己的感受，不妨问问自己：“我现在最糟糕的感受是什么？”我喜欢这个后续问题，因为很多时候我们压抑自己的感受是为了避免羞耻或自我评判。我们不想感受这些感受，我们希望它们是别的什么。所以我们选择与这些感受脱离。然而，压抑或否认并不能让它们消失。正视我们“最糟糕的”感受（我之所以用引号，是因为感受本身无所谓好坏，它们只是存在），即使它们看起来并不讨喜，也能减轻它们对我们的影响，帮助我们减轻情绪负担。一旦我们正视这些感受，就能更清晰地找到前进的方向。

The Big Two Hidden Emotions

两大隐藏情绪

Speaking of our “worst” feelings, I want to share with you the two most common feelings people feel but don’t express when they are in conflict. I’ve seen these two emotions so many times I’ve lost count. We try to suppress them, but to no avail—they always come back up, like the monster at the very end of the action movie, causing havoc for the hero and heroine. What are they?

说到我们内心“最糟糕”的感受，我想和大家分享两种人们在冲突中最常见的感受，但往往不会表达出来。这两种情绪我见过太多次了，都数不清了。我们试图压抑它们，但徒劳无功——它们总是会卷土重来，就像动作电影结尾出现的怪物，给男女主角带来灾难。它们究竟是什么呢？

Guilt. And fear.

内疚。以及恐惧。

Guilt and fear are what I call the Big Two—the two emotions we avoid most, and the two emotions that blow up negotiations and relationships more than any other. I’m always reminded of the John F. Kennedy quote: “Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate.” When people seem difficult in a negotiation or relationship discussion, chances are they are feeling one of these emotions.

我把内疚和恐惧称为“两大情绪”——我们最想逃避的两种情绪，也是最容易破坏谈判和人际关系的两种情绪。我总是想起约翰·F·肯尼迪的那句名言：“我们绝不应因恐惧而谈判，但我们也绝不应害怕谈判。” 当人们在谈判或人际关系讨论中表现得难以相处时，他们很可能正感受到这两种情绪中的一种。

Last year I traveled around the United States to provide training for many of the regional offices of the Department of Education’s Office for Civil Rights. These offices handle lawsuits filed by parents against school districts over aspects of their child’s education—pretty intense stuff in terms of emotions. When I asked the civil rights investigators in one office to identify what they thought were the most common emotions parents might feel toward school districts, they generated a short list: anger, distrust, rage. I then asked them, “What would you say if I told you I thought most parents sitting in front of you were also feeling fear or guilt?”

去年，我走遍美国各地，为教育部民权办公室的许多地区办事处提供培训。这些办事处负责处理家长就子女教育问题起诉学区的案件——这些案件往往牵涉到非常强烈的情感。当我问其中一个办事处的民权调查员，他们认为家长对学区最常见的感受是什么时，他们列出了几个选项：愤怒、不信任、怨恨。然后我问他们：“如果我说，我认为坐在你们面前的大多数家长也感到恐惧或内疚，你们会怎么说？”

There was a collective “Ohhhhhh,” as eyes widened around the room. One participant said:

房间里响起一片“哦”的惊叹声，众人睁大了眼睛。一位参与者说道：

This makes so much sense. I bet the parents are feeling tons of guilt. Yes, the school district may have messed up, but could I have done better for my child? Why couldn’t I solve this problem before we got here? And fear… that may be the number one emotion. Parents are scared their child’s future may be ripped away depending on how they handle this one case. It makes them shut down and unable to negotiate. Now that I’m sitting here, I think a lot of the rage I’ve been seeing against the school district is really the parents’ fear or guilt about the situation. And if we addressed that, maybe some of the rage would evaporate.

这完全说得通。我敢肯定，家长们都感到非常内疚。没错，学区可能犯了错，但我本可以为我的孩子做得更好吗？为什么我没能在事情发展到今天这一步之前解决这个问题？恐惧……或许是他们最主要的情绪。家长们害怕孩子的未来会因为他们如何处理这件事而被毁掉。这种恐惧让他们封闭自己，无法进行任何协商。现在我坐在这里，我认为我看到的很多针对学区的愤怒，实际上都是家长们对现状的恐惧或内疚造成的。如果我们能解决这个问题，或许一些愤怒就会消散。

Think about this story about other people’s feelings when you endeavor to tackle your own, and consider whether you might be dealing with the Big Two. Confronting feelings can be hard, right? Well, as a teacher, I believe in walking with you as we grapple with these challenging issues… so I’ll go first. I’m going to tell you a story about my feelings and how my failure to recognize them almost damaged a close family relationship.

当你试图处理自己的感受时，想想这个关于他人感受的故事，并思考一下你是否正在面对“两大难题”。直面感受可能很难，对吧？作为一名教师，我相信在你们共同面对这些挑战性问题时，我们应该陪伴在你们身边……所以，我先来。我要讲一个关于我自身感受的故事，以及我未能识别这些感受是如何几乎破坏了一段亲密的家庭关系。

I grew up with a lawyer father I greatly admired and whose approval I always chased. Boisterous and somewhat combative, one of his colleagues described him to me as “the most pugnacious trusts and estates attorney I’ve ever met.” I vividly recall at five years old asking my dad what a lawyer did and him telling me, “People come to Dad asking for advice. I tell them what I think they should do, and they give me their pennies and dimes.” I thought that sounded like the best job in the world. (No surprise that I ended up going to law school twenty years later.)

我从小就有一个非常敬佩的律师父亲，我一直渴望得到他的认可。他性格豪爽，有时甚至有些好斗，他的一位同事曾这样形容他：“他是我见过的最好斗的信托和遗产律师。” 我清楚地记得五岁时问父亲律师是做什么的，他告诉我：“人们来找爸爸咨询。我告诉他们我的想法，然后他们给我一些零钱。” 我觉得这简直是世界上最好的工作。（不出所料，二十年后我最终还是去了法学院。）

I always longed for a closer relationship with my dad, one where we could talk more frequently or deeply about things that mattered. But my dad was never one for deep, emotional chats; he used to invent work reasons to call me, and then awkwardly transition to more personal talk with an “Um, so what else is new?” Our love of the law was one of our bonding points. When I won a major award at law school graduation, his beaming expression as they announced my name was worth more to me than the award itself.

我一直渴望与父亲建立更亲密的关系，能够更频繁、更深入地谈论一些重要的事情。但父亲从来不擅长深入的情感交流；他总是编造工作上的理由给我打电话，然后尴尬地转入私人话题，用一句“嗯，又有什么新鲜事吗？”来敷衍我。我们对法律的热爱是我们之间的纽带之一。当我在法学院毕业典礼上获得一项重要奖项时，宣布我名字的那一刻，他脸上洋溢的笑容比奖项本身更令我珍视。

Three years ago, my father, only seventy years old, became sick. Suddenly he went from seeming mildly apathetic and detached to forgetting my name and sending me emails with strings of unconnected words. My brothers and I feared a stroke. I called the Columbia Neurology department and brought my dad in for a series of memory tests. He failed all of them. The doctor told us we were dealing with a degenerative disease for which there was no cure and no treatment. My brothers and I coordinated the appointments and testing and worked together to cope with this devastating news.

三年前，我年仅七十岁的父亲突然病倒了。他原本只是略显冷漠疏离，后来却突然忘记了我的名字，发给我的邮件也总是语无伦次。我和兄弟们都担心他中风了。我赶紧打电话给哥伦比亚大学神经内科，带父亲去做了一系列记忆力测试。结果他全部不及格。医生告诉我们，他患上了一种无法治愈也无法治疗的退行性疾病。我和兄弟们协调安排了各种预约和检查，共同努力应对这突如其来的噩耗。

My uncle Bill, Dad’s lifelong best friend, confidant, champion, and only brother, has always been a second father to me. Since I was a teenager, I have called my “Unc” and aunt more times than I can count, for support and smart advice in a tough situation. This time, my uncle was part of the group of us who were dealing with this diagnosis, and so I didn’t want to unload on him and make things worse. He similarly tried to spare me his own pain—and so for a period of time I felt we talked less than usual while each of us dealt with the news. The problem was, I started telling myself that this temporary space meant he wasn’t happy about how I was handling my dad’s treatment. This increased my fear. Was I up to this? Could I handle things better? Finally, at a family reunion where we were all confronted with how frail my dad was looking, my uncle asked an innocuous, offhand question about whether my dad’s medications might need to be changed to help some of his symptoms. I lost it. I talked to my uncle and aunt angrily, without asking any questions first. I told them that my brothers and I were handling things now. That we knew what we were doing and had consulted the best doctors. That my dad was going to die of this disease and there was nothing any medication could do to stop it. And I walked off.

我的叔叔比尔，爸爸一生的挚友、知己、支持者，也是他唯一的兄弟，对我来说就像第二个父亲。从十几岁起，我就数不清多少次给叔叔和婶婶打电话，寻求他们在困境中的支持和建议。这一次，叔叔也和我们一起面对这个诊断结果，所以我不想向他倾诉，以免雪上加霜。他也同样不想让我承受他的痛苦——因此，有一段时间，我觉得我们之间的交流比平时少了很多，因为我们各自都在努力消化这个消息。问题是，我开始告诉自己，这种暂时的疏远意味着他对我处理爸爸治疗的方式不满意。这加剧了我的恐惧。我能应付得了吗？我能做得更好吗？最终，在一次家庭聚会上，我们都不得不面对爸爸虚弱的模样，叔叔漫不经心地问了一个无关紧要的问题：爸爸的药物是否需要调整，以缓解他的一些症状？我彻底崩溃了。我没问任何问题，就怒气冲冲地跟叔叔婶婶说话。我告诉他们，现在我和哥哥们会处理这件事。我们知道自己在做什么，也咨询过最好的医生。我爸爸会死于这种病，任何药物都无济于事。说完，我就走了。

For the rest of the evening I felt terrible. A confusing mess of emotions surged inside me. When I took a moment to ask myself what I was feeling, what I discovered first was fear. I had been trying to project confidence, setting up meetings and asking all the right questions, but deep inside I was terrified about managing my dad’s health care. In many respects I felt like a child again. I was scared to make such important decisions when I no longer had my dad—or now, my uncle—to ask for advice. Second, guilt. I secretly felt guilty that I couldn’t do more for my dad to stop his suffering. I also felt awful that I had spoken to my loved ones in that way. I knew that they were terrified and grieving, just like I was. This fear and guilt made me defensive; I desperately needed my uncle and aunt’s approval, but I’d gone about asking for it in the worst way possible.

那天晚上剩下的时间里，我感觉糟透了。各种复杂的情绪在我心中翻腾。当我停下来思考自己的感受时，首先发现的是恐惧。我一直努力表现得自信，安排各种会议，问出所有该问的问题，但内心深处，我却对如何照顾父亲的健康感到无比恐惧。在很多方面，我感觉自己又回到了童年。我害怕做出如此重要的决定，因为我已经没有父亲——或者现在，没有叔叔——可以向我征求意见了。其次是内疚。我暗自感到内疚，因为我没能为父亲做更多，让他摆脱痛苦。我也为自己用那种方式与亲人交谈而感到难过。我知道他们和我一样，既恐惧又悲痛。这种恐惧和内疚让我变得防备；我迫切地需要叔叔和婶婶的认可，但我却用了最糟糕的方式去寻求他们的认可。

My aunt approached me later in the evening and asked to talk. I’ll always be grateful to her for this. We sat down on the stairs and she said, “You know… your uncle and I have never done this before, sitting back and watching the younger generation make decisions. We are feeling a little lost. But we have good intentions.”

那天晚上晚些时候，我姑姑找到我，想跟我聊聊。我永远都会感激她。我们坐在楼梯上，她说：“你知道吗……你叔叔和我以前从来没这样过，看着年轻一代做决定。我们感觉有点迷茫。但我们是出于好意。”

I said, “Thanks. You know, I’ve never done this before either. I’m also feeling lost. I’ve been freaking out on the inside. My dad is no longer able to tell me he approves of what I’m doing, so I really need to hear that you trust and support me.”

我说：“谢谢。你知道，我以前也没做过这种事。我也感到很迷茫，内心一直很焦虑。我爸爸已经不能再告诉我他认可我的做法了，所以我真的很需要听到你信任我、支持我。”

She reassured me, “We do trust you. You and your brothers have done an amazing job with your dad. We didn’t mean to question you by asking about the medication. Can we just assume the best of each other going forward?”

她安慰我说：“我们确实信任你。你和你的兄弟们照顾你父亲做得非常出色。我们问起药物方面的问题，并不是想质疑你。以后我们能互相信任吗？”

I agreed. “Definitely. I completely overreacted because I’m trying so hard to control a situation I can’t control. Let’s start over.”

我同意了。“没错。我反应过度了，因为我太想控制一个我根本无法控制的局面。我们重新开始吧。”

By confronting my own feelings and sharing them honestly with my aunt, each of us was able to recognize and honor each other’s deep fear. We transformed a challenging family conflict into an opportunity to grow closer together. Today, my uncle and aunt are one of my main sources of support in a devastating time. My dad’s doctors recently commented that they have rarely seen such a cohesive family unit. We all feel great sadness as my dad’s condition worsens, but we find great comfort and relief in one another.

通过直面自己的感受，并坦诚地与姑姑分享，我们彼此都能够理解并尊重对方内心深处的恐惧。我们将一场棘手的家庭冲突转化为增进彼此感情的契机。如今，在这段艰难的时期，我的叔叔和姑姑是我最重要的精神支柱之一。我父亲的医生最近也表示，他们很少见到如此团结的家庭。随着父亲病情加重，我们都感到无比悲痛，但我们彼此之间也找到了莫大的安慰和慰藉。

The Final Step: Expressing Your Emotions in Negotiation

最后一步：在谈判中表达你的情绪

So you’ve begun processing how you feel in order to prepare for negotiating. The next logical question is often, “Do I show that emotion when I sit down with the other person?”

所以你已经开始梳理自己的感受，为谈判做好准备。接下来合乎逻辑的问题通常是：“当我与对方坐下来谈判时，我会表现出这种情绪吗？”

As a general principle, I believe in transparency during negotiation. Clear communication helps you create more value. And expressing positive emotions like compassion, excitement, or pride have been shown to help build a connection with the other party and increase the chance that they want to help you achieve your goals, as well as their own. But what about more negative emotions? I’ll talk about the two that people ask about most—anger and anxiety—below.

总的来说，我认为谈判中应该保持透明。清晰的沟通有助于创造更多价值。表达积极的情绪，例如同情、兴奋或自豪，已被证明有助于与对方建立联系，并增加他们帮助你实现目标（以及他们自身目标）的可能性。但是，负面情绪呢？下文我将讨论人们最常问到的两种情绪——愤怒和焦虑。

Anger

愤怒

Anger is a legitimate emotion, in life and in negotiation. Many people, especially women and people from certain cultures, are given the message that they should not feel or express anger, even though recognizing and expressing anger can generate empowering effects for many people.

愤怒是一种合理的情绪，无论在生活中还是在谈判中。许多人，尤其是女性和某些文化背景的人，从小就被灌输不应该感受或表达愤怒的观念，尽管认识和表达愤怒对许多人来说都能带来积极的力量。

But what do you do with that anger in negotiation? If you feel angry during a negotiation, research shows you may experience more difficulty coming up with creative, win-win solutions. You may also have more difficulty accurately assessing the needs of the person across from you (which we’ll discuss in chapter 6). Addressing your anger in advance will help you communicate clearly and with intention when you do sit down with someone else.

但在谈判中，该如何处理这种愤怒情绪呢？研究表明，如果在谈判过程中感到愤怒，你可能更难提出富有创意且双赢的解决方案。你也可能更难准确评估对方的需求（我们将在第六章讨论这一点）。提前处理好你的愤怒情绪，将有助于你在与他人坐下来谈判时，能够清晰、有目的地进行沟通。

Ultimately, the decision whether to show your anger in any given negotiation belongs to you. Displaying anger in negotiation has been shown to lead to mixed results. If you have more power than your counterpart, they may be more likely to make concessions in the short term as a result of your anger. But research shows that they may also be less likely to want to do business with you in the long term. If you have less power than your counterpart, showing anger may lead to escalation of the conflict and negotiation impasse.

最终，是否在任何谈判中表现出愤怒，完全取决于你。研究表明，在谈判中表现出愤怒会带来好坏参半的结果。如果你比对方更有优势，对方可能更倾向于在短期内因为你的愤怒而做出让步。但研究也表明，从长远来看，他们可能更不愿意与你合作。如果你不如对方有优势，表现出愤怒则可能导致冲突升级，谈判陷入僵局。

For situations where you are angry but may not want to show your anger when you talk with someone else, expressing a milder emotion like disappointment may give you the chance to communicate that you are unhappy about something, while minimizing the likelihood of a reaction and maximizing your chances of achieving what you need from the negotiation.

当你生气但又不想在与他人交谈时表现出愤怒时，表达失望等较温和的情绪，可以让你有机会表达你对某事的不满，同时最大限度地减少对方的反应，并最大限度地提高你在谈判中获得所需结果的机会。

Anxiety

焦虑

Another tricky emotion to express in negotiation is anxiety. Anxiety in negotiation can lead people to accept flawed advice, give up easily, and ignore their own needs. If you’ve listed anxiety in your list of feelings from earlier in this chapter, in most cases you’ll want to address this yourself instead of stating it out loud when you sit down with the other person. (The exception would be if this is a negotiation with someone close to you in your life, perhaps a family member or partner, in which one of the goals is complete transparency and closeness.)

谈判中另一个难以表达的情绪是焦虑。焦虑会让人在谈判中接受错误的建议、轻易放弃，甚至忽略自身的需求。如果你在本章前面提到的感受列表中包含了焦虑，那么在大多数情况下，你应该在与对方谈判时，私下处理这个问题，而不是直接说出来。（但如果谈判对象是你生活中关系亲近的人，比如家人或伴侣，而谈判的目标之一就是完全透明和亲密，那就另当别论了。）

When you address anxiety, it’s important to consider whether you have anxiety about the substance of your negotiation (for example, how your salary compares to others in your department and what that means for your future at the company) or anxiety about the negotiation itself (such as the process of going to management to ask for more money).

当你面对焦虑时，重要的是要考虑你是对谈判的实质内容感到焦虑（例如，你的薪水与部门内其他人的薪水相比如何，以及这对你在公司的未来意味着什么），还是对谈判本身感到焦虑（例如，向管理层要求加薪的过程）。

Either way, you will benefit from acknowledging that anxiety and reflecting on it in advance. If you’re feeling anxious about the substance of the conflict and you work through these questions before the negotiation, you’ll have much more information that will help you feel prepared to tackle the negotiation. And if you feel anxious about the process of negotiating, you’ll benefit even more from acknowledging and dealing with that anxiety. Recognizing that emotion and answering the other Mirror questions in this book will go a long way toward allaying the anxiety you feel about the negotiation itself. Negotiation always involves things we can’t control, but there is also a lot that we can—and by asking yourself the right questions, you’ll have tackled the part that’s within your influence.

无论如何，承认并提前反思这种焦虑都会对你有所裨益。如果你对冲突的实质感到焦虑，并在谈判前认真思考这些问题，你就能获得更多信息，从而更好地为谈判做好准备。如果你对谈判过程感到焦虑，那么承认并应对这种焦虑将对你更有帮助。认识到这种情绪并回答本书中的其他“镜像”问题，将大大有助于缓解你对谈判本身的焦虑。谈判总是包含一些我们无法控制的因素，但也有很多因素是我们能够掌控的——通过问自己正确的问题，你就能掌控那些在你能力范围之内的部分。

One final way to handle anxiety is to look at the Window questions in advance, and imagine what the other person might say in response. Write those answers down, and map out a potential strategy for when you ask the questions and then work to move the negotiation forward.

应对焦虑的最后一个方法是提前查看“窗口问题”，并设想对方可能会如何回答。把这些答案写下来，并制定一个可能的策略，以便在提出这些问题时推动谈判向前发展。

Wrapping Up

总结

You’ve looked in the Mirror, confronted your feelings, and survived. Before we finish, take a moment to read through what you wrote down for this chapter, and summarize any important points or themes.

你已经审视过自己，直面过自己的感受，并且挺过来了。在结束之前，请花点时间回顾一下你为本章写下的内容，并总结一下其中的要点或主题。

Next, we’ll move on to a question that will help you generate excellent ideas for a solution to your issue—and feel great while doing it.

接下来，我们将讨论一个问题，这个问题将帮助你产生解决问题的绝妙想法——而且在这个过程中你会感到非常满足。

#↩

FOUR HOW HAVE I HANDLED THIS SUCCESSFULLY IN THE PAST?

第四，我过去是如何成功处理这件事的？

Even for smart, successful people, few negotiations bring up more unease and worry than asking for more money at work.

即使对于聪明成功的人来说，也很少有谈判比在工作中要求加薪更令人不安和担忧。

Andrew graduated from college three years ago with an undergraduate business degree and went to work for a financial institution. He wanted help negotiating for his first promotion, and an increased compensation package to go with it. From the moment Andrew arrived at the company, he launched himself into contributing not only to the bottom line but to the positive work environment by recruiting college students, mentoring them, and serving on a committee dedicated to employee well-being.

安德鲁三年前大学毕业，获得商科学士学位，之后进入一家金融机构工作。他希望有人能帮他争取第一次晋升，以及随之而来的更高薪酬。安德鲁一到公司就积极投身其中，不仅为公司盈利做出贡献，还通过招募大学生、指导他们以及参与员工福利委员会的工作，营造了积极的工作氛围。

Andrew told me that when he first joined the company as an entry-level employee, the compensation was done in lockstep, which meant that everyone at that level was paid the same. You could still negotiate for good work assignments and mentors, but the money was the money. He worked hard and his work spoke for itself.

安德鲁告诉我，他刚入职公司时，薪酬是统一制定的，也就是说，同级别的员工薪水都一样。虽然可以争取好的工作机会和导师，但薪水就是最终的定额。他工作非常努力，业绩也证明了这一点。

But three years in, Andrew wanted to become a manager. He had become eligible for promotion last year, but didn’t advocate for it and hadn’t been promoted. A child of immigrants, Andrew had been raised to believe that he wasn’t entitled to anything, that hard work and dedication would lead to the best results. Now, however, he started to see he would need more than that in order to be successful. As his yearly review approached, Andrew hoped to use that occasion to make a case for his promotion, as well as a raise. He had a general sense that managers made 15–25 percent more than he was making right now, but the promotion—and his compensation—would depend on his advocacy. This year, he wanted to craft a strategy to ask for more.

三年过去了，安德鲁渴望成为一名经理。他去年就达到了晋升条件，但他没有积极争取，最终未能如愿。作为移民的后代，安德鲁从小就被灌输一种观念：没有什么是理所当然的，只有努力工作、尽职尽责才能获得最好的结果。然而，现在他开始意识到，要想成功，仅仅依靠这些是不够的。随着年度考核的临近，安德鲁希望借此机会争取晋升和加薪。他大致了解经理的收入比他现在高出15%到25%，但能否晋升以及薪酬待遇，都取决于他能否积极争取。今年，他打算制定一个策略，争取更高的待遇。

We defined Andrew’s main goal: he wanted to negotiate for as close to a 25 percent increase as possible. But he wanted more than that. He wanted to show management that he had what it took to be a future leader within the company. He also wanted to feel confident negotiating for himself, and not just on behalf of his company or clients. His needs included recognition of all he was doing for the company, including his client work and his institutional work; a sense that he was advancing toward senior partnership and perhaps company management; and more experience negotiating successfully for himself.

我们明确了安德鲁的主要目标：他希望尽可能争取到接近25%的加薪。但他想要的远不止这些。他想向管理层证明，他具备成为公司未来领导者的潜质。他还希望能够自信地为自己谈判，而不仅仅是代表公司或客户。他的需求包括：他为公司所做的一切，包括客户工作和机构工作，都得到认可；感受到自己正在向高级合伙人甚至公司管理层迈进；以及积累更多成功为自己谈判的经验。

We also contemplated Andrew’s feelings: On the one hand, he was excited to start actively managing his own career. On the other, he had mixed feelings about accumulating wealth for wealth’s sake. At this point, he was making enough money to support himself and also help his parents out, too. He was comfortable negotiating on behalf of his company, but he felt slightly guilty about asking for more for himself. He acknowledged that these conflicting feelings had prevented him from asking for a raise or promotion last year, when he first became eligible.

我们也思考了安德鲁的感受：一方面，他很兴奋能开始积极掌控自己的职业生涯；另一方面，他对为了财富而积累财富感到矛盾。目前，他的收入足以养活自己，还能补贴家用。他很乐意代表公司进行谈判，但为自己争取更多却让他感到有些内疚。他承认，正是这些矛盾的感受让他去年第一次符合加薪或晋升条件时，没有提出要求。

I asked him how he had handled negotiations like this successfully in the past. He looked back at me and said, “This is the first time. During college, I interned for great companies, but all those positions were unpaid. Now I’m here. I work in finance, I’m doing very well, and yet I’ve never negotiated for my own compensation before. So I don’t have a prior success to draw from here.”

我问他过去是如何成功处理这类谈判的。他看着我说：“这是第一次。大学期间，我曾在一些很棒的公司实习，但那些职位都是无薪的。现在我在这里工作，从事金融行业，而且做得非常出色，但我以前从未为自己争取过薪酬。所以，我没有什么成功的经验可以借鉴。”

I looked back over my notes. “Okay. Let’s look at the different elements of your approach and break it down. What do you think it’s going to take for you to be successful here?”

我翻阅了一下笔记。“好的。我们来分析一下你的方法，把它分解开来。你觉得要想在这里取得成功，需要做些什么？”

He thought for a minute. “Well, I need to build a case, meaning that I’m going to need to review all the different aspects of my performance and cast them in the best possible light. I should also frame my arguments in terms that also make it clear that the company will benefit from promoting me and compensating me at a level I deserve. In my experience, this kind of approach works best with management, in addition to being consistent with my values. I should also spend some time talking individually to key players at my company, who can advocate for me when they make promotion decisions. Get them on board and give them the talking points they’ll need to help make my case. Last… I’m going to need to kind of psych myself up to do this; like, really believing that I’m worth this much so that I can convince them of the same.”

他想了一会儿。“嗯，我需要好好准备一下，也就是说，我需要回顾一下自己工作表现的方方面面，并尽可能地展现出它们最好的一面。我还应该用一些能清晰地表明公司会因提拔我并给予我应得的薪酬而受益的措辞来阐述我的观点。以我的经验来看，这种方法对管理层最有效，而且也符合我的价值观。我还应该花些时间单独和公司里的关键人物谈谈，让他们在做晋升决定时为我争取支持。让他们理解我的想法，并告诉他们我需要哪些论点才能更好地阐述我的观点。最后……我需要给自己打打气；比如，真正相信自己值这么多钱，这样才能说服他们也这么认为。”

I summarized: “To be successful here, it sounds like you’ll need to (1) research and build a case, (2) frame this as a mutual win, (3) get some key people on board, and (4) psych yourself up to believe that the outcome you’re advocating is actually the right one, and not just the one you want. Let’s look back through the past and see if there’s a time you had a negotiation success involving those elements. You said earlier that you have experience with the company that indicated framing things as a mutual win would be most successful. Might that give us a clue as to where to start?”

我总结道：“要想成功，听起来你需要做到以下几点：(1) 调研并构建论据；(2) 将此事定位为双赢；(3) 争取关键人物的支持；(4) 让自己相信你所倡导的结果才是正确的，而不仅仅是你想要的结果。我们回顾一下你过去的经历，看看你是否曾经在谈判中运用过这些要素并取得成功。你之前提到过，你与这家公司合作的经验表明，将事情定位为双赢是最有效的策略。这或许能给我们一些启发，告诉我们从哪里入手？”

Andrew thought about it and mentioned that as soon as he arrived at the company, he’d had the idea to start a training program for its junior employees, something that at the time was unique among competitive firms. His efforts led to a speaker series focused on mentoring junior employees in leadership, negotiation, and other skills that would help them advance. The program was extremely successful but had taken some advocating with the management team. Andrew had to make the case that it would help attract and retain top talent, which in turn would produce better PR and better financial results in the long term, since they’d have happier employees and less turnover. He had to frame it as a win for both junior ranks (including himself) and senior management.

安德鲁思考了一会儿，提到他一到公司就萌生了为初级员工设立培训项目的想法，这在当时的竞争激烈的公司中是独一无二的。在他的努力下，公司推出了一系列讲座，旨在指导初级员工提升领导力、谈判技巧以及其他有助于他们职业发展的技能。该项目取得了巨大的成功，但为此他费了不少周折才说服管理团队。安德鲁必须证明，该项目有助于吸引和留住顶尖人才，从而从长远来看，提升公司形象和财务业绩，因为员工满意度更高，人员流动率更低。他必须让这个项目对初级员工（包括他自己）和高层管理人员都有利。

Andrew explained his hesitation with doing the same thing this time around: “The one difference in this scenario is that I didn’t have to advocate for just myself, so psyching myself up wasn’t as much of an issue… But now that I’m thinking about it, I needed to advocate for myself in order to get this job in the first place. This is a competitive job market and a sought-after company to work for. I wasn’t asking for specific compensation, but I was asking for a position, as well as the specific group I wanted, which had very limited openings. I believed I was a great fit for the job, that I could contribute here, and it showed. Maybe this negotiation isn’t so different.”

安德鲁解释了他这次犹豫不决的原因：“这次不同的是，我不用只为自己争取，所以自我激励不成问题……但现在想想，我当初为了得到这份工作，确实需要为自己争取。这是一个竞争激烈的就业市场，而且这家公司非常抢手。我当时并没有要求具体的薪酬，而是要求一个职位，以及我想要加入的特定团队，而这个团队的空缺非常有限。我相信自己非常适合这份工作，能够做出贡献，而事实也证明了这一点。也许这次的谈判并没有那么大的区别。”

As a result of considering his prior negotiation success, Andrew came out of this conversation with concrete ideas for how he could approach this negotiation for his compensation. Six months later, he was a manager in his division, with two direct reports and an 18 percent compensation increase. But Andrew also got more than that. In the process of his individual conversations with management around the promotion, he shared that he was interested in rising to a senior management position eventually. One year later, he was placed on a company management committee that had only two spots for junior managers, a prestigious placement that signaled upper management’s confidence in his leadership. He was on track to achieve his goals.

鉴于之前谈判的成功经验，安德鲁在这次谈话后有了具体的方案来争取更高的薪酬。六个月后，他晋升为部门经理，直接管理两名下属，薪酬也上涨了18%。但安德鲁获得的远不止这些。在与管理层就晋升事宜进行单独谈话的过程中，他表达了自己最终晋升到高级管理岗位的意愿。一年后，他被任命为公司管理委员会成员，该委员会仅有两个初级经理的席位，这是一个极具声望的职位，表明高层管理人员对他的领导能力充满信心。他正朝着自己的目标稳步前进。

“How Have I Handled This Successfully in the Past?”

“我过去是如何成功处理这类事情的？”

In this chapter, I want you to mine your past for ways in which you have successfully handled challenges similar to the one you face now. I will help you put yourself back in that successful mind-set so that you can access your inner wisdom and generate ideas that will help you move forward in your future negotiations. Considering a prior success will also make you feel more confident when you negotiate. And if, like Andrew, you can’t recall a previous success in a similar situation, I’ll help you find another success to help you tackle your current negotiation. Together, I know we’ll discover that your prior success has more similarities to your current situation than you might expect. You’ll finish this chapter with a clearer picture of your situation, ready to launch yourself into the future.

在本章中，我希望你回顾过往经历，寻找那些你曾成功应对过与当前挑战类似情况的经验。我会帮助你重拾成功的心态，从而激发你的内在智慧，并产生有助于你未来谈判的思路。回顾过往的成功案例也能增强你的谈判信心。如果你像安德鲁一样，想不起之前在类似情况下取得的成功，我会帮助你找到其他成功案例，以助你应对当前的谈判。我相信，我们最终会发现，你之前的成功经验与你目前的情况比你想象的更为相似。读完本章，你将对自身处境有更清晰的认识，并为未来做好准备。

Considering a Prior Success

考虑到之前的成功

When I prompt people to consider a prior success, I often get to watch them transform before my eyes. They go from feeling unsure, apprehensive, or lost, to confident, organized, and even excited to negotiate. Asking about a prior success not only prepares you for the last question in the Mirror section but also helps get you ready for when it’s time to sit down with someone else.

当我引导人们回顾以往的成功经历时，我常常亲眼见证他们的转变。他们从最初的犹豫、焦虑或迷茫，转变为自信、条理清晰，甚至对谈判充满热情。询问过往的成功经历不仅能帮助你回答“镜像”部分的最后一个问题，还能让你在与他人面对面交流时更加游刃有余。

“How have I handled this successfully in the past?” is transformative for a few reasons. First, it places this one negotiation into context. When we experience an issue—a tough negotiation, a “no” from a prospective client, a relationship conflict, a collapsed business deal, or something we’ve never done before—we often dwell on that experience to the point that we forget about the many successes we’ve experienced in the past. Second, as in the example above, this question focuses us more specifically on approaches, circumstances, and techniques that have worked favorably for us, from which we can gather good data about what might work for us this time. Last—and most important—I know, both from research and experience, that when people spend time thinking about a previous success, they are more likely to achieve better results in their next negotiation. It’s a powerful positive anchor. Together, we will help you use it to your advantage and launch you into your future in the best way possible.

“我过去是如何成功处理类似情况的？”这个问题之所以具有变革意义，原因有几点。首先，它能将当前的谈判置于更广阔的背景之中。当我们遇到问题时——比如艰难的谈判、潜在客户的拒绝、人际关系冲突、失败的商业交易，或者我们从未经历过的事情——我们往往会过度沉溺于这种经历，以至于忘记了过去取得的诸多成功。其次，正如上面的例子所示，这个问题能让我们更具体地关注那些曾经奏效的方法、情境和技巧，从中我们可以汲取宝贵的经验，从而更好地把握这次的谈判策略。最后，也是最重要的一点——根据研究和经验，我知道，当人们花时间思考过去的成功经验时，他们更有可能在下一次谈判中取得更好的结果。这是一个强大的积极因素。我们将携手合作，帮助您充分利用这一优势，以最佳方式开启您的未来。

Let’s take each of these reasons in turn.

让我们逐一分析这些原因。

Placing Your Negotiation into Context

将你的谈判置于特定背景下

Sometimes, as with the executive above, we experience negative emotions around a negotiation—perhaps a conversation that didn’t go well, one that is proving to be tougher than expected, or one that we haven’t tackled yet but is making us anxious. This is especially true if your negotiation involves a long-term relationship, whether at work, at home, or with yourself.

有时，就像上面那位高管一样，我们在谈判过程中会产生负面情绪——也许是谈话进行得不顺利，也许是谈判比预期更艰难，又或许是我们尚未着手处理但却令我们焦虑不安。如果你的谈判涉及长期关系，无论是在工作中、家庭中还是与自己之间，这种情况尤其如此。

If you are facing a negotiation that involves a long-standing person or issue in your life, and in chapter 3 you uncovered any negative emotions around your negotiation, this question will be helpful to you. When people encounter a conflict with someone they have known for a while, they sometimes allow that conflict to take up so much brain space (and with good reason!) that they forget they have handled a similar negotiation—or many similar negotiations—successfully in the past.

如果你正面临一场涉及生活中长期存在的人或问题的谈判，并且在第三章中你已经意识到谈判过程中存在任何负面情绪，那么这个问题将对你有所帮助。当人们与相识已久的人发生冲突时，他们有时会让这场冲突占据太多的精力（这也不无道理！），以至于忘记了自己过去曾成功处理过类似的谈判——甚至很多类似的谈判。

Let’s take the situation of a doctor, Jamila, who was struggling with her long-time patient Ben. Ben had diabetes, and Jamila couldn’t get him to stay on his medication. Jamila, who cared about Ben as a patient and even saw a bit of herself in him (they were both musicians), grew tremendously frustrated as she watched Ben suffer health consequences from his inconsistent approach to his own care. Jamila left the last appointment feeling depleted and angry. She knew she had shown her frustration more than was optimal, and that she needed to cool off and figure out another approach.

我们不妨设想一下医生贾米拉的处境。她长期以来的病人本患有糖尿病，但贾米拉始终无法让他坚持服药。贾米拉很关心本，甚至在他身上看到了自己的影子（他们都是音乐家）。眼看着本因为不规律的服药而遭受健康损害，贾米拉感到非常沮丧。上次就诊结束后，贾米拉感到精疲力竭，怒火中烧。她知道自己刚才的情绪过于激动，需要冷静下来，想想别的办法。

When Jamila took a moment to contemplate a prior success in her work with this patient, she realized that, in fact, she had been successful with this patient a few times before. When Ben had first come to Jamila for treatment, for example, he had been struggling with very poor eating habits. Jamila had spent time talking to Ben, asking him questions about his life and what made him happy. Most important, Jamila reassured him that change could feel manageable. Ben had agreed to see a nutritionist and overall was eating better than when he first came in. He had even lost a bit of weight. Jamila realized that her negotiation with this longtime patient was not an overall failure, and that maybe the medication issue posed more of a speed bump than a roadblock.

贾米拉回想起之前与这位病人合作的成功案例，意识到自己其实已经成功帮助过他好几次了。比如，本第一次来找贾米拉治疗时，他的饮食习惯非常糟糕。贾米拉花时间与本交谈，询问他的生活状况以及让他感到快乐的事情。最重要的是，贾米拉让他相信改变是可以做到的。本同意去看营养师，而且总体来说，他的饮食比刚来的时候好多了。他甚至还减了一些体重。贾米拉意识到，她与这位老病人的沟通并非完全失败，也许药物问题只是一个小小的障碍，而不是真正的阻碍。

Placing the negotiation into context by considering a prior success also works wonders for difficult negotiations where you don’t have a long-term relationship with the other person. I also spoke to an advertising executive, Elijah, about a recent failed negotiation; he had interviewed for a job he really wanted, and then tried to come to terms with company management about compensation and job responsibilities. They resisted some of the terms Elijah felt were non-negotiable. Eventually, the back-and-forth generated a lot of bad feelings on both sides. They mutually agreed Elijah would not take the job.

在谈判中，如果双方没有长期合作关系，那么将谈判置于更广阔的背景中，并参考之前的成功案例，对于棘手的谈判也大有裨益。我曾与一位名叫伊莱贾的广告主管谈过他最近一次失败的谈判经历。他面试了一份自己非常想得到的工作，之后试图与公司管理层就薪酬和工作职责达成一致。但对方拒绝了伊莱贾认为不可妥协的一些条款。最终，双方反复拉锯，导致彼此都产生了诸多不满。他们一致同意伊莱贾放弃这份工作。

Elijah was very upset about the way things had gone down. He went back and forth between anger at how they had handled things and self-doubt about his approach. Frustrated and sad, he stopped his job-seeking efforts for a little while. But when Elijah prompted himself to consider his prior successes in job negotiation, he realized that over the course of his career he had successfully negotiated his way into almost a dozen jobs—some that he took, and some where he liked the offer but ultimately made another choice. By placing this recent “failure” into context, Elijah realized that one bad job negotiation did not define his worth as a negotiator, or in the market. He restarted his search.

伊莱贾对事情的进展非常不满。他一会儿愤怒于他们的处理方式，一会儿又怀疑自己的方法。沮丧和难过让他暂时停止了求职。但当伊莱贾回想起自己以往在求职谈判中的成功经验时，他意识到，在他的职业生涯中，他已经成功谈判获得了近十份工作——有些他接受了，有些他很喜欢对方的条件，但最终还是选择了其他工作。通过对这次“失败”的重新审视，伊莱贾意识到，一次糟糕的求职谈判并不能定义他作为谈判者的价值，也不能定义他在就业市场上的地位。于是，他重新开始了求职。

Like Jamila or Elijah, you might find some of those negative feelings melting away as you consider how you handled a similar situation successfully and place this negotiation in its proper context. Once we take the time to remind ourselves of a prior success, we reduce the noise in our minds and allow ourselves to see that this negotiation is just one of many we have tackled in our lifetime.

就像贾米拉或伊利亚一样，当你回想自己如何成功处理过类似情况，并将这次谈判置于恰当的背景中时，你可能会发现一些负面情绪逐渐消散。一旦我们花时间回顾之前的成功经验，就能减少脑海中的杂音，并意识到这次谈判只是我们一生中经历的众多谈判之一。

Your Prior Success as a Data Generator

您之前作为数据生成器的成功经验

The second benefit of this question is that it acts as a data generator, helping you to recall strategies that have worked in the past and might work for you again. Andrew, the executive whose story started this chapter, considered a prior success (or two) and generated a helpful action list of things to try in his compensation negotiation. He left with an action plan that included research, argument formulation, meeting with key players, and self-motivation.

这个问题的第二个好处是它能生成数据，帮助你回忆起过去行之有效的策略，这些策略或许还能再次奏效。本章开头的主人公安德鲁，回顾了之前一两次成功的经验，并据此制定了一份实用的行动清单，供他在薪酬谈判中尝试。他最终制定了一份行动计划，其中包括调研、论点构建、与关键人物会面以及自我激励。

I’ve seen this work over and over again for other people in vastly different situations.

我见过这种方法在各种截然不同的情况下对其他人都奏效过。

Smith is a contractor who has done many jobs for Rosa, a landlord and business owner. After many years of working together happily and profitably on many of Rosa’s apartments, their last job, a kitchen renovation, ended with a breached agreement, no payment, an unfinished kitchen, and a lot of bad feelings. They were left trying to negotiate how much money would be paid, and whether or how they would work together going forward. As their mediator, I asked them how they had handled their dealings successfully in the past. Several important things happened almost immediately. First, they remembered just how many projects they had completed together over the years with absolutely no issue. This helped place their current dispute into context and focus them on the fact that the relationship had been mostly good. Second, they were able to diagnose that certain practices that had worked for them in the past—writing out the contract, picking out fixtures together—were missing from this last deal, which had been rushed and more involved than their typical projects. After focusing on these previous successes, we restored some of the good feeling between them and gave them ideas for the future. They decided to continue to work together and to always create a written contract. And they set some guidelines for ways they would communicate about design choices once a job was in progress.

史密斯是一位承包商，曾为房东兼企业主罗莎做过很多项目。多年来，他们合作愉快，合作愉快，罗莎的许多公寓都装修过。然而，他们最近的一个项目——厨房翻新——却以违约告终：罗莎没有支付款项，厨房也未完工，双方关系破裂，怨气冲天。他们不得不协商付款金额，以及未来是否以及如何继续合作。作为他们的调解人，我询问了他们过去是如何成功处理合作的。几乎立刻，几个重要的方面发生了变化。首先，他们回忆起多年来合作完成的众多项目，从未出现任何问题。这有助于他们理解当前的纠纷，并意识到他们之间的关系总体上是良好的。其次，他们意识到，过去行之有效的一些做法——例如签订合同、共同挑选配件——在最近的项目中缺失了。这次项目进展仓促，而且比他们通常的项目更加复杂。在回顾了这些成功经验之后，我们帮助他们重拾了彼此间的良好关系，并为他们未来的合作提出了建议。他们决定继续合作，并始终签订书面合同。他们还制定了一些指导原则，规定在项目进行过程中，如何就设计选择进行沟通。

Brad is a father of a tween girl, Harper, who struggles with anxiety that manifests in explosive arguments at home. These “blowouts,” as Brad calls them, usually occur when Harper is heading off to school in the morning. They have affected the whole family, including Brad’s other two children and spouse, and lately have driven Brad to the point of yelling himself, which makes him feel terrible. Brad has been trying desperately to negotiate this situation with Harper, but has started to despair about his ability to make it better.

布拉德有个正值青春期的女儿哈珀，她患有焦虑症，经常在家爆发激烈的争吵。布拉德称这些争吵为“爆发”，通常发生在哈珀早上上学前。这些争吵影响了全家，包括布拉德的另外两个孩子和妻子，最近更是让布拉德自己也忍不住大吼大叫，这让他感到非常内疚。布拉德一直在努力尝试和哈珀沟通，但他开始对自己能否改善现状感到绝望。

When I asked Brad about a prior success, it took him a few minutes to get into the headspace to consider it. Once he did, though, he thought of one: years earlier, Harper had a difficult time mastering reading. She struggled with confidence and fought Brad every night over homework. They had a number of similar “high volume” arguments that ended in tears on both sides. Eventually, Brad helped her over the hump. How? In looking back, Brad realized that he had done a couple of things. One, he had found Harper a reading tutor who was young, and who Harper looked up to and respected. The tutor had made a personal connection with Harper and that translated into more motivation to read. Second, Brad had made an effort to spend more one-on-one time with Harper when they weren’t reading. They did activities they both enjoyed, like going to kids’ museums or out for ice cream. Brad felt this had helped them build their relationship so that they could get through the difficult times around Harper’s reading.

当我问布拉德之前有没有成功的经历时，他花了点时间才回过神来。但一旦他回过神来，就想起了一件事：几年前，哈珀在阅读方面遇到了困难。她缺乏自信，每天晚上都会因为家庭作业和布拉德争吵。他们之间有过很多类似的“激烈”争吵，每次都以双方落泪告终。最终，布拉德帮助她克服了阅读的难关。他是怎么做到的呢？回想起来，布拉德意识到自己做了两件事。首先，他为哈珀找了一位年轻的阅读辅导老师，哈珀很敬重这位老师。这位老师和哈珀建立了良好的个人关系，这激发了她更大的阅读动力。其次，布拉德努力在不读书的时候多花时间陪伴哈珀。他们一起做彼此都喜欢的事情，比如去儿童博物馆或者吃冰淇淋。布拉德觉得这些努力帮助他们建立了亲密的关系，从而能够共同度过哈珀阅读困难的时期。

With this information, Brad decided to look for a young, personable therapist who might be able to connect with Harper and help with her anxiety. He also made a commitment to spending a couple hours a week with Harper at a less stressful time, to connect and do things they both enjoyed. He started to feel more optimistic about his ability to help Harper—and himself—get through this latest challenge.

有了这些信息，布拉德决定找一位年轻、性格亲和的心理咨询师，希望她能与哈珀建立良好的关系，帮助她缓解焦虑。他还承诺每周抽出几个小时，在哈珀比较放松的时候陪伴她，增进彼此的感情，一起做些她们都喜欢的事情。他开始对自己帮助哈珀——也帮助自己——度过这次难关的能力感到更加乐观了。

In both of these situations, looking at a prior success helped someone approach a challenging negotiation with some concrete ideas that gave them a roadmap toward continued success. If this applies to you, take a moment to see if your prior success helps you generate ideas for your own negotiation.

在这两种情况下，回顾之前的成功经验都能帮助人们带着一些具体的想法来应对棘手的谈判，从而为他们持续取得成功指明方向。如果这种情况也适用于你，不妨花点时间思考一下，你之前的成功经验是否能帮助你为自己的谈判提供思路。

Priming Yourself for Creativity and Success in Negotiation

为谈判中的创造力和成功做好准备

There’s one additional, powerful benefit to considering a prior success as part of your negotiation strategy. When you consider a prior success, you feel better. And when you feel better, you increase the chances that you will perform better in your next negotiation. One of the main reasons to ask this question is that, in addition to placing your situation in context and generating helpful ideas, it makes you feel empowered, happy, and proud in a way that has a positive impact on the issue you are working on.

将以往的成功经验纳入谈判策略，还有一个额外的强大好处。当你回顾以往的成功时，你会感觉更好。而当你感觉更好时，你在下次谈判中表现更佳的几率也会增加。提出这个问题的主要原因之一是，除了能帮助你将当前处境置于更广阔的背景中，并激发有益的想法之外，它还能让你感到更有力量、更快乐、更自豪，从而对你正在处理的问题产生积极的影响。

We also know from chapter 3, and many studies, that focusing on positive events may increase your creativity and resourcefulness in negotiation. One study at Columbia found that graduate business school candidates who wrote about an experience of personal power prior to participating in a mock job interview saw their odds of acceptance shoot up: They were accepted 68 percent of the time, compared with a normal acceptance rate of 47 percent. And people who wrote about a time in which they lacked power plummeted in effectiveness, with only 26 percent of them getting selected by the judges.

我们从第三章以及许多研究中也了解到，关注积极事件可以提升你在谈判中的创造力和应变能力。哥伦比亚大学的一项研究发现，在参加模拟面试前，那些撰写自己拥有个人权力经历的商学院研究生申请者，其录取几率显著提高：录取率达到68%，而正常录取率仅为47%。相反，那些撰写自己缺乏权力经历的人，其面试表现则大幅下滑，只有26%的人被评委选中。

And in another recent study, researchers at Harvard Business School found a close link between positive emotion and creativity that proved to be very helpful in negotiation, especially when the negotiating parties reached moments of difficulty. As researchers Teresa Amabile and Steven Kramer explained in their subsequent book The Progress Principle , this effect is self-reinforcing. Says the Harvard Business Review of their work: “Positive feelings increase creativity, which in turn can lead to positive feelings within a team or an organization. Creativity is particularly important in negotiation when the parties are at an impasse.”

在另一项近期研究中，哈佛商学院的研究人员发现积极情绪与创造力之间存在密切联系，这在谈判中发挥了重要作用，尤其是在谈判双方陷入僵局时。正如研究人员特蕾莎·阿玛比尔和史蒂文·克雷默在他们后来的著作《进步原则》中所解释的那样，这种效应具有自我强化作用。《哈佛商业评论》对他们的研究评论道：“积极的情绪可以提升创造力，而创造力反过来又能促进团队或组织内部的积极情绪。当谈判双方陷入僵局时，创造力尤为重要。”

The process of negotiating, not to mention the substantive issues that we’re negotiating about, can lead us to feel anxious or disempowered as we prepare for our next negotiation. Generating positive feelings around a prior negotiation success may be just what we need to carry that positive emotion forward and access the creativity and decision-making capabilities that will make us successful in our next negotiation.

谈判过程，更不用说我们谈判的实质性议题，都可能让我们在准备下一次谈判时感到焦虑或无力。如果能从之前的谈判成功中汲取积极情绪，或许正是我们所需要的，它可以帮助我们保持这种积极情绪，并激发创造力和决策能力，从而在下一次谈判中取得成功。

Tip for Recalling a Prior Success

回忆先前成功经验的小技巧

We know all the benefits you can experience when you contemplate a prior success. Now I have a tip for you when you are answering this question. This is important, so don’t skip it! When you consider “How have I successfully handled this in the past?” I want you to do something before you write your answer down. I want you to close your eyes and picture it—your previous triumph—in as much detail as possible. Go ahead and play some Rocky-style montage music in your head (or out loud!) as you do it. What did it feel like? Sound like? Taste like? What posture were you in? What location? What outfit? Visualize yourself making your pitch as the client nods. Experience the relief as your spouse says, “I get it,” feel the joy of the handshake as you make a deal—or as the money hits your bank account.

我们都知道，回顾过去的成功能给你带来诸多益处。现在，我有个小技巧，在你回答这个问题时一定要注意。这一点非常重要，千万别忽略！当你思考“我过去是如何成功处理这件事的？”时，我希望你在写下答案之前先做一件事。闭上眼睛，尽可能详细地想象你过去的成功。你可以一边想象，一边在脑海中（或者大声地！）播放一些类似《洛奇》的蒙太奇配乐。当时的感觉如何？听起来如何？尝起来如何？你当时的姿势是什么？身处何地？穿着什么？想象一下，你正在向客户推销，客户点头表示赞同。感受一下你的伴侣说“我明白了”时的轻松，感受一下达成交易时握手的喜悦——或者感受一下钱到账时的喜悦。

I also want you to remember the time leading up to that moment. Picture your preparation. Your thoughts. Your tasks. Your emotion. All of this is data—remembering everything that went into your prior success can help you prepare to repeat it. Remember, when you recall a previous success, you are more likely to perform better in your next negotiation. The more you can picture it, the more you’ll put yourself back in that mind frame to achieve another triumph.

我还希望你记住那一刻之前的准备过程。想象一下你的准备工作、你的想法、你的任务、你的情绪。所有这些都是数据——记住之前成功过程中的所有因素，可以帮助你做好准备，再次取得成功。记住，当你回忆起之前的成功时，你更有可能在下一次谈判中表现得更好。你越能清晰地回忆起当时的情景，就越能让自己重新进入那种状态，从而再次取得胜利。

Your Turn in the Mirror

轮到你照镜子了

Now it’s your turn to look in the Mirror. Remember, you’ve already identified your needs and what’s brought you here. You’ve considered your feelings, positive and otherwise. Now you’re going to look at a prior success. As you did in the other chapters, create the occasion by finding a physical space where you can think and write freely, and allow yourself to consider this question: How have I handled this successfully in the past?

现在轮到你审视自己了。记住，你已经明确了自己的需求以及把你带到这里的原因。你已经思考过自己的感受，包括积极的和消极的。现在，你要回顾一下过去的成功经验。就像你在其他章节中所做的那样，找一个可以自由思考和写作的空间，让自己思考这个问题：我过去是如何成功处理这件事的？

Write as much as you can for the next five minutes.

接下来五分钟，尽可能多地写下来。

Troubleshooting

故障排除

Now let’s tackle a couple of issues that might come up when you’re considering a prior success.

现在让我们来探讨一下在考虑之前的成功时可能会出现的一些问题。

1. “I don’t have a similar success”

1.“我没有取得类似的成功”

So, what if you can’t recall a similar success? Again, like Andrew did at the beginning of this chapter, you’ll want to break down this negotiation to think about the steps this situation involves, and what you might need to be successful. (Verbs tend to be especially helpful here: researching, framing, psyching up, for example.)

那么，如果你想不起类似的成功案例该怎么办呢？就像安德鲁在本章开头所做的那样，你需要将谈判过程分解开来，思考这种情况涉及的步骤，以及你可能需要哪些条件才能成功。（动词在这里尤其有用：例如，研究、构建框架、调整心态。）

I did this exercise with a group of business graduate students in Brazil. One student, Frida, a businesswoman who was returning to school to further her career, and who had participated in the first day of my course with a lot of confidence, gave me an apprehensive look when I told the class we would be working through the questions in this book to help them with an upcoming negotiation. At first, she approached me privately to ask, “So… let’s say you’re working through a career change. Does that count as a negotiation?” I said, “Absolutely. You’re steering your career toward your goals. These steering conversations are negotiations.” She looked more resigned than happy to hear this situation counted for the exercise.

我在巴西和一群商科研究生一起做了这个练习。其中一位学生弗里达是一位女企业家，她重返校园是为了进一步发展事业。第一天上课时，她信心满满，但当我告诉全班同学我们将一起完成这本书里的问题，以帮助他们应对即将到来的谈判时，她却露出了担忧的神情。起初，她私下问我：“所以……假设你正在经历职业转型，这算谈判吗？”我回答说：“当然算。你正在朝着你的目标规划你的职业发展。这些规划过程中的对话就是谈判。”听到这种情况也算在练习里，她看起来更多的是无奈，而不是高兴。

I saw her work through her problem definition, her needs, and even her emotions. She continued to look apprehensive, but gamely wrote down her answers. Then we got to this question, about a prior success. This was when she openly teared up and put her head in her hands. I walked over so we could speak privately. She took a deep breath and exhaled forcefully: “This is the situation. I was fired from my last job. Fired! I mean, I knew it wasn’t working. Honestly, I hated the work I was doing—that’s the reason I applied to graduate school. I thought I’d have time to make my next plan. But it ended before I was totally ready. I need to accept that this happened and figure out a new direction. But I don’t have a prior success at this. That’s the whole reason this is so bad. I’ve never been fired before!”

我看着她一步步梳理问题、需求，甚至情绪。她看起来依然忐忑不安，但还是勇敢地写下了答案。然后我们问到了一个关于她之前成功经历的问题。这时她突然泪流满面，双手捂住了脸。我走过去和她单独谈谈。她深吸一口气，又用力地吐了出来：“情况是这样的。我被上一份工作解雇了。解雇！我知道那份工作做不下去。说实话，我讨厌那份工作——这也是我申请读研的原因。我以为我有时间好好规划下一步。但还没等我完全准备好，一切就结束了。我必须接受这个事实，找到新的方向。但我在这方面没有任何成功经验。这就是我感觉这么糟糕的原因。我以前从来没有被解雇过！”

We worked together to summarize her answer. She needed to (1) accept that this work relationship, which was not satisfying or successful from her point of view but was serving a purpose at the time, had ended, and (2) figure out a new, more satisfying direction for herself. I asked her, “Can you recall a prior time when you succeeded in accepting the end of a chapter and crafting a new beginning for yourself?” For a few seconds she shook her head and sat in silence. Then she looked up. “Wait—yes. Would a personal relationship count? I had a long-term relationship that just wasn’t working, for either of us. There were some good aspects, and the companionship was nice, but I knew that we just weren’t meant to be. So we ended it. I was sad, but after a few days I was also excited for the future. I knew that now I had freed myself up to be with someone who would be my ‘forever.’ I started plugging back into my hobbies and starting conversations with people that I thought might share interests with me that would make us more compatible for the long term.”

我们一起总结了她的回答。她需要做到两点：(1) 接受这段工作关系已经结束——这段关系在她看来既不令人满意也不成功，但当时却发挥了一定的作用；(2) 为自己找到一条新的、更令人满意的发展道路。我问她：“你还记得以前成功接受一段经历的结束，并为自己开启新篇章的经历吗？” 她摇了摇头，沉默了几秒钟，然后抬起头来。 “等等——是的。私人关系算吗？我之前谈过一段长期的恋爱，但对我们俩来说都不合适。这段感情也有一些美好的方面，陪伴也很美好，但我知道我们注定无法走到一起。所以我们分手了。我很伤心，但几天后，我也开始对未来充满期待。我知道现在我可以自由地去寻找那个能陪伴我一生的人了。我开始重新投入到我的爱好中，并主动和一些我认为可能与我有共同兴趣的人聊天，这样我们才能更适合长久地发展下去。”

This brief conversation helped Frida greatly. Contemplating a prior success in starting a new chapter after the end of a relationship took some of the sting out of the experience of being fired. She was able to remind herself that the work relationship, like her prior personal relationship, was mutually unsatisfying. And she remembered that she had, in fact, achieved success in designing a new chapter of her life. She decided to get involved with some professional associations that aligned with her interests (similar to the way she had rediscovered her hobbies after her breakup). And she was able to recognize that even her graduate school acceptance, and the networking possibilities it presented, was a major step toward designing that better future for herself. She stood a bit taller as she walked out the door that day.

这短暂的谈话对弗里达帮助很大。回想起之前在一段感情结束后成功开启新篇章的经历，让她在被解雇的痛苦中稍稍减轻了一些。她提醒自己，这段工作关系，就像她之前的感情一样，都是双方都不满意的。她也想起，事实上，她已经成功地规划了人生的新篇章。她决定加入一些与自己兴趣相符的专业协会（就像她在分手后重新发现爱好一样）。她意识到，即使是被研究生院录取，以及随之而来的各种人脉资源，也是她迈向美好未来的重要一步。那天走出办公室时，她感觉自己挺直了腰杆。

2. “I can’t think of a success at all”

2.“我完全想不出有什么成功的例子。”

Occasionally, I get someone who tells me they can’t think of a success. At all. Sometimes people, no matter how successful or accomplished they appear to be from the outside, have difficulty describing their own work as successful. They may attribute the outcome to other people (“It was a team effort”) or luck (“I was in the right place at the right time”). For others, their standard for what counts as a success is so high as to exclude… well, everything (e.g., “I submitted my op-ed to multiple major newspapers. One of them snapped it up right away, but cut it down significantly to be printed as a letter.”). And still others, including Michelle Obama and Sheryl Sandberg, have described suffering from a well-known phenomenon called “impostor syndrome,” in which instead of considering yourself a success, you’re just waiting for the world to recognize you for the fraud you know you are.

偶尔，我会遇到一些人，他们告诉我他们根本想不出自己做过什么成功的事情。完全想不起来。有时候，无论人们从外表上看多么成功或有成就，都很难将自己的工作描述为成功。他们可能会把结果归功于他人（“这是团队合作的成果”）或运气（“我恰好在对的时间出现在了对的地方”）。而另一些人，他们对成功的标准高得惊人，以至于排除了……几乎所有事情（例如，“我向多家主流报纸投稿了一篇评论文章。其中一家很快就接受了，但却大幅删减，最终以信件的形式刊登。”）。还有一些人，包括米歇尔·奥巴马和谢丽尔·桑德伯格，都曾描述过自己患有一种被称为“冒名顶替综合症”的常见现象。在这种综合症下，人们不认为自己是成功的，而是在等待世人识破自己心知肚明的骗局。

Sound familiar? Whether you’re dealing with a confidence gap or imposter syndrome, you might run into difficulty when you’re trying to recall a prior success in order to feel more confident and competent in your negotiations. Awareness is the first step. Sometimes just by knowing these phenomena exist, we can recognize them in our lives and start to unpack their effects.

听起来是不是很熟悉？无论你是缺乏自信还是觉得自己像个冒名顶替者，当你试图回忆起过去的成功经历来增强谈判信心和能力时，都可能会遇到困难。意识到这一点是第一步。有时，仅仅知道这些现象的存在，我们就能在生活中识别它们，并开始分析它们的影响。

First, let me emphasize that your prior success doesn’t have to be something huge, like landing the deal that transformed your company and ended up leading to an initial public offering. Take some time to think about a period when things went well at/with work or in your personal life. A time you felt proud, even in the moment. Or when you received a piece of positive feedback. Maybe that’s your prior success.

首先，我想强调的是，你之前的成功并不一定要是惊天动地的大事，比如拿下那笔彻底改变公司命运、最终促成首次公开募股的交易。花点时间想想，在工作或生活中，哪些事情进展顺利？有没有那么一段时期，即使当时你感到自豪？或者，有没有收到过积极的反馈？也许，这就是你之前的成功。

And speaking of feedback, my second tip is to try consulting a friend or close colleague—either for real, or in your imagination. What would your closest colleague on the team say about your contribution to that team project? What would your best friend say you excel at? Sometimes, feedback from a close, respected person in your life can be enough to help shake loose a prior success. I did this exercise with a friend who was looking for a new job after significant time off as a stay-at-home parent, and found himself struggling with self-confidence about his ability to interview his way back into the workforce. He told me that when he tried to identify a prior success, he drew a blank. “That’s the issue. Basically, I haven’t had a real job outside the home since right after college. I’m a completely different person now.” I asked him, “What about your at-home job? What are the things you’re best at or that bring you the most satisfaction?” He said, “Well, I pay all the bills and I’m always on time. My partner did that for a while, but I’m much better at it. So I took it over. And when our son was diagnosed with dyslexia, I coordinated all the testing. I advocated with his school to make sure they supported him in the classroom as required by law. And I found a tutor that I knew would be a good match for his needs.” In other words, my “unsuccessful” friend was a very organized manager who could handle multiple deadlines at once. He could research legal standards, make successful arguments, and coordinate policy implementation. Hearing all this from a good friend allowed him to see his prior success, and how that could translate into his negotiation efforts to land a full-time job.

说到反馈，我的第二个建议是尝试咨询朋友或关系密切的同事——无论是现实中的咨询，还是想象中的咨询。团队里你最亲近的同事会如何评价你对团队项目的贡献？你最好的朋友会说你最擅长什么？有时候，来自你生活中亲近且受人尊敬的人的反馈，就足以帮助你回忆起过去的成功。我曾和一位朋友做过这个练习。他之前在家带孩子，休息了很长时间，现在想找份新工作，却发现自己缺乏自信，不知道该如何通过面试重返职场。他告诉我，当他试图回忆自己过去的成功经历时，却一片空白。“问题就在这里。基本上，自从大学毕业后，我就没在外面工作过。我现在完全变了一个人。”我问他：“那你在家带孩子的时候呢？你最擅长什么？或者说，哪些事情最能让你感到满足？”他说：“嗯，我负责支付所有账单，而且总是准时。我的伴侣之前也做过这些，但我做得更好，所以我就接手了。后来我们儿子被诊断出有阅读障碍，我负责协调所有的测试。我与学校沟通，确保他们按照法律规定在课堂上为他提供支持。我还找到了一位我认为非常适合他需求的家教。”换句话说，我这位“不成功”的朋友其实是一位非常有条理的管理者，能够同时处理多个截止日期。他能够研究法律标准，提出有力的论据，并协调政策的实施。从一位好友那里听到这些，让他看到了自己过去的成功，以及这些经验如何能够转化为他争取全职工作的谈判优势。

Sometimes, your prior success will contain lots of clues to help you negotiate better in the present and future. But even if the success is quite different from the challenge in front of you, just knowing that you have been successful at your prior endeavors will help put emotional gas in your tank to go forth and negotiate.

有时候，你过去的成功经验会蕴含许多线索，帮助你在现在和未来更好地进行谈判。即使过去的成功与你面临的挑战截然不同，仅仅是知道自己过去取得的成功，就能为你注入强大的精神动力，让你更有勇气去谈判。

Wrapping Up

总结

With this question answered, you’ve almost finished looking in the Mirror. In this chapter, you identified a time when you handled a similar negotiation challenge successfully. If you didn’t have an obviously similar prior success, you searched your internal data bank for any successes that share some common elements with the negotiation facing you now. And you may have worked through some mental baggage in actually recognizing prior events or your personal qualities as a success. Before we finish, take a moment to read through what you wrote down for this chapter, and summarize any important points or themes.

回答了这个问题，你就差不多完成了“镜中反思”。在本章中，你回忆起自己曾经成功应对类似谈判挑战的经历。如果没有明显类似的成功案例，你就需要在自己的“成功经验库”中寻找与当前谈判有共同之处的成功案例。你或许也克服了一些心理障碍，能够真正认识到过去的成功经验或自身特质的重要性。在结束之前，请花点时间回顾一下你在本章的记录，并总结其中的要点或主题。

Next, we’ll move on to a question with which we consider the future, and get you started on designing it.

接下来，我们将探讨一个关乎未来的问题，并引导你开始设计未来。

#↩

FIVE WHAT’S THE FIRST STEP?

第五步是什么？

Mei Xu walked into Bloomingdale’s in New York City, taking a moment to contemplate the sights, sounds, and scents. Years ago, she had walked through these doors as a customer. Today, she was an entrepreneur.

梅旭走进纽约市的布鲁明戴尔百货公司，驻足片刻，欣赏着眼前的景象，聆听着耳边的声音，嗅着空气中弥漫的香气。多年前，她曾以顾客的身份踏入过这家百货公司。而今天，她已成为一名企业家。
