Mei emigrated from China to the U.S. in 1991, after working at the World Bank and training for a career as a Chinese diplomat. Thanks to her diplomatic education, which included not only English language lessons but also courses in Renaissance art—and hours spent browsing the clothing stalls that sprang up next to her middle school—she arrived in the U.S. deeply interested in art and fashion. But she didn’t have any relevant experience in that field, and she needed a job to support herself. So she took a position working for an American medical device company that exported equipment to Chinese hospitals. The work was boring, but it paid the bills.

梅于1991年从中国移民到美国。此前，她曾在世界银行工作，并接受过成为一名中国外交官的培训。得益于她的外交教育——不仅包括英语课程，还包括文艺复兴艺术课程，以及在中学附近涌现的服装摊位上花费的大量时间——她来到美国时对艺术和时尚有着浓厚的兴趣。但她没有任何相关经验，而且需要一份工作来维持生计。于是，她找到了一份在美国医疗器械公司的工作，该公司向中国医院出口医疗器械。这份工作虽然枯燥乏味，但足以支付生活开销。

Fortuitously, her company housed her in a New York City hotel next to the department store Bloomingdale’s. On her off-hours, she would find herself walking around Bloomingdale’s, looking longingly at the wares for sale. She was amazed at the incredible sense of fashion she saw in their women’s clothing, but when she walked into the home department, she saw something very different. The sense of fashion that permeated the rest of Bloomingdale’s was totally lacking in home furnishings—most of which looked to Mei like they were stuck decades in the past, like “Grandma’s wallpaper.” Mei told Guy Raz of NPR that her goal was to “close the gap between home and fashion.”

幸运的是，她的公司安排她住在纽约市一家毗邻布鲁明戴尔百货公司的酒店里。下班后，她常常会去布鲁明戴尔百货公司逛逛，对琳琅满目的商品流连忘返。她惊叹于女装区令人惊艳的时尚感，但当她走进家居用品区时，却看到了截然不同的景象。布鲁明戴尔百货公司其他区域弥漫的时尚气息，在家居用品区却荡然无存——在梅看来，大部分家居用品都像是停留在几十年前的“奶奶家的墙纸”。梅告诉美国国家公共电台的盖伊·拉兹，她的目标是“弥合家居与时尚之间的鸿沟”。

Her first step was to negotiate where in home goods she could best make her mark. After evaluating various business possibilities, she decided to focus on scented candles. She did some research and took a guess that with the right upscale look and scent, people would buy those candles not just at holiday time but year-round.

她的第一步是洽谈如何在家居用品领域脱颖而出。在评估了各种商业可能性后，她决定专注于香薰蜡烛。她做了一些市场调查，并猜测只要拥有合适的高端外观和香味，人们不仅会在节假日购买这些蜡烛，而且会在一年四季购买。

But first, she needed to figure out how to make one.

但首先，她需要弄清楚如何制作一个。

So her next step was to gain experience by trial and error. She went to a fragrance vendor in New Jersey to learn how to blend scents with wax. And then she spent weeks making trial candles in her basement, using Campbell’s Soup cans as molds and experimenting with adding scents. One day during her experiments, she forgot to add a chemical that made the oil blend with the wax. So when she took the candle out of the mold, it looked different—fossilized, or aged—due to the lack of this chemical. Mei decided to make this mistake part of her candle’s brand, which she launched in 1994: the Chesapeake Bay Candle Company.

于是，她下一步就是通过反复试验来积累经验。她去了新泽西州的一家香料供应商那里，学习如何将香料与蜡混合。然后，她花了几个星期在地下室里制作试制蜡烛，用坎贝尔汤罐头做模具，并尝试添加不同的香料。有一天，在实验过程中，她忘记添加一种能使精油与蜡混合的化学物质。所以当她把蜡烛从模具里拿出来时，由于缺少这种化学物质，蜡烛看起来不一样了——像化石一样，或者说很陈旧。梅决定把这个“失误”变成她蜡烛品牌的一部分，并于1994年创立了切萨皮克湾蜡烛公司。

Her next step was to negotiate her way into stores. Mei told me, “Taking things one step at a time is very important. I sold my candles in mom-and-pop stores because I knew that in order to survive against the big chains, they had to know the trends really, really well. I knew I would benefit from what I learned there, and that it would help me take the next step to the big stores when we were ready.”

她的下一步是想办法打入商店。梅告诉我：“一步一步来非常重要。我先在夫妻店里卖蜡烛，因为我知道，要想在大连锁店的竞争中生存下来，他们必须对潮流趋势了如指掌。我知道在那里学到的东西会让我受益匪浅，而且当我们准备好时，这些经验会帮助我迈向进军大型商店的下一步。”

Armed with her local success, Mei went to Bloomingdale’s, where she started by building relationships with the assistants who answered the phones. Every time she called or visited, she would ask them about themselves: where they lived before this job, what made them want to work in fashion. Eventually, using charm and persistence, she got them to give her the name of the buyer, the person who made decisions about what products Bloomingdale’s would order. The buyer immediately loved Mei’s candles and placed an order to sell them—in the same Bloomingdale’s stores where Mei had built her relationships.

凭借在本地取得的成功，梅前往布鲁明戴尔百货公司，首先与接电话的助理们建立联系。每次打电话或拜访时，她都会询问她们的个人情况：在来这里工作之前住在哪里，是什么让她们想从事时尚行业。最终，凭借魅力和坚持不懈，她成功地让她们告诉了买手的名字，也就是决定布鲁明戴尔百货公司进货哪些产品的人。买手立刻就喜欢上了梅的蜡烛，并下了订单——就在梅之前建立人脉的那些布鲁明戴尔百货公司门店里销售。

As soon as she landed this life-changing order, the next step became apparent to Mei. She needed to fulfill it. Fulfilling the order would require a dedicated facility to produce her unique candles, including the fragrance oil she would need. Mei called her sister, who was working together with Mei’s brother-in-law at a computer company in Hangzhou, China. Hearing what she needed, they mobilized, and in 1995, opened a factory to make the candles. The factory is still in operation today.

梅接到这份改变人生的订单后，下一步该怎么做就变得显而易见了。她必须完成订单。而要完成订单，就需要一个专门的工厂来生产她独具特色的蜡烛，包括她需要的香精油。梅打电话给她的妹妹，妹妹当时正和妹夫在中国杭州的一家电脑公司工作。妹妹了解了梅的需求后，立即行动起来，并在1995年开设了一家蜡烛工厂。这家工厂至今仍在运营。

After her Bloomingdale’s success, Mei knew where she needed to go next to grow the company. In order to reach a larger segment of the market, she would need to get into a store that presented more options for value-focused consumers, but which also had a reputation for good design. She set her sights on Target, which had 750 stores nationally and two dedicated aisles with forty-eight feet of candle space.

在布鲁明戴尔百货公司取得成功后，梅知道下一步该往哪里发展才能壮大公司。为了触及更广泛的市场，她需要进入一家既能为注重性价比的消费者提供更多选择，又以设计精良著称的商店。她将目光投向了塔吉特百货，这家公司在全美拥有750家门店，并设有两条长达48英尺的蜡烛专区。

However, the persistence and relationship-building techniques that got her into Bloomingdale’s fell flat at Target. Despite an entire year of outreach, Mei couldn’t get the buyer to return her calls. Finally, the sympathetic receptionist suggested Mei call the buyer’s boss and complain. She did. The buyer called her back immediately—only to yell at her that this was not the way to start a relationship, before hanging up.

然而，让她成功打入布鲁明戴尔百货的坚持不懈和人脉拓展技巧，在塔吉特百货却完全失效。尽管梅整整一年都在积极联系，采购员始终没有回电。最后，一位善解人意的接待员建议梅打电话给采购员的上司投诉。她照做了。采购员立刻回电——却只是冲她大吼，说这不是建立关系的正确方式，然后就挂断了电话。

Deflated, Mei waited a bit, but then she called again. And again. And finally, months later, a different voice greeted her on the voice mail. Mei received a quick call back from the new, very young buyer, and flew to Target headquarters in Minneapolis to meet with her. The buyer ended the meeting by saying, “Mei, I want to put your candles in all 750 of our stores.” Target placed an order worth over $1 million, with a forecast for the year of more than $3 million.

梅有些沮丧，等了一会儿，然后又打了一次电话。接着又打了一次。几个月后，她终于在语音信箱里听到了另一个声音。这位年轻的新买手很快回了电话，梅随即飞往位于明尼阿波利斯的塔吉特总部与她见面。会面结束时，这位买手说：“梅，我想把你的蜡烛摆放在我们全部750家门店里。”塔吉特下了超过100万美元的订单，并预计全年销售额将超过300万美元。

Mei’s series of candle experiments, conducted in the basement of her home using Campbell’s Soup cans, eventually led to the creation of her multimillion-dollar company Chesapeake Bay Candle. In a little more than twenty years, Mei went from landing on U.S. soil knowing no one but her husband, and with no design or consumer goods experience, to building a huge company that would later sell to Newell Brands, a multibillion-dollar consumer goods company, for a reported $75 million dollars.

梅在自家地下室用坎贝尔汤罐头进行的一系列蜡烛实验，最终促成了她创立价值数百万美元的切萨皮克湾蜡烛公司。短短二十多年，梅从初来乍到美国，除了丈夫之外人生地不熟，也没有任何设计或消费品行业的经验，一跃成为一家庞大的公司，并最终以7500万美元的价格将其出售给了价值数十亿美元的消费品公司纽威品牌。

And she did it one step at a time.

她一步一步地做到了。

What’s the First Step?

第一步是什么？

To end our Mirror session, I want to ask you about the future. We started by defining our problem or goal and examining what led to it. Then, we explored our needs and feelings, which helped set our priorities and make decisions. After, we generated momentum and ideas by investigating a prior success. Now it’s time to take the first step—it’s time to start designing the future.

在结束今天的“镜像”环节之前，我想问问大家对未来的展望。我们首先明确了问题或目标，并分析了导致这些问题或目标出现的原因。然后，我们探索了自身的需求和感受，这有助于我们确定优先事项并做出决策。之后，我们通过研究以往的成功案例来激发动力和新想法。现在是时候迈出第一步了——是时候开始设计未来了。

I often work with people who have correctly identified the problem they need to solve but haven’t yet figured out how to fix it completely. In this chapter, we’ll investigate the reason why focusing on your first step is so effective for negotiation success. After we explore the why of this question, we turn to the how : I will help you focus your attention on yourself, tap into your inner wisdom, and plot your first steps forward.

我经常遇到这样的人：他们虽然正确地找到了需要解决的问题，但却还没找到彻底解决之道。在本章中，我们将探讨为什么专注于第一步对谈判成功如此有效。在探究了这个问题背后的原因之后，我们将转向如何实现：我会帮助你将注意力集中在自身，挖掘内在智慧，并规划出迈向成功的第一步。

Taking That First Step Forward

迈出这向前的第一步

I like to say that every negotiation involves time travel: we need to understand the past and the present before we move to designing a better future. In this chapter, we are looking to the future. This is the last phase of our time in the Mirror.

我常说，每一次谈判都像是一次时间旅行：我们需要了解过去和现在，才能着手设计更美好的未来。本章，我们将展望未来。这是我们在“镜中世界”的最后阶段。

Asking yourself “What’s the first step?” is important for two main reasons: it builds momentum and enables the next steps.

问问自己“第一步是什么？”之所以重要，主要有两个原因：它可以积蓄动力，并为下一步行动奠定基础。

One Step at a Time Builds Momentum

一步一个脚印，积蓄力量

First, focusing on the first step can help us build momentum. When facing a negotiation or steering ourselves toward a big and exciting goal, trying to design the whole solution from the outset can feel more overwhelming than productive. And being overwhelmed can lead even the most motivated people to give up prematurely or approach things in a haphazard way. Sometimes, we need that one step to help us build a little momentum.

首先，专注于第一步有助于我们积蓄动力。在面对谈判或朝着远大目标迈进时，试图从一开始就设计出完整的解决方案，往往会让人感到不知所措，而非事半功倍。而不知所措甚至会让最有干劲的人过早放弃，或者采取杂乱无章的方式行事。有时，我们需要迈出这关键的一步，才能积蓄一些动力。

When I coach a team through a negotiation where we have multiple issues on the table, I like to have them list everything on a whiteboard for all of us to see. Then I pick one issue to start with—one where I know we are likely to have success. And once we cross that off the board, you can see the looks of relief around the room and feel the excitement start to build. We’re on our way. And that helps everyone stay motivated to start solving the rest of the issues before us.

当我指导团队进行谈判，而谈判桌上又摆着多个问题时，我喜欢让他们把所有问题都列在白板上，让大家都能看到。然后我会选择一个问题先解决——一个我知道我们很有可能成功的问题。一旦这个问题解决了，你就能看到房间里每个人如释重负的表情，也能感受到兴奋的气氛开始升温。我们走在正确的道路上。这有助于大家保持动力，继续解决摆在我们面前的其他问题。

I recently spoke to a well-known journalist at the top of her game, who has covered prominent stories all over broadcast media, but who privately has been beating herself up for several years over the one major career step she has yet to accomplish: writing a book. She told me, “I think my main talent is that I can synthesize large amounts of research quickly and digest it for people in an easy-to-understand format. I’m used to getting the idea for a story at three p.m. and then appearing on the news an hour or two later. This past year in particular, I’ve been covering some of the biggest stories out there. One of these could be sold as a book proposal pretty quickly if I got the story just right. I just need to figure out how to do this while also doing my reporting job.”

我最近采访了一位事业如日中天的知名记者，她报道过众多广播媒体的重大新闻，但私下里，她却因为一个尚未完成的重要职业目标——写书——而懊恼不已。她告诉我：“我认为我的主要才能在于能够迅速整合大量研究资料，并以通俗易懂的方式呈现给读者。我习惯于下午三点才想到一个新闻选题，然后一两个小时后就出现在新闻节目中。尤其是去年，我报道了一些最重大的新闻事件。如果我能把其中一个故事写好，很快就能把它写成一本书。我只是需要找到一种方法，既能做好新闻报道工作，又能把这件事写成书。”

At this point, she was ready to look forward. I asked her, “What’s one step you could take right now, in your spare time, to get yourself ready so that when that one big story hits, you could quickly transfer your material into a proposal and shop it?”

这时，她已经准备好展望未来。我问她：“你现在可以利用空闲时间做哪一件事，让自己做好准备，这样当那个重大新闻事件发生时，你就能迅速将素材整理成提案并投稿？”

She thought about it. “Wow. You know, I could start by writing the non-time-sensitive parts of a book proposal—like my autobiographical information and a market analysis—so that when I know I have that story , the one that’s going to be my book, I could just drop it in and send it out. This way I’ve set myself up for the thing I do best—get a story, and get it quickly—to help me land a deal. I’m going to do that this week!” Two months later, she’s nearly finished her book proposal. Sometimes, focusing on the first step helps us organize our thoughts and take back our own power.

她想了想。“哇。你知道吗，我可以先写一些对时间要求不高的书稿提案部分——比如我的自传信息和市场分析——这样，等我找到那个故事，那个能写成书的故事时，就可以直接放进去发过去。这样一来，我就为我最擅长的事情——快速找到故事——做好了准备，这能帮我签下出版合同。我这周就打算这么做！”两个月后，她的书稿提案几乎完成了。有时候，专注于第一步能帮助我们理清思路，重新掌握主动权。

One Step as Preparation for the Next

一步为下一步做准备

The second reason to start with the first step is that many times negotiation is cumulative. We can’t take the fifth step, for example, until we have traveled the first four. Mei Xu told me that one of the biggest mistakes entrepreneurs make is skipping steps in their negotiations. She knew she needed experience selling her candles in smaller venues before she would amass the experience, judgment, and proof of sales needed to take her company to the next level with a larger buyer.

从第一步开始的第二个原因是，谈判往往是一个循序渐进的过程。例如，我们必须先完成前四步，才能进行第五步。梅旭告诉我，企业家犯的最大错误之一就是在谈判中跳过某些步骤。她知道，在与更大的买家合作之前，她需要先在较小的场所积累销售蜡烛的经验，才能获得经验、判断力和销售业绩，从而将公司推向新的高度。

The same is true for the book you’re reading right now! In order to figure out the best first step for you to take, you need to do the work of figuring out where you want to go, what you need, what you’re feeling, and how you have been successful in the past. Answering all these questions prepares you to answer this final question and help you solve your issue.

你现在正在读的这本书也是如此！为了找到最适合你的第一步，你需要先弄清楚你想去哪里，你需要什么，你现在的感受是什么，以及你过去是如何取得成功的。回答所有这些问题，就能帮助你回答最后一个问题，并最终解决你的问题。

One Step at a Time: Some Examples

循序渐进：一些例子

Considering the first step can be transformative, no matter what kind of negotiation you are facing. Sometimes the first step can feel small but carry a huge impact. One United Nations ambassador, Luis Gallegos of Ecuador, told me that in major diplomatic negotiations, where you have dozens, if not hundreds, of players, people can sway the final vote by changing one word in a massive document. One small business owner, Julie, wanted to start attracting bigger work, and so after landing one large client, she decided to start documenting her work for that client on social media, so that people could see her capability. That one decision landed her multiple new large clients.

无论你面临何种谈判，迈出第一步都可能带来变革。有时，第一步看似微不足道，却能产生巨大的影响。厄瓜多尔驻联合国大使路易斯·加列戈斯告诉我，在大型外交谈判中，即使有数十甚至数百名参与者，仅仅更改一份冗长文件中的一个词，就可能左右最终结果。一位名叫朱莉的小企业主想要拓展业务，于是在拿下一位大客户后，她决定在社交媒体上记录自己为这位客户所做的工作，以便让更多人了解她的能力。正是这个决定，为她带来了多位新的大客户。

Taking things one step at a time is especially useful when you’re steering yourself toward a large goal.

当你朝着一个远大目标前进时，一步一步来尤其有用。

Celebrity trainer Autumn Calabrese has helped many people achieve health- and fitness-related goals and lose large amounts of weight. Autumn told me that she sees losing weight as—you guessed it—a negotiation, and one that is common to a lot of people around the world. She recently built a nutrition program that focuses on having people ask themselves questions, in order to take a deeper look in the Mirror and start steering themselves toward their goals.

明星教练奥特姆·卡拉布雷斯帮助许多人实现了健康和健身目标，并成功减掉了大量体重。奥特姆告诉我，她认为减肥就像一场谈判——没错，就像一场谈判，而且是世界各地许多人都会经历的。她最近推出了一项营养计划，旨在引导人们进行自我反思，从而更深入地审视自己，并开始朝着目标前进。

Autumn told me, “I try to get my clients to ask themselves the deeper questions that can help lead them to the real answers about their issue, as well as real solutions. Most people are on that hamster wheel of jumping from diet to diet. When you do that, you’re never stopping to ask yourself the deeper, harder questions about what’s going on for you.

奥特姆告诉我：“我努力引导我的客户问自己一些更深层次的问题，这些问题能帮助他们找到问题的真正答案和真正的解决方案。大多数人就像仓鼠一样，不停地尝试各种节食方法。这样做，你永远不会停下来问问自己一些更深层次、更难的问题，比如你到底怎么了。”

“And once we have those answers, setting short-term goals [is] the first step. So if your long-term goal is, ‘I want to lose fifty pounds,’ great. We need a roadmap to get there. We can’t just say, ‘I want to lose fifty pounds,’ and then wing it. I have people start with small steps, maybe one per week. So we say, ‘Okay, what do we need to do in week one, week two, week three, and week four?’ Those are small steps, and we take them one at a time. We do this for a couple of reasons. One, those individual steps help motivate people. You need little celebrations along the way, because fifty pounds is a big number—it’s not going to happen overnight, so we need small victories to happen along the way to keep us going.

“一旦我们找到了这些问题的答案，设定短期目标就是第一步。所以，如果你的长期目标是‘我想减掉50磅’，那很好。我们需要一个实现目标的路线图。我们不能只是说‘我想减掉50磅’，然后就随波逐流。我会让人们从小目标开始，比如每周一个目标。我们会说，‘好，第一周、第二周、第三周和第四周我们需要做什么？’这些都是小步骤，我们一次只做一件事。我们这样做有两个原因。首先，这些小步骤有助于激励人们。你需要一路庆祝，因为50磅是一个很大的数字——它不会一蹴而就，所以我们需要一路上的小胜利来激励我们坚持下去。”

“The second reason to do things step-by-step is that you need each step to progress. If you’re trying to lose fifty pounds, you may not be able to add in a lot of exercise, for example, until you’re eating well and giving yourself more energy. So maybe in week 1 you say, ‘I’m going to drink less soda,’ and then week 2 is eating more vegetables, and then, once you’re feeling better, the step for week 3 is walking a couple of times a week. So you have those small steps along the way that add up to the big goal. At the beginning, I think it is really important to just focus on step one. You don’t have to know all the steps yet. You don’t have to know where you need to be at month 6. So let’s talk about what we can do in weeks 1 and 2 to start getting closer to that goal. That first week is all about us talking and asking, ‘What’s step one?’ ”

“循序渐进的第二个原因是，你需要每一步都取得进展。例如，如果你想减掉50磅，在你饮食健康、精力充沛之前，你可能无法进行大量的运动。所以，也许第一周你可以说，‘我要少喝汽水’，第二周多吃蔬菜，然后，一旦你感觉好多了，第三周就可以每周散步几次。这样，你就能在实现最终目标的过程中迈出这些小步。我认为，在开始阶段，专注于第一步至关重要。你不需要现在就了解所有步骤，也不需要知道第6个月你需要达到什么目标。所以，让我们来讨论一下在第一周和第二周我们可以做些什么，才能开始朝着目标迈进。第一周的重点是讨论和提问：‘第一步是什么？’”

Your Turn in the Mirror

轮到你照镜子了

Now it’s your turn to look in the Mirror. Remember, you’ve already identified what’s brought you here, and your needs. You’ve considered your feelings, positive and otherwise. You’ve examined a prior success. And now you’re going to look to the future. As you did in the other chapters, create the occasion to answer this question in a comfortable space where you can think and write freely. Allow yourself to consider this question:

现在轮到你审视自己了。记住，你已经明确了是什么把你带到了这里，以及你的需求。你已经思考过自己的感受，包括积极的和消极的。你已经回顾过过去的成功。现在，你要展望未来。就像你在其他章节中所做的那样，找一个舒适的空间，让你能够自由地思考和写作，并回答这个问题。请允许自己认真思考这个问题：

What’s the first step?

第一步是什么？

Wrapping Up the Mirror Section: Designing Your Steps Forward

总结“镜子”部分：规划你的下一步

In this chapter, we will wrap up our work looking in the Mirror. You’ve just written down one or more “first steps” you can take in your negotiation as a roadmap for the future. Now we’re going to make that roadmap as complete as possible. Together, we will take your history from chapter 1, your needs from chapter 2, feelings from chapter 3, successes from chapter 4, and then use them to design your next steps in this chapter—putting them together in an action plan that leaves you feeling confident, empowered, and connected to yourself and your goals.

在本章中，我们将结束“审视自我”的练习。您刚刚写下了一个或多个谈判中的“第一步”，作为未来行动的路线图。现在，我们将尽可能完善这份路线图。我们将结合您在第一章中记录的经历、第二章中提出的需求、第三章中的感受以及第四章中的成功经验，共同设计本章的下一步行动——最终形成一个行动计划，让您充满自信、充满力量，并与自我和目标紧密相连。

Reviewing Your Problem (or Goal)

回顾你的问题（或目标）

First, I want you to take a look back at your summary for chapter 1. What was the problem or goal you identified? Again, all of our decisions in negotiation flow from the reason we’re here. If, like Steve Jobs, you are designing a mini-computer that people can use for every purpose, which also makes phone calls, you’re studying all the separate devices that people currently carry, and figuring out how to build those functions into your device. If you’re negotiating with your contractor to build your dream bathroom, you’re researching the latest design innovations and which of those you want in your home; if, instead, you’re fixing up your home to sell it, you’re figuring out what someone else wants—you’re looking at the bathrooms from the last few homes that sold in your neighborhood and making sure your design compares to theirs.

首先，请大家回顾一下第一章的总结。你们当时确定的问题或目标是什么？再次强调，我们在谈判中的所有决策都源于我们存在的目的。如果你像史蒂夫·乔布斯一样，正在设计一款可以用于各种用途（包括打电话）的迷你电脑，那么你就会研究人们目前使用的所有独立设备，并思考如何将这些功能集成到你的设备中。如果你正在与承包商谈判，建造你梦想中的浴室，那么你就会研究最新的设计创新，并思考哪些设计是你希望在家中实现的；如果你正在装修房子准备出售，那么你就会考虑其他人的需求——你会查看你所在社区最近售出的几套房子的浴室，并确保你的设计与它们的浴室相媲美。

You’ll also want to take a look at any history that led you to where you are today. If you’re Antonia working through a major dispute with your sister Carmen, or Andrew gathering data for his compensation negotiation, you want to go back through the brief history of your issue and consider what’s happened to date when thinking about the best steps forward.

你还需要回顾一下导致你走到今天这一步的过往经历。如果你是安东尼娅，正在处理与妹妹卡门之间的重大纠纷；或者你是安德鲁，正在收集数据准备进行薪酬谈判，那么你需要回顾一下问题的简要历史，并思考迄今为止发生的事情，以便找到最佳的后续步骤。

Looking Back at Your Needs

回顾您的需求

Next, I want you to focus back on the needs you uncovered in chapter 2. Remember that you looked at both tangibles (what you can count, see, or touch) and intangibles (the themes or values, like appreciation and respect, that give our lives meaning). These are what’s most important to you, and any steps you take should reflect those needs.

接下来，我希望你重新关注你在第二章中发现的需求。记住，你既考虑了有形的（你可以计数、看到或触摸到的东西），也考虑了无形的（那些赋予我们生活意义的主题或价值观，例如欣赏和尊重）。这些对你来说最为重要，你采取的任何行动都应该体现这些需求。

When you consider your intangibles, go back to the follow-up question I asked, to explore any specific ideas that came up under “What would that look like?” Remember that something like fairness will look vastly different to different people. For one person, it might be a $20,000 addition to her base salary. For another, it’s going to look like better placement for his art in the gallery exhibition. For yet another, it’s going to be that each spouse takes a night cleaning the kitchen. Take a look back now at the specific items that brought your intangibles to life.

当你考虑那些无形因素时，请回到我提出的后续问题，深入探讨“那会是什么样子？”这个问题下出现的任何具体想法。记住，公平这类事情对不同的人来说意义截然不同。对一个人来说，公平可能意味着基本工资增加2万美元；对另一个人来说，公平可能意味着在画廊展览中获得更好的展示位置；而对另一些人来说，公平可能意味着夫妻双方轮流打扫厨房。现在，回顾一下那些让你的无形因素变得生动具体的项目。

And then, reviewing all your needs, think about what actions you could take to fully and completely meet those needs. Remember, successful aspirations in negotiation are based on our needs, so be specific as well as optimistic. Give yourself permission to consider a world in which all your needs could be met, and then make a list of concrete first steps to get there. If you’re finding this hard, pretend I’m handing you a twenty-dollar bill for every idea you generate. Crazy, impractical—it doesn’t matter. Some of the world’s successful negotiations have come from an improbable-sounding first idea.

然后，回顾你所有的需求，思考你可以采取哪些行动来彻底满足这些需求。记住，谈判中成功的愿景源于我们的需求，所以要具体明确，同时也要保持乐观。设想一下，如果所有需求都能得到满足，你会是什么样子？然后列出实现这一目标的具体步骤。如果你觉得这很难，就想象你每想出一个点子，我就给你20美元。想法疯狂、不切实际——都没关系。世界上一些成功的谈判正是源于最初看似不太可能的想法。

Consider a now-famous negotiation success story from Teddy Roosevelt’s presidential campaign in 1912. Toward the end of the campaign, Roosevelt and his campaign manager planned for a whistle-stop trip by train, one in which Roosevelt expected to meet millions of potential voters. They had printed three million copies of a pamphlet that contained one of Roosevelt’s speeches along with a flattering picture. Shortly before they left, however, the campaign realized they had a serious problem: they had not secured permission from Moffett Studios, the copyright holder of the picture. In researching the law, they discovered that if they went ahead and distributed the pamphlets without the copyright, they could be liable for one dollar per picture. They couldn’t afford the risk. They needed an idea, fast.

不妨想想西奥多·罗斯福1912年总统竞选中一个如今广为人知的谈判成功案例。竞选临近尾声时，罗斯福和他的竞选经理计划乘坐火车进行一次旋风式巡回演讲，罗斯福预计会与数百万潜在选民见面。他们印制了三百万份小册子，其中包含罗斯福的一篇演讲稿和一张对他有利的照片。然而，就在出发前不久，竞选团队意识到他们遇到了一个严重的问题：他们没有获得照片版权所有者莫菲特工作室的许可。在查阅相关法律后，他们发现，如果未经版权许可就继续散发这些小册子，他们可能要为每张照片支付一美元的赔偿金。他们承担不起这样的风险。他们急需一个解决办法。

Roosevelt’s campaign manager, George Perkins, came up with one. But it sounded improbable. He sent Moffett Studios the following cable:

罗斯福的竞选经理乔治·珀金斯想出了一个办法。但这听起来不太靠谱。他给莫菲特制片厂发了以下电报：

“We are planning to distribute millions of pamphlets with Roosevelt’s picture on the cover. It will be great publicity for the studio whose photograph we use. How much will you pay us to use yours? Respond immediately.”

“我们计划印制数百万份以罗斯福照片为封面的宣传册。这将为我们使用照片的摄影工作室带来极大的宣传效果。请问贵公司愿意支付多少费用使用贵公司的照片？请立即回复。”

Moffett replied to the cable and said that although he’d never done something like this before, he’d be willing to offer them $250. They accepted. Roosevelt’s campaign turned a potential liability into a financial benefit. All they needed was one good idea.

莫菲特回复了电报，表示虽然他以前从未做过类似的事情，但他愿意支付250美元。他们接受了。罗斯福的竞选活动化腐朽为神奇，将潜在的损失转化为经济收益。他们需要的仅仅是一个好主意。

Looking at Your Feelings

审视你的感受

After considering your problem and your needs, look back at what you wrote about your feelings in chapter 3. Feelings—positive and negative—are part of any negotiation, and they can help us make decisions.

在考虑了你的问题和需求之后，回顾一下你在第 3 章中写下的关于你感受的内容。感受——无论是积极的还是消极的——都是任何谈判的一部分，它们可以帮助我们做出决定。

Recognizing your feelings may help you to craft better solutions. Recall the magic follow-up question that helps anyone turn feelings into future-focused ideas. If you are feeling any negative emotions, ask yourself: “What would help eliminate or reduce my [insert negative feeling] in this situation?” Recall the example of a doctor, Jamila, who is negotiating how to care for a certain patient, and who discovers that her overwhelming emotion is frustration. In this situation, Jamila may ask herself, “What would help eliminate or reduce my frustration in this situation?” When you ask this follow-up question, you start to use your feelings as an idea generator to give you concrete ideas for how to move forward. If you didn’t do this in chapter 3, take a moment to look now and see what steps would help you decrease these negative emotions. (And, by the way, you can do the opposite with your positive emotions. If you’re feeling joy at the way certain aspects of your career have progressed, try asking yourself, “What steps could I take to maintain or increase my joy?”)

认识到自己的感受或许能帮助你找到更好的解决方案。回想一下那个神奇的后续问题，它能帮助任何人将感受转化为面向未来的想法。如果你感到任何负面情绪，问问自己：“在这种情况下，什么方法可以帮助我消除或减轻我的[此处插入负面情绪]？”想想医生贾米拉的例子，她正在商讨如何照顾一位病人，却发现自己最强烈的情绪是沮丧。在这种情况下，贾米拉可能会问自己：“在这种情况下，什么方法可以帮助我消除或减轻我的沮丧？”当你提出这个后续问题时，你就开始利用自己的感受作为灵感来源，从而获得具体的行动方案。如果你在第三章没有这样做，现在花点时间思考一下，看看哪些步骤可以帮助你减轻这些负面情绪。（顺便说一句，你也可以用相反的方法来处理你的积极情绪。如果你对职业生涯某些方面的进展感到高兴，试着问问自己：“我可以采取哪些步骤来保持或增加这种喜悦？”）

Considering a Prior Success

考虑到之前的成功

Finally, go back to your answers from chapter 4 about a prior success, whether it was similar to the problem you’re facing now, or a success in a different arena. What did you envision when you closed your eyes and recalled everything in detail—your habits, actions, mental state—that led to that negotiation success? If you have a similar prior success, take a look at that again now and see what steps you took there that might work again here. For example, if you’re negotiating with your spouse on your different attitudes toward money, and this was something that worked well in the early years of your marriage, you might look back at the past and see what made you two successful at handling this issue back then. This not only helps you feel better about your current situation, but gives you useful data on what might work. You also can use this prior success when you talk to the other person in this negotiation, as evidence of an approach you know has worked.

最后，回顾一下你在第四章中关于先前成功的回答，无论它与你现在面临的问题类似，还是发生在其他领域。当你闭上眼睛，详细回忆起促成那次谈判成功的种种细节——你的习惯、行动、心理状态——你脑海中浮现的画面是什么？如果你有过类似的成功经历，现在再回顾一下，看看当时采取了哪些步骤，或许可以再次运用到现在的谈判中。例如，如果你正在与配偶就你们不同的金钱观进行谈判，而这在你们婚姻初期曾行之有效，那么你可以回顾过去，看看是什么让你们当时成功地处理了这个问题。这不仅能让你对目前的处境感到更加安心，还能为你提供一些有用的信息，帮助你找到可能有效的方法。你也可以在与对方谈判时，利用之前的成功经验，作为你已知有效方法的佐证。

And if you don’t have a similar prior success, take a look at the unrelated prior success you listed in chapter 4. If you’re negotiating your salary for the first time and that makes you anxious, but you realized in chapter 4 that you are excellent at making client pitches and convincing people of the strength of your ideas, you can examine what leads you to that success (and confidence) and see what steps you can replicate for this negotiation.

如果你之前没有类似的成功经验，可以回顾一下你在第四章中列出的其他成功案例。如果你是第一次谈判薪资，感到焦虑不安，但你在第四章中意识到自己非常擅长向客户推销产品，并能说服别人相信你的想法，那么你可以分析一下是什么让你取得了成功（并建立了自信），看看哪些步骤可以复制到这次谈判中。

What If I Came Up with a Lot More Than One Step?

如果我想出的步骤不止一个呢？

You’ve just reviewed all the work you did in the first four chapters of this book and come up with some ideas for how to move forward. Great! If you did some writing in the first five minutes you set aside for this chapter, and you’re still coming up with ideas, write them all down now.

你刚刚回顾了本书前四章的所有内容，并想出了一些下一步的写作思路。太棒了！如果你在为本章预留的五分钟内已经写了一些内容，并且现在还在思考新的想法，那就把它们都写下来。

As you’re reading this chapter, and even afterward, feel free to write down as many ideas as come to mind. By asking you to come up with one step, I don’t mean to limit you if the ideas are flowing. The idea behind taking one step is to free you from feeling as though you have to know all the answers now. Because most of the time, you won’t. Sometimes, even if we have a lot of ideas now, we need the other person we’ll be negotiating with in order to figure out potential solutions (we’ll get to that in the upcoming Window section). And sometimes, the road we’re on is too long to see the final destination. We can feel stymied trying to solve it all in one go. But even if you’re not able to design your entire future just yet, you likely have a sense of what you want your tomorrow to look like. So instead of trying to see all the turns you’ll need to make on your GPS, let’s just focus on the one that’s next.

在阅读本章的过程中，甚至之后，请随时记下你脑海中浮现的所有想法。我要求你先提出一个步骤，并不是要限制你思路的流畅性。这样做的目的是为了让你摆脱必须立刻知道所有答案的压力。因为大多数时候，你确实无法做到。有时，即使我们现在有很多想法，我们也需要与谈判对象沟通，才能找到可能的解决方案（我们将在接下来的“窗口”部分详细讨论这一点）。有时，我们面临的挑战太过漫长，以至于无法看到最终的目的地。试图一次性解决所有问题可能会让我们感到束手无策。但即使你现在还无法规划出完整的未来，你也可能已经对未来的模样有所憧憬。所以，与其试图在导航仪上规划出所有需要转弯的地方，不如让我们专注于下一步。

Troubleshooting

故障排除

Occasionally when I ask people this question, they have trouble coming up with an answer. Let’s troubleshoot a couple of reasons you might experience a speed bump when answering this question.

有时我问别人这个问题时，他们很难回答。让我们一起来探讨一下你在回答这个问题时可能遇到的几个难题。

Too Many Cooks in the Kitchen

厨房里厨师太多了

As we’ve talked about in prior chapters, one of the main reasons people have trouble thinking of steps forward is that they’re hearing other voices in their head. In other words, your older sister, outspoken coworker, or your close friends or family members have already weighed in and given you advice—asked or unasked. Perhaps they’ve gone beyond advice and even told you what you should do about your negotiation.

正如我们在前几章讨论过的，人们难以想出下一步行动方案的主要原因之一是他们脑海中充斥着各种声音。换句话说，你的姐姐、直言不讳的同事，或者你的亲朋好友可能已经对你发表意见并给出了建议——无论你是否主动询问。他们甚至可能已经超越了建议的范畴，直接告诉你应该如何进行谈判。

I see this sometimes when I teach negotiation. When I assign all the students in my class to negotiate a particular problem—let’s say a negotiation over the price for a used car—and have people meet in groups, buyer and seller, to discuss their answers to the Mirror questions, occasionally you can see on someone’s face that they are beginning to second-guess themselves after hearing someone else’s priorities. Should I be pushing for a payment plan, like this other person wants? Demand a third-party inspection by a person I alone can choose? Suddenly, their own list of needs feels less legitimate next to someone else’s.

我在教授谈判技巧时有时会看到这种情况。比如，我会布置全班学生就某个特定问题进行谈判——比如二手车价格谈判——然后让他们分组（买卖双方）讨论他们对“镜像问题”的回答。有时，你会从某些人的脸上看出，在听到对方的诉求后，他们开始犹豫不决。我应该像对方那样争取分期付款吗？我应该要求由我指定的第三方进行车辆检验吗？突然间，他们自己的需求清单似乎不如别人的合理。

And if this happens during a role play in class—which is just a simulation—imagine how much we might allow someone’s advice to sway us in real life, when the stakes can be high. So what do you do if you’re drawing a blank, or if you’re feeling conflicted as you’re writing answers to this question? Consider whether you might be hearing what someone else thinks is your first step forward. Has anyone talked with you about the negotiation you are working on? Engage with those voices in your head by asking yourself: Who are the different audiences to your issue—maybe your coworkers, clients, spouse, kids—and then ask yourself, What would they think is your first step? Write it down. Then study it. What seems right to you about what you wrote? What doesn’t resonate? This will help you develop your own critique of other people’s ideas for you, so that you can develop your own sense of what will work for you. Eventually, your goal will be to move other people’s perspectives to the side so that you can tune in to your own goals and design your own steps forward.

如果这种情况在课堂角色扮演中都会发生——而角色扮演只是模拟而已——那么想象一下，在现实生活中，当风险很高时，我们又会多么容易受到他人建议的影响。那么，如果你一时语塞，或者在回答这个问题时感到矛盾，该怎么办呢？想想你是否听到了别人认为你应该采取的第一步。是否有人和你讨论过你正在进行的谈判？不妨问问自己：你的问题可能涉及哪些不同的受众——比如你的同事、客户、配偶、孩子——然后问问自己，他们会认为你的第一步是什么？把这些想法写下来。然后仔细审视。你觉得你写下的内容哪些是对的？哪些让你觉得不妥？这将帮助你培养对他人建议的批判性思维，从而形成你自己的判断力，找到真正适合自己的方法。最终，你的目标将是把别人的观点放在一边，以便你可以专注于自己的目标，并设计自己的前进步骤。

“I’m Stuck”

“我被困住了”

What if you’ve read this chapter and still can’t think of anything in answer to this question? Read on.

如果你读完这一章后仍然想不出这个问题的答案怎么办？请继续阅读。

SET THE OCCASION, AGAIN. I want you to think once again about setting the occasion for this question. I want you to go beyond setting aside time in your day to think about where and when you do your best idea generation. Morning, noon, or night? At work, or at home? During a long run? In a busy coffeehouse? Or a quiet library? Wherever you’re most likely to generate creative ideas, that’s where you want to think about this question.

再次设定思考时机。我希望你再次思考一下这个问题应该在什么情况下提出。我希望你不仅要每天抽出时间思考，还要想想你最容易产生创意的时间和地点。是早上、中午还是晚上？是在工作场所还是在家？是在长跑时？是在熙熙攘攘的咖啡馆？还是在安静的图书馆？无论你最有可能产生创意的地方，就是你思考这个问题的地方。

ASKING YOURSELF THE WORST OPTION. If you’re still feeling stuck or inhibited, let’s play a game. Ask yourself the following question: “What’s the worst step I could take?” Sometimes, we are self-censoring what we really want. Or we need the freedom to try on a bunch of options before we figure out what works. Freeing ourselves to consider the worst-case scenario often gives us clarity on what might be better.

问问自己最糟糕的选择是什么。如果你仍然感到困惑或畏缩不前，我们来玩个游戏。问问自己：“我能采取的最糟糕的步骤是什么？” 有时，我们会自我审查，压抑自己真正想要的东西。或者，我们需要尝试多种选择，才能找到最有效的方案。让自己去考虑最坏的情况，往往能让我们更清楚地认识到什么才是更好的选择。

One manufacturing executive needed to decide whether to accept a promotion within his current department, where he had mastered all the job functions and had been very successful but couldn’t stand the workplace climate, or to transfer to a totally new international division where he didn’t know anyone and would have to get up to speed on 50 percent of the job responsibilities. He was scheduled to sit down with the two departments within a week to negotiate. When I asked him to come up with his first step, he answered, “I’m not sure. I’ve been going back and forth about the future of the company and what division will offer the best path forward for me. I’ve already gotten all the information I think I can from each of these departments.” So I asked him, “What’s the worst step you could take at this point?” He closed his eyes, paused a moment, and then surprised himself by answering, “I can’t stay here another year. I don’t have a good feeling about where my department is going. It’s time.” He accepted the offer to move to the new international division. Considering the “worst” option freed his mind up and gave him clarity that he needed to make a decision.

一位制造企业高管需要决定是接受在现有部门的晋升——他已经精通所有工作职能，业绩斐然，但却无法忍受那里的工作氛围——还是调往一个全新的国际部门——在那里他人生地不熟，而且需要快速掌握一半的工作职责。他计划在一周内与这两个部门进行谈判。当我问他下一步打算怎么做时，他回答说：“我还没想好。我一直在纠结公司的未来发展方向，以及哪个部门能为我提供最佳的职业发展道路。我已经从这两个部门收集了我认为所有能收集到的信息。”于是我问他：“你现在能做的最糟糕的决定是什么？”他闭上眼睛，停顿片刻，然后出乎自己意料地回答说：“我不能再在这里待一年了。我对我们部门的未来发展方向感到担忧。是时候离开了。”他接受了调往新国际部门的邀请。考虑“最坏”的选择让他思路清晰，从而能够做出决定。

This “worst idea” method works well for individuals, and just as well (or better) for negotiations that involve a group. In fact, some companies use this technique to help them generate innovative business ideas. 3M calls this “reverse thinking,” or “turning the problem upside down.” As an example, when pondering the issue of how to get more customers to subscribe to their newsletter, they might ask, “How can we get people to unsubscribe to our newsletter?” If answering that question ends up generating steps like, “Include content that isn’t relevant to consumers’ lives,” “Mail people too often,” or “Don’t include promotions or discounts for products we know will interest them”… well, you can already start to see what your first several steps toward the solution might be. If you started this chapter having issues with thinking of even one step forward, try thinking of the worst step, and see what ideas come to mind. You might surprise yourself.

这种“最坏主意”法对个人来说非常有效，对涉及团队的谈判也同样有效（甚至更有效）。事实上，一些公司就运用这种方法来激发创新的商业理念。3M公司称之为“逆向思维”，或者“把问题反过来思考”。举个例子，当思考如何吸引更多客户订阅他们的电子报时，他们可能会问：“我们怎样才能让人们取消订阅我们的电子报？” 如果回答这个问题最终得出的方案是“包含与消费者生活无关的内容”、“过于频繁地发送邮件”或“不推送我们知道他们会感兴趣的产品的促销或折扣信息”……那么，你就可以开始看到解决方案的最初几个步骤了。如果你在阅读本章时连一个步骤都想不出来，不妨试着想想最糟糕的方案，看看会想到什么。你可能会惊喜地发现自己的思路。

Wrapping Up

总结

Congratulations! You’ve completed the Mirror section of this book. By asking yourself these five questions and listening closely to your answers, you’ve started your negotiation way ahead of where you were before—and where most people begin. You’ve uncovered a lot of information that gives you deep insight into yourself and your issue, as well as lots of ideas for potential solutions. Take one last look over your answers and summarize any last thoughts on what you’ve discovered.

恭喜！您已完成本书的“镜像”部分。通过自问这五个问题并仔细聆听自己的答案，您的谈判进程已经远远超越了之前的阶段——也超越了大多数人的起点。您挖掘出了大量信息，让您对自身和问题有了更深刻的理解，同时也获得了许多潜在的解决方案。请最后再回顾一下您的答案，并总结一下您对所发现内容的最终想法。

Now, we move on to the Window. For some people, looking in the Mirror and talking to themselves feels more challenging than sitting down with someone else. And for the rest of you… you might be thinking, Do I really need to do this with someone else?

现在，我们来说说“窗户”。对某些人来说，对着镜子自言自语比和别人坐下来交谈更具挑战性。而对于其他人来说……你们可能会想，我真的需要和别人一起做这件事吗？

First of all, that’s a closed question, so I’m going to reframe it: Go ahead and ask yourself, “What do I have to gain by asking questions of someone else?” This is a much better question. Why? Because of course you don’t have to do anything. You could take what I call the ostrich approach to negotiation—sticking your head in the sand and waiting until the issue goes away. But you stand to gain a lot by taking the plunge. When I tell people to ask for more and teach them how to get it, this—a clear window into someone else—is a huge part of the more this approach to negotiation offers you. What is that more again?

首先，这是一个封闭式问题，所以我打算换个角度问：不妨问问自己，“我向别人提问能获得什么好处？” 这才是更好的问题。为什么呢？因为你当然可以什么都不做。你可以采取我所谓的“鸵鸟式”谈判策略——把头埋进沙子里，等着问题自行消失。但如果你勇敢地迈出这一步，你将受益匪浅。当我告诉人们要争取更多，并教他们如何争取时，这种——清晰地了解他人——正是这种谈判方法能为你带来的“更多”之一。那么，这“更多”究竟是什么呢？

  • More options for a valuable solution
    更多有价值的解决方案可供选择
  • More confidence that you can talk to anyone, or handle any issue that comes your way
    你会更有自信与任何人交谈，或处理遇到的任何问题。
  • More progress toward your personal goals, by understanding the people who may be important to your success
    通过了解那些可能对你的成功至关重要的人，可以让你朝着个人目标取得更大的进步。
  • More closeness with another person
    与他人更加亲近
  • By asking someone else questions that expand the pie of information available to you, more of a head start toward your next negotiation
    通过向他人提问，拓展你可获取的信息范围，可以为你的下一次谈判奠定更坚实的基础。
  • More peace of mind that comes with honest (and compassionate) conversation
    坦诚（且富有同情心）的对话能带来更多安心。

But don’t worry, you won’t be doing this alone. Just as I did for the Mirror section of this book, I will guide you as you complete the Window questions. I will give you an overview of how to ask each question and listen for the answers so that you get as much as possible from the conversation. I will give you some insight into what may happen when you ask each question. I’ll give you tips on how to follow up and troubleshoot any difficulties. And then I will help you use the information you gather from the Window questions to move forward toward your solution.

但别担心，你不会孤军奋战。就像我在本书“镜像”部分所做的那样，我会指导你完成“窗口”问题。我会概述如何提出每个问题以及如何倾听答案，以便你从对话中获得尽可能多的信息。我会让你了解提出每个问题后可能发生的情况。我会提供一些技巧，教你如何跟进并解决任何困难。然后，我会帮助你运用从“窗口”问题中收集到的信息，朝着解决方案迈进。

#↩

PART 2 THE WINDOW

第二部分：窗户

When people talk, listen completely. Most people never listen.

—ERNEST HEMINGWAY

当别人说话时，要全神贯注地听。大多数人从不认真听。——欧内斯特·海明威

Research, and our own experiences, show how hard it can be to truly see another person. The same film clouding the mirror and preventing us from seeing ourselves is also fogging up the window we should be using to see the person next to us.

研究和我们自身的经历都表明，真正看清另一个人有多么困难。就像镜子里的那层薄膜让我们看不清自己，也让我们无法看清身边的人。

Even in ordinary circumstances we have trouble seeing people clearly, without the “noise” of our own experiences, judgments, and emotions. Hearing, sight, and touch can fail to deliver an accurate perception. And it’s even more challenging when we engage in negotiation or try to make a deal. We often fail to hear—or worse, actively devalue—what comes out of another person’s mouth during a challenging conversation. And when we do ask questions, we often ask closed questions, which shut down communication and may influence the other person to give answers they think you want to hear, rather than what they actually want to say.

即使在平常情况下，我们也很难不受自身经历、判断和情绪的干扰，清晰地看待他人。听觉、视觉和触觉都可能无法提供准确的感知。而当我们进行谈判或试图达成交易时，这种情况就更加棘手了。在充满挑战的对话中，我们常常听不到——甚至更糟的是，会刻意贬低——对方所说的话。即使我们提出问题，也常常会问封闭式问题，这会阻碍沟通，并可能影响对方给出你希望听到的答案，而不是他们真正想说的话。

The Window section of this book is about raising the right questions and then listening to the answers. And in order to listen—really listen—to another person, we need to hear their needs, concerns, and feelings, not just prepare our response.

本书的“窗口”部分讲述的是如何提出正确的问题，然后倾听答案。为了真正倾听他人，我们需要了解他们的需求、顾虑和感受，而不仅仅是准备自己的回应。

People sometimes tell me they don’t need to ask any questions when negotiating because they “have the information already,” or “have heard it all a million times.” Not once have I found that to be true. Even with people we feel like we’ve known forever, we are less than perfect listeners, especially when it comes to the important stuff. We tune out, we get distracted, or we hear things through the static of our own perceptions.

人们有时会告诉我，谈判时他们不需要问任何问题，因为他们“已经掌握了信息”或者“已经听过无数遍了”。但我从未发现这种说法属实。即使是对我们感觉认识很久的人，我们也并非完美的倾听者，尤其是在重要的事情上。我们会走神，会分心，或者被自身固有的认知所蒙蔽。

Funny enough, I’ve found that of all the people I teach every year—diplomats, lawyers, executives, human resources professionals—the best listeners are the ten-year-old girls I teach about conflict resolution in my New Jersey hometown. Why do these girls outperform us adults in listening? They’re not thinking about themselves, while we allow our own needs and feelings to cloud our view of the people around us. This section will help you clear up your window to hear, and see, the person sitting across from you better. And when you hear better, you steer better.

有趣的是，我发现每年我教过的所有人——外交官、律师、高管、人力资源专家——中，最善于倾听的竟然是我在新泽西老家教的那些十岁女孩，她们教我如何解决冲突。为什么这些女孩在倾听方面比我们成年人做得更好？因为她们不会想着自己，而我们却常常让自己的需求和感受蒙蔽了双眼，让我们看不到周围的人。本节将帮助你拨开迷雾，更好地倾听和理解坐在你对面的人。当你听得更清楚时，你就能更好地应对。

Listening to an Adversary?

听信对手的话？

Most people understand the importance of listening to a spouse, colleague, or someone with whom they’re having an important conversation. But perhaps you’re skeptical about listening to someone you’re going up against in a fierce negotiation, thinking the same techniques might not apply under these circumstances.

大多数人都明白倾听配偶、同事或与自己进行重要谈话的人的意见的重要性。但或许你会对在激烈谈判中与自己针锋相对的人的意见持怀疑态度，认为同样的技巧在这种情况下可能并不适用。

They do. Even if you are in a true win-lose negotiation, where usually only one person can win, spending time listening to and observing your opponent will give you the greatest chance of success. It works the same way in sports. Take tennis as an example: observing the angle of the other player’s racket and his footwork, as well as listening to the sound his shot makes, will tell you whether to expect a hard shot down the line or a softer slice. You’re then better positioned to hit your own shot.

确实如此。即使在真正的零和博弈中，通常只有一方能够获胜，花时间倾听和观察对手也能最大程度地提高你的成功几率。体育运动也是如此。以网球为例：观察对手球拍的角度和步法，以及聆听击球的声音，就能判断出他可能会打出强劲的直线球还是较轻的切削球。这样，你就能更好地调整自己的击球位置。

The same is true of monetary negotiations. Rather than stating your desired monetary amount or position up front, starting your negotiation by asking questions about the other person’s needs, concerns, and goals gives you the best chance of pitching your proposal with success and creating value from a seemingly win-lose situation. Professor Leigh Thompson at the Kellogg School of Management found that 93 percent of all negotiators failed to ask diagnostic questions about their counterpart’s needs, concerns, and goals in circumstances where getting them answered would have significantly improved their outcomes. So even if you’re at odds, listening to the other side will help you in negotiation.

金钱谈判也是如此。与其一开始就直接说出你期望的金额或立场，不如先询问对方的需求、顾虑和目标，这样才能最大程度地提高你成功推销方案的几率，并在看似零和博弈的局面中创造价值。凯洛格管理学院的利·汤普森教授发现，93%的谈判者在谈判中未能询问对方的需求、顾虑和目标，而这些问题的答案本可以显著改善谈判结果。因此，即使你们意见相左，倾听对方的观点也有助于谈判。

Remember, many times your adversary at the table becomes (or stays) your partner once the deal is done. That contractor you’re negotiating with on your bathroom? Once you’ve settled on a price, you’re trusting her to build a room you’ll love for years to come. If you’re a product company negotiating with a distributor, once you’ve settled on price and terms, you need them to be a committed, enthusiastic partner in getting your product into as many homes as possible. And even when my husband can feel like my opponent (and vice versa), we’re still sleeping in the same bed at the end of the day.

记住，很多时候，谈判桌上的对手一旦达成交易，就会变成（或一直保持）你的合作伙伴。比如，你正在和装修浴室的承包商谈判？一旦价格敲定，你就是在信任她，相信她能为你打造一个让你在未来几年都满意的房间。如果你是一家产品公司，正在和分销商谈判，一旦价格和条款确定下来，你就需要他们成为一个尽心尽力、充满热情的合作伙伴，帮助你的产品尽可能多地进入千家万户。即使我的丈夫有时感觉像我的对手（反之亦然），但最终我们还是睡在同一张床上。

When thinking about your approach to a negotiation, consider to what extent you will be working (or living) with this person once your negotiation is done. The world is always smaller than you think; we’re all connected in one way or another. Treating someone as a partner in problem-solving helps you achieve your goals, gives you a reputation as a fair negotiator, and also helps make the world a bit better.

在思考谈判策略时，请考虑谈判结束后你将与对方在多大程度上继续共事（或生活）。世界远比你想象的要小；我们彼此之间都以某种方式相互联系。将对方视为解决问题的伙伴，不仅有助于你实现目标，还能让你赢得公正谈判者的美誉，并有助于让世界变得更美好。

Listening: Foundational, but Not Easy

倾听：基础，但并不容易

Listening is a fundamental negotiation skill, perhaps the most important. And because it’s so foundational to good negotiating, you might think it’s only for undergraduate students or people new to negotiation. Hardly. Let me explain.

倾听是一项基本的谈判技巧，或许是最重要的技巧。正因为它对良好的谈判至关重要，你可能会认为它只适用于本科生或谈判新手。并非如此。让我来解释一下。

I practice yoga, both for my own sanity and the sanity of those around me. One of my wisest yoga teachers once said that an advanced yoga practice does not mean one has mastered the most difficult arm balances or achieved a ballerina’s level of flexibility (despite what you might see on Instagram). Rather, it means bringing an advanced level of awareness to even the most basic postures.

我练习瑜伽，既是为了保持自己的精神健康，也是为了身边人的精神健康。我的一位最睿智的瑜伽老师曾说过，高阶瑜伽练习并不意味着掌握了最难的手臂平衡体式，或者达到了芭蕾舞演员般的柔韧性（尽管你可能在Instagram上看到过一些例子）。相反，它意味着即使是最基本的体式，也能带来更高层次的觉知。

To achieve a basic pose like Warrior Two, for example, you need to stand with your feet apart on the yoga mat, stretch your arms straight out in either direction, bend your front knee, pivot your back foot forward about ten degrees, and hold. As if that isn’t hard enough, it’s just the beginning for an advanced practitioner. When you bend your knee in Warrior Two, for example, you’re working to stack it directly over the ankle, so that your knee tracks over the middle toe of your foot. Your front thigh is working to get parallel to the floor, you’re engaging your core, keeping your shoulders down, arms level, chest open… and breathing.

例如，要完成战士二式这样的基本体式，你需要双脚分开站在瑜伽垫上，双臂向两侧伸直，弯曲前膝，后脚向前转动约十度，并保持这个姿势。即便如此，对于进阶练习者来说，这仅仅是个开始。例如，在战士二式中弯曲膝盖时，你要努力使膝盖位于脚踝正上方，也就是膝盖与脚趾中部对齐。你的前侧大腿要努力与地面平行，同时收紧核心肌群，保持肩膀下沉，双臂水平，胸部打开……并配合呼吸。

So, like achieving Warrior Two, listening may be foundational, but it’s not at all easy. Being an advanced negotiator means bringing an advanced level of awareness to even the most foundational skills.

所以，就像掌握“战士二式”一样，倾听或许是基础，但绝非易事。成为一名高级谈判者意味着即使是最基础的技能，也需要具备高水平的意识。

The most proficient negotiators are those who listen best. Research on game theory, which is the study of strategic decision-making, tells us that cluelessness, or a lack of strategic thinking, can result from a lack of sincere communication that focuses on the other person’s experience. Studies show that empathic listeners not only create better connections with the people across from them, they actually maximize how much information they take and retain from a conversation. The Window section of this book will equip you to do just that. From now on, you will bring an advanced level of listening to your everyday negotiations.

最优秀的谈判者往往是那些善于倾听的人。博弈论（一门研究战略决策的学科）的研究表明，缺乏战略思维或缺乏洞察力，往往源于缺乏真诚的沟通，而这种沟通应以对方的体验为中心。研究表明，善于倾听的人不仅能与对方建立更好的联系，还能最大限度地获取和记住对话中的信息。本书的“窗口”章节将帮助你掌握这项技能。从现在开始，你将在日常谈判中运用更高水平的倾听技巧。

How to Use the Window Section

如何使用窗口部分

In the Mirror section of this book, you worked to understand yourself and your situation better. You’ll use the Window section of this book to do that with another person. Remember again that a negotiation is any conversation in which you are steering a relationship. So, in addition to a conversation with your boss or the other party to a contract or litigation, you’ll use these second five questions in a wide range of situations, such as initiating contact with a new potential client, having a discussion with your friend or spouse, or starting a new business, before you even have a client.

在本书的“镜子”部分，你努力更好地了解自己和自身处境。本书的“窗口”部分将帮助你更好地了解他人。再次记住，谈判是指任何你试图引导关系的对话。因此，除了与你的老板或合同/诉讼的另一方进行对话之外，你还可以在各种情况下运用这五个问题，例如：主动联系潜在客户、与朋友或配偶进行讨论，甚至在正式开展新业务之前。

You may be thinking, Did I read that last part right? Can I really use this section where there is no client or another person involved yet? Absolutely. If you’re an entrepreneur, you know that one of your first objectives when founding a company is defining and understanding your ideal customer or target market. You need to steer that conversation with your future customer base long before you open your doors. Answering these questions on behalf of your future customer base is a fantastic way to do that. Go through the questions yourself, or with your team, and answer them as though you are the person your company is targeting. By the end of this section, you will have defined a lot about your customer that will help you move forward.

你可能在想：我刚才没看错吧？现在还没有客户或其他相关人员，我真的可以用到这部分内容吗？当然可以。如果你是一位创业者，你肯定知道，创办公司之初的首要目标之一就是明确并了解你的理想客户或目标市场。在正式开业之前，你就需要与未来的客户群体展开对话。以未来客户的身份回答这些问题，正是实现这一目标的绝佳途径。你可以自己或与团队一起仔细阅读这些问题，并设身处地地站在目标客户的角度来回答。读完这部分内容，你将对客户有更深入的了解，这将有助于你更好地推进下一步工作。

Looking Through the Window

透过窗户往外看

In the Window part of the book, you’re going to ask five important, open, game-changing questions of someone else, and write down the answers. But never fear: I’m not sending you in unprepared. The following five tips will help you use this part of the book to get the most out of any negotiation.

在本书的“窗口”部分，你需要向他人提出五个重要、开放且能改变局面的问题，并记下答案。但别担心：我不会让你毫无准备。以下五个技巧将帮助你充分利用本书的这一部分，在任何谈判中都取得最大成效。

TIP ONE: LAND THE PLANE. People sometimes get nervous to ask open questions, since they feel, and are indeed, quite different from the usual types of questions we ask. Perhaps you’re nervous to ask a question to which you don’t yet know the answer. Or maybe you’re intimidated by the thought of the silence waiting for you at the end.

建议一：先把话题引到下一个问题上。人们有时会因为害怕而不敢问开放式问题，因为这类问题与我们通常问的问题类型截然不同。或许你害怕问一个自己还不知道答案的问题，又或许你害怕最后面对的是一片沉默。

But have courage. Land the plane. Meaning, you ask the question and… that’s it.

但要有勇气。把飞机降落。意思是，你问出问题，然后……就结束了。

So often people will ask a great question and then do the verbal equivalent of keeping the plane in the air while circling the airport, like, “Tell me about your kids… I have a couple of my own. How old are they?” You’ve just turned an open question (“Tell me about your kids”) into a closed one that at most will get you a word or two answer (“How old are they?”). Don’t wreck an open question by adding a ton of extra words, such as: “So, Sarah, what are your thoughts on our offer? You asked why the base is lower than a few of our competitors, but I think you’ll see that our compensation structure allows for a lot of growth, and then there’s our corporate culture… Have you seen our professional development programs?” If you were Sarah, would you even remember the original, open question? Doubtful. In this book, I want to teach you to steer decisively. When you ask these Window questions, don’t add more; pose each question and wait. Land the plane.

人们常常会问出一个好问题，然后就像飞机在机场上空盘旋一样，喋喋不休地追问：“说说你的孩子吧……我也有几个孩子。他们多大了？” 你就这样把一个开放式问题（“说说你的孩子吧”）变成了一个封闭式问题，最多只能得到一两个字的回答（“他们多大了？”）。不要因为添加一大堆额外的信息而毁掉一个开放式问题，比如：“莎拉，你对我们的待遇有什么看法？你问过为什么我们的基本工资比一些竞争对手低，但我相信你会发现我们的薪酬结构提供了很大的发展空间，而且我们的企业文化也很棒……你了解我们的职业发展项目吗？” 如果你是莎拉，你还会记得最初那个开放式问题吗？恐怕不会。在这本书里，我想教你如何果断地引导问题。当你提出这些“窗口问题”时，不要再添加其他内容；提出每个问题，然后等待。让问题“降落”。

TIP TWO: ENJOY THE SILENCE. Silence can be uncomfortable. So it can be scary to ask an open question, only to be met with a few seconds of silence in response. Lots of people jump back in to fill that silence with a narrow question, or worse, a judgment. It takes bravery to ask a question like the ones you’re going to read in this Window section. You’re asking big, open questions. Give the other person, whether they are sitting in front of you or talking to you over the phone, time to consider their answer. For the listener, silence can be a gift.

技巧二：享受沉默。沉默有时会让人感到不自在。所以，提出一个开放式问题，却只换来几秒钟的沉默，可能会让人感到害怕。很多人会急于用狭隘的问题填补沉默，或者更糟糕的是，妄下评判。提出像你将在本“窗口”栏目中读到的这类问题需要勇气。你提出的是意义深远、开放式的问题。无论对方是坐在你面前还是通过电话交谈，都应该给他们一些时间思考答案。对于倾听者来说，沉默或许是一种馈赠。

An exercise I teach in my negotiation workshops requires people to pair off, with one person speaking for three minutes, and the other listening silently. Many people cannot stay silent for three minutes. Often, they don’t even know they are talking, they just do it out of habit! One executive, realizing he had failed to stay silent for a mere 180 seconds, responded by literally clapping both his hands over his mouth in embarrassment. “I know I talk over people,” he said. “But I never realized how bad it was. This stops now.” For the rest of the three-day workshop, I saw him sitting in silence when people spoke to him. At the end, he thanked me and said that within a matter of hours following that exercise, he already could see how much silence was going to improve his professional and personal life.

我在谈判工作坊里教授一项练习，要求学员两人一组，一人发言三分钟，另一人则默默聆听。很多人都无法保持三分钟的沉默。很多时候，他们甚至意识不到自己在说话，只是出于习惯！一位高管意识到自己连180秒的沉默都没能坚持下来，他尴尬地捂住了嘴。“我知道我经常打断别人说话，”他说，“但我从未意识到情况这么糟糕。以后不能再这样了。”在接下来的三天工作坊里，我看到他每次听到别人说话都保持沉默。最后，他向我道谢，并说，练习结束后几个小时，他就意识到沉默将如何改善他的职业和个人生活。

Why is it so hard for us to be silent, even for a few seconds or minutes? Often we believe we need to talk to connect with others, when silence would actually be better. Lizzie Assa, an early childhood play expert, teaches parents about the value of silence in getting kids to talk. “If parents walk in while their child is playing and say something like, ‘Oh, that’s pretty,’ they’re not connecting, they’re actually making a judgment. The kids feel evaluated and clam up. Instead I like to sit in silence and observe. The more I am silently reflective, the more likely it is they will open up. Eventually the language dribbles out. Silence makes kids feel heard.” Silence works for adults, too. It demonstrates respect, allows space for people to reflect on themselves and their situation, and can work more effectively than any question in encouraging people to talk.

为什么我们很难保持沉默，哪怕只是几秒钟或几分钟？我们常常认为需要说话才能与他人建立联系，但实际上沉默才是更好的选择。幼儿游戏专家莉齐·阿萨（Lizzie Assa）教导家长们沉默在引导孩子开口说话方面的价值。“如果家长在孩子玩耍时走进来，说‘哦，真漂亮’，他们不是在与孩子建立联系，而是在评判他们。孩子们会感到被评价，从而变得沉默寡言。相反，我喜欢静静地坐着观察。我越是默默地思考，他们就越有可能敞开心扉。最终，他们会慢慢地开口说话。沉默让孩子们感到被倾听。”沉默对成年人也同样有效。它表达了尊重，为人们提供了反思自身和处境的空间，并且在鼓励人们开口说话方面，比任何提问都更有效。

We also talk in order to demonstrate our competence or skills, especially when we feel we’re being evaluated. One executive told me, “A long time ago, when I was a new junior manager, I started holding weekly team meetings. On the occasions my director observed, I felt like I needed to show my value, so I talked a lot more. Afterward, I felt uneasy; I knew it was better when I let my direct reports lead most of the discussion. In later years, I was okay with staying silent more. Management eventually told me one of my greatest strengths was giving people space to contribute.”

我们说话也是为了展现自己的能力或技能，尤其是在感觉自己被评估的时候。一位高管告诉我：“很久以前，我刚当初级经理的时候，开始每周召开团队会议。每次主管旁听的时候，我都觉得自己需要证明自己的价值，所以就多说了几句。事后，我感到很不自在；我知道最好还是让我的下属主导大部分讨论。后来，我发现自己更愿意保持沉默。管理层最终告诉我，我最大的优势之一就是给别人留出发言的空间。”

Finally, we talk to control a conversation and play it safe. We may have been taught that we need to know where our negotiation is going at all times, or that confidence and success in negotiation is all about having answers at the ready. But the reverse is true: it takes more confidence and skill to stay open in negotiation and hear what someone else has to say. It takes preparation, too. When you’ve taken the time to uncover your priorities and then listen to someone else, you’ll be able to evaluate what they have said against your perspective, which leads to better solutions.

最后，我们说话是为了掌控对话，求稳妥。我们可能被教导要时刻掌握谈判的走向，或者认为谈判的自信和成功在于随时准备好答案。但事实恰恰相反：在谈判中保持开放的心态，倾听对方的意见，需要更大的自信和技巧。这同样需要准备。当你花时间明确自己的优先事项，然后再倾听对方的意见时，你就能根据自己的视角评估对方的观点，从而找到更好的解决方案。

TIP THREE: FOLLOW UP. When the other person is done speaking, you may have a rush of thoughts, from reactions to specific details you need to know right now! Hold it. You want to keep casting a wide net. In each chapter, I’m going to give you simple, open questions you can use to follow up and get more information. These are clarification questions, which will help the other person understand more about how they think, feel, and behave, rather than just leading them to a particular answer.

技巧三：跟进。当对方说完话后，你可能会思绪万千，从反应到你现在就需要知道的具体细节，应有尽有！先别急。你需要继续扩大信息范围。在每一章中，我都会提供一些简单、开放式的问题，你可以用这些问题进行跟进，获取更多信息。这些问题旨在澄清对方的想法、感受和行为方式，而不是引导他们给出某个特定的答案。

TIP FOUR: SUMMARIZE AND ASK FOR FEEDBACK. You’ve asked an open question, listened patiently for the answer, and followed up with another open question. Now is when you really want to give your opinion on things. You have so much to say! Before doing so, summarize what your negotiation partner has just told you. Repeat back to them what you believe they have said, and ask for their feedback at the end.

技巧四：总结并征求反馈。你已经提出了一个开放式问题，耐心倾听了对方的回答，并追问了另一个开放式问题。现在正是你表达自己观点的时候。你有很多话想说！但在发表意见之前，请先总结一下你的谈判伙伴刚才所说的话。复述一下你理解的内容，并在最后征求对方的反馈。

Don’t skip this step! Summarizing is one of the most powerful tools you can use in negotiation. It really drives home to the other person that you have heard them and digested what they had to say. Second, a summary helps both people take more from the conversation. Hearing their own words played back may allow the other person to hear information they hadn’t realized before, and it enhances your memory of what the person actually said. Research shows us that when you listen in order to understand what the other person is saying, not to respond, you listen differently, and better.

千万别跳过这一步！总结是谈判中最有效的工具之一。它能让对方真切地感受到你已经听懂并理解了他们的观点。其次，总结有助于双方从对话中获得更多收获。听到自己说过的话，对方可能会注意到之前没有意识到的信息，同时也能加深你对对方实际所说内容的记忆。研究表明，当你为了理解对方的意思而不是为了回应而倾听时，你的倾听方式会截然不同，而且效果也会更好。

We often assume we know what someone means because we understand the words they are saying to us, but frequently that is not the case. Never was this clearer to me than on my first trip to Oklahoma, eight years ago, when I arrived there for work with my colleague Shawn. After a delayed flight, we made our way to the rental car company, where a nice young man behind the counter asked me what I did for a living. When I said, “I’m a law professor,” he asked me a four-word question: “What do you teach?”

我们常常以为自己听懂了对方说的话，就明白了他们的意思，但事实往往并非如此。八年前，我第一次去俄克拉荷马州出差，和同事肖恩一起去那里，这次经历让我对此有了更深刻的体会。航班延误后，我们来到租车公司，柜台后面一位和蔼的年轻人问我做什么工作。我说：“我是法学教授。”他却只问了我一个四个字的问题：“你教什么？”

I was tired. And was used to people blinking at me in disbelief when I gave this same response, since I was early in my career, a woman, and looked pretty young. So instead, I heard him ask, “What, do you teach?” Anyone who lives in New York knows what this means: “Really? You teach?” So in response to this totally innocent question, I barked at the guy, “Yeah. REALLY. I’m a law professor.” The employee’s mouth hung open in shock, and Shawn completed my embarrassment by answering from behind me, “She teaches peacebuilding!” Summarizing what someone said is a great way to test that you’ve actually understood what they wanted to communicate (and in doing so, avoid the embarrassment I experienced in Oklahoma).

我当时很累。而且，因为我刚入行不久，又是个女人，看起来也很年轻，所以每次我给出同样的回答时，人们都会难以置信地眨着眼睛看着我，我已经习以为常了。结果，我听到他问：“什么？你是教书的？”任何一个在纽约生活过的人都知道这句话的潜台词：“真的？你教书？”于是，面对这个完全无辜的问题，我脱口而出：“是啊，真的！我是法学教授。”那名员工目瞪口呆，而肖恩从我身后插话，更是让我尴尬不已：“她教的是和平建设！”总结别人说过的话是检验你是否真正理解对方意思的好方法（这样做可以避免我在俄克拉荷马州经历的那种尴尬）。

After you summarize, you’ll want to ask the other person for feedback. I like to stick with open questions, so instead of asking, “Did I get it right?” I like to summarize and then say, “What did I miss?” In this way I’m inviting the other person to let me know what else is on their mind. Often, when I ask this question, people will supplement what they originally said with something that has been on their mind but they were trying to hold back. Feedback is important, not only to make sure you have understood, but to enlarge the pie of information so that you are steering with greater accuracy.

总结之后，你需要向对方征求反馈意见。我喜欢用开放式问题，所以与其问“我理解对了吗？”，不如先总结一下，然后问“我漏掉了什么？”。这样，我就能引导对方告诉我他们还有哪些想法。通常，当我问这个问题时，人们会补充一些他们之前想说但一直没说出口的内容。反馈很重要，不仅能确保你理解了对方的意思，还能帮助你掌握更多信息，从而更准确地做出判断。

TIP FIVE: LISTEN FOR WHAT IS NOT SAID. When someone is talking, listen for everything their body is telling you. Also listen for what they don’t say. You’re looking for body language, the tone in which things are said, and the absence of certain words. More than 50 percent of communication is non-verbal, yet many of us have not trained ourselves to focus on anything beyond the words people speak.

第五条建议：倾听言外之意。当有人说话时，要留意他们肢体语言传递的信息，以及他们没有说出口的话。你要观察肢体语言、说话的语气，以及某些词语的缺失。超过一半的沟通是非语言的，但我们很多人却没有训练自己去关注人们言语之外的信息。

One of my best students, Kate, is Korean, and introduced me to the Korean concept of nunchi , which literally means “eye-reading.” Nunchi is the study of “reading” people’s statements, actions, facial expressions, and body language, to get the fullest picture possible of what they mean and what motivates them. Michael Suk-Young Chwe, who writes about game theory, says this about nunchi:

我最优秀的学生之一凯特是韩国人，她向我介绍了韩国的“读心术”（nunchi）概念，字面意思是“读懂眼神”。读心术研究的是如何“解读”人们的言语、行为、面部表情和肢体语言，从而尽可能全面地了解他们的真实意图和动机。研究博弈论的迈克尔·苏克-杨·楚（Michael Suk-Young Chwe）对读心术是这样描述的：

Even when you know a person well, it is not always easy to figure out her preferences; for example, when your mother says on the telephone that she will not be disappointed if you do not come home for the holidays, it can take substantial effort—listening to her tone of voice and interpreting her side remarks—to figure out, even imperfectly, how she really feels. A person with good nunchi can understand another’s desires when they are not expressed explicitly, can size up a social situation quickly, and can use this skill to get ahead.

即使你很了解一个人，也并非总能轻易猜透她的喜好；例如，当你的母亲在电话里说，如果你假期不回家，她也不会失望，你可能需要花费大量精力——仔细聆听她的语气，揣摩她话里的弦外之音——才能勉强弄明白她真正的感受。拥有敏锐洞察力的人能够理解他人未明确表达的愿望，迅速把握社交情境，并运用这种能力在人际关系中脱颖而出。

In looking for body language cues, don’t assume that one expression or one body position always means one thing. For example, folded arms don’t always mean defensiveness; the other person may just be cold! Instead, try to observe someone’s default, or baseline: their natural posture, tone of voice, or expression. Then, as you talk, watch for any changes from that baseline. If someone naturally seems to fold their arms most of the time, and then when you say something they change positions and lean forward, that tells you your words had an impact. Sometimes, I can tell that people are having a reaction to a negotiation offer because they reach for cookies sitting on the table. They may change their expression, from a frown to a smile, or vice versa. All these clues give us information that goes beyond words.

在观察肢体语言线索时，不要想当然地认为某种表情或身体姿势总是代表某种特定含义。例如，双臂交叉并不总是意味着防御；对方可能只是觉得冷！相反，你应该观察对方的默认状态或基准状态：他们自然的姿势、语调或表情。然后，在你说话的过程中，注意观察他们与基准状态的任何变化。如果一个人似乎大部分时间都习惯性地双臂交叉，而当你说话时，他们改变了姿势并向前倾身，这说明你的话对他们产生了影响。有时，我甚至能看出人们对谈判提议的反应，因为他们会伸手去拿桌上的饼干。他们的表情可能会发生变化，从皱眉变成微笑，反之亦然。所有这些线索都能提供超越言语本身的信息。

Wrapping Up

总结

This concludes our introduction to the Window. In the following chapters, you’ll learn five powerful questions that will help you gain new perspective into anyone or anything you might encounter in negotiation. And armed with the strategies in this introduction, you’ll be prepared to make the most of them.

至此，我们对“窗口”的介绍就结束了。在接下来的章节中，你将学习五个强有力的问题，它们将帮助你以全新的视角看待谈判中可能遇到的任何人或事。掌握了本介绍中的策略，你就能充分利用它们。

#↩

SIX TELL ME…

六号告诉我……

Ben McAdams, a lifelong member of the Church of Latter-Day Saints, also known as the Mormon Church, is a first-time United States congressperson from Utah. And, unusual for a practicing Mormon, he is also a Democrat.

本·麦克亚当斯是摩门教（又称耶稣基督后期圣徒教会）的终身成员，他是犹他州首次当选的美国国会议员。而且，与大多数摩门教徒不同的是，他也是一名民主党人。

McAdams has spent much of his adult life working in politics in his home state of Utah. One day in 2008, he got in his car and drove to a meeting that would change his life and the lives of many in his state. And it all started with one important question.

麦克亚当斯成年后的大部分时间都在家乡犹他州从事政治工作。2008年的某一天，他开车去参加一个会议，这次会议改变了他的人生，也改变了犹他州许多人的命运。而这一切都始于一个重要的问题。

In January of 2008, the year in which the Mormon Church helped pass California’s Proposition 8, banning same-sex marriage, then Salt Lake City mayor Ralph Becker proposed a Domestic Partnership Registry whereby same-sex couples could register as partners, with the purpose of encouraging employers to approve health insurance and other partner benefits for them. Mayor Becker and McAdams hoped that this registry would help Utahns in same-sex partnerships and benefit the entire state by attracting more business to Salt Lake City. They knew there were many national companies that wanted their employees to receive benefits no matter which state they lived in.

2008年1月，摩门教会协助加州通过了禁止同性婚姻的8号提案。同年，时任盐湖城市长拉尔夫·贝克尔提议建立“家庭伴侣登记处”，允许同性伴侣登记，旨在鼓励雇主为他们提供医疗保险和其他伴侣福利。贝克尔市长和麦克亚当斯希望这项登记制度能够帮助犹他州的同性伴侣，并通过吸引更多企业落户盐湖城，使整个州受益。他们知道，许多全国性公司都希望他们的员工无论居住在哪个州都能享受福利。

But as they expected, the mayor’s office faced serious opposition, including from within McAdams’s own religion. Then senator Chris Buttars and others in the state legislature resisted the ordinance by introducing legislation that would invalidate the city’s registry and prohibit municipalities from passing similar ordinances. Many people viewed the situation between the church and same-sex advocates as a war during this time period in Utah.

正如他们预料的那样，市长办公室遭遇了强烈的反对，甚至来自麦克亚当斯所属的宗教内部。当时的州参议员克里斯·巴特斯和其他州议员提出立法，试图使该市的登记制度无效，并禁止其他市政当局通过类似的法令，以此来抵制这项法令。在犹他州的那个时期，许多人将教会与同性恋权益倡导者之间的冲突视为一场战争。

Some in the mayor’s office despaired for the future of the registry. But McAdams believed there was a way to make it work. After Buttars introduced this legislation, McAdams, who at the time worked in the mayor’s office, called Senator Buttars to set up a meeting at Buttars’s home. McAdams drove to the senator’s home that day with a strategy in mind. He did not demand or threaten. Instead, he decided to listen. He sat down with Buttars in his living room and simply said, “Tell me your perspective.”

市长办公室里有些人对登记制度的未来感到绝望。但麦克亚当斯相信总有办法让它继续下去。巴特斯提出这项法案后，当时在市长办公室工作的麦克亚当斯打电话给巴特斯参议员，安排在巴特斯家中会面。那天，麦克亚当斯带着策略驱车前往参议员家。他没有提出要求，也没有威胁对方。相反，他决定倾听。他坐在巴特斯的客厅里，简单地说：“请告诉我您的想法。”

The two men met for three hours, most of which McAdams spent most of the time listening to Buttars’s concerns. He later told The Deseret News , “I usually find that when I listen to others, we can find common ground.” In the meeting, he learned something critically important: Buttars’s primary concern was that the registry would give same-sex couples rights that opposite-sex couples didn’t have. McAdams asked another question: What if we made the registry mutual, so that anyone—same-sex or opposite-sex—could register to get these benefits?

两人会面三个小时，麦克亚当斯大部分时间都在倾听巴特斯的担忧。他后来告诉《德塞雷特新闻报》：“我通常发现，当我倾听他人的意见时，我们往往能找到共同点。” 在这次会面中，他了解到一件至关重要的事情：巴特斯的主要担忧是，登记制度会赋予同性伴侣异性伴侣所不享有的权利。麦克亚当斯提出了另一个问题：如果我们把登记制度改为互惠性质，让任何人——无论同性还是异性——都可以登记以获得这些福利，那会怎么样？

This meeting kicked off a series of negotiations that led to the creation of Salt Lake City’s Mutual Commitment Registry, an ordinance with a different name but the same substance of the domestic partnership proposal. The modified ordinance was unanimously approved by the Salt Lake City Council in April 2008, with Buttars’s support.

这次会议开启了一系列谈判，最终促成了盐湖城“相互承诺登记处”的建立。该法令名称虽与之前的同性伴侣提案不同，但实质内容相同。在巴特斯的支持下，修改后的法令于2008年4月获得盐湖城市议会一致通过。

Ben McAdams’s wife, Julie (herself a trained mediator), later told the press, “Buttars was worried about something that was not in the bill the way that he understood it. Ben was able to write the bill to address his particular concern, but it didn’t change what Ben was trying to do. Had [Ben] not sat down and spent the time to figure out what [Buttars] was worried about, they wouldn’t have gotten that far.”

本·麦克亚当斯的妻子朱莉（她本人也是一名受过专业训练的调解员）后来告诉媒体：“巴特斯担心的是法案中他所理解的内容之外的东西。本修改了法案以解决他特别关心的问题，但这并没有改变本的初衷。如果本没有坐下来花时间弄清楚巴特斯究竟在担心什么，他们根本不可能走到今天这一步。”

Casting the Widest Possible Net

尽可能撒下最广的网

Ben McAdams discovered the power of one simple, open question to transform a negotiation that profoundly affected many people in Utah. We ask questions of other people every day, and especially in negotiation. But are we asking the right ones? You already know from the Mirror section how staying curious and asking open questions can open up more information than we ever thought possible. Now we’re going to learn how to do this with someone else.

本·麦克亚当斯发现，一个简单而开放的问题就能彻底改变一场谈判，这场谈判对犹他州的许多人产生了深远的影响。我们每天都会向他人提问，尤其是在谈判中。但我们问的问题是否正确呢？你已经从“镜报”栏目了解到，保持好奇心并提出开放式问题，能够挖掘出远超我们想象的信息。现在，我们将学习如何运用这种方法与他人交流。

For our first question, we want to start broad, and ask the question that casts the widest net. In this chapter, we’ll explore the power of “Tell me.” This one question invites the other person to share with you (1) their view of the goal or problem that’s brought you together; (2) any important details relating to the problem or goal; (3) their feelings and concerns; and (4) anything else they feel like adding. It’s the negotiation equivalent of casting a giant net into the water to see how much you can catch. This question is the most important question you should use, for any negotiation, with any person, anywhere.

对于第一个问题，我们希望从宽泛的角度出发，提出一个覆盖面最广的问题。在本章中，我们将探讨“告诉我”的力量。这个问题引导对方分享：(1) 他们对促成你们会面的目标或问题的看法；(2) 与该目标或问题相关的任何重要细节；(3) 他们的感受和顾虑；以及 (4) 他们想补充的任何其他内容。这就像在谈判中撒下一张大网，看看能捕到多少东西。无论在任何场合，无论与任何人谈判，这都是你应该使用的最重要的问题。

“Tell Me”: The Ultimate Open Question

“告诉我”：终极开放式问题

As we explored in the introduction, “Tell me” is the most open question you can ask on any topic. It allows the person to share anything they want about themselves or a particular topic. No question unlocks trust, creativity, understanding, and mind-blowing solutions like “Tell me.” Open questions like “Tell me…” have been called “wellsprings of innovation” because the information they produce can transform institutions as well as individuals.

正如我们在引言中探讨的那样，“告诉我”是你能就任何话题提出的最开放的问题。它允许对方分享任何关于自身或特定话题的信息。没有哪个问题能像“告诉我”那样，激发信任、创造力、理解和令人惊艳的解决方案。像“告诉我……”这样的开放式问题被称为“创新的源泉”，因为它们产生的信息可以改变机构，也可以改变个人。

Instead of sticking a line in the water and limiting yourself to one fish, you’re allowing yourself the opportunity to find out a wealth of information and establish a positive relationship with the person across the table.

与其把鱼线抛入水中，却只钓到一条鱼，不如让自己有机会了解大量信息，并与对面的人建立积极的关系。

“Tell Me” Allows You to Learn the Other Person’s Definition of the Problem

“告诉我”能让你了解对方对问题的定义。

“Tell me” as a negotiation starter helps you get the most information possible by allowing you to hear someone else’s perspective on your problem or goal. Getting this perspective requires deliberate effort, but produces so much value.

在谈判中，以“告诉我”作为开场白，能让你听到别人对你的问题或目标的看法，从而获取尽可能多的信息。虽然获取这种视角需要刻意努力，但却能带来巨大的价值。

Switching perspective can be surprisingly hard to accomplish. Seeing things from another person’s point of view can feel like putting on a new pair of glasses: initially it takes work and focus and may feel unpleasant before your eyes adjust. But getting that perspective is important. It helps us move from a black-and-white (and often biased) view of a situation to what some negotiation experts have called a “learning conversation,” where we grow in our understanding of an issue rather than remain stuck. It gives us the best possible information from which to advocate, allows us to examine our contribution to a situation (which enables us to then change it if we desire), and empowers us to design a workable solution.

转换视角可能比想象中要难得多。从他人的角度看待事物就像戴上一副新眼镜：起初需要付出努力和集中注意力，在眼睛适应之前可能会感到不适。但获得这种视角至关重要。它能帮助我们摆脱非黑即白（且往往带有偏见）的视角，转而进入一些谈判专家所说的“学习型对话”模式，在这种模式下，我们能够加深对问题的理解，而不是停滞不前。它能让我们掌握最充分的信息来维护自身权益，让我们审视自身在局势中的作用（从而使我们能够根据需要做出改变），并赋予我们设计切实可行的解决方案的能力。

Mila Jasey is an elected member and Deputy Speaker of the New Jersey General Assembly, where for the last decade she has focused on education policy. In 2019 she won an important legislative battle on a divisive issue: salaries for school district superintendents. And she did it by taking the time to see things from someone else’s perspective.

米拉·杰西是新泽西州议会的民选议员和副议长，过去十年她一直致力于教育政策。2019年，她在一个极具争议的议题——学区总监薪资——上赢得了一场重要的立法胜利。而她之所以能取得胜利，是因为她愿意花时间从他人的角度看待问题。

In 2011 the governor of New Jersey had instituted a salary cap for superintendents, the administrative heads of each school district, saying it would save the state money. But Mila, who had previously served on a school board, could predict the consequences: experienced superintendents immediately left New Jersey for Pennsylvania and other states, where salaries were higher, and districts found it difficult to replace them. Increased turnover led to school budget inefficiencies, which erased most of the hoped-for cost savings. And most important, school performance suffered.

2011年，新泽西州州长对学区总监（各学区的行政主管）的薪资设定了上限，声称此举将为州政府节省开支。但曾担任过学区委员的米拉预见到了后果：经验丰富的学区总监立即离开新泽西州，前往薪资更高的宾夕法尼亚州和其他州，而各学区发现很难找到替代者。人员流动加剧导致学校预算效率低下，抵消了大部分预期的成本节约。而最重要的是，学校的教学质量受到了影响。

Mila saw the problems clearly, but she also knew that the salary cap had some support. So she embarked on a listening tour around New Jersey, asking families, school boards, and officials their perspective on the measure. In rural towns, she learned that even the capped amount—$175,000 per year—seemed enormous to most local families. They wondered whether more money was really necessary to attract talent. And in some of the wealthier districts, where people paid high property taxes, additional salary money felt like a burden. By sincerely listening to differing perspectives, Mila was able to generate trust and also respond effectively, acknowledging that the salaries were substantial while also focusing people on the many ways raising the cap could benefit schools, from reducing turnover to improving academic performance. She helped families think about other measures that would help contain their tax burden.

米拉清楚地看到了问题所在，但她也知道工资上限政策得到了一些支持。于是，她开始了在新泽西州各地的巡回听证会，询问家庭、学校董事会和官员们对这项措施的看法。在乡村小镇，她了解到，即使是每年17.5万美元的上限，对大多数当地家庭来说也显得过于庞大。他们质疑是否真的需要更多资金来吸引人才。而在一些较富裕的地区，由于人们缴纳着高额的房产税，额外的工资支出反而成了负担。通过认真倾听不同的观点，米拉赢得了信任，并有效地回应了各方意见。她承认工资数额巨大，同时也引导人们关注提高工资上限能够给学校带来的诸多益处，例如降低人员流动率和提升学业成绩。她还帮助家庭思考其他能够减轻税收负担的措施。

Slowly, public opinion started to change. Mila was ready to propose a bill removing the salary cap. But she needed the assembly speaker to bring it to a vote—and he wasn’t sold. So Mila decided to have one more learning conversation. “Normally,” Mila told me, “there’s a protocol of sorts in state government, where staff only talk to staff, members only talk to members, and leadership only talks to leadership. But I had a sense of who I thought might be the most persuasive influence. So I went to the staffer I know the speaker trusts most, and we had a long, open conversation. They were concerned about appearing fiscally irresponsible. Knowing that concern helped me to make the best argument: I focused on the fact that the expected cost savings from the cap hadn’t materialized.” Mila waited months, but finally, one morning she got the call: the bill was coming to a vote. No one spoke out against it, not even the districts that had favored the cap. It passed by a wide margin. The years she spent engaging with other people’s perceptions of the problem paid off in a major policy change.

公众舆论开始慢慢转变。米拉准备提出一项法案，取消工资上限。但她需要议长将其付诸表决——而议长并不认同。于是，米拉决定再进行一次深入的沟通。“通常，”米拉告诉我，“州政府内部有一套不成文的规章制度，工作人员只和工作人员沟通，议员只和议员沟通，领导层只和领导层沟通。但我心里清楚谁最有说服力。所以我去找了议长最信任的那位工作人员，我们进行了一次长时间的坦诚对话。他们担心这样做会显得财政不负责任。了解了他们的顾虑，我才能更好地论证：我着重强调工资上限带来的预期成本节约并没有实现。”米拉等了几个月，终于在一个早晨接到了电话：法案即将进行表决。没有人反对，甚至连那些支持工资上限的选区也没有。法案以较大优势获得通过。她多年来与他人探讨该问题的看法，最终促成了一项重大的政策变革。

Sometimes the Problem Isn’t What You Think It Is

有时候，问题并非你想的那样。

The beauty of “Tell me” is that sometimes it transforms your view of what a situation is about. I experienced this firsthand watching another lawyer recently when mediating an employment discrimination case, in which one party alleged he had been fired from a U.S. government agency because of racial discrimination. Months before I took the case, the parties had a contentious phone mediation that resulted in a rebuffed monetary offer and an audibly unhappy, emotional complainant. The other mediator then moved out of state, turning the case over to me. After talking with him and hearing this story, I decided to try a different tack and have the parties meet in person, on neutral ground, at our Columbia mediation office.

“告诉我”的妙处在于，它有时能彻底改变你对事情的看法。我最近亲身经历了这一点。当时我调解了一起就业歧视案件，其中一方声称自己因种族歧视而被美国政府机构解雇。几个月前，双方进行了一次激烈的电话调解，结果一方拒绝了对方提出的赔偿方案，而原告则明显情绪激动，非常不满。之后，那位调解员搬去了外州，把案子转给了我。在和他交谈并听他讲述了事情经过后，我决定换个思路，安排双方在哥伦比亚的调解办公室进行面对面的调解，地点要选择中立的场所。

An agency lawyer, who had studied mediation, flew up to meet the complainant. The lawyer gave his introductory statement, but instead of asking why the complainant had turned down the agency’s last monetary offer, turned to the complainant and asked, “Tell me what this case is about for you.” This clearly was a different question than the complainant was expecting. What we heard next surprised us all: faced with this open question, the complainant thought about it and said, “I think what I really want is to go back to work, even if that means a smaller monetary settlement. I want to provide for my family. I want my dignity back.” We ended up discussing a radically different settlement agreement, one that suited both parties better and met their interests. The two men ended mediation with a handshake, thanking each other for a productive discussion.
