一位曾接受过调解培训的机构律师飞来与投诉人会面。律师做了开场白，但他并没有询问投诉人为何拒绝了机构上次提出的赔偿方案，而是转向投诉人问道：“告诉我，对你而言，这个案子的意义何在？”这显然与投诉人预想的问题截然不同。接下来发生的事让我们所有人都感到惊讶：面对这个开放式的问题，投诉人沉思片刻后说道：“我想我真正想要的是重返工作岗位，即便这意味着赔偿金额会减少。我想养家糊口，我想重拾尊严。”最终，我们讨论了一份截然不同的和解协议，这份协议更符合双方的利益。两人握手结束了调解，并互相感谢对方富有成效的讨论。

By starting your negotiation with “Tell me…” you are stepping into the other person’s shoes and allowing yourself to learn from the conversation. But that’s not all you get from asking this question.

以“告诉我……”开头进行谈判，意味着你站在对方的角度思考问题，并能从对话中学习。但这并非提出这个问题所能获得的全部益处。

“Tell Me” Builds a Relationship with the Person across from You

“告诉我”这句话能与你对面的人建立联系。

Terry Gross, the renowned interviewer for National Public Radio, has said that “Tell me about yourself” is the only ice-breaker you need for an interview or conversation. In a New York Times profile of Gross, she elaborates, “The beauty in opening with ‘tell me about yourself’ is that it allows you to start a conversation without the fear that you’re going to inadvertently make someone uncomfortable or self-conscious. Posing a broad question lets people lead you to who they are.”

美国国家公共广播电台（NPR）著名访谈主持人特里·格罗斯曾说过，“请介绍一下你自己”是开启采访或对话的唯一破冰方式。在《纽约时报》对格罗斯的专访中，她进一步阐述道：“以‘请介绍一下你自己’作为开场白的妙处在于，它让你能够轻松开启对话，而不用担心会无意中让对方感到不自在或尴尬。提出一个宽泛的问题，可以让对方引导你了解他们。”

When the person across from you feels as though you’re making a genuine effort to understand them and their perspective, rather than just pushing your own agenda, they’ll share more with you and be more open to what you have to say. “Tell me” not only allows you to see the person as they are; it also implicitly puts you on the same level as the person across from you, and invites that person into a conversational partnership with you that encourages greater trust and openness.

当你对面的人感受到你真心实意地想要理解他们和他们的观点，而不是仅仅推销自己的观点时，他们会更愿意与你分享，也更愿意倾听你的想法。“告诉我”不仅能让你看到对方的真实面貌，还能让你与对方建立起平等的关系，并邀请对方与你进行对话，从而增进彼此的信任和坦诚。

“Tell me” also communicates confidence in a way that helps you build rapport with your negotiation partner. The best negotiators are those who are comfortable enough to listen, stay open, and not just stick to a script of points they want to make. One of my students at Columbia received job offers from every single firm to which she applied, and while she had been a smart student, she hadn’t achieved academic honors, a common prerequisite for interviewing success at the top law firms. When I asked her how she had been so successful, she told me that she had used the “tell me” prompt, asking the interviewer about themselves and their path at the organization. She said, “I wanted to hear about them at least as much as they heard about me. And after they told me about themselves and the firm, I would summarize and pick out some themes in what they said that connected up with what interested me about the firm, or what I could bring to the table. A number of those interviewers told me afterward that my interview was one of the best they’d ever had, because I had the confidence to treat the interview like we were partners in the conversation. I showed that I could listen on the spot, really understand them, and then manage a conversation successfully. And that told them I’d be successful with their clients, too.”

“告诉我”也能传递自信，帮助你与谈判伙伴建立融洽的关系。优秀的谈判者懂得倾听，保持开放的心态，而不是固守自己预设的观点。我在哥伦比亚大学的一位学生收到了她申请的所有律所的录用通知。虽然她学习成绩优异，但并没有获得学术荣誉——这通常是顶尖律所面试成功的必要条件。当我问她成功的秘诀时，她告诉我，她使用了“告诉我”这个开场白，询问面试官关于他们自身以及他们在公司发展历程的信息。她说：“我希望了解他们的程度至少和他们了解我的程度一样多。在他们介绍完自己和公司之后，我会总结并提炼出一些与我对公司感兴趣的地方或我能为公司带来的价值相关的要点。很多面试官事后都告诉我，我的面试是他们经历过的最好的面试之一，因为我自信地把面试当成是对话中的伙伴。我展现出了能够当场倾听、真正理解他们，并成功掌控对话的能力。这让他们相信，我也能成功地服务他们的客户。”

Using “Tell Me” as the First Question in Every Negotiation

在每次谈判中都以“告诉我”作为第一个问题

“Tell me” works as a first question not just in a formal business setting when you don’t know the other person well, but also across virtually every kind of negotiation.

“告诉我”不仅适用于你不太了解对方的正式商务场合，而且几乎适用于所有类型的谈判，都可以作为第一个问题。

When Jamie, a successful family photographer with a social work background, prepares to do a photo session with a family she hasn’t met before, the first question she asks is “Tell me about your family.” She told me, “You’d be surprised at what you learn when you ask that question. Sometimes one parent is nervous about posing for pictures and may want some coaching, sometimes the kid has a neurodevelopmental issue that makes it hard for them to look at the camera. When I start with this question, I get the most information possible, and that helps me get to know this family and what they are hoping for from their photos.”

杰米是一位成功的家庭摄影师，拥有社会工作背景。每当她准备为一个素未谋面的家庭拍摄照片时，她问的第一个问题总是“请介绍一下你们的家庭”。她告诉我：“你会惊讶于问这个问题能了解到多少信息。有时，父母一方会因为不习惯摆姿势而感到紧张，可能需要一些指导；有时，孩子可能存在神经发育问题，难以直视镜头。当我以这个问题作为开场白时，我能获得尽可能多的信息，这有助于我了解这个家庭以及他们对照片的期望。”

Likewise, Amy, an experienced physical therapist, uses “Tell me” to gain a patient’s trust and define treatment goals. She explains, “Lots of people are scared about physical therapy. They’re worried it might hurt, or they’re intimidated by the work of rehabbing from a surgery or injury. So to start out a conversation with a new client, I might ask, ‘Tell me about your day-to-day,’ or ‘Tell me about yourself.’ If they say they like to read and enjoy going to the library, but they’re having trouble getting there, okay, we can work on that. The most important thing is to gain their trust. Because then we can work together. I know they’ll be more likely to tell me if something hurts, or if they feel they’ve overdone it one week. It’s important for me to know what they enjoy, what motivates them. Because if we link the work to something they love, it all becomes that much easier.”

同样，经验丰富的理疗师艾米也运用“告诉我”这个方法来赢得患者的信任并制定治疗目标。她解释说：“很多人害怕理疗。他们担心会疼，或者害怕术后或受伤后的康复过程。所以，在和新患者开始对话时，我可能会问：‘跟我说说你的日常生活吧’，或者‘跟我说说你自己吧’。如果他们说喜欢阅读，喜欢去图书馆，但去图书馆有困难，没关系，我们可以一起想办法解决这个问题。最重要的是赢得他们的信任。因为只有这样我们才能一起努力。我知道，如果哪里疼，或者感觉哪周运动过度，他们更愿意告诉我。了解他们的喜好和动力对我来说很重要。因为如果我们把治疗和他们喜欢的事情联系起来，一切都会变得容易得多。”

Using “Tell Me…” with Loved Ones

与亲人使用“告诉我……”

It takes practice to ask “Tell me…” of the people closest to us. Even as a trained mediator, I realized in shame one day that I had been coming home every day and asking my spouse, “How was your day?” Sometimes the response I got was, “Pretty good,” and other times only a shrug as he sorted through the day’s mail. Why? I was asking him a completely closed (not to mention rote) question! The day I finally decided to practice at home what I preached in the office, I arrived home from work and said, “Tell me all about your day.” I was surprised at how much he opened up. He was wrapping up a difficult work project and stressed about it. The trains had been late getting into the office, but he ran into one of our classmates from law school and got a chance to catch up. He’d had a good morning workout and was feeling strong. And so on. These days, “Tell me…” is the number one question I ask my spouse, on almost every occasion.

向我们最亲近的人提出“跟我说说……”这样的问题需要练习。即使作为一名受过专业训练的调解员，有一天我羞愧地意识到，我每天回家都会问我的伴侣：“你今天过得怎么样？”有时他的回答是“还不错”，有时他只是耸耸肩，一边整理当天的邮件。为什么呢？因为我问了他一个完全封闭（更不用说机械）的问题！终于有一天，我决定在家实践我在办公室里倡导的原则。我下班回家后说：“跟我说说你今天都做了些什么吧。”我惊讶地发现他敞开了心扉。他正在收尾一个棘手的工作项目，为此感到压力很大。火车晚点了，但他碰巧遇到了我们法学院的一位同学，有机会聊了一会儿。他早上锻炼了一下，感觉精力充沛。等等。如今，“跟我说说……”几乎成了我问伴侣的首要问题。

I’ve also used this prompt with my eight-year-old daughter and remember a specific occasion when her answer to this question took me by surprise. I had taken her to a swim meet at the local pool. After a long day of swimming, she came out of the locker room in the evening in tears. I asked her what was wrong. She said, “Mom, at this pool you need to share showers. Another girl came in while I was showering. It was so awkward!” I paused for a moment. Internally, I wondered, “Could she be feeling awkward about her body? Are we at the point where she wants more privacy?” But I stayed in the moment with her, and simply asked, “Can you tell me what made it awkward?” She huffed at me. “Mom, isn’t it obvious?” I said, “I’m not sure. Tell me what made it awkward for you.” She responded, rolling her eyes, “We wanted our shower at different temperatures.”

我也用这个方法问过我八岁的女儿，记得有一次她的回答让我很意外。那天我带她去当地游泳池参加游泳比赛。游了一整天后，晚上她从更衣室出来时哭了起来。我问她怎么了。她说：“妈妈，这个游泳池要共用淋浴间。我洗澡的时候，另一个女孩进来了。太尴尬了！”我愣了一下。心里想着：“她是不是对自己的身材感到不自在？是不是到了她想要更多隐私的地步了？”但我还是没有离开她，只是问：“你能告诉我哪里尴尬吗？”她哼了一声。“妈妈，这不是很明显吗？”我说：“我不确定。告诉我，你觉得哪里尴尬。”她翻了个白眼，回答说：“我们想要不同的水温。”

“Tell me…” allows us to hear what our partner or kids are actually thinking, instead of suggesting the answer we think is right. When sincerely asked, it also registers as genuine in a way that encourages an actual answer.

“告诉我……”这句话能让我们听到伴侣或孩子真实的想法，而不是强加我们认为正确的答案。真诚地问出这句话，也能让对方感受到你的诚意，从而鼓励他们给出真实的回答。

Your Turn: How to Ask This Question

轮到你了：如何提出这个问题

Now that we know why we are asking this question—to learn more and build better relationships—we’re going to work together on how to ask it.

既然我们知道了为什么要问这个问题——为了了解更多信息并建立更好的关系——我们将共同努力，探讨如何提出这个问题。

You’re going to ask the other person to tell you their perspective on the situation you’re discussing. How exactly you pose the question depends on the type of negotiation. Here are some examples of what “Tell me…” can look like depending on the situation.

你要请对方谈谈他们对你们讨论的情况的看法。具体如何提问取决于谈判的类型。以下是一些“告诉我……”的提问方式示例，具体形式取决于具体情况。

When You’ve Initiated the Negotiation

当你发起谈判时

If you’ve initiated the negotiation, you will want to frame the issue first, and then ask the other person to tell you their perspective. Before you ask the question, you will explain the reason you asked for the conversation, as briefly as possible, and let the other person know the issue on which you’d like to hear their perspective.

如果你主动发起谈判，首先要明确问题所在，然后再请对方阐述他们的观点。在提问之前，你要尽可能简明扼要地说明发起对话的原因，并让对方知道你想听取他们意见的具体问题。

For example, Brittani has asked the CEO of her start-up company to meet with her to discuss compensation. She has been with the company for a year as the VP of sales for her region, and has wildly exceeded every sales benchmark, winning several major deals that have set her company up to raise even more money. With her company heading into meetings for its next round of investors, Brittani has telegraphed to management that she’d like to discuss her results and a larger equity stake in the company. So her Window conversation may start as follows: “Thanks so much for making time for me today. I asked for a meeting because, as I think you know, I’d like to discuss my progress at the company and compensation package going forward. When I signed on last year, we had an agreement that we would review my terms after I’d been with the company for a year and we had some results to discuss. I’m very pleased with how things have gone and I’m eager to make my long-term home here. But before we get down to discussing the future, I’d love it if you could tell me , from your perspective, how things have gone this past year.” In this way, Brittani has framed the issue in a way that sets herself up for success, but also provides an open space for her CEO to share information to round out the picture.

例如，布里塔尼已经要求她所在初创公司的首席执行官与她会面，讨论薪酬事宜。她担任公司区域销售副总裁已有一年，业绩远超各项销售目标，并赢得了几笔大单，为公司筹集更多资金奠定了基础。随着公司即将召开下一轮融资会议，布里塔尼已向管理层表示，她希望讨论自己的业绩以及获得公司更多股权的可能性。所以，她的窗口对话可能会这样开始：“非常感谢您今天抽出时间与我见面。我想您也知道，我之所以提出这次会面，是因为我想和您讨论一下我在公司的工作进展以及未来的薪酬方案。去年我入职时，我们约定在我入职一年并取得一些业绩后，我们会重新评估我的待遇。我对目前的工作进展非常满意，也渴望在这里长期发展。但在我们深入探讨未来之前，我想请您从您的角度谈谈过去一年的情况。” 这样，布里塔尼巧妙地提出了一个有利于自己成功沟通的问题，同时也为她的首席执行官提供了一个开放的空间，让他可以分享信息，从而更全面地了解情况。

When Someone Else Has Initiated the Negotiation

当谈判由他人发起时

For a meeting with a boss, client, or family member where you’re not sure of the topic, you might begin by saying something like: “You asked to meet with me today. Tell me what’s on your mind.” Or “Tell me your hopes for this meeting.”

如果你要和老板、客户或家人见面，但不确定谈话主题，你可以这样开头：“你今天约我见面，说说你有什么想法吧。”或者“告诉我你对这次会面有什么期望。”

When You’ve Both Agreed to Discuss a Particular Topic

当你们双方都同意讨论某个特定话题时

If you are sitting down with someone by mutual agreement, with a specific topic in mind—for example, your performance at work or a difficult argument at home—you want to ask the broadest possible “tell me” question about that topic: “Tell me your perspective on what’s been happening recently.” “Tell me about the position you’re looking to fill.” “Tell me your thoughts on the settlement.” When in doubt, a great way to start the conversation can be something as simple as “Tell me your perspective.”

如果你和某人经双方同意坐下来，讨论某个特定话题——例如，你的工作表现或家中的棘手争吵——你应该就此话题提出尽可能宽泛的“请告诉我”式问题：“请谈谈您对最近发生的事情的看法。”“请谈谈您正在招聘的职位。”“请谈谈您对和解的看法。” 如果拿不定主意，不妨用“请谈谈您的看法”这样简单的开场白来开启对话。

Land the Plane

降落飞机

Remember this tip from the Window introduction? Here’s where you start to put it into practice. Landing the plane means that you ask your “Tell me…” question and then wait. Landing the plane is critically important for this question! This is your first Window question, and it’s meant to be extremely broad.

还记得窗口介绍里提到的那个技巧吗？现在就要开始实践了。所谓“降落飞机”，是指你问出“告诉我……”的问题，然后等待。对这个问题来说，“降落飞机”至关重要！这是你的第一个窗口问题，它应该非常宽泛。

Don’t add another question on the end. I have seen countless people say things like, “Tell me what’s brought you here… Have you made an offer yet?” You’ve taken a great open question and completely closed it. Instead of staying open to what the person had to say about their situation as a whole, you’ve now told them you’re just here to talk numbers. Ask your question and then keep your lips closed.

别在最后再加问题。我见过无数人说类似这样的话：“告诉我你来这里的原因……你出价了吗？” 你把一个很好的开放式问题彻底扼杀了。你没有继续倾听对方的整体情况，而是告诉他们你只是来谈数字的。问完问题就闭嘴吧。

Enjoy the Silence

享受安静

Often we are scared of silence. We fear that we won’t be prepared for what’s on the other side of that silence. We fear the other person may feel pressured or burdened by the pause in conversation. But “Tell me” is a big, important question. It may take time for the other person to consider their answer. Give them that time. If you’re nervous, try counting in your head while you maintain eye contact and a positive expression. Challenge yourself to see how high you can go before you break the silence. If you’re on the phone, you can take this moment to stretch or just fix your gaze out the window.

我们常常害怕沉默。我们害怕自己无法预料沉默之后会发生什么。我们害怕对方会因为谈话的停顿而感到压力或负担。但“告诉我”是一个重要而深刻的问题。对方可能需要时间思考答案。给他们一些时间。如果你感到紧张，可以尝试在保持眼神交流和积极表情的同时，在心中默数。挑战一下自己，看看在打破沉默之前你能数到多高。如果你正在打电话，可以利用这段时间伸展一下身体，或者只是看看窗外。

You know who often requires the most time to answer this question? Kids. The first time I asked my daughter, “Tell me all about your day!” I waited for her to answer. And when I tell you I waited, I mean I waited minutes while my daughter doodled in a notebook, walked around the kitchen, and then started playing with some slime she had made at summer camp. For a moment, I thought to myself, Well, that flopped! But I stayed silent.

你知道谁最难回答这个问题吗？孩子。我第一次问女儿“跟我说说你今天都做了些什么！”的时候，等了好一会儿她才回答。我说等，可不是随便说说，我等了足足几分钟，女儿一会儿在笔记本上涂鸦，一会儿在厨房里走来走去，一会儿又开始玩她在夏令营做的史莱姆。那一刻，我心想：完了，这下彻底没戏了！但我还是保持沉默。

Then, slowly but surely, the trickle of information started. She’d had a substitute counselor. The sub told the kids to be quiet a lot. Someone got in trouble. She ate pizza for lunch. Could we work together on an art project?… And just like that, we were off to the races. Silence works.

然后，消息开始慢慢地、一点一点地流传开来。她换了个代课辅导员。代课辅导员老是让孩子们安静。有人惹了麻烦。她午饭吃了披萨。我们能一起做个艺术项目吗？……就这样，我们开始了合作。沉默真的管用。

Follow Up

跟进

If my favorite question is “Tell me,” can you guess my second favorite?

如果我最喜欢的问题是“告诉我”，你能猜出我第二喜欢的问题是什么吗？

“Tell me more…”

“请告诉我更多……”

That’s right. Let’s say you’ve asked someone, “Tell me,” and heard a bunch of information in response. After you ask someone to tell you their perspective on a situation or topic, you then will want to follow up and get more information about any valuable topics or insight they offer in response. So once you’ve heard the person out, you’ll want to continue by summarizing what they said and then asking “Tell me more” questions about aspects of what they told you.

没错。假设你问了某人“告诉我”，然后听到了一堆信息。在你请别人谈谈他们对某个情况或话题的看法之后，你肯定会想跟进，了解更多关于他们提供的有价值的信息或见解。所以，在听完对方的发言后，你应该总结他们所说的话，然后就他们提到的某些方面提出“请继续说”之类的问题。

For example, in a conversation with a direct report about changes they’d like to make to their position at work, you might say, “So you’re seeking more client contact as well as the greater feeling of autonomy you had in your previous position. Can you tell me more about that prior position?” By asking “Tell me more,” you keep the person talking and get more detailed information without resorting to yes-or-no questions that shut the conversation down.

例如，在与下属讨论他们希望对工作岗位做出哪些调整时，你可以这样说：“所以你希望有更多机会接触客户，同时也希望拥有之前职位上那种更大的自主权。你能详细说说之前的职位吗？” 通过问“请详细说说”，你可以引导对方继续发言，获取更详细的信息，而无需使用那些容易导致对话中断的“是/否”式问题。

Imagine you’ve gone fishing off the coast of your favorite body of water. You’ve cast your net wide and hauled in twenty fish, along with seaweed and some other stuff. You’re going to take a minute to sort through your catch and separate the fish from the stuff you’re going to throw back or away. And now I want you to look at those twenty fish. Each of those fish is valuable. When you ask this question and hear some valuable information, I want you to treat each topic as a “fish” you’ve hauled into your net. For each topic where you’d like more information, you’re going to follow up and ask the person to tell you more about that topic.

想象一下，你到你最喜欢的水域附近钓鱼。你撒网很广，捞起了二十条鱼，还有海藻和其他一些东西。你花点时间整理一下渔获，把鱼和要扔掉的东西分开。现在，我想让你看看这二十条鱼。每一条鱼都很有价值。当你问这个问题并听到一些有价值的信息时，我希望你把每个话题都当作你网里的一条“鱼”。对于每个你想了解更多信息的话题，你都要继续追问，请对方详细解释一下。

So let’s say, for example, that you’ve asked me to tell you about my last trip to India. In response I say, “It was great! We held a Peace Summit in which we convened together ambassadors from a number of countries with Indian government leaders and some CEOs of private companies to talk about public-private partnerships for peacebuilding. My students did a fantastic job with the research and also assisted in the teaching. We stayed at a lovely hotel that had these gorgeous gardens; I tried to spend a few minutes there every day. I managed to call home every day, but sometimes my daughter was too tired to talk. That was rough, because I missed her a lot, especially in the last days of the trip. Toward the end, we spent a couple of days traveling to the Taj Mahal. Hopefully we’ll be able to do this summit again every year.”

比如说，你让我说说我上次去印度的经历。我会回答说：“太棒了！我们举办了一次和平峰会，邀请了多国大使、印度政府领导人和一些私营企业首席执行官，共同探讨如何通过公私合作促进和平建设。我的学生们在调研方面做得非常出色，也协助了教学工作。我们住在一个很棒的酒店，酒店花园非常漂亮；我尽量每天都去那里待一会儿。我每天都给家里打电话，但有时女儿太累了，没法接。这让我很难过，因为我非常想念她，尤其是在旅程的最后几天。临近行程结束时，我们花了几天时间游览了泰姬陵。希望以后每年都能举办这样的峰会。”

Okay, you’ve just heard a lot of information in response to this question. Some of the things I talked about were:

好的，你刚才已经听到了很多关于这个问题的回答。我谈到的一些内容包括：

  • This year’s Peace Summit
    今年的和平峰会
  • My students
    我的学生
  • The hotel and gardens
    酒店和花园
  • • My sadness at missing my daughter
    • 我因思念女儿而感到悲伤
  • The Taj Mahal
    泰姬陵
  • My hopes for the future of the summit
    我对峰会未来的期望

Let’s say for purposes of this conversation that you’re interested in talking more about the work aspects of my trip. You would then pick those topics and say, “Tell me more about the summit this year,” or “Tell me more about your students’ roles on the trip.” If you were interested in some of the non-work parts of my trip, too, you might also ask me to tell you more about the Taj Mahal.

假设为了方便谈话，您对我的行程中的工作方面更感兴趣。那么您可以选择相关话题，例如：“请您详细介绍一下今年的峰会”，或者“请您详细介绍一下您的学生在这次行程中的角色”。如果您也对我的行程中的非工作方面感兴趣，您可能还会请我详细介绍一下泰姬陵。

The purpose of “Tell me more” is to continue to keep the conversation open for as long as possible. Sometimes, people do a great job asking an initial open question, and then they narrow it precipitously in the second round. For example, you might ask me to tell you about my trip to India, and then follow up with: “How many days did the summit run?” That’s a really narrow question that doesn’t get you nearly as much information as “Tell me more about the summit.”

“请多讲讲”的目的是尽可能长时间地保持对话的开放性。有时，人们一开始会提出一个很好的开放式问题，但在第二轮提问中却会突然缩小范围。例如，你可能会问我关于印度之行的经历，然后追问：“峰会持续了几天？”这是一个非常狭隘的问题，远不如“请多讲讲峰会”那样能获取大量信息。

If you stay with the conversation and ask “Tell me more” for the information you uncover, you’ll get the most out of this question and set yourself up for success in the rest of your negotiation.

如果你继续参与对话，并就你了解到的信息提出“请告诉我更多信息”，你就能从这个问题中获得最大收益，并为接下来的谈判取得成功奠定基础。

Summarize and Ask for Feedback

总结并征求反馈意见

Next, you’re going to summarize what the other person has said, and make sure you give them a chance to weigh in about it. You may think you’ve demonstrated to the other person that you’re listening by simply sitting and hearing them out. You may also feel confident that you’ve heard everything they said. But if you want to make sure that you have heard all the information you need, as well as demonstrate that you have been listening, summarize what they’ve said after they answer. This means that you will summarize the other person’s answer both after the initial “Tell me,” as well as any follow-up “Tell me more” questions you ask.

接下来，你要总结对方所说的话，并确保给他们机会表达自己的看法。你可能认为，只要坐下来认真听，就足以表明你在倾听。你也可能自信地认为自己已经听到了他们说的所有内容。但是，如果你想确保自己已经听到了所有需要的信息，并证明你一直在认真倾听，那么在他们回答之后，你需要总结他们所说的话。这意味着，无论是在对方最初提出“请告诉我”之后，还是在你提出任何后续的“请继续说”的问题之后，你都需要总结对方的回答。

Some of the greatest leaders across every profession know the value of summarizing. Recall Stephen, the law firm litigation partner from chapter 3, with the junior partner, Craig, who broke the firm’s policy by filing a case in court without having run it by a litigation partner? When Stephen talked to Craig, he asked Craig’s perspective on the situation, and then summarized what he had heard from Craig as follows:

各行各业的一些杰出领导者都深谙总结的价值。还记得第三章中提到的律师事务所诉讼合伙人斯蒂芬吗？他的初级合伙人克雷格违反了事务所的规定，未经诉讼合伙人同意就擅自提起诉讼。斯蒂芬与克雷格交谈后，询问了克雷格对此事的看法，然后将克雷格的回答总结如下：

“Craig, I think I understand what you’ve said today. The fact is, you’re extremely busy, this was an important client, and it’s a field of law that you know well. You’ve been involved in dozens of these cases, and you had studied all the laws that apply; you knew the facts cold, you had a complaint drafted that was well-researched and which you reviewed repeatedly. You weren’t trying to hide anything, you just knew you had to get this done. You felt the complaint was good and that it would result in more expense for the client to run it through the required litigation partner review. You didn’t want to bill your client $900 an hour for me or someone else from Litigation to look at this in light of all of the above.”

“克雷格，我想我明白你今天说的意思了。事实是，你非常忙，这是个重要的客户，而且你对这个领域的法律非常熟悉。你处理过几十起类似的案件，研究过所有适用的法律；你对案情了如指掌，你起草了一份经过充分调研并反复审查的诉状。你并没有试图隐瞒什么，你只是知道必须完成这项工作。你觉得诉状已经足够好，如果让诉讼合伙人审核，会增加客户的费用。考虑到以上所有因素，你不想让客户支付我或其他诉讼部门人员每小时900美元的费用来审查这份诉状。”

When you summarize, you make sure you have learned all you can from the conversation. Stephen told me that in summarizing Craig’s perspective, he understood in a new way what Craig was thinking about the situation. In addition, Stephen’s summary reduced Craig’s defensiveness and put Craig in a frame of mind to really hear what Stephen had to say.

总结的时候，你要确保自己从对话中尽可能多地了解了信息。斯蒂芬告诉我，在总结克雷格的观点时，他以一种全新的方式理解了克雷格对这件事的看法。此外，斯蒂芬的总结也降低了克雷格的防备心理，让他能够真正倾听斯蒂芬的话。

After you summarize, you’ll ask the other person for feedback. Again, I like to do this by asking, “That’s everything I have in my notes. What did I miss?” By asking for feedback, I make sure that I learn the most possible from the conversation, and that the other person knows that I really want to hear them.

总结之后，你需要向对方征求反馈意见。我通常会这样问：“我的笔记里都记下来了，还有什么遗漏的吗？” 通过征求反馈意见，我可以确保从对话中尽可能多地学习，同时也能让对方感受到我真心想听取他们的意见。

Stephen asked Craig for feedback on the summary above. And when he did, Craig added some information—while he didn’t consult with a litigation partner, he had asked a very competent litigation associate to work with him on the case—that helped Stephen understand the situation more fully. Stephen summarized this additional information, and thanked him for adding it. After having his feedback heard, the junior partner visibly relaxed and Stephen was able to share the firm’s concerns with much greater success.

斯蒂芬就上述摘要征求了克雷格的意见。克雷格随后补充了一些信息——虽然他没有咨询诉讼合伙人，但他请了一位非常称职的诉讼律师助理协助他处理此案——这些信息帮助斯蒂芬更全面地了解了情况。斯蒂芬总结了这些补充信息，并感谢克雷格的补充。在得到反馈后，这位初级合伙人明显放松下来，斯蒂芬也因此能够更有效地表达律所的担忧。

Asking for feedback is the last critical step in making sure we have heard and understood the other person’s perspective on the situation at hand. It sets us up for success when we eventually turn to thinking about the future, and what steps we want to take.

征求反馈意见是确保我们听到并理解对方对当前情况的看法的最后一个关键步骤。这为我们最终思考未来以及我们想要采取的措施奠定了成功的基础。

Listen to What’s Not Said

倾听那些未说出口的话

When you ask this question, you’ll want to pay attention to the other person’s expression and body language as they are answering the question and giving you feedback. Stephen told me that Craig looked extremely tense when they first sat down. He could see by the furrow in Craig’s brow and his crossed arms that Craig might be feeling defensive. When Stephen started to summarize, Craig relaxed a little bit but also leaned forward and pressed his hands together. That told Stephen that Craig might have more to say. When Stephen gave Craig the chance for feedback and summarized the additional information, Craig smiled for the first time and leaned back in his chair. Stephen could see by Craig’s expression and body language that, finally, Craig had felt completely heard.

当你提出这个问题时，你需要留意对方在回答问题和提供反馈时的表情和肢体语言。斯蒂芬告诉我，他们刚坐下时，克雷格看起来非常紧张。他从克雷格紧锁的眉头和交叉的双臂看出，克雷格可能感到有些防备。当斯蒂芬开始总结时，克雷格放松了一些，但同时也向前倾身，双手交握。这让斯蒂芬意识到克雷格可能还有话要说。当斯蒂芬给克雷格机会提供反馈并总结了补充信息后，克雷格第一次露出了笑容，并向后靠在了椅子上。斯蒂芬从克雷格的表情和肢体语言中看出，克雷格终于感到自己被完全倾听了。

Wrapping Up

总结

You’ve learned to ask a terrific open question, followed up, summarized, and asked for feedback. Your negotiation is off to a great start. Now let’s continue the conversation in a way that will start to produce ideas for your eventual solution.

你已经学会了如何提出一个绝妙的开放式问题，并进行后续跟进、总结和征求反馈。你的谈判开局非常顺利。现在，让我们继续对话，以便为最终解决方案集思广益。

#↩

SEVEN WHAT DO YOU NEED?

七、你需要什么？

A senior television executive flew across the country, ready to start what she expected to be a heated legal negotiation over one of the television programs in her portfolio.

一位资深电视高管飞越全国，准备开始一场她预期会非常激烈的法律谈判，这场谈判涉及她负责的某个电视节目。

The program in question centered around a comedy act. Just after going live with the program, her network got hit with an unwelcome surprise: a small content producer, a husband-and-wife team with a comedy act that had been playing on local TV elsewhere in the country, sued for trademark infringement. Their small program had been on the air for two years, and the couple felt the network was trying to profit off public awareness and their reputation by using a similar name.

这个节目以喜剧表演为中心。节目刚上线不久，她的电视台就遭遇了意想不到的打击：一家小型内容制作公司——一对夫妇，他们的喜剧表演曾在其他地方的电视台播出——以商标侵权为由起诉了她。他们的节目已经播出两年了，这对夫妇认为电视台试图通过使用类似的名称来利用他们的知名度和声誉牟利。

The network immediately changed the title of their comedy program. But the couple refused to drop the suit. The resulting litigation had dragged on, heavily costing both parties, and had led to the television executive’s flying across the country for a mediation, designing a strategy for how to approach the meeting with the other side. She knew the company’s position: Not one dime. We can take this to trial and win.

电视台立即更改了喜剧节目的名称。但这对夫妇拒绝撤诉。由此引发的诉讼旷日持久，双方都损失惨重，最终导致这位电视高管飞越全国参加调解，并制定了与对方会面的策略。她很清楚公司的立场：一分钱也不要给。我们可以把这案子闹上法庭，而且一定会赢。

She arrived at the mediation with her army of lawyers, sat down, and saw the husband-and-wife team on the other side, sitting with their lawyer. Reviewing the plan she’d hatched on the plane, she looked across the table and asked the couple if they would be willing to talk to her without any lawyers in the room. The couple looked at each other, paused, and agreed. After all the lawyers (nervously) filed out, she turned to the couple and asked them a single question:

她带着一大帮律师来到调解室，坐下后看到对面坐着一对夫妇，他们的律师也在场。她回顾了一下在飞机上制定的计划，然后看向桌子对面，问这对夫妇是否愿意在没有律师在场的情况下和她谈谈。这对夫妇互相看了看，停顿了一下，然后同意了。等所有律师（略显紧张地）离开后，她转向这对夫妇，问了他们一个问题：

“What do you need?”

你需要什么？

This question seemed to both stun and relieve the couple. They thought for a moment and then told the executive, “We just love the program we’ve created. This is our passion project. We sued because we feared we wouldn’t survive. What we need now more than anything else is exposure. Otherwise, that fear may come to pass.” The executive thought about it and made an offer: How about a few advertising spots on one of the other TV channels she was responsible for overseeing? She had a few upcoming spots that no advertisers had bought yet; it would cost her network very little but would represent significant value to the local comedy group by providing broad exposure they otherwise could not afford on their own. The couple looked astonished when she revealed this offer, and quickly accepted. The two sides settled the case. As the executive headed to the airport, she received a text from the wife with a note of thanks and some book recommendations for her flight.

这个问题似乎让这对夫妇既震惊又如释重负。他们沉思片刻，然后告诉那位高管：“我们非常热爱我们创作的这个节目。这是我们倾注心血的项目。我们提起诉讼是因为担心无法继续经营下去。现在我们最需要的莫过于曝光度。否则，我们的担忧可能会变成现实。” 高管考虑了一下，提出了一个方案：在她负责监管的另一个电视频道上投放几个广告怎么样？她手头正好有几个空档，还没有广告商购买；这对她的电视台来说成本很低，但对于这个本地喜剧团体来说却意义重大，因为它可以提供他们自己无法负担的广泛曝光。当她提出这个方案时，这对夫妇显得十分惊讶，并立即接受了。双方达成了和解。高管前往机场的路上，收到了妻子发来的短信，感谢她的请求，并推荐了一些适合在飞机上阅读的书籍。

This one question opened up a whole negotiation. As the network had hoped, the executive settled the case for a zero-dollar payout. But her question generated so much more than just a mediation agreement. Shocked and impressed by this executive’s creative, collaborative approach, the couple stayed in touch and eventually became good friends with her. Later on in her career, when the executive was seeking to make a career move, the couple connected her with some people in their network.

这一个问题开启了一场完整的谈判。正如电视台所希望的那样，这位高管最终以零赔偿金达成和解。但她的问题带来的远不止一份调解协议。这对夫妇对这位高管富有创意和协作精神的做法感到震惊和钦佩，他们一直与她保持联系，最终成为了好朋友。后来，当这位高管寻求职业发展机会时，这对夫妇将她介绍给了他们人脉圈中的一些人。

This one question transformed the situation, and the executive’s life, in a way she never expected.

这一个问题彻底改变了局面，也改变了这位高管的人生，这是她始料未及的。

Asking about Needs: A Game-Changer in Negotiation

询问需求：谈判中的制胜法宝

This story, where “What do you need?” transformed a tense moment between a network executive and husband-and-wife team, is what originally inspired me to write this book. It demonstrates the ability of a single question to turn a contentious situation into an opportunity for lifelong mutual gain.

这个故事——“你需要什么？”——化解了一位电视台高管和一对夫妻之间紧张的局面，也正是这个故事最初启发我写了这本书。它展现了一个简单的问题如何将一场争论转化为终身互惠的机会。

Asking “What do you need?” is a life changer. It helps you access the reasons why people do what they do. It’s much easier to negotiate from someone’s underlying need than their demand. Think about the above case: the couple’s position was, “You stole our title for your own gain. You owe us damages.” The large company’s position was, “We didn’t steal your title. And moreover, you can’t show that you suffered any damages. We owe you nothing.” Had they just stuck to their positions, they would have ended up with a very different, costlier, and less productive result.

问一句“你需要什么？”会改变你的人生。它能帮助你了解人们行为背后的原因。从对方的潜在需求出发进行谈判，远比从他们的要求出发容易得多。想想上面的例子：这对夫妇的立场是：“你们为了自己的利益窃取了我们的产权。你们应该赔偿我们。”而那家大公司的立场是：“我们没有窃取你们的产权。而且，你们也无法证明自己遭受了任何损失。我们不欠你们任何东西。”如果他们各自坚持己见，最终的结果将会截然不同，代价更高，效率更低。

Getting underneath someone’s demands to figure out the needs driving them can help transform someone’s ideas about a conflict and what to do with it. The fact is that needs, not rights, are the real reason many people initiate lawsuits. Needs, not rights, are the reason many negotiations stall out or end badly. They are the person’s why , the reason for taking the position they do. And when we figure out someone else’s needs, those needs help us generate much better solutions to tough problems.

深入了解他人诉求背后的真正需求，有助于转变他们对冲突的看法以及处理冲突的方式。事实上，许多人提起诉讼的真正原因并非权利，而是需求。许多谈判陷入僵局或以糟糕的方式告终，原因也并非权利，而是需求。需求才是当事人采取某种立场的根本原因。当我们理解他人的需求时，这些需求就能帮助我们找到更有效的解决难题的方案。

Practice Identifying Needs

练习识别需求

How often have you sat across from someone, even someone you know very well, and asked them what they need? Most of us, seasoned negotiators included, need some practice in asking this question and then listening—really listening—to the answer. Especially because, over time, we see a lot of the same demands popping up again and again, so it’s easy to assume they’ll have similar solutions. But once you dig deeper, you’ll most likely find that the parties’ individual needs are very different.

你是否经常坐在某人对面，即使是熟人，问他们有什么需求？我们大多数人，包括经验丰富的谈判者，都需要练习如何提出这个问题，然后认真倾听——真正地倾听——对方的回答。尤其因为随着时间的推移，我们经常看到类似的需求反复出现，所以很容易想当然地认为他们的解决方案也大同小异。但一旦你深入了解，很可能会发现双方的实际需求其实大相径庭。

My Columbia students and I mediate a lot of employment disputes involving the U.S. government, and the difference in outcome between two similar cases—for example, where a woman has been denied a promotion and sues for sex discrimination—shows just how varied a negotiated agreement can be for the same initial problem.

我和我的哥伦比亚大学学生调解了很多涉及美国政府的雇佣纠纷，两个类似案件的结果差异——例如，一名女性被拒绝晋升并起诉性别歧视——表明，对于同一个初始问题，协商达成的协议可以有多么多样化。

Let’s imagine two women from Agency X arrive simultaneously at my office. Each of them has the same position: “Alex, I was denied a promotion purely because I am a woman.” I invite in the first woman, who repeats her position. We ask her, “What do you need?” and she says, “Because I was denied that promotion, I couldn’t provide for my son’s medical and special needs educational therapies.”

假设X机构的两名女性同时来到我的办公室。她们的陈述都一样：“亚历克斯，我仅仅因为是女性就被拒绝晋升。”我请第一位女性进来，她重复了一遍她的说法。我们问她：“你需要什么？”她说：“因为我被拒绝晋升，我无法承担儿子的医疗和特殊教育治疗费用。”

Her needs here are monetary. Of course she has other needs as well—any parent out there knows that the only way you can sleep at night is to know you did your best to provide for your child—but her primary, tangible need in this case is money. This negotiation likely ends with a monetary settlement.

她现在最迫切的需求是金钱。当然，她还有其他需求——任何为人父母者都知道，只有尽力照顾好孩子，才能安心入睡——但就目前的情况来看，她最主要、最实际的需求是钱。这次谈判很可能以金钱和解告终。

Now the second woman comes in. Again, she states her position: “I was denied a rightful promotion because I’m a woman.” We ask her, “What do you need?” and she tells us, “I need what happened to me to never happen to another woman ever again.” Her need varies greatly from the first woman’s; she needs institutional change. For this plaintiff, we might end up with a managerial training program aimed at gender equity in the workplace. A similar position does not have to equate to identical needs.

现在第二位女士走了进来。她再次陈述了自己的立场：“我因为是女性而被剥夺了应得的晋升机会。”我们问她：“您需要什么？”她告诉我们：“我希望发生在我身上的事永远不要再发生在其他女性身上。”她的需求与第一位女士截然不同；她需要的是制度变革。对于这位原告，我们最终可能会制定一个旨在促进职场性别平等的管理培训计划。相似的立场并不一定意味着完全相同的需求。

Uncovering underlying needs also works wonders for relationship issues. Perhaps your partner has spent years telling you something like, “You never remember to clean out the sink and load the dishwasher before we go to bed!” Chances are this leads to a response like, “I just did it yesterday—and besides, I’m exhausted! I put out the trash and helped with homework. What else do you want from me?”

挖掘潜在需求对解决关系问题大有裨益。也许你的伴侣多年来一直抱怨：“你从来不记得在睡觉前清理水槽和装洗碗机！” 你很可能会这样回应：“我昨天才做过——而且，我累死了！我倒了垃圾，还辅导了作业。你还想让我做什么？”

Again, this is a fight centered entirely on demands. When you ask a question that focuses instead on your partner’s needs, you might hear something different. I once worked through this with a couple, and it turned out that what the person who valued a clean sink actually needed was a feeling of peace and harmony when she came downstairs in the morning. The sink just did that for her. If she saw a clean sink and counter, she could relax and breathe as she started her day. The partner started to see that his spouse’s need was actually not about controlling him—it was about controlling her anxiety. In turn, her partner needed some flexibility for unusually busy nights. After discussing their needs, the couple decided that if they needed to make a choice, they would forgo the trash collection and focus instead on tidying the kitchen. They also gained a greater understanding of each other that helped keep things happier around the home.

再说一遍，这是一场完全围绕需求展开的争吵。如果你换个角度，问问伴侣的需求，或许会听到不同的答案。我曾经帮一对夫妻解决过这个问题，结果发现，重视水槽清洁的那一方真正需要的，是每天早上下楼时感受到的平静与和谐。水槽恰好能给她带来这种感觉。如果她看到的是干净的水槽和台面，就能放松下来，舒舒服服地开始新的一天。另一方也开始意识到，伴侣的需求并非控制他，而是为了控制自己的焦虑。反过来，伴侣也需要在特别忙碌的夜晚拥有一些灵活性。经过一番沟通，这对夫妻决定，如果需要做出选择，他们就放弃倒垃圾，转而专注于整理厨房。他们也因此加深了对彼此的了解，让家里的气氛更加和谐。

Identifying the underlying needs helps us avoid cookie-cutter negotiations and create innovative, durable, and specific solutions that work for the people involved. Never make the mistake of assuming that you know what someone’s needs are just because their demand sounds familiar.

明确潜在需求有助于我们避免千篇一律的谈判，并制定出创新、持久且切实可行的解决方案，真正满足相关人员的需求。切勿因为对方的要求听起来似曾相识就想当然地认为自己了解他们的需求。

Your Turn: Asking about Someone’s Needs

轮到你了：询问他人的需求

You’ve already started this conversation as openly as possible by asking the other person “Tell me…” and listening to the answer. Now you’re ready to ask the question “What do you need?”

你已经尽可能坦诚地开始了这段对话，你问对方“告诉我……”并认真倾听了对方的回答。现在，你可以问“你需要什么？”这个问题了。

Feel free to personalize this question in a way that makes sense for your negotiation. For example, if you’re approaching a buyer at Target to sell your home product, you could ask, “What do you need from your vendors?” or “What do you need from this deal?” If you’re negotiating with your spouse over the home budget and whether one of you can book that expensive vacation: “When we’re thinking about how we prioritize our money, what do you need?” If you’re sitting down with that bathroom contractor: “What do you need when you work with homeowners?” or “What do you need to get this job done?”

您可以根据谈判实际情况灵活调整这个问题。例如，如果您在Target超市向采购员推销家居产品，您可以问：“您需要供应商提供什么？”或者“您希望从这笔交易中获得什么？”如果您正在和配偶商量家庭预算以及你们中是否有人能预订昂贵的假期，您可以问：“当我们考虑如何分配资金时，您需要什么？”如果您正在和浴室装修承包商洽谈，您可以问：“您在与业主合作时需要什么？”或者“您需要什么才能完成这项工作？”

Land the Plane

降落飞机

Even seasoned professionals, or longtime couples, hesitate to ask an open question about needs. It feels deeper, riskier, different from the usual types of questions we ask. I see so many negotiators ask this question and then metaphorically circle the airport with a string of words like, “What do you need? I feel like earlier in our relationship you wanted…” “What do you need here? How about we move this number…” Don’t worry about asking this question as is, don’t add your own judgments, and also don’t think you know better than the person sitting across from you. Be brave. Ask your four-word question and land the plane.

即使是经验丰富的专业人士或交往多年的伴侣，也常常犹豫是否要直接询问对方的需求。这感觉更深入、更冒险，也与我们通常问的问题截然不同。我见过太多谈判者问完这个问题后，就像在机场里兜圈子一样，说着一连串的话，比如：“你需要什么？我觉得在我们交往初期，你想要的是……”“你需要什么？要不我们把这个号码挪一下……”别担心直接问这个问题，不要掺杂你自己的判断，也不要觉得自己比坐在你对面的人更懂。勇敢一点，问出你那四个字的问题，然后顺利结束对话。

Enjoy the Silence

享受安静

Then, leave room for silence for the other person to consider and answer your question.

然后，留出一些沉默的时间，让对方思考并回答你的问题。

Follow Up

跟进

Sometimes when you ask someone what they need, you may get a short or vague answer, such that you’d like to follow up—but don’t do it with a narrow question or, worse, your idea for a solution! You’ll be closing off the flow of information just when you stand to gain the most. Instead, remember my trip to India, and say, “Thanks. Can you tell me more about _____?”

有时当你询问别人需要什么时，可能会得到简短或含糊的回答，让你想要追问——但千万不要提出过于具体的问题，更不要直接抛出你的解决方案！那样只会阻碍信息的流通，而你恰恰最有可能从中获益。相反，想想我去印度的经历，你可以说：“谢谢。您能跟我详细说说____吗？”

The follow-up question is where so many people go wrong, remembering to ask the big question but then losing their discipline for the follow-up. Instead, try our handy “Tell me more.” This is particularly helpful if you ask, “What do you need?” and someone says, “I don’t know.” In the process of asking for more information in a broad way, you can help someone clarify with, “Okay, so you’re not sure what you need. Maybe tell me more about what’s running through your mind right now.” Then enjoy the silence once more.

很多人在后续提问上容易出错，他们记得问了关键问题，却忽略了后续的追问。不妨试试我们这个简单易用的“请详细说说”。如果你问“你需要什么？”，对方回答“我不知道”，这个方法尤其有效。在询问更多信息的过程中，你可以用“好的，所以你还不确定自己需要什么。能不能详细说说你现在在想什么？”来帮助他们理清思路。然后，再次享受片刻的宁静吧。

Two main buckets of needs come up when you ask this question that may look familiar from earlier in the book: intangibles and tangibles. Let’s talk about how to follow up on each.

当你提出这个问题时，会浮现出两大类需求，这两类需求在本书前面可能已经出现过：无形需求和有形需求。我们来谈谈如何分别跟进这两类需求。

Dealing with Intangibles

处理无形资产

You’ve asked a question about needs. We know from research and practice that asking about needs yields deep-seated, important information that can unlock a deal or a conflict. Many needs, however, are intangibles (as you found out for yourself in chapter 2), meaning they are conceptual instead of concrete. Which leads us to our important follow-up question that, as you did for yourself in chapter 2, you’re going to ask next: What would that look like?

你问了一个关于需求的问题。我们从研究和实践中得知，询问需求能够获得一些深层次的重要信息，这些信息可以促成交易或化解冲突。然而，许多需求是无形的（正如你在第二章中自己发现的那样），这意味着它们是概念性的而非具体的。这就引出了我们接下来要问的重要问题，就像你在第二章中自己问的那样：那会是什么样子？

“What would that look like?” helps the person you’re talking to bring their needs to life and visualize what they could look like in reality. It helps them look to the future and picture what they most want to see. Finally, this question opens a window between you and the person you’re talking to, and gives you important details that can be critical in finding a mutual path forward. When you ask this critical question, you help the person sitting across from you bring their needs into the realm of the concrete and give you powerful clues about potential solutions to the issue between you.

“那会是什么样子？”这个问题能帮助对方将他们的需求具体化，并想象这些需求在现实中可能呈现出的样子。它能帮助他们展望未来，描绘出他们最渴望看到的景象。最后，这个问题在你和对方之间打开了一扇窗，为你提供重要的细节信息，这些信息对于找到双方都能接受的前进方向至关重要。当你提出这个关键问题时，你帮助坐在对面的人将他们的需求具体化，并为你提供解决你们之间问题的潜在方案的重要线索。

A health coach sat down with her client, whom she’d been working with for about a year. The client, a professional woman, was a dedicated yoga practitioner who suffered from emotional eating and had grown frustrated that every year since she turned forty, despite all her efforts, the scale had crept up a pound or two until her clothes no longer fit. In the initial meeting with her coach, the woman had identified a weight-loss goal of twenty pounds. She had access to high-quality fresh foods, a gym membership—everything she needed to reach her goal. She started working to eat healthier. She dropped her yoga classes and vigorously exercised five to six times a week, including weight training. And yet, the scale seemed to be stuck within a pound or two of her original weight. The more the number refused to move, the more this client fixated on it. Finally, the client expressed her frustration and despair to her coach—who responded immediately and scheduled a meeting.

一位健康教练与她的客户坐下来谈话，这位客户已经和她合作了一年左右。这位客户是一位职业女性，也是一位虔诚的瑜伽练习者，她深受情绪化进食的困扰。自从四十岁以来，尽管她竭尽全力，体重却每年都会增加一两磅，直到衣服都穿不下了，这让她感到非常沮丧。在与教练的初次会面中，这位女士设定了减重20磅的目标。她可以买到高质量的新鲜食物，也办了健身卡——她拥有实现目标所需的一切。她开始努力健康饮食，放弃了瑜伽课，每周进行五到六次高强度锻炼，包括力量训练。然而，体重秤上的数字似乎始终停留在她最初体重的几磅之内。数字越是纹丝不动，这位客户就越是耿耿于怀。最终，这位客户向她的教练倾诉了自己的沮丧和绝望——教练立即做出了回应，并安排了一次会面。

This time, the coach took a different approach. She asked her client to put aside the weight for a minute and think about what she needed . The client responded immediately, “I need to feel healthier and more in balance.” The coach replied, “Great. You need to feel healthy and in balance. What would that look like?” The client thought for a moment, and then responded, “I don’t know… I think I need more rest, and I think I miss yoga. That was my sanity, and now I’m doing other stuff in an attempt to lose weight, but it just leaves me feeling more tired. Between work, grocery shopping, exercise, and my kids, I’m so exhausted that I find myself eating at night just to stay awake.”

这次，教练换了一种方法。她让客户暂时放下体重问题，想想自己真正需要什么。客户立刻回答说：“我需要感觉更健康、更平衡。”教练说：“很好。你需要感觉健康、平衡。那会是什么样子呢？”客户想了一会儿，然后回答说：“我不知道……我想我需要更多休息，而且我想念瑜伽。瑜伽是我保持理智的方式，现在我尝试做其他事情来减肥，但只会让我感觉更累。工作、买菜、锻炼，再加上照顾孩子，我筋疲力尽，晚上甚至要靠吃东西来保持清醒。”

Now the coach and the client had information they needed to move forward. By asking this question, the coach helped her client access her inner wisdom and self-diagnose the solution to the problem. Together, they focused on rest and balance. By setting an earlier bedtime and coming up with a relaxing evening routine, they helped the client cut down on her late-night eating. They integrated some yoga classes back into her exercise routine and helped her achieve balance between that and cardio workouts. They also brainstormed some meal-prep shortcuts to help the client feel less burdened. With the pressure off and some balance restored, the client started to feel better and lose weight at a slow, sustainable pace. All of this came from asking one question that helped both the coach and the client herself conceptualize what health and balance looked like to achieve her goal.

现在，教练和客户都掌握了继续前进所需的信息。通过提出这个问题，教练帮助客户唤醒内在智慧，并自我诊断出问题的解决方案。他们共同专注于休息和平衡。通过设定更早的就寝时间并制定一套放松的睡前习惯，他们帮助客户减少了深夜进食。他们将瑜伽课程重新融入客户的日常锻炼中，并帮助她在瑜伽和有氧运动之间找到平衡。他们还集思广益，想出了一些简化备餐的妙招，以减轻客户的负担。压力减轻，生活恢复平衡后，客户开始感觉好转，并以缓慢而可持续的速度减重。这一切都源于一个问题，这个问题帮助教练和客户共同理解了健康和平衡对于实现目标意味着什么。

I love the “What would that look like?” question and ask it in virtually every negotiation scenario—but most negotiators don’t even know this question exists. Or if they do, they can’t ask it. Why? Because they haven’t first found out from the other person what they need, as you just did. Here is where you start to see your earlier work in posing broad questions and listening—really listening—to the answers, pay off.

我喜欢问“那会是什么样子？”这个问题，几乎在所有谈判场景中都会问——但大多数谈判者甚至不知道这个问题的存在。或者即使他们知道，也问不出来。为什么？因为他们没有像你刚才那样，先了解对方的需求。而这正是你之前提出宽泛问题并认真倾听——真正倾听——对方回答的努力开始发挥作用的地方。

When you get to this question, you are going to ask it by first reflecting back what you heard as the person’s needs, and then asking them what that would look like. As an example, if you’re talking to one of the owners of a thriving bakery: “You know, Ilan, I heard you say earlier that one of your biggest needs was feeling recognized at work for your expertise. What would that look like here?” Then, you’re going to continue to reflect back his words and ask for more information using a “What else?” question. So when Ilan responds, perhaps by saying, “I’d like the bakers in our store to take my direction on our product, rather than just nodding and then asking my husband,” you can respond with, “Okay, so you’d like to know that when you give advice to your bakers, they will follow it first, without needing to check with your husband. What else would recognition at work look like?”

当你问到这个问题时，首先要复述对方的需求，然后再问他们这些需求具体体现在哪些方面。举个例子，如果你正在和一家生意兴隆的面包店老板交谈：“伊兰，我刚才听到你说，你最大的需求之一是希望自己的专业技能在工作中得到认可。这具体体现在哪些方面呢？” 然后，你要继续复述他的话，并用“还有什么？”这样的问题来询问更多信息。比如，伊兰可能会回答说：“我希望我们店里的面包师在产品方面能听从我的指导，而不是点头同意后再来问我丈夫。” 你可以接着说：“好的，所以你希望当你给面包师们提建议时，他们会首先采纳你的建议，而不需要先问你丈夫。那么，在工作中，你还希望得到哪些方面的认可呢？”

The openness of this question is so important because it allows you to dig into what the other person sees for their (and perhaps your shared) future. Here is where, once more, we must resist the urge to tack on narrow follow-on questions at the end. Those questions often reflect our assumptions about the person or the situation—which may be very far from the reality. If your tween girl says she needs more freedom at home, hold yourself back from saying, “What would more freedom look like? Wait, is this about getting an iPhone again?” As the parent of a tween girl myself, I can rarely predict what’s on my daughter’s mind. Disciplining myself to listen to her has made us so much closer as I get to know the person she is, and is becoming.

这个问题之所以如此重要，是因为它能让你深入了解对方对未来（或许也包括你们共同的未来）的看法。在这里，我们必须再次克制住最后追问一些狭隘问题的冲动。这些问题往往反映了我们对对方或情况的假设——而这些假设可能与事实相去甚远。如果你的女儿说她需要在家里拥有更多自由，请克制住自己不要问：“更多自由意味着什么？等等，你又说要买iPhone了？”我自己也是一位十几岁女孩的家长，我很少能预料到女儿在想什么。通过努力倾听，我更加了解她，也更了解她正在成为怎样的人，这让我们之间的关系更加亲密。

This question is also important if you are facing a negotiation with what I call a counterpuncher. You know, the person who has shot down every single one of your ideas, saying, “That’s not going to work,” without so much as one positive suggestion of their own? That one. When you ask them a question that puts the ball in their court—like, “What would a workable solution look like?”—and then patiently enjoy the silence that follows, you are forcing—ahem, inviting—them to actively participate in the search for a solution.

如果你遇到我称之为“反击者”的谈判对手，这个问题就显得尤为重要。你知道，就是那种会否决你所有想法，只会说“这行不通”的人，自己却提不出一个像样的建议。当你问他们一个能让他们主动出击的问题——比如，“一个可行的解决方案是什么样的？”——然后耐心地享受随之而来的沉默时，你就是在迫使——或者说，邀请——他们积极参与到寻找解决方案的过程中来。

Dealing with Tangibles

处理有形资产

And if you get tangibles when you ask this question (as an example, “I need you to report your results to me by telephone twice a week”), then you know how you’re following up: “Help me understand: What makes the twice-weekly call important?”

如果你在提出这个问题时得到了具体的答复（例如，“我需要你每周两次通过电话向我汇报结果”），那么你就知道该如何跟进了：“请帮我理解一下：为什么每周两次的电话很重要？”

Once someone has stated a tangible need, we use this follow-up question to get a deeper understanding of the intangible need behind it.

当某人表达了具体的需要之后，我们会使用这个后续问题来更深入地了解其背后的无形需求。

Again, avoid asking “Why is that important?” Instead of why ask, “What made/makes… ?” or just “Tell me…” Especially if there is any difficulty or previous patterns of unsatisfactory communication, why can seem confrontational or aggressive. Social workers rarely ask why questions because they are looking to increase trust and rapport. For example, compare “Why don’t you want to cancel your golf membership when you know we are struggling financially?” with “What makes the golf membership important for you?” You can see which question is more likely to produce a constructive answer.

再次强调，避免问“为什么这很重要？”。相反，应该问“是什么原因导致……？”或者直接说“告诉我……”。尤其是在沟通存在困难或以往沟通不畅的情况下，“为什么”这样的问题可能会显得咄咄逼人或带有攻击性。社工很少问“为什么”的问题，因为他们希望建立信任和融洽的关系。例如，比较一下“既然你知道我们经济困难，为什么你不想取消你的高尔夫会员资格？”和“是什么让你觉得高尔夫会员资格很重要？”这两个问题，你会发现哪个问题更有可能得到建设性的回答。

In this way, the colleague who asked you to report your results to them by telephone twice a week will be able to clarify what that report represents. Will it help them communicate better with the board of directors? Or is it that they need to feel more in the loop and have the security of knowing what’s going on? We’re trying to get at the need that’s underneath the tangible they just listed, so that you understand the problem they’re trying to solve and can start to troubleshoot potential solutions. If they say they need the reports to be in the loop, but you know that twice a week won’t work for a particular reason, you now have some ideas for a path forward. Eventually, once you have finished summarizing and given them an opportunity for feedback, you might acknowledge their need to be in the loop, describe the challenges with the suggested phone reports, and then ask them what ideas they have, or propose some ideas yourself, for other ways you could work together to meet this need.

这样一来，那位要求你每周两次电话汇报结果的同事就能更清楚地了解这份汇报的意义所在。是为了帮助他们更好地与董事会沟通吗？还是仅仅为了让他们更了解情况，从而获得安全感？我们试图挖掘他们刚才列举的那些具体需求背后更深层次的真正需求，以便你理解他们试图解决的问题，并开始着手寻找可能的解决方案。如果他们说需要汇报来了解情况，但你知道每周两次汇报由于某些原因行不通，那么你现在就有了改进的思路。最终，在你完成总结并给予他们反馈机会后，你可以肯定他们确实需要了解情况，描述一下电话汇报的难点，然后询问他们有什么想法，或者提出你自己的想法，探讨其他可以合作满足这一需求的方式。

Another example is a vice president at a Fortune 100 company in New York who was offered, one year into her job, responsibility for an additional business unit. The promotion didn’t include a title change, but the role would have a significantly higher profile than before, and require a lot of travel to the West Coast. She went back and forth with her company on salary, and relatively quickly reached the maximum they could give for this position (which she verified with some research). She told them that she needed more value from the deal, to which they responded, “We hear that. We’ve hit the maximum on the compensation. How else can we help you get some value here?” The executive thought about it. This new job, which she wanted, would mean significantly more travel away from her husband. She would be away twice a month, for a week each time. She went back and asked them for her husband to be able to join her once a month, with his airfare, hotel, and daily expenses paid. That “value” came out of a different pot of money from the compensation pot. They quickly agreed, and she had a deal.

另一个例子是一位纽约财富100强公司的副总裁，入职一年后，公司给她提供了一个新的业务部门的管理权。虽然职位名称没有改变，但新职位的重要性远超以往，而且需要频繁前往西海岸出差。她和公司就薪资问题反复协商，很快就达到了公司能提供的最高薪资（她也通过调查证实了这一点）。她告诉公司，她希望这份工作能带来更多价值，公司回应说：“我们明白。薪酬已经达到上限了。我们还能如何帮您提升价值呢？”这位高管认真考虑了一下。这份她梦寐以求的新工作意味着她要花更多时间出差，远离丈夫。她每月要出差两次，每次一周。于是，她再次提出，希望公司能让她丈夫每月来探望她一次，并承担他的机票、酒店和日常开销。这部分“价值”是从薪酬之外的另一笔资金中拨出来的。公司很快同意了，双方达成了协议。

If you know that you’re going to have trouble meeting someone’s tangible need, one great strategy forward is to uncover the intangible that’s beneath it, and then (after you’ve completed the questions!) ask how else you could help them with their need.

如果你知道自己难以满足某人的实际需求，一个很好的策略是找出其背后的无形需求，然后（在你完成提问之后！）询问你还可以如何帮助他们满足需求。

Summarize and Ask for Feedback

总结并征求反馈意见

After asking your question, honoring the silence, and following up with more open questions, it’s time to repeat back what you heard. Summarizing ensures that you have heard the person who is talking with you and that you’ve digested what they had to say. In particular, having one’s needs heard can be incredibly cathartic.

提出问题后，尊重对方的沉默，并提出更多开放式问题，之后就可以复述你听到的内容了。总结能确保你听清了对方的发言，并且理解了他们的意思。尤其重要的是，把自己的需求表达出来，能带来极大的情感宣泄。

One of the exercises my mentor, Carol Liebman, taught me is a listening exercise where we have trainees break out into groups and listen to one another describing a conflict they are experiencing. After they finish, their fellow group members will, among other things, summarize what they need. I ran this exercise in a recent training I conducted for civil rights lawyers, and afterward, the department head pulled me aside to say, “Alex, I know you came here to train us in mediation, but I just experienced something even more powerful. I’m dealing with a thorny work conflict that’s been keeping me up at night. Having someone actually hear my needs and summarize them for me induced in me the most profound feeling of relief I can ever recall experiencing. It was as though it put gas back in my tank to get to work and actually solve the problem. I’m going to go back to my office and do that right now!” So the first benefit for the other person of having their needs heard and summarized is it makes them feel respected and heard.

我的导师卡罗尔·利布曼教过我一个练习，叫做倾听练习。在这个练习中，学员们分成小组，互相倾听彼此描述正在经历的冲突。小组成员说完后，会总结彼此的需求。我最近为民权律师举办了一次培训，并在培训中运用了这个练习。培训结束后，部门主管把我拉到一边说：“亚历克斯，我知道你是来培训我们调解技巧的，但我刚刚经历了一件更震撼的事情。我正被一个棘手的工作冲突困扰，夜不能寐。有人真正倾听我的需求，并帮我总结出来，这让我感到前所未有的轻松和解脱。就像重新注入了动力，让我重新投入工作，解决问题。我现在就回办公室去处理！” 因此，让对方的需求被倾听和总结，首先会让他们感到被尊重和被理解。

Summarizing what someone needs also may give them information that they may not have understood before. I summarized once for Andrea, a businessperson who was having a conflict with her younger brother, Chad. After Chad went through a rough financial period, Andrea had bought him an apartment and brought him into her business as an employee. She told me she now regretted it; Chad had gotten into a relationship with someone who had a criminal record for assault as well as illegal financial dealings; all of a sudden, he was buying cars he couldn’t possibly afford and talking about bringing his girlfriend into the company, too. Andrea talked to me about the importance of maintaining a spotless reputation for the health of her business, and finished by saying, “I think I may need to step away and just not see him socially for now.”

总结别人的需求或许还能让他们获得一些之前可能并不了解的信息。我曾经为安德莉亚做过一次总结，她是一位女商人，正和弟弟查德闹矛盾。查德之前经历了一段经济困难时期，安德莉亚给他买了一套公寓，还让他加入了自己的公司。她告诉我她现在很后悔；查德和一个有暴力犯罪记录以及非法金融交易记录的人谈恋爱；突然之间，他开始买他根本负担不起的车，还说要把女朋友也拉进公司。安德莉亚跟我谈到了维护公司良好声誉的重要性，最后她说：“我想我可能需要暂时和他保持距离，不要再和他有任何社交往来。”

I said, “You’ve told me you regret bringing Chad into the business, and your reputation is very important to you. I wonder if you need to take a break from him in the business arena, too.”

我说：“你曾告诉我你后悔把查德带进公司，而且你的名誉对你来说非常重要。我想知道你是否也需要在商业领域和他保持一段时间的距离。”

She nodded. “I didn’t want to think about that, but I do.”

她点点头。“我本来不想考虑这件事，但现在我不得不考虑了。”

Summarizing also has powerful effects for you, the listener. By forcing you to listen in a different way, it increases your understanding of what the person actually said. So often we listen with half our attention or through the lens of our own experience, but listening to understand what the other person is saying, rather than to respond, helps you listen differently and better.

总结对你——听者——也有着强大的作用。它迫使你用不同的方式聆听，从而加深你对对方真正意思的理解。我们常常心不在焉地听，或者带着自身的经验去听，但为了理解对方的意思而倾听，而不是为了回应而倾听，能帮助你以不同的方式、更好地聆听。

You also have a chance to test your understanding of what the person actually said when you summarize. If you thought you heard that your client needed more frequent email communication, and what they actually needed was communication only when certain substantive or personnel changes were being considered, that’s an important distinction. This last step gives you a chance to make sure that you’ve heard what the other person intended you to hear.

总结的过程中，你也有机会检验自己是否真正理解了对方的意思。如果你以为客户需要更频繁的邮件沟通，而他们实际需要的只是在考虑某些实质性或人事变动时才进行沟通，那么这其中的区别就非常重要。最后一步能让你确保自己理解了对方真正想表达的意思。

Always end a summary by asking for the other person’s feedback. Feedback lets you know how you did. Avoid “Did I get that right?” because it’s fishing with a line, inviting a simple yes or no answer. Instead, ask for feedback in a way that lets the listener know you expect and welcome it, such as “How’d I do?” or even “What did I miss?” Then give the person your full attention and patience once again.

总结结束时，一定要征求对方的反馈意见。反馈能让你了解自己的表现。避免问“我说得对吗？”，因为这就像在钓鱼，只会得到简单的“是”或“否”的回答。相反，你应该以一种让对方知道你期待并欢迎反馈的方式询问，例如“我做得怎么样？”或者“我漏掉了什么？”。然后，再次给予对方充分的关注和耐心。

Listen for What Is Not Said

倾听言外之意。

Sometimes when you ask someone this question, they will flat-out tell you their needs. But sometimes, uncovering what someone needs requires listening carefully between the words for what they mean, including nonverbal cues. If, for example, I summarize and then ask someone, “Did I get that right?” and they have a questioning or reluctant tone, a frown, a head shake, or a downward look, those may be signs that I’ve left something unexplored. In that case, I usually say something like, “It looks like I did miss something after all—please tell me how I can understand better.”

有时候，当你问别人这个问题时，他们会直接告诉你他们的需求。但有时候，要真正了解一个人的需求，需要仔细聆听言外之意，包括非语言线索。例如，如果我总结完之后问对方“我理解对了吗？”，而对方语气中带着疑问或犹豫，皱着眉头，摇摇头，或者低着头，这些都可能表明我遗漏了某些信息。在这种情况下，我通常会说：“看来我确实漏掉了一些——请告诉我怎样才能更好地理解。”

You’ve now asked someone else about their needs. You’ve helped them make those needs concrete or connected those tangible needs to something greater. You’ve summarized what the person has said and asked for feedback. You’ve also looked for non-verbal communication and invited the person to be as open as they wish.

你现在已经询问了对方的需求。你帮助他们将这些需求具体化，或者将这些具体的需求与更宏大的事物联系起来。你总结了对方的回答并征求了反馈意见。你还观察了对方的非语言沟通，并鼓励他们尽可能地敞开心扉。

Now let’s move on to the next question, where I’m going to give you a simple, effective, “no therapist couch necessary” way to ask someone about their emotions—like you did for yourself in chapter 3.

现在让我们进入下一个问题，我将给你一个简单、有效且“无需心理咨询师”的方法，来询问别人的情绪——就像你在第 3 章中对自己做的那样。

#↩

EIGHT WHAT ARE YOUR CONCERNS?

八、您有哪些顾虑？

Rahul walked into his boss’s office to start what he feared would be a tough conversation. Six months earlier, seeking a new challenge beyond his domestic portfolio of work, he had applied for and been named vice president of his company’s international division, in charge of operations. He was a dynamic young leader with a management style that inspired his millennial staff. The president of the international division had spent his career in that division and was promoted when the previous president became CEO of the entire company.

拉胡尔走进老板的办公室，准备开始一场他预感会很艰难的谈话。六个月前，为了寻求国内业务之外的新挑战，他申请并被任命为公司国际部门副总裁，负责运营。他是一位充满活力的年轻领导者，其管理风格激励着他的千禧一代员工。国际部门总裁在该部门工作多年，前任总裁升任公司首席执行官后，他才得以晋升。

Once Rahul arrived in his new position, the challenges of running the international division became apparent. International markets were experiencing the brunt of fluctuations happening across the world, and Rahul’s specific company, a veteran in an industry with increasingly strong competition from new players, was struggling. One week earlier Rahul, a new divisional vice president, and his boss had a tense meeting with the company’s CFO, Arya, who had looked over their personnel chart and asked why a certain category of positions needed to exist, since they didn’t on the domestic side. There was a moment of silence before Rahul said, “That’s an interesting question. I’ll take a look at it.”

拉胡尔到任后，管理国际部门的挑战便显露无疑。国际市场正承受着全球经济波动的冲击，而拉胡尔所在的这家老牌企业，在竞争日益激烈的行业中举步维艰，面临着来自新兴企业的猛烈挑战。一周前，这位新上任的部门副总裁拉胡尔和他的上司与公司首席财务官阿雅进行了一次气氛紧张的会面。阿雅审阅了他们的人员配置表，并质疑为何某些职位类别需要在国际部门设立，因为国内部门并没有这些职位。短暂的沉默后，拉胡尔说道：“这确实是个有趣的问题。我会研究一下。”

Recalling this interaction later, he told me, “In that moment, after my exchange with Arya, I saw my boss look at me with an expression I couldn’t really read. Initially, I thought things were fine, but over the next week his communications to me were much shorter and less frequent than usual. Things just seemed off… like he was hurt by my response.” He continued, “So I went to see him in his office. I really wanted to ask my boss what he was feeling, but I was afraid to be so blunt about it. I thought it might put him on the defensive, like I was calling him emotional. Instead I said, ‘It might just be me, but I feel like things have been off between us since that conversation with Arya last week. I want to understand your concerns.’ ”

后来他回忆起这段对话时告诉我：“当时，我和艾莉娅交谈之后，我看到老板看着我，眼神里充满了难以捉摸的情绪。起初，我以为没什么大不了的，但接下来的一个星期，他跟我联系的频率和内容都比平时少了很多，也短了很多。感觉有点不对劲……好像我的回应让他很受伤。” 他接着说：“所以我去他办公室找他。我真的很想问问老板的感受，但我又怕说得太直白。我怕他会觉得我在指责他情绪化，让他产生防御心理。所以我说：‘也许只是我的错觉，但自从上周和艾莉娅谈话之后，我觉得我们之间有点不对劲。我想了解一下您的顾虑。’”

Rahul’s boss opened up. He told Rahul that his job performance was terrific, but that he needed to feel like Rahul was on his team. The president felt extremely loyal to his staff, many of whom had also grown up in the international division, like him (and unlike Rahul). He had hoped Rahul would help him articulate the unique needs of their division to Arya, or even reserve comment until they could come up with a strategy together, rather than immediately entertaining the idea of cutting international staff just because they didn’t exist on the domestic side. As the president was talking, Rahul listened to his soft tone and figured something else out: the previous international president had been a larger-than-life presence in the office, who was outgoing and commanded a room. This new president, Rahul’s boss, was a quiet man, brilliant with data but more reserved in personal interactions. Listening to him, Rahul realized that he had been hired in part to fill in the areas where the president felt less strong—but that only worked as long as he felt they were operating under one purpose. Otherwise, Rahul realized, he might come across as wanting the president job himself, which was not the case. He was learning a great deal in this role, and his preference was to stay on the operations side rather than assume total responsibility for this division.

拉胡尔的老板敞开心扉。他告诉拉胡尔，他的工作表现非常出色，但他需要感受到拉胡尔是他团队的一员。这位总裁对他的员工极其忠诚，他们中的许多人也像他一样，在国际部门成长起来（而拉胡尔则不同）。他原本希望拉胡尔能帮助他向艾雅阐明他们部门的特殊需求，或者至少在他们共同制定策略之前保持沉默，而不是仅仅因为国内部门没有国际员工就立即考虑裁减国际员工。总裁说话时，拉胡尔听着他温和的语气，又想到了另一件事：前任国际部门总裁在办公室里是一位极具魅力、性格外向、气场强大的人物。而这位新总裁，也就是拉胡尔的老板，则是一位沉默寡言的人，他精通数据分析，但在人际交往中却比较内敛。听着他的讲述，拉胡尔意识到，他被聘用的部分原因是为了弥补总裁能力不足的领域——但这只有在他觉得他们朝着同一个目标努力时才有效。否则，拉胡尔意识到，他可能会被误解为想要自己担任总裁一职，而事实并非如此。他从这个岗位上学到了很多，而且他更愿意留在运营部门，而不是全面负责这个部门。

Rahul summarized his boss’s concerns and thanked him for his candor. He thanked his boss for taking a chance on him in this role and shared how much he had been learning. Together, they worked to educate Arya about the roles of international staff, while privately making contingency plans in case the company insisted on cuts. They also made a plan for future interactions with Arya. Things felt better around the office. They were once again on the same team.

拉胡尔总结了老板的担忧，并感谢他的坦诚。他感谢老板给他这个机会，让他担任这个职位，并分享了自己学到了很多东西。他们一起努力向阿雅讲解国际员工的职责，同时私下制定了应对公司可能坚持裁员的应急方案。他们还制定了未来与阿雅互动的计划。办公室里的气氛缓和了下来。他们又重新回到了同一个团队。

Asking about Someone’s Concerns

询问他人的担忧

The next step in your negotiation is to ask the person about their concerns. Hearing people’s concerns will help you in any negotiation. Not only does it help you get information that will be critical to your negotiation but it also has the powerful effect of making the other person feel heard.

谈判的下一步是询问对方的顾虑。倾听对方的顾虑对任何谈判都大有裨益。这不仅能帮助你获取对谈判至关重要的信息，还能有效地让对方感到被重视。

Asking about someone’s concerns is the best way to understand and address any lingering concerns about you or your business that might prevent a successful deal. People often won’t share their concerns with you upfront. Instead, they’ll leave them unsaid, and leave your negotiation unresolved, or give someone else their business. But when you ask someone about their concerns, you give yourself the best possible chance of reaching success in your negotiation.

询问对方的顾虑是了解并解决他们可能对你或你的业务造成的任何潜在疑虑的最佳方式，这些疑虑可能会阻碍交易的成功。人们通常不会一开始就坦诚地表达他们的顾虑。相反，他们会选择沉默，导致谈判悬而未决，或者把生意拱手让给别人。但是，当你主动询问对方的顾虑时，你就能最大限度地提高谈判成功的几率。

Second, asking about someone’s concerns is a great way of getting at their needs. This is especially useful when you are meeting someone for the first time, or are trying to win over a new client. This question will help you uncover what needs aren’t being met and explain how you can meet them.

其次，询问对方的顾虑是了解其需求的绝佳方法。这在初次见面或争取新客户时尤为有效。这个问题能帮助你发现对方尚未满足的需求，并解释你能如何满足这些需求。

Last, getting at someone’s concerns is a great way of discovering their feelings about a situation without using what I call the “F-word” and putting a person on the spot.

最后，了解别人的顾虑是发现他们对某种情况的感受的好方法，而无需使用我所谓的“F字词”，也不会让别人难堪。

Addressing Barriers to Agreement

消除达成协议的障碍

Addressing someone’s potential concerns with you or what you’re proposing helps you eliminate any barriers to agreement. It gives you good data on why a resolution has not already been reached with this person—what has been holding someone back. Many times, our clients, spouses, and colleagues will not make their concerns clear. They may be waiting for permission, an opening to say it’s okay. If you don’t ask, they won’t tell, and you may not reach an agreement. So you need to invite them—in the right way.

事先了解对方可能对你或你的提议有所顾虑，有助于消除达成共识的障碍。这能让你更好地了解为什么之前与对方未能达成一致——究竟是什么阻碍了他们。很多时候，我们的客户、配偶和同事不会直接表达他们的顾虑。他们可能在等待许可，等待一个可以开口的契机。如果你不问，他们就不会说，你们可能就无法达成一致。所以，你需要以恰当的方式邀请他们参与讨论。

I once talked to a company about a potential speaking engagement. This company had never brought in an outside speaker to coach them in negotiation, instead relying exclusively on their in-house trainers. When we spoke about my coming in, I asked them directly, “I know you have an in-house training team. What concerns do you have about bringing in an outside speaker?” They literally exhaled in relief. “I’m so glad you asked,” said the senior manager on the call. “Historically, we’ve had a couple of concerns. One was about price and whether we could justify the additional expense to senior management. But the other was about what it might signal to our employees. Because we normally use our in-house training team, we didn’t want them to feel devalued, or our employees to get the message that something was seriously wrong and that’s why we hired a big speaker from the outside.”

我曾与一家公司洽谈过一次演讲邀约。这家公司从未聘请过外部讲师来指导他们的谈判技巧，一直以来都只依赖内部培训师。当我们谈到我的邀请时，我直接问他们：“我知道你们有内部培训团队。你们对聘请外部讲师有什么顾虑吗？”他们如释重负地叹了口气。“很高兴你问了这个问题，”电话那头的高级经理说道，“过去，我们确实有一些顾虑。一是价格，我们能否向高层管理人员证明这笔额外支出的合理性。二是这可能会给员工传递什么信息。因为我们通常都使用内部培训团队，我们不想让他们觉得自己被轻视，也不想让员工觉得我们出了大问题，所以才聘请了这么一位大牌讲师。”

This information helped me structure a proposal for this company that met their needs. I made sure to include all the companies I had trained that also had in-house training teams, so that management could tell their employees that most companies now found it valuable to get some outside expertise on negotiation. I also included bullet points on why many companies were choosing to hire outside speakers on negotiation to train even their internal trainers—that this kind of training could help anyone, including trainers, advance their careers within their companies. And I gave management ideas for how I could involve their in-house trainers in my session, so that we were also celebrating the expertise in the room. Asking their concerns gave me valuable information that helped me land the deal.

这些信息帮助我为这家公司撰写了一份符合他们需求的提案。我特意列出了所有我曾培训过且拥有内部培训团队的公司，以便管理层可以告诉员工，现在大多数公司都认为聘请外部谈判专家非常有价值。我还列出了许多公司选择聘请外部谈判专家来培训内部培训师的原因——这类培训可以帮助包括培训师在内的所有人提升职业发展。此外，我还向管理层提出了一些建议，让他们可以邀请内部培训师参与我的培训，从而充分展现他们的专业知识。询问他们的顾虑也让我获得了宝贵的信息，最终促成了这笔交易。

In addition to helping you address any barriers to agreement, the other reason to ask what concerns someone has with you or what you are offering is that it builds rapport and it encourages openness. It shows that you simultaneously possess enough confidence to address any concerns that may come up, and that you care about making sure what you are offering is right for this deal. One successful art buyer told me that she has built credibility over the years by making sure she hears her clients’ concerns. If a piece of art she has identified for that client doesn’t meet those concerns, she advises them not to buy, despite the fact that she would earn a commission. She tells people to wait for something that will meet their needs in the long term. And in doing so, she has earned the lifelong loyalty—and commission dollars—of her clients.

除了帮助你消除达成协议的障碍之外，询问对方对你或你提供的产品或服务有何顾虑的另一个原因是，这有助于建立融洽的关系，并鼓励坦诚交流。这表明你既有足够的自信来应对可能出现的任何疑虑，又关心你提供的产品或服务是否适合这笔交易。一位成功的艺术品买家告诉我，多年来，她通过认真倾听客户的顾虑来建立信誉。如果她为客户找到的艺术品不符合这些顾虑，即使她会因此获得佣金，她也会建议客户不要购买。她会告诉人们等待一件能够长期满足他们需求的艺术品。通过这种方式，她赢得了客户的终身忠诚——以及丰厚的佣金。

Addressing Unmet Needs

满足未被满足的需求

Asking someone about their concerns helps you understand any needs they have that aren’t being met, or what’s not working for the person as things stand. If you’re looking to secure a new client or deal, you will want to know what didn’t work in the last deal they did. So you can ask, “What were your concerns about your last deal?” In this way, you’ll understand better what their priorities and needs are, and you’ll be positioned to do better for them.

询问他人的顾虑有助于你了解他们有哪些需求尚未得到满足，或者目前哪些方面对他们来说行不通。如果你想争取新客户或达成新交易，你需要了解他们在上一笔交易中哪些环节出了问题。因此，你可以问：“您对上一笔交易有哪些顾虑？” 这样，你就能更好地了解他们的优先事项和需求，从而更好地为他们服务。

Elizabeth is an insurance broker who advises families with large businesses or property holdings on their insurance needs. One day, she and her team walked into a conference room for a meeting with a prospective client, a family with substantial insurance needs, in hopes of winning their business. The family had been with another insurance broker for a while and said things were “fine,” but yet they had asked for this meeting.

伊丽莎白是一位保险经纪人，专门为拥有大型企业或房产的家庭提供保险咨询服务。一天，她和她的团队走进会议室，准备与一位潜在客户——一个保险需求量很大的家庭——会面，希望能拿下他们的业务。这个家庭之前已经和另一位保险经纪人合作了一段时间，他们说一切都“还不错”，但还是要求和伊丽莎白会面。

Elizabeth’s team started the meeting by introducing their company and talking about what they could offer. Elizabeth, who had been watching the family and sizing up the situation, paused the presentation to ask the family a question: “Before we go any further, I want to make sure we are responsive to your needs. What are your concerns about your current situation?”

伊丽莎白的团队在会议开始时介绍了他们的公司以及他们能提供的服务。伊丽莎白一直在观察这家人，评估情况，她暂停了介绍，问了他们一个问题：“在我们继续之前，我想确保我们能够满足您的需求。您对目前的状况有什么担忧？”

The family said they were concerned about the level of service they were receiving from their current broker. Elizabeth summarized and followed up: “So the level of service hasn’t been what you needed. Can you tell us more?” They elaborated. Their current broker was working part-time. Sometimes they would try to reach her and she wasn’t in—and they had to wait a few days for help. They didn’t feel as though they had someone who was taking care of them and prioritizing their concerns.

这家人表示他们对目前经纪人的服务水平感到担忧。伊丽莎白总结并追问：“所以，您觉得目前的服务水平没有达到您的预期。您能详细说明一下吗？” 他们进一步解释说，他们目前的经纪人是兼职的。有时他们联系她时，她不在——他们不得不等上几天才能得到帮助。他们感觉没有人真正关心他们，也没有把他们的需求放在心上。

Insurance brokers normally put together proposals for potential clients that look like spreadsheets, with a number of different policies listed and the numbers for each. But at the conclusion of the meeting, Elizabeth put together a service plan that showed the family who would have primary responsibility for their account, including backup personnel in case that person was out. After she sent it over, the family spokesperson called her and said, “Wow, this is different from what we usually see. I’ve never seen a proposal that focused on service.” The family awarded Elizabeth’s company their full account. Not only did Elizabeth’s question help her win the business, it won the family’s trust. When Elizabeth changed companies a few years later, the family called and said, “We’re going with you.”

保险经纪人通常会为潜在客户准备一份类似电子表格的方案，上面列出各种不同的保单及其对应的保费。但在会面结束时，伊丽莎白却拿出了一份服务计划，向这家人明确了谁将负责他们的账户，以及在负责人缺勤时可以顶替的人员。她把计划发过去后，这家人的发言人打电话给她说：“哇，这跟我们通常看到的完全不一样。我从来没见过这么注重服务的方案。”这家人最终决定把整个账户都交给伊丽莎白的公司。伊丽莎白的提问不仅帮她赢得了这笔生意，也赢得了这家人的信任。几年后，当伊丽莎白更换公司时，这家人打电话来说：“我们以后就认准你了。”

Getting to the Root of Someone’s Feelings

探寻他人情感的根源

“What are your concerns?” is a really effective way of asking about someone’s feelings without using the “F-word” itself. We know how critical feelings are to unlocking conflict and reaching deals. But a lot of us have strong reactions to the “F-word,” whether in work or relationships. It can be difficult to ask a coworker, someone you don’t know well, or someone with whom you may be having a conflict, what they are feeling without provoking defensiveness. Many people in negotiations are not ready to confront their own emotions when asked about them by another person. And to make things worse, people often ask a more closed version of the feelings question—“Are you upset with me?”—that at best gets limited information and instead, frequently inflames the conversation. When you ask someone about their concerns, you give them an open, safe prompt to talk about their feelings.

“你有什么顾虑？”是一种非常有效的询问他人感受的方式，无需直接说出那个“F”开头的词。我们都知道，感受对于化解冲突、达成协议至关重要。但无论是在工作还是人际关系中，很多人都会对“F”开头的词产生强烈的抵触情绪。询问同事、不太熟悉的人，或者与你存在冲突的人的感受，而不引起对方的防御心理，往往是一件难事。许多谈判者在被问及自身情绪时，都不愿面对。更糟糕的是，人们常常会问一个更封闭式的问题——“你生我的气了吗？”——这种问题充其量只能获得有限的信息，反而常常会激化矛盾。当你询问对方的顾虑时，你实际上是在为他们提供一个开放、安全的契机，让他们可以畅所欲言地表达自己的感受。

Consider Rahul’s story from the beginning of this chapter. He sensed that something was wrong in his relationship with his boss. He could have just made a plan with his boss to address Arya’s concern, but it wouldn’t have fixed the real issue, which was the CEO’s wanting to feel like a team. Rahul’s asking about his CEO’s concerns paved the way for them to address the root issue, rather than cycling through potential solutions to an unknown problem. Because they addressed this underlying concern, they fixed their working relationship in addition to formulating a plan to talk to the CFO.

回顾本章开头拉胡尔的故事。他察觉到自己和老板的关系有些不对劲。他本可以和老板商量一下如何解决阿雅的担忧，但这并不能解决根本问题——首席执行官渴望融入团队。拉胡尔主动询问首席执行官的顾虑，这让他们得以直面问题的根源，而不是盲目地寻找各种解决方案来应对一个未知的问题。正是因为他们解决了这个根本问题，才得以改善彼此的工作关系，并制定了与首席财务官沟通的计划。

Trainer Autumn Calabrese told me a story about how addressing a client’s concerns helped her negotiate with him and make progress toward his goals. Autumn works with a small number of high-profile clients on personal training and nutrition for weight loss. One day, she used this question to negotiate with one of her clients, a successful and overweight man in his thirties who was working on his fitness and nutrition in order to get healthier. Autumn said, “One day we were working out and something major came up. Because he was significantly overweight, over four hundred pounds, exercise was hard for him. Up until that point, we had just been working out. But that day, I had him do one particular exercise move, and then I could see it. There was anger coming out of him. The more we would do the workout move, the more he would get mad and frustrated with himself—and the more you get mad and frustrated, the more that your form can slip, meaning you’re not doing the move right. That can lead to injury, so I had to stop him. I said, ‘What’s going on? What is concerning you?’ He said, ‘I’m mad because I can’t do it.’ I said, ‘I don’t think that’s what you’re mad about.’ And we sat there. For a minute he said, ‘Forget it, I’m not going to do this,’ but I said to him, ‘You’re not walking out of the gym. Sit down. Tell me what’s concerning you.’ And what came out surprised us both. He had lost his parents when he was very young, and his grandfather had raised him. When he was ten years old, he went in the bedroom in the morning to get ready for school and found his grandfather had passed away. Because of that, over a yearlong period he went into foster care, where he went through a lot of traumatic stuff. There were several kids in the house, and his foster parents would lock the refrigerator at night so they could only eat at certain times.”

健身教练奥特姆·卡拉布雷斯给我讲了一个故事，讲述了她如何通过解决客户的顾虑来与他协商，并最终帮助他实现目标。奥特姆为少数几位高端客户提供私人健身和营养指导，帮助他们减肥。有一天，她用这个问题与一位客户进行协商。这位客户是一位三十多岁的成功人士，身材略胖，他正在努力改善体能和营养，以求变得更健康。奥特姆说：“有一天我们一起锻炼，突然出了点问题。因为他严重超重，超过四百磅，所以锻炼对他来说很困难。在那之前，我们一直都在锻炼。但那天，我让他做某个特定的动作，然后我察觉到了。他好像很生气。我们越是做那个动作，他就越生气，越是对自己感到沮丧——而越生气、越沮丧，动作就越容易变形，也就是说，动作做错了。这很容易导致受伤，所以我不得不阻止他。我问他：‘怎么了？你有什么烦心事？’他说：‘我生气是因为我做不到。’我说：‘我觉得你生气的原因不是这个。’然后我们就坐在那里。他犹豫了一会儿，说：‘算了，我不做了。’但我对他说：‘你不能离开健身房。坐下。’” “告诉我你有什么烦心事。”他接下来说的话让我们俩都感到惊讶。他很小的时候就失去了双亲，是由祖父抚养长大的。十岁那年，他早上走进卧室准备上学，却发现祖父已经去世了。因此，在接下来的一年里，他被送去寄养家庭，在那里经历了许多创伤。寄养家庭里有好几个孩子，他的养父母晚上会把冰箱锁上，这样他们就只能在特定的时间吃饭。

As Autumn told me, he developed a bad relationship with food as a result of this traumatic event. So years later, at thirtysomething years old, what was happening during this workout was that all his sadness about losing his grandpa, the emotions that came along with going into foster care, and the way he was abused around food and eating that he had suppressed for all those years, bubbled to the surface. She added, “And so he got it out, and then we got back to the workout, because we had addressed some of the real work. Asking about his concerns let us both figure out that it wasn’t about a lunge or because the weights were heavy—there was something much bigger there under the surface. Addressing it helped him, and us, get back on the right foot toward his goals.” Autumn used this one open question to help her negotiate her relationship with her client so he could continue to work toward a healthier future.

正如奥特姆告诉我的那样，那次创伤事件导致他与食物的关系变得很糟糕。多年后，在他三十多岁的时候，在这次锻炼中，他所有关于失去祖父的悲伤、进入寄养家庭的种种情绪，以及多年来他因食物和饮食问题而遭受的虐待，都涌上心头，这些情绪他一直压抑着。她补充道：“他把这些情绪释放出来后，我们又回到了锻炼上，因为我们已经解决了一些真正的问题。询问他的顾虑让我们都意识到，问题不在于弓步，也不在于哑铃的重量——表面之下隐藏着更深层次的原因。解决这个问题帮助他，也帮助我们，重新走上了正确的道路，朝着他的目标前进。”奥特姆正是利用这个开放式的问题，帮助她与客户建立良好的关系，使他能够继续朝着更健康的未来努力。

How to Ask the Question

如何提问

In the rest of this chapter, we will discuss how to ask someone about their concerns effectively. I will give you tips to set the stage and then deal with some of the reactions you might get to this question. I will also help you work through what to do when you have accurately summarized how someone is feeling, but they’re not ready to hear it from you. And I will give you strategies for how to handle feedback from the other person once you have summarized their answer.

在本章剩余部分，我们将讨论如何有效地询问他人的顾虑。我会提供一些技巧，帮助你做好准备，并应对可能出现的各种反应。我还会帮助你了解，当你准确概括了对方的感受，但他们却还没准备好接受你的反馈时，应该怎么做。最后，我还会提供一些策略，教你如何在总结对方的回答后，妥善处理他们的反馈。

Land the Plane

降落飞机

This question is one where you may be nervous to bring the plane down for a landing. Asking someone about their concerns invites them to tell you something you may not agree with or like—or something for which you may not feel totally prepared. But take heart. First of all, the person may not have concerns about you but about something or someone else. Wouldn’t that be great to know? Second, if the person has concerns, it’s much better to know than not.
