It allows you a chance to address them and close your deal, instead of letting them fester and get in the way of your negotiation. Don’t try to guess someone’s concerns or close off the conversation. Ask the question and land your plane. And remember, following the tips below means that you don’t even need to come up with an answer to those concerns immediately. You have time to gather information and formulate a plan.

这个问题可能会让你紧张得不知所措，就像飞机迫降一样。询问对方的顾虑，意味着他们可能会告诉你一些你不认同或不喜欢的事情，或者一些你还没做好充分准备的事情。但别担心。首先，对方的顾虑可能并非针对你，而是针对其他人或事。如果能知道这一点，岂不是更好？其次，即使对方确实有顾虑，了解总比不知道好。这让你有机会解决这些问题，促成交易，而不是让它们滋生蔓延，阻碍谈判。不要试图猜测对方的顾虑，也不要急于结束对话。提出问题，就像降落飞机一样，让对话顺利进行。记住，遵循以下建议意味着你甚至不需要立即给出答案。你有时间收集信息，制定计划。

Enjoy the Silence

享受安静

After you ask this question, you’re going to enjoy (or at least allow) the silence that may follow. This question in particular might take someone an extra beat or two to answer. Do not jump in to fill what may feel like dead air—because that air isn’t dead, it’s alive with great possibility. What comes out on the other end of that silence may change everything you know about the negotiation and the other person.

问完这个问题后，你会享受（或者至少允许）随之而来的沉默。这个问题可能需要对方思考一两秒才能回答。不要急于打破这看似沉寂的沉默——因为那并非死寂，而是充满无限可能。沉默过后，对方的回答或许会彻底改变你对谈判和对方的认知。

Follow Up

跟进

When you ask someone about their concerns, you may uncover some of their feelings or unmet needs that they didn’t share before. For example, when Elizabeth asked this question of her prospective clients, they told her they needed better service. One of the best ways to follow up and hear more about those needs is to summarize (see next page) and then ask, as she did, “Can you tell me more about that?” In this way, you’ll help them (and yourself) make those needs concrete so that you can address them in your negotiation. In this case, Elizabeth found out that better service meant knowing that someone would always be in to return their call if they had a business need.

当你询问别人的顾虑时，你可能会发现他们之前没有透露的一些感受或未被满足的需求。例如，当伊丽莎白向她的潜在客户提出这个问题时，他们告诉她他们需要更好的服务。跟进并了解更多需求的最佳方法之一是进行总结（见下一页），然后像伊丽莎白那样问道：“您能详细说说吗？” 这样，你就能帮助他们（也包括你自己）将这些需求具体化，以便在谈判中加以解决。在这个例子中，伊丽莎白发现更好的服务意味着，如果他们有任何业务需求，总会有人及时回复他们的电话。

Summarize and Ask for Feedback

总结并征求反馈意见

Again, you’ll want to summarize what you hear when you ask this question. By repeating back what you’ve heard and giving the other person an opportunity to weigh in, you’ll also help them (and you) hear what they have said and make any corrections or additions they wish. Finally, summarizing also helps the other person know their concerns were important enough that you took the time to understand them.

同样，在提出这个问题时，你需要总结你听到的内容。通过复述你听到的内容，并给对方机会发表意见，你也能帮助他们（以及你自己）更好地理解他们所说的话，并进行任何必要的更正或补充。最后，总结还能让对方感受到你重视他们的顾虑，并花时间去理解。

Listen to What Is Not Said

倾听那些未说出口的话。

I’ve asked you to pay attention to non-verbal language throughout these Window questions, but when you’re asking someone their concerns, you must pay attention to what isn’t said. Sometimes that means reading between the lines of what someone is telling you about their concerns, to figure out what’s really bothering them. Paying attention to non-verbal communication is crucial when you ask about someone’s concerns. People frequently censor their concerns in negotiation unless directly invited—sometimes multiple times—to share them. I can’t tell you the number of times I have asked someone if a particular proposal will work for them and they say yes while shaking their head no ! Nikhil Seth of the United Nations told me that asking about someone’s concerns is extremely important in diplomatic negotiations and that the answer to the question may not be stated verbally. “You have to interpret the person’s emotive language—it may not be verbal, but instead may be from what I call the ‘eyes of the body’—to see how people really feel about a certain issue.”

在这些“窗口”问题中，我一直要求你们注意非语言交流，但当你询问他人的顾虑时，更要关注那些未说出口的信息。有时，这意味着你需要揣摩对方言外之意，才能弄清真正困扰他们的是什么。在询问他人顾虑时，关注非语言沟通至关重要。人们在谈判中常常会隐藏自己的顾虑，除非被直接邀请——有时甚至被多次邀请——才能表达出来。我数不清有多少次问别人某个提议是否可行，他们嘴上说着“是”，实际上却在摇头！联合国尼基尔·塞思告诉我，在外交谈判中，询问他人的顾虑极其重要，而且答案可能不会以口头形式表达。“你必须解读对方的情感语言——它可能并非口头表达，而是通过我所谓的‘肢体语言’——来了解人们对某个问题的真实感受。”

So when you ask someone about their concerns, you want to be extremely attentive to body language as well as tiny wording clues that tell you they may be holding back on their concerns or experiencing something they are reluctant to share. When this happens, I respond by (1) respectfully noting the verbal and non-verbal communication I’m seeing; (2) stating my respect for this person and her viewpoint; and (3) re-asking the question. As a mediator, I’ve asked people many times what concerns they have about a particular deal. If they shrug, look down and say, “Yeah, this is fine,” that tells me that “fine” means “less than good,” and the shrug may indicate resignation. I might respond, “Your words are telling me we’re fine, but your face is saying something different. You’re the decision-maker here, not me, so if you have concerns, I want to understand them. What did I miss?” They appreciate this and add whatever I didn’t get the first time.

所以，当你询问对方的顾虑时，你需要格外留意他们的肢体语言以及措辞中的细微线索，这些都可能暗示他们有所保留，或者正在经历一些不愿提及的事情。遇到这种情况，我会这样做：(1) 尊重地记录我观察到的言语和非言语交流；(2) 表达我对对方及其观点的尊重；(3) 再次询问。作为一名调解员，我曾多次询问人们对某项交易的顾虑。如果他们耸耸肩，低头说“嗯，还行”，这说明“还行”的意思是“不太好”，而耸肩可能表示无奈。我会回应说：“你的话告诉我一切都好，但你的表情却另有深意。你是决策者，不是我，所以如果你有任何顾虑，我希望能够理解。我漏掉了什么吗？” 他们会对此表示感谢，并补充我第一次没有理解的内容。

Even your loved ones, whether family or other close relationships, may hold back on sharing their concerns out of fear or embarrassment. My brother and sister-in-law recently welcomed a baby girl. At our first big family gathering after her birth, I could tell that my daughter, who for many years had been the only child in our extended family, was struggling with the shift in everyone’s attention. During a quiet moment, I asked her what she was feeling, and she said, “Nothing, Mom! I’m fine. I’m just tired from the trip.” I tried again. “I know you’re telling me you’re fine, but your face looks a little sad. If anything is bothering you, even if it’s just a tiny bit, you can tell me.” This time, she snuggled in for a hug and told me that she loved her baby cousin but felt like maybe she didn’t matter as much to the adults in our family anymore. We had a meaningful conversation in which I was able to share that as the oldest child in my family, I too had struggled with feeling left behind when my siblings were born. Listening to what she didn’t say and inviting her to be open with me helped pave the way for us to connect.

即使是你的至亲，无论是家人还是其他亲密关系，也可能因为害怕或尴尬而不敢表达他们的担忧。我的哥哥嫂子最近生了个女儿。在她出生后的第一次大型家庭聚会上，我看得出来，我的女儿——多年来一直是我们大家庭里唯一的孩子——不太适应大家关注的焦点转移。趁着安静的时刻，我问她感觉如何，她说：“没事，妈妈！我很好。只是旅途劳顿。”我又问了一遍：“我知道你说你没事，但你的脸色看起来有点难过。如果你有什么烦心事，哪怕只是一点点，都可以告诉我。”这一次，她依偎过来抱住我，告诉我她很爱她的小表妹，但感觉自己好像不再像以前那样被我们家里的成年人重视了。我们进行了一次意义深刻的谈话，我跟她分享了我自己的经历：作为家里的老大，当我的弟弟妹妹出生时，我也曾有过被冷落的感觉。倾听她未说出口的话，并鼓励她对我敞开心扉，这有助于我们建立联系。

What about if you ask this question and meet some resistance? Let’s say I ask someone, “What’s concerning you?” and they push their chair back, cross their arms, and say, “I’m not sure what you’re talking about.” This is a sign they may be feeling defensive or worried you may try to put them on the spot. (Note that they may also be feeling one or both of the “Big Two”: fear and guilt.) If this happens to you, here’s something to try: remember in the Mirror question about feelings, how I told you a story about myself before I asked you to return the favor? You’re going to do that here, the way Rahul did in the story that began this chapter, when he led with his own concerns before asking his boss to reciprocate. So as an example, I might respond with, “I feel like that question didn’t land the way I intended. Let me try again: for the last week, I’ve been concerned about the way things have felt between us. I found myself concerned that something had gone wrong, and I didn’t know what. I greatly value what you have to say. So I’m here to listen to anything that may be concerning you.” Chances are that by respecting their initial hesitation and showing a little of your own humanity, you’ll be more successful in this second attempt.

如果你问这个问题时遇到阻力怎么办？比如说，我问某人“你有什么顾虑？”，他们却把椅子往后一推，双臂交叉抱在胸前，说：“我不太明白你在说什么。” 这表明他们可能感到防备，或者担心你会让他们难堪。（注意，他们也可能同时感受到“两大情绪”中的一种或两种：恐惧和内疚。）如果你遇到这种情况，可以试试这个方法：还记得在“镜子”问题中关于感受的提问吗？我先讲了自己的故事，然后才请你也讲讲我的故事。你在这里也要这样做，就像本章开头故事里的拉胡尔那样，他先说了自己的顾虑，然后才请老板也分享一下。举个例子，我可能会这样回答：“我觉得你刚才的问题可能没达到我的预期效果。让我再说一遍：过去一周，我一直在担心我们之间的关系。我总觉得哪里出了问题，但又说不上来。我很重视你的想法，所以如果你有什么顾虑，我愿意倾听。” 尊重对方最初的犹豫，并展现出你的一些人性化一面，第二次尝试很可能会更加成功。

If you do this, and the person still insists they don’t have concerns, I would let it rest for now. They may not be ready to share. Instead, work on continuing to establish rapport. You can make some small talk, or move on to the next two questions, both of which should produce more positive feelings, and try again later if the moment seems right.

如果你这样做，对方仍然坚持说他们没有顾虑，那就暂时先别再问了。他们可能还没准备好分享。相反，你应该继续努力建立融洽的关系。你可以和对方闲聊几句，或者直接问接下来的两个问题，这两个问题应该都能让他们感觉更积极。如果时机合适，之后再尝试。

Wrapping Up

总结

You’ve asked someone their concerns and better understand where they’re coming from. Now let’s turn to the next question, in which you’re going to examine a prior success so that you can pave the way for your own negotiation success in the final chapter and beyond.

你已经询问了对方的顾虑，更好地理解了他们的立场。现在让我们来看下一个问题，你需要分析之前的成功案例，以便为你在最后一章及以后的谈判中取得成功奠定基础。

#↩

NINE HOW HAVE YOU HANDLED THIS SUCCESSFULLY IN THE PAST?

九、你过去是如何成功处理这件事的？

Rachel and Nick, out of college for five years and dating for two, moved in together six months ago. At the beginning of their relationship, they’d spent a lot of time outdoors, hiking on weekends, and also in the kitchen cooking together. Each had never felt happier. They had lots of family similarities and views on what was important to them in life. Both felt they were moving toward marriage.

瑞秋和尼克大学毕业五年，交往两年后，六个月前开始同居。恋爱初期，他们经常一起户外活动，周末徒步旅行，也经常一起下厨做饭。他们从未感到如此幸福。他们的家庭背景和人生观有很多相似之处。两人都觉得这段感情正朝着婚姻的方向发展。

Rachel has a demanding public relations job, while Nick works as a freelance graphic designer with mostly regular hours. Prior to this job, Rachel had spent three years as a PR manager at an established beauty company with regular hours but seemingly no room to move up. Then she was offered the chance to work at an emerging cosmetics brand, with a promotion to senior PR manager. Rachel was excited to work at a new company and represent products she would actually use. But her new job quickly ate up most of her life. The company was expanding rapidly, with all the growing pains you’d expect: turnover, changes in strategy. On top of this, Rachel’s manager left unexpectedly two weeks into her job, and she had to pick up extra responsibility while they searched for the replacement. She went from not traveling at all to traveling once a month for almost a week. But the cultural changes impacted Rachel most. Not only did she spend more hours in the office on weekdays, but her evenings and weekends became consumed by texts, calls, and requests to respond to the latest “fire drill.” Her CEO was an eccentric personality who demanded immediate responses, sometimes contradicted herself, and occasionally yelled. Rachel often felt stressed. Even when the texts had seemed to stop for the evening, Rachel, fearing she might miss an alert, would continue to check her phone as she and Nick watched television.

瑞秋从事一份工作繁忙的公关工作，而尼克则是一名自由平面设计师，工作时间相对规律。在此之前，瑞秋曾在一家老牌美妆公司担任了三年公关经理，工作时间规律，但似乎没有晋升空间。后来，她获得了一个机会，加入一家新兴化妆品品牌，并晋升为高级公关经理。瑞秋很高兴能加入一家新公司，推广她自己真正会使用的产品。但这份新工作很快就占据了她生活的大部分。公司正在快速扩张，随之而来的是各种成长的烦恼：人员流动、战略调整等等。雪上加霜的是，瑞秋的经理在她入职两周后突然离职，在公司寻找接替人选期间，她不得不承担额外的责任。她从完全不用出差变成了每月出差一次，每次将近一周。但对瑞秋影响最大的还是工作文化的转变。她不仅工作日要在办公室待更长时间，晚上和周末也都被短信、电话和各种“紧急通知”填满。她的CEO性格古怪，要求立即回复，有时自相矛盾，偶尔还会大吼大叫。瑞秋经常感到压力很大。即使晚上短信似乎已经停止发送，瑞秋仍然担心错过任何提醒，所以和尼克一起看电视时，她会不停地查看手机。

Nick grew resentful of Rachel’s lack of free time, frequently rolling his eyes and making cutting comments about her work. Each of them started to feel disconnected. Weekend activities slowed down and almost stopped. The last time they had gone hiking, they were in an area with spotty cell phone coverage, and Rachel spent most of the hike stressed that she might miss something. They drove home in silence.

尼克对瑞秋缺乏空闲时间感到不满，经常翻白眼，并对她的工作冷嘲热讽。两人之间开始出现隔阂。周末活动逐渐减少，最终几乎停止。他们上次去徒步旅行时，所在区域手机信号时断时续，瑞秋一路都在担心错过什么。回家的路上，他们一路沉默。

Finally, Nick and Rachel sat down to talk things out. Nick felt Rachel had chosen her job over their relationship. Rachel told Nick she felt frustrated with his eye rolling, and also helpless, like he was blaming her for something she couldn’t control. The work environment had been high pressure and relentless. Rachel, too, had felt desperate for more balance in her life.

最后，尼克和瑞秋坐下来好好谈谈。尼克觉得瑞秋为了工作放弃了他们的感情。瑞秋告诉尼克，她对他的白眼感到恼火，也感到无助，好像他在责怪她做了她无法控制的事情。工作环境压力巨大，令人疲惫不堪。瑞秋也渴望在生活中找到更多平衡。

Nick said, “I know you’re wired differently from me. I need a lot of free time, and you’ve always liked working hard. How have you managed to have a life in your previous jobs?” Rachel thought back and told Nick about her first year out of college, when she worked on a U.S. presidential campaign as one of the coordinators for her home state. The hours were intense and the demands of the job seemingly endless. She had been in a relationship then, too, and struggled to find time to connect. But once she had acclimated and built credibility with her team, she’d found ways to set boundaries around some of her weekends and weeknights. She did this by looking in advance to see when important fund-raising deadlines or events were happening, and then finding other times that seemed likely to be slower. She worked with her interns to build their knowledge so that they could sub in for her sometimes. Then she communicated in advance when she needed time off and arranged for coverage. Now that she was thinking about it, Rachel remembered that she had even negotiated time every day when she could run or go to the gym and not be called except in real emergencies—and that had been a huge mood lifter. She realized she hadn’t gone for a run in weeks.

尼克说：“我知道你和我性格不一样。我需要很多空闲时间，而你一直都喜欢努力工作。你以前是怎么兼顾工作和生活的？”瑞秋回忆起大学毕业后的第一年，告诉尼克她当时在家乡州参与美国总统竞选活动，担任协调员之一。那段时间工作强度很大，工作需求似乎永无止境。那时她也有男朋友，很难抽出时间来维系感情。但一旦她适应了新环境，并在团队中建立了信誉，她就找到了一些方法来安排自己的周末和工作日晚上。她会提前查看重要的筹款截止日期或活动安排，然后寻找其他可能比较清闲的时间段。她会帮助实习生提升技能，以便他们有时可以替她工作。然后，她会在需要休假时提前告知，并安排好人手。现在回想起来，瑞秋想起她甚至每天都会抽出时间跑步或去健身房，除非真的有紧急情况，否则不会被叫醒——这让她心情大好。她意识到自己已经好几个星期没跑步了。

As she talked, Rachel started to think out loud about how she could put this strategy into practice in her current job, now that she’d been there a year. Yes, there were times when she would have to work weekends. But not every weekend. As chaotic as things could be sometimes, she was starting to see a rhythm to things—like times around their events or investor calls where breaks might be possible. Plus, she was a senior manager now—and a great boss, someone who shared information and strategies with her team. She had a terrific PR manager below her who was asking for more responsibility. With a bit of training, this manager could cover for Rachel sometimes.

瑞秋一边说着，一边开始思考如何将这个策略运用到她现在的工作中，毕竟她已经在这份工作上工作一年了。没错，有时候她确实需要周末加班，但并非每个周末都如此。尽管工作有时确实很混乱，但她开始摸索出一些规律——比如在公司活动或投资者电话会议前后，她可以抽出一些时间休息。此外，她现在是一位高级经理，而且是一位很棒的老板，会与团队分享信息和策略。她手下有一位非常优秀的公关经理，这位经理正在争取承担更多责任。经过一些培训，这位经理有时可以帮瑞秋分担工作。

These ideas all helped Rachel to feel better about her current situation—and her relationship with Nick. But she also realized, in the process of detailing this prior success, that she was able to get through the demanding presidential campaign in part because she knew it was time-limited, and she had a supportive boss. This PR job had no time limit, and her boss didn’t always communicate respectfully, or consistently. While Rachel wanted to work hard and advance in her career, she also needed time for her health, as well as the important people in her life. Recalling what had made her prior campaign job sustainable gave Rachel permission to consider whether this job was the best fit for her in the long term.

这些想法都让瑞秋对她目前的处境以及与尼克的关系感觉好了一些。但她也意识到，在回顾之前的成功经历时，她之所以能够挺过那场艰苦的总统竞选，部分原因是她知道那是限时的，而且她有一个支持她的老板。而这份公关工作没有时间限制，她的老板沟通方式也并非总是尊重她，或者前后不一致。瑞秋虽然渴望努力工作，在事业上有所发展，但她也需要时间照顾自己的健康，以及陪伴生命中重要的人。回想起之前那份竞选工作让她能够坚持下去的原因，瑞秋开始认真思考这份工作是否真的适合她长远发展。

Rachel and Nick came out of this conversation with a plan. She would negotiate for her Saturdays and Sunday mornings off, unless there was an emergency. They would have two nights a week where she turned off her phone after seven p.m., so they could have dinner and talk. Nick in turn promised to show more support for what Rachel was going through at work, that if she indicated she was dealing with an emergency, Nick would empathize rather than blame—and curtail the eye rolls. And Rachel started a casual job search, remaining open to the possibility of either staying and continuing to negotiate for what she needed, or finding another challenging position that also offered a respectful and healthy work culture. The following weekend, they went for a Saturday hike and each felt like they could draw a deep breath for the first time in months.

瑞秋和尼克经过一番谈话后制定了一个计划。她会争取周六和周日上午休息，除非有紧急情况。他们每周会安排两个晚上，瑞秋在晚上七点后关掉手机，这样他们就可以一起吃晚饭、聊聊天。作为回报，尼克承诺会更加支持瑞秋在工作中遇到的困难，如果她表示自己遇到了紧急情况，他会表示理解而不是责备——并且不再翻白眼。瑞秋开始非正式地寻找新工作，她对两种可能性都持开放态度：要么继续留在公司争取自己想要的待遇，要么寻找一份既具有挑战性又能提供尊重和健康工作氛围的工作。接下来的周末，他们一起去徒步旅行，感觉几个月来第一次可以真正放松下来。

Asking about a Prior Success

询问之前的成功

In this chapter, we once again travel back in time to help the other person remember ways in which they have successfully handled challenges similar to the one they—and you—face now.

在本章中，我们将再次回到过去，帮助对方回忆起他们曾经成功应对过与他们（以及你）现在面临的挑战类似的挑战的方法。

We know from the Mirror section that asking yourself about a prior success yields all sorts of helpful benefits. It triggers our memory bank of experiences to allow us to expand our pie of potential options for our current situation by examining where we’ve had success previously. In addition, memory influences how we make decisions; it affects how we feel about the path ahead of us. Memory can influence our sense of motivation and empowerment, and help us solve our next issue.

我们从“镜子”部分了解到，回顾过去的成功经历会带来诸多益处。它能激活我们过往的经验记忆，让我们通过审视以往的成功案例，拓展应对当前困境的潜在选择。此外，记忆还会影响我们的决策方式，以及我们对未来道路的感受。记忆能够增强我们的动力和掌控感，并帮助我们解决下一个问题。

In asking this question of someone else, you will open up a window so that you can expand your view of the other person and get to know more about what has made them successful in the past. You’ll gather important data about what has worked for this person in the past, and what might work for them—and you—again in the future.

通过向他人提出这个问题，你将打开一扇窗，从而拓宽对对方的了解，并深入了解他们过去成功的秘诀。你将收集到关于此人过去成功经验的重要信息，以及未来可能再次奏效的方法——无论对他们还是对你而言。

Additionally, in asking about a prior success, you’ll anchor the other person in positive, empowering feelings that research has shown to improve the way they will handle their next interpersonal interaction—with you! In this chapter, I will give you strategies to put the other person back in a success mind frame so that they can access their inner wisdom and generate ideas that will help move them forward. And if they can’t recall a previous similar success, I’ll help you follow up with them to find a different kind of previous success; you will then work with them to find similarities to the current situation. Together, you’ll leave this chapter empowered and ready to move toward what comes next.

此外，询问对方过去取得的成功，能够帮助对方建立积极、充满力量的心态。研究表明，这种心态能够改善他们下次与你互动时的表现！在本章中，我将提供一些策略，帮助你引导对方重拾成功的心态，从而激发他们的内在智慧，并产生有助于他们前进的想法。如果他们想不起之前类似的成功经历，我会帮助你跟进，找到其他类型的成功案例；然后，你们将一起探讨这些成功案例与当前情况的相似之处。读完本章，你们将充满力量，准备好迎接接下来的挑战。

Recalling a Prior Success Helps Someone Define Their Problem and Access Potential Solutions

回顾之前的成功经验有助于人们明确问题所在并找到潜在的解决方案。

When you ask someone this question, you allow them to remember and review, in detail if possible, the techniques and strategies that have worked for them in the past. When you help them remember what has worked in the past, you’ll be better positioned to work with them to figure out which of those strategies will work for both of you in this negotiation.

当你问别人这个问题时，你实际上是在引导他们回忆并尽可能详细地回顾过去行之有效的技巧和策略。当你帮助他们回忆起过去行之有效的方法时，你就能更好地与他们合作，找出哪些策略在这次谈判中对双方都有效。

Remember that in asking “How have you handled this successfully in the past?” you first need to understand what “this” is. “This” is your problem or goal from our first Window question, “Tell me.” Which means we are going back to that answer to make sure we have accurately defined the problem or goal. In the example that started this chapter, Rachel and Nick both supported Rachel’s need to work hard, and also desired to work on their partnership. Together, they defined the problem as “How can we honor Rachel’s career ambition while also finding space to nourish our relationship?”

记住，在问“你过去是如何成功处理这件事的？”之前，首先需要理解“这件事”指的是什么。“这件事”指的是我们在第一个问题“告诉我”中提出的问题或目标。这意味着我们要回到之前的回答，确保我们已经准确地定义了问题或目标。在本章开头的例子中，瑞秋和尼克都支持瑞秋努力工作，同时也希望维系彼此的关系。他们共同将问题定义为“我们如何在尊重瑞秋的职业抱负的同时，也找到空间来滋养我们的感情？”

Once you know the goal you’re working on, or the problem you are solving, recalling a prior related success helps you and the other person remember concrete strategies that might help again in your current negotiation. In many situations, this question will help you refine your understanding of the problem you want to solve and give you ideas to fix it.

一旦你明确了目标或要解决的问题，回顾之前相关的成功案例就能帮助你和对方记住一些具体的策略，这些策略在当前的谈判中可能再次奏效。在很多情况下，这个问题能帮助你更深入地理解想要解决的问题，并为你提供解决问题的思路。

Let’s go back to Smith and Rosa, the contractor and homeowner who worked together successfully on a number of home improvement projects in Rosa’s apartments up until their most recent job, which fell apart and resulted in litigation. Imagine that they sit down together to negotiate, and the mediator asks them: “Okay, so you both say your collaboration was great until this last job. How did you handle your previous work together so successfully?” The homeowner says, “Well, those were smaller jobs, and I also had more time to communicate with him on design choices. This time I had a lot going on, and he ended up picking those terrible cabinets.” The contractor says, “Usually we had a written contract, and she had always paid me a twenty-five percent down payment upfront. This time, since we’d already done a number of jobs together, we just shook hands on it. But she never paid me that deposit—or anything, for that matter. I know she was taking her kid to college, but how does that justify completely missing the payment?”

让我们回到史密斯和罗莎这对夫妇身上。这位承包商和房主之前在罗莎的公寓里合作过很多次，一直都很成功，直到最近一次合作出了问题，最终闹上了法庭。想象一下，他们坐下来协商，调解员问他们：“好的，你们都说之前的合作一直很顺利，直到这次。你们之前是怎么合作得那么成功的呢？”房主说：“那些都是小工程，而且我有更多的时间和他沟通设计方案。这次我有很多事情要忙，结果他选了那些难看的橱柜。”承包商说：“通常我们都会签合同，她总是会预付25%的定金。这次，因为我们之前合作过好几次，所以就握手成交了。但她既没付定金，也没付任何款项。我知道她要送孩子上大学，但这怎么能成为她完全不付款的理由呢？”

Asking about a prior success gave us so much information, both to diagnose what happened here and to help these two people figure out how they might work together better in the future. These two entrepreneurs were the victims of their own prior success. Rather than being some terrible personality conflict, we now know that this conflict resulted because they (1) trusted each other enough not to have a contract, which ended up backfiring; (2) were working on a bigger job than they’d ever done together before; (3) had been unable to communicate about design choices due to outside commitments; and (4) hadn’t followed their usual plan when it came to payment. Just in considering what made them successful in the past, we figured out that writing a contract with payment dates, and setting aside time for joint design choices, seemed to be their winning formula.

询问他们之前的成功经验让我们获得了大量信息，不仅有助于诊断此次事件的成因，还能帮助这两位创业者思考未来如何更好地合作。这两位创业者可以说是他们之前成功的受害者。我们现在了解到，这次冲突并非源于严重的性格冲突，而是因为：(1) 他们彼此过于信任，没有签订合同，结果适得其反；(2) 他们正在合作一个规模空前的项目；(3) 由于各自忙于其他事务，无法就设计方案进行充分沟通；(4) 在付款方面，他们没有遵循以往的惯例。仅仅回顾他们过去的成功经验，我们就发现，签订包含付款日期的合同，并预留时间共同讨论设计方案，似乎是他们成功的秘诀。

Recalling a Prior Success Acts as a Power Prime

回忆先前的成功可以起到强大的动力作用

The second reason to ask about a prior success is that it helps the other person gather the confidence and motivation to help solve the problem you both face. Remembering that feeling of power or confidence can help tremendously when facing a negotiation.

询问对方过往成功经验的第二个原因是，这有助于对方建立信心和动力，从而更好地解决你们共同面临的问题。在谈判中，重拾那种力量感或自信至关重要。

Research shows the value of what Columbia Business School professor Adam Galinsky and his co-authors call “power priming,” or the act of “coax[ing] ourselves into feeling more or less powerful than we typically feel.” Hundreds of studies have shown that simply recalling a previous time in which one had power can produce the same effects as actually having power in the present situation. Power priming can be especially helpful when we face challenging or stressful experiences, like in negotiation.

研究表明，哥伦比亚商学院教授亚当·加林斯基及其合作者提出的“权力启动”策略具有重要价值，即“诱导我们感觉自己比平时更有权力或更弱”。数百项研究表明，仅仅回忆起过去拥有权力的经历，就能产生与在当前情境中实际拥有权力相同的效果。当我们面对挑战或压力时，例如在谈判中，权力启动尤其有用。

Recalling a prior success acts as a power prime. You used it yourself in chapter 4, and here, you’re going to use that question to achieve a similar effect with someone else. You’ll remind them of a time when things went well for them, so that they can place this current negotiation into context. Looking at a prior success will help them see themselves, and the current situation, more positively, which may help you generate solutions that will be more advantageous for you both.

回忆过去的成功经历可以起到激发积极情绪的作用。你在第四章中就运用过这种方法，在这里，你将运用这个问题来帮助他人达到类似的效果。你要让他们想起过去一切顺利的经历，以便他们能够更好地理解当前的谈判。回顾过去的成功经历有助于他们更积极地看待自己和当前的处境，这或许能帮助你找到对双方都更有利的解决方案。

Asking an Adversary about a Prior Success?

询问对手之前的成功？

When I teach this question in workshops, people sometimes ask me: Do you really want to ask your adversary about a prior success? What if you’re both trying to get as much as possible from the negotiation?

当我在研讨会上讲授这个问题时，人们有时会问我：你真的想问你的对手之前的成功吗？如果你们双方都想从谈判中获得尽可能多的利益呢？

First, remember that your adversary during the negotiation is often your partner after the deal is done. Asking your boss for a better compensation package? Negotiating a good price and shelf space for your product at a large chain store? Trying to get another country to agree to the enforcement language you want in a joint resolution? Advocating for your client to upgrade to a package that better reflects the work they need you to do? Many of these situations require you to problem-solve with the other person at the table, or work with them again once this conversation is complete. Asking them how they have handled similar situations in the past successfully expands the pie of options so that you can better advocate for the ones that make sense for you.

首先，请记住，谈判中的对手往往是交易完成后你的合作伙伴。比如，你向老板争取更好的薪酬方案？在大连锁店为你的产品争取优惠价格和货架空间？试图让另一个国家同意你在联合决议中提出的执行条款？或者为客户争取升级到更能体现他们所需工作的方案？很多情况下，你需要与谈判桌上的对方共同解决问题，或者在谈判结束后再次与他们合作。询问他们过去如何成功处理类似情况，可以拓宽你的选择范围，让你更好地争取对你有利的方案。

Also, just because you’re asking for their ideas doesn’t mean you have to adopt all of them. Remember, you have already done the work to understand your own goals, needs, and ideas. So once you hear ideas from them, you’ll be able to evaluate them against the backdrop of everything you uncovered in the Mirror section. All this question does is expand the universe of possible options that will also meet your needs. If they raise something that doesn’t work for you, you’ll be able to articulate exactly why, and offer alternatives.

此外，征求他们的想法并不意味着你必须全盘接受。记住，你已经做足功课，了解了自己的目标、需求和想法。所以，当你听到他们的想法时，你可以结合你在“镜像”部分发现的一切来评估它们。这个问题的作用在于拓展可能满足你需求的选项范围。如果他们提出的方案不适合你，你可以清楚地说明原因，并提出替代方案。

And even if the person you’re negotiating with is not someone with whom you will have an ongoing relationship, I’ve seen this question produce great results. If you’re negotiating for a potential job, for example, and having a disagreement with the prospective hiring manager over salary, asking how they have successfully resolved a concern like this in the past may give you useful information. Maybe in the end they didn’t offer enough salary to make the job work, but if they offered you a budget for training and personal development and that sounded appealing, you could ask your next prospective employer what they offer on that front.

即使你谈判的对象并非你未来会长期合作的人，我也见过这个问题带来意想不到的好结果。例如，如果你正在洽谈一份工作，并且与未来的招聘经理在薪资方面存在分歧，那么询问他们过去是如何成功解决类似问题的，或许能为你提供一些有用的信息。也许他们最终提供的薪资不足以让你接受这份工作，但如果他们提供了培训和个人发展预算，而这听起来很有吸引力，那么你就可以询问下一位潜在雇主在这方面提供的待遇如何。

Finally, asking an adversary about a prior success also has the benefit of establishing rapport. By treating the other person as a partner in your negotiation, you increase the odds that they will want to do something beneficial for you, too.

最后，询问对手之前的成功经验也有助于建立融洽的关系。通过将对方视为谈判伙伴，你就能提高他们也愿意为你做些有益事情的可能性。

Your Turn in the Window: Asking about a Prior Success

轮到你发言了：询问之前的成功案例

Now that we know why this question is so beneficial, it’s time to turn to the how : as we did for ourselves in the Mirror chapter, we are going to ask about a prior success. This time we’re doing it through the Window, so that we can get a better view of the other person and what they are thinking.

既然我们已经了解了这个问题为何如此有益，接下来就该探讨如何操作了：就像我们在“镜子”那一章中为自己做的那样，我们要询问对方之前的成功经历。这次我们通过“窗口”来提问，以便更好地了解对方的想法。

Land the Plane

降落飞机

After you ask about a prior success, land the plane. As a reminder, that means that you ask this question and… that’s it. Some examples we want to avoid: “How have you handled this successfully in the past?… What about last year’s sales meeting?” or “From my perspective, you’ve been really successful at…”

询问过往的成功经验后，就应该及时收尾。再次提醒，这意味着你问完这个问题后……就到此为止。我们想避免的一些例子包括：“你过去是如何成功处理这件事的？……去年的销售会议怎么样？”或者“在我看来，你在……方面做得非常出色。”

Enjoy the Silence

享受安静

After you ask the question, make room for the silence that may follow. Allow the person the time to sort through their mental Rolodex of prior situations and come up with a success that resonates for them. If they ask for help, then read on for how to help.

提出问题后，请给对方一些时间，让他们回忆过往的经历，从中找到一个能引起共鸣的成功案例。如果他们寻求帮助，请继续阅读，了解如何提供帮助。

Follow Up

跟进

You want to follow up in a way that helps both of you get the most from this question. After asking about a prior success, you want to do for the other person what you did for yourself by allowing them to picture in as much detail as possible what the prior success looked and felt like. Remember how I had asked you to close your eyes and picture your previous success in as much detail as possible—what it felt, sounded, and tasted like? What posture or location were you in? I also asked you to remember the time leading up to that moment: your preparation, thoughts, tasks, and emotion.

你想以一种能让双方都从这个问题中获益最多的方式来跟进。在询问了对方之前的成功经历之后，你要像你之前帮助自己那样，引导对方尽可能详细地回忆起那次成功时的情景和感受。还记得我之前请你闭上眼睛，尽可能详细地回忆起你之前的成功吗？那种感觉、那种声音、那种味道是什么样的？你当时的姿势或所处的环境如何？我还请你回忆起当时的情景：你的准备、想法、任务以及情绪。

You did this because the above is useful data—remembering everything that went into a prior success helps you prepare to repeat it. Plus, when you recall a previous success, research shows that you are more likely to perform better in your next negotiation. When I ask people about a previous success, I try to help them recall that success in as much vivid detail as possible, and you’re also going to do that for someone else. How? You’re going to use two key skills you’ve been practicing: following up and summarizing.

你之所以这样做，是因为以上信息很有用——记住之前成功过程中的所有细节，有助于你为再次取得成功做好准备。此外，研究表明，当你回忆起之前的成功时，你在下次谈判中更有可能表现得更好。当我询问别人之前的成功经历时，我会尽力帮助他们尽可能生动地回忆起那次成功，你也要这样做。怎么做呢？你要运用你一直在练习的两项关键技能：跟进和总结。

Revisit your notes on what the person told you about their previous success. You’re going to ask about these one at a time, using “Tell me more…” For example: “Thanks for all this helpful information. Can you tell me more about the training and personal development budget?” Or, “Smith and Rosa, can you tell me more about the successful contracts you drafted in the past?” Then summarize: “It sounds like you pushed hard for this training budget and have been pleased that you got it through. Most of your competitors don’t have this, and you’ve found it to be successful in retaining and developing great talent.” Or, “It sounds like you clearly spelled out payment amounts and dates, as well as some language around design choices.”

回顾一下你之前记录的对方讲述的过往成功案例。你要逐一询问，使用“请详细说说……”这样的句式。例如：“感谢您提供的所有有用信息。您能详细介绍一下培训和个人发展预算吗？”或者，“史密斯和罗莎，您能详细介绍一下您过去起草的那些成功的合同吗？”然后总结道：“听起来您为争取到这笔培训预算付出了很多努力，而且很高兴最终成功了。您的大多数竞争对手都没有这项预算，而您发现它在留住和培养优秀人才方面非常有效。”或者，“听起来您清楚地列出了付款金额和日期，以及一些关于设计选择的条款。”

Following Up if the Person Can’t Recall a Similar Success

如果对方无法回忆起类似的成功案例，则需要进行后续跟进。

If the other person has trouble recalling a prior success—maybe saying to you, “This is the first time I have ever faced this issue”—then remember that you can still help them by asking them to recall a prior success that has any element similar to the current situation you’re discussing. In this way, you can help the person you’re talking to cast a wider net, and recall a prior success that may still give them useful data in solving the issue at hand.

如果对方难以回忆起之前的成功经验——比如他们会说：“这是我第一次遇到这个问题”——那么请记住，你仍然可以通过询问他们是否遇到过与当前情况有相似之处的成功案例来帮助他们。这样，你就能帮助对方拓宽思路，回忆起一些可能对解决当前问题有所帮助的成功案例。

Let’s look at some examples to see how recalling a different, but related, success can work as a means of helping you through your negotiation. If you’re working with your boss on an issue where a client who initially seemed happy is now questioning the entire project close to delivery, and this is the first time this has happened, you might ask them whether they’d ever had a last-minute success getting another working relationship back on track—with a coworker, for example. Perhaps there are techniques they used in that situation that could also work for a client-facing situation.

让我们来看几个例子，看看回忆起一个不同但相关的成功案例如何能帮助你进行谈判。如果你正在和老板讨论一个问题：一位客户起初看起来很满意，但在项目即将交付时却对整个项目提出了质疑，而这种情况还是第一次发生，你可以问问老板是否曾经在最后关头成功地挽回过其他工作关系——比如和同事的关系。也许他们当时使用的一些技巧也能应用于与客户的沟通中。

Or, imagine that Smith and Rosa, the contractor and homeowner, had never worked together before. You might ask them to recall a different but related success. For example, you might say to the contractor, “You’ve said you never worked with this homeowner before. How have you handled contracts successfully with other clients?” And to the homeowner, “You said you felt the design communication was lacking here—how have you handled this successfully with other contractors?”

或者，假设承包商史密斯和房主罗莎之前从未合作过。您可以请他们回忆一个与之相关的成功案例。例如，您可以问承包商：“您说过您之前从未与这位房主合作过。您之前是如何成功地与其他客户签订合同的？”您可以问房主：“您说过您觉得这次的设计沟通存在不足——您之前是如何成功地与其他承包商解决这个问题的？”

Similarly, if your spouse is worried because you have a financial planning issue between you, and this is the first time you’ve faced that problem, you might ask, “How do you feel we have successfully handled other issues between us in the past?” This type of question will help them see beyond the recent, specific failure they are consumed with, and open up new sources of helpful information. Again, you’ll want to follow up with a question about how they felt: “How did it feel when we were able to get through that problem and become close again?” This will help anchor the person in those positive feelings, which in turn will unlock their creativity to solve the new, and different, issue before them.

同样，如果你的配偶因为你们之间出现了财务规划问题而感到担忧，而这是你们第一次遇到这类问题，你可以问问：“你觉得我们过去是如何成功处理其他类似问题的？”这类问题能帮助他们跳出最近这个具体问题的困扰，从而找到新的、有用的信息来源。接下来，你可以追问他们的感受：“当我们克服了那个问题，重新建立起亲密关系时，你感觉如何？”这有助于他们重拾积极的感受，进而激发他们的创造力，帮助他们解决眼前这个新的、不同的问题。

What if the person you’re negotiating with is having trouble recalling any success at all? As you did with yourself, ask the other person about any area in which they have felt successful. One career coach I spoke with told me a story about a client of hers who was having great difficulty defining his goals for their work together. The client, who had been out of the workforce for a while and now wanted to get back to work, kept tossing out half-hearted (and often conflicting) ideas and then shooting them down, with the result that they weren’t making much progress in their work together. The client had trouble even working on updating his résumé or attending a networking event. When the coach asked the client how he had successfully made career decisions in the past, he froze and said he didn’t have any successes to speak of. He had basically graduated college, tried a few things briefly, and then took a break to parent his children.

如果你谈判的对象完全想不起任何成功案例该怎么办？就像你之前问自己一样，询问对方在哪些方面感到成功。我曾和一位职业教练交流，她给我讲过她的一位客户的故事。这位客户很难为他们的合作设定目标。这位客户已经离开职场一段时间，现在想重返工作岗位，但他总是提出一些不切实际（而且常常自相矛盾）的想法，然后又否定它们，结果导致他们的合作进展甚微。这位客户甚至连更新简历或参加社交活动都困难重重。当教练问他过去是如何成功做出职业决策时，他顿时语塞，说自己没有任何值得一提的成功案例。他基本上就是大学毕业后，短暂地尝试过一些工作，然后就休息了一段时间，专心照顾孩子。

The coach switched tacks and said, “No worries. That’s why we’re working together—to help jump-start you in this area. Where else in your life have you felt more successful?” The client sheepishly said, “Well, I guess I did lose seventy pounds… and I’ve managed to keep it off. Five years ago I found out I was prediabetic and decided to make a change.” The coach reflected back this incredible accomplishment, and asked him more questions about actions he took to make himself successful. She watched as the client’s confidence grew. Slowly, they started to make progress on his résumé and career objectives. This prior success, while unrelated to his career, still had the power to help this client negotiate his way toward his goals.

教练转换了话题，说道：“别担心。这就是我们合作的原因——帮助你在这个领域快速起步。你人生中还有哪些方面感觉比这更成功呢？”客户不好意思地说：“嗯，我减掉了70磅……而且一直保持着。五年前我发现自己有糖尿病前期，于是决定做出改变。”教练回顾了这项了不起的成就，并进一步询问了他为了取得成功所采取的行动。她看到客户的自信心逐渐增强。慢慢地，他们开始着手完善他的简历，并制定职业目标。虽然这项之前的成功与他的职业无关，但它仍然能够帮助这位客户更好地朝着目标前进。

Summarize and Ask for Feedback

总结并征求反馈意见

It’s no surprise that most people love hearing about their successes, so when I reflect these back, I like to really show that I’ve heard all the details. So, as an example, let’s take the situation where your boss is facing a major, last-minute client problem. You don’t have a prior client example to examine, but your boss has told you about an internal situation that she handled under time pressure. Your summary could look something like, “Wow. I had no idea that you had handled such a major issue with [coworkers X and Y] until you told me about it just now. I guess that speaks to the success you had in resolving it—no one around here knew. So to sum it up, it wasn’t a client-facing issue but an issue between two account executives about who would have which responsibilities on the account. And it came up last minute. It sounds like you resolved it by convening them together so that you could cut down on the email misunderstandings. And once they were in person, you helped them focus on their common objective—doing the best work possible for this client while also advancing their careers. You listened to their concerns so they felt confident they had been heard. And you asked for ideas. Ultimately, this conversation helped each of them feel good about what role they could play on this account, and you were able to go forward with the original division of labor.”

大多数人都喜欢听别人讲述自己的成功经历，这并不奇怪。所以，当我复述这些经历时，我喜欢确保自己听到了所有细节。举个例子，假设你的老板遇到了一个棘手的客户问题，而且是临时发生的。你没有之前的客户案例可以参考，但你的老板跟你讲过她之前在时间紧迫的情况下处理过的一个内部问题。你的总结可以这样写：“哇！我之前完全不知道你处理了和[同事X和Y]之间这么重要的问题，直到你刚才告诉我。这足以说明你解决问题的成效——我们这里没人知道。总而言之，这不是客户方面的问题，而是两位客户经理之间关于各自负责哪个客户项目的问题。而且这个问题是临时出现的。听起来你通过召集他们开会解决了这个问题，这样可以减少邮件沟通造成的误解。他们见面后，你帮助他们专注于共同的目标——尽最大努力为客户提供最佳服务，同时促进他们自身的职业发展。你认真倾听了他们的顾虑，让他们感到自己的意见得到了重视。你还征求了他们的意见。最终，这次谈话让他们各自对自己在项目中的角色感到满意，你们也得以继续执行原先的分工方案。”

In this way, you’re able to help your boss feel good about her work on this issue—but you’ve also highlighted all the specific actions she took to make this situation successful. And bringing up those actions will help you greatly in moving to the next, and last, question—one in which you’re looking to the future and trying to solve the client problem.

这样一来，你既能让你的老板对她在这个问题上的工作感到满意，又能突出她为成功解决问题所采取的具体行动。而提及这些行动将极大地帮助你过渡到下一个，也是最后一个问题——一个着眼未来并试图解决客户问题的问题。

Wrap up your summary by asking for feedback, so that you can make sure you haven’t missed anything. You might also find, as I frequently have, that when you summarize back their prior success, the other person might respond to add even more actions they took that contributed to their success. For example, your boss might say, “Yes, that’s right—but now that I’m thinking about it, I think what also helped is that I followed up with each of the executives after our joint meeting, just to thank them for participating and helping me reach a resolution for this client. It created even more good feeling that helped us weather some stressful times down the road.” In this way, you’ve made the other person feel great, and generated even more ideas that may help make you successful in this negotiation.

在总结结束时，务必征求对方的反馈意见，以确保没有遗漏任何重要信息。你可能还会发现（就像我经常遇到的情况一样），当你总结对方之前的成功经验时，他们可能会补充一些促成成功的行动。例如，你的老板可能会说：“是的，没错——但现在想想，我觉得另一个有帮助的地方是，我们在联席会议结束后，我分别联系了每位高管，感谢他们的参与，并帮助我为这位客户找到了解决方案。这让我们彼此之间建立了更良好的关系，也帮助我们度过了之后的一些难关。” 这样一来，你不仅让对方感觉良好，还激发了更多可能帮助你在这次谈判中取得成功的想法。

Listen for What Is Not Said

倾听言外之意。

Finally, you’ll want to make sure you pay attention to any body language you see when you ask this question. It’s most helpful to notice any changes from someone’s baseline, or default posture, expression, or tone of voice. If someone’s body language baseline appears to be that they tend to lean away from you when you’re negotiating, and all of a sudden they sit up, or even lean in, that may be a sign that you’re having a positive effect in engaging them. The tone of their voice may rise. They may smile more, or open their eyes wider. Remember that a lot of our communication is non-verbal, and if you’re picking up on those cues, you’ll take much more from this question—and the rest of the Window questions—that will help you in your negotiation.

最后，在提出这个问题时，务必留意对方的肢体语言。观察对方姿势、表情或语气的变化尤为重要，这些变化可能与对方的基线或默认姿势有所不同。如果对方的基线肢体语言表现为在谈判时倾向于远离你，而突然间他们坐直甚至靠近你，这可能表明你的提问对他们产生了积极影响。他们的语调可能会提高，笑容可能会更多，或者眼睛睁得更大。记住，我们的大部分沟通都是非语言的，如果你能捕捉到这些线索，就能从这个问题以及其他“窗口”问题中获得更多有助于谈判的信息。

Wrapping Up

总结

You’ve just helped someone discuss a prior success that likely gave you clues to help solve the challenge before you now. In the last question, you’ll put everything together and start to look to the future. At the end of this next chapter, you’ll be ready to launch yourself into the future with the best possible chance of success.

你刚刚帮助别人讨论了之前的成功经验，这些经验很可能为你解决眼前的挑战提供了线索。在最后一个问题中，你会将所有信息整合起来，开始展望未来。在下一章结束时，你将做好准备，以最佳的成功几率迈向未来。

#↩

TEN WHAT’S THE FIRST STEP?

十、第一步是什么？

In just two years, David Greenwald led his firm—Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson LLP (“Fried Frank”)—from the bottom 2 percent to the top 10 percent in a key employee satisfaction metric—while increasing productivity and hours worked. And it all started with one unexpected step.

短短两年内，大卫·格林沃尔德就带领他所在的律所——弗里德、弗兰克、哈里斯、施赖弗和雅各布森律师事务所（简称“弗里德·弗兰克”）——在一项关键的员工满意度指标上，从排名垫底的2%跃升至前10%，同时还提高了生产力和员工工时。而这一切，都始于一个意想不到的举动。

When David joined Fried Frank, an international law firm, as its chairman late in 2013, he found a number of pressing issues before him. David told me, “Our revenues were down, and our profits down even more. We’d just finished an especially poor year for the firm in terms of our financial results. And it wasn’t just that one year. When I looked back a decade or more, and compared us to our peers and how they’d grown, it was clear that Fried Frank had fallen behind.”

2013年底，大卫加入国际律师事务所Fried Frank担任主席时，他发现事务所面临着诸多紧迫的问题。大卫告诉我：“我们的收入下降了，利润下降得更多。就财务业绩而言，我们刚刚经历了一个极其糟糕的年份。而且这并非个例。回顾过去十年甚至更久，将我们与同行进行比较，看看他们的发展情况，很明显，Fried Frank已经落后了。”

Another major issue? His associate satisfaction ranking was in the basement. When law firms refer to an associate, they are talking about a lawyer who isn’t a partner, or owner, of the firm. At a large firm like Fried Frank, associates comprise the majority of the firm’s lawyers, in many cases outnumbering partners by 4 to 1 or more. Which means that if many of the associates are unhappy, a large portion of your entire firm is unhappy.

另一个主要问题？他的助理律师满意度排名垫底。律师事务所所说的助理律师，指的是并非合伙人或事务所所有者的律师。在像Fried Frank这样的大型律师事务所，助理律师占律师总数的大多数，在很多情况下，助理律师的数量是合伙人的四倍甚至更多。这意味着，如果很多助理律师不满意，那么整个事务所的大部分员工都会感到不满。

Every year, a publication called The American Lawyer ranks the nation’s biggest law firms on a number of metrics, one being the satisfaction of their mid-level associates—those lawyers who are in their third, fourth, or fifth year of practice. The overall satisfaction ranking takes into account things like the associates’ satisfaction with work, benefits and compensation, partner-associate relations, training and guidance, management’s openness about firm strategies and partnership chances, the firm’s attitude toward pro bono work and billable hours, and the likelihood of the associate being at the firm in two years.

每年，《美国律师》杂志都会根据一系列指标对全美最大的律师事务所进行排名，其中一项指标便是中级律师（即执业第三、第四或第五年的律师）的满意度。整体满意度排名会考虑诸多因素，例如律师对工作、福利和薪酬的满意度、合伙人与律师之间的关系、培训和指导、管理层对事务所战略和合伙人晋升机会的开放程度、事务所对公益法律服务和计费工时的态度，以及律师两年后继续留在事务所的可能性。

In 2013, out of the nation’s 134 large law firms that were ranked in the survey, Fried Frank’s associate satisfaction ranking was 132.

2013 年，在全国 134 家大型律师事务所的调查排名中，Fried Frank 的律师满意度排名第 132 位。

David told me, “I went into our next partnership meeting and said, ‘Well, the first piece of good news is we don’t have far to fall. The second piece of good news is that we have a lot of room to move up.’ ”

大卫告诉我：“我参加了下一次的合作会议，我说：‘第一个好消息是我们跌的余地不大。第二个好消息是我们上升的空间很大。’”

Looking around the firm, David could see Fried Frank’s associate satisfaction problem reflected in more than just this ranking. “The low morale showed up in a couple of ways. One, we had high turnover. Now, law firms generally have a lot of turnover, and some of that is expected—but the issue is, where are those people going? And why are they going? We had people leaving us unhappy. And they weren’t going home to Chicago, where we don’t have an office, or to a different kind of legal job, like a corporation. They were going to our peer firms. In other words, these were people who wanted to practice law in a big firm—just not at Fried Frank. And we needed to change that.” David also looked at their recruiting numbers and felt that Fried Frank was not doing nearly as well as it should.

环顾公司，大卫发现弗里德·弗兰克律师事务所的律师满意度问题不仅仅体现在排名上。“士气低落体现在几个方面。首先，我们的人员流动率很高。律师事务所的人员流动普遍存在，这在一定程度上是可以预料的——但问题是，这些人去了哪里？他们为什么要离开？我们有很多员工离开时并不开心。他们没有回芝加哥（我们在那里没有办公室），也没有去其他类型的法律工作，比如公司。他们去了我们同行律所。换句话说，这些人想在大律所执业——只是不想去弗里德·弗兰克。我们需要改变这种状况。” 大卫还查看了他们的招聘数据，认为弗里德·弗兰克的招聘工作远未达到应有的水平。

After spending some time getting a handle on the firm’s issues, David set about to change the culture around the way associates and partners communicated. And he did it from the top. Starting in early 2015, he established twice-yearly town hall meetings where he would speak to all the associates about substantive matters, including firm strategy. He also met regularly with a smaller associate committee. And one of the first things he did in those meetings? He asked them what steps he could take to make things better. In spring 2015, after David met with his associates and asked for their ideas, The American Lawyer surveyed associates again about their satisfaction with Fried Frank. Fried Frank’s satisfaction ranking jumped from its sub-100 position to #16 out of 101.

在花了一些时间了解事务所的问题后，大卫着手改变合伙人和律师之间的沟通方式。他从高层做起。从2015年初开始，他设立了每年两次的全体律师大会，与所有律师讨论包括事务所战略在内的实质性问题。他还定期与一个由律师组成的小组会面。在这些会议上，他做的第一件事是什么？他询问律师们可以采取哪些措施来改善现状。2015年春季，在大卫与律师们会面并征求他们的意见后，《美国律师》杂志再次对律师们进行了满意度调查。结果显示，Fried Frank的满意度排名从100名开外跃升至101家事务所中的第16名。

Then, the associates came up with an idea. And it wasn’t at all what David expected. For years, the associates said they had been asking for an associates-only lounge in their New York headquarters, a place where they could gather to talk, work, or just relax while they were in the office. Their request had gone nowhere. David jumped on the opportunity. The associates made the request for the lounge on September 15, 2015. The partnership approved it almost immediately, announced to the firm by Thanksgiving, and then opened it a few months later, in February.

随后，合伙人们想出了一个主意。这完全出乎大卫的意料。多年来，合伙人们一直要求在纽约总部设立一个仅限合伙人使用的休息室，一个他们可以聚在一起聊天、工作或放松身心的地方。但他们的请求一直没有得到回应。大卫抓住了这个机会。合伙人于2015年9月15日提出了设立休息室的请求。合伙人几乎立即批准了这项请求，并在感恩节前通知了公司全体员工，几个月后的2月份，休息室正式开放。

What’s in the associates’ lounge? A foosball table, ping-pong table, a large TV, soft furniture for relaxing, as well as snacks and drinks. But what it meant to the associates was much greater. David told me, “What that lounge did for our relationship with the associates was huge. As a partnership, it gave us credibility—they asked for something and we got it done, quickly. It helped us build trust. And it also elevated the level of our discussions more generally. Before, I think the associates were used to feeling ignored, so they didn’t ask us questions about substantive matters. But now we talk about everything: our international strategy, financial performance, diversity, the review process. Once they knew their views would be considered, they started asking terrific questions and engaging with us.”

员工休息室里有什么？桌上足球、乒乓球桌、一台大电视、舒适的休闲家具，还有零食和饮料。但它对员工的意义远不止于此。大卫告诉我：“休息室对我们与员工的关系产生了巨大的影响。作为一家合伙企业，它提升了我们的信誉——他们提出要求，我们就能迅速满足。这有助于我们建立信任。而且，它也从整体上提升了我们讨论的水平。以前，员工们可能习惯了被忽视，所以他们不会就实质性问题向我们提问。但现在我们无所不谈：我们的国际战略、财务业绩、多元化、绩效考核流程等等。一旦他们知道自己的意见会被考虑，他们就开始提出很多精彩的问题，并积极参与到我们的讨论中。”

David goes on: “Our associates are the future of the firm. They’re the vast majority of lawyers at the firm. One day, one of them will have my job. And so they’re very important. We want and need them to be motivated and happy. The lounge was a great first step toward that goal.”

大卫接着说：“我们的律师助理是律所的未来。他们占律所律师总数的绝大多数。总有一天，他们中的某个人会接替我的职位。所以他们非常重要。我们希望也需要他们保持积极性和快乐。休息室的建设是朝着这个目标迈出的重要一步。”

In spring 2016, The American Lawyer surveyed associates again about their satisfaction with Fried Frank. Fried Frank’s satisfaction ranking catapulted into the top ten, landing them at #8.

2016年春季，《美国律师》杂志再次对律师事务所的律师助理进行了满意度调查。Fried Frank的满意度排名跃升至前十，位列第八。

What was even more remarkable: the associates were more satisfied while also working more hours. Between 2013, the year Fried Frank scraped the bottom of the barrel at #132, and 2016, when they ranked #8 out of #94, the number of hours worked by their associates increased by more than 10 percent. And the firm’s financial results have turned around, too. In 2018, for the first time in the firm’s history, Fried Frank passed the $3 million mark in profits per equity partner (PEP); that number represented 100 percent growth from where they were in 2013.

更令人瞩目的是：律师助理们在工作时间更长的同时，满意度也更高了。2013年，Fried Frank律师事务所排名垫底，位列第132名；而到了2016年，该事务所跃升至第8名（共94家律师事务所），在此期间，律师助理的工作时长增长了10%以上。事务所的财务业绩也随之扭转。2018年，Fried Frank律师事务所的每位权益合伙人（PEP）利润首次突破300万美元大关，较2013年增长了100%。

Recently, a reporter visited David to interview him about Fried Frank’s transformation. The reporter asked to see the associates’ lounge. David told him, “Well, we can see it if you want. But I can’t get us in. My access card doesn’t work.” Incredulous, the reporter replied, “You’re the chairman, can’t you open any door at the firm?” David explained that the associates had wanted a place that was just for them. Together, they walked down the hall and tried David’s access card. It was denied. He had kept to his word.

最近，一位记者来拜访大卫，想采访他关于弗里德·弗兰克律师事务所的转型。记者提出想看看律师休息室。大卫说：“好吧，如果你想看，我们可以去。但我进不去。我的门禁卡打不开门。” 记者难以置信地问道：“你是主席，难道你连事务所的门都打不开吗？” 大卫解释说，律师们想要一个只属于他们自己的空间。他们一起沿着走廊走到休息室，大卫用门禁卡试了试。果然被拒绝了。他信守了承诺。

Your Turn in the Window

轮到你了，窗口

So far in your negotiation, you’ve covered a lot of ground: You’ve asked the other person their view of the situation, you’ve delved into their concerns and needs, and you’ve also asked them what those needs would look like. You’ve covered how they have handled an issue like this successfully in the past, and gathered some useful information. This is your last chance to look through the Window and see them, and your situation, as clearly as possible. Now you will have the chance to ask them to look forward, just as you’ve done.

到目前为止，你们的谈判已经取得了长足的进展：你们询问了对方对现状的看法，深入了解了他们的顾虑和需求，并询问了他们这些需求具体体现在哪些方面。你们还探讨了他们过去如何成功处理类似问题，并收集了一些有用的信息。这是你最后一次机会，可以透过“窗口”尽可能清晰地了解对方以及你们自身的处境。现在，你将有机会像你之前那样，请求他们展望未来。

At this stage, asking “What’s the first step?” is important for many reasons. This question benefits your deal, helping you generate as many options as possible for a solution to your negotiation. Again, listening to the other side doesn’t mean you need to accept everything you hear. But by asking you increase the chance that some option they offer, or a variation on that option, will also meet the needs you unearthed in the Mirror section.

在这个阶段，询问“第一步是什么？”至关重要，原因有很多。这个问题有利于你的谈判，能帮助你尽可能多地提出解决方案。再次强调，倾听对方并不意味着你必须接受他们所说的一切。但通过提问，你可以增加他们提出的某些方案，或其变体，能够满足你在“镜像”部分挖掘出的需求的可能性。

Next, this question benefits the negotiators—both you and the other person—in several ways. When you ask someone their ideas for a first step, you treat them as a partner in your negotiation, making it more likely they will accord your ideas the same listening and respect you showed theirs. We know from psychology professor Robert Cialdini that people tend to reciprocate gestures in negotiation, meaning that if you do something for someone, you’re more likely to get them to do it for you in response. Asking someone else for their ideas, especially a coworker or loved one, also gives them the chance to demonstrate leadership and connects them to a sense of purpose, which makes them happier in whatever work they’re doing—in the office or at home. And research shows that by asking other people questions about their ideas, you cultivate what Stanford psychologist Carol Dweck calls a “growth mind-set” that helps you learn and achieve more.

其次，这个问题对谈判双方——包括你和对方——都有诸多益处。当你征求对方的意见作为第一步时，你便将他们视为谈判伙伴，这让他们更有可能像你尊重他们的想法一样认真倾听并重视你的想法。心理学教授罗伯特·西奥迪尼指出，人们在谈判中倾向于互惠互利，也就是说，如果你为别人做了某件事，他们更有可能反过来为你做同样的事情。征求他人的意见，尤其是同事或亲人的意见，也能让他们有机会展现领导力，并赋予他们使命感，从而让他们在工作中——无论是在办公室还是在家——都感到更加快乐。研究表明，通过询问他人的想法，你可以培养斯坦福大学心理学家卡罗尔·德韦克所说的“成长型思维模式”，这种模式有助于你学习和取得更大的成就。

Finally, asking for the first step is important because it can establish momentum, and a path forward, even if you don’t yet know all the steps you want to take.

最后，寻求迈出第一步很重要，因为它可以建立动力，并指明前进的方向，即使你还不知道你想采取的所有步骤。

Asking the First Step Benefits the Deal

主动询问对交易有利

In negotiation, one of our goals is to generate as many ideas as possible, in hopes of reaching the idea that will allow us to achieve our objectives. Those who are in scientific fields know that it often takes many ideas—and many unsuccessful ideas—to find one that makes people’s lives better. John Kirwan, a rheumatology professor at the University of Bristol, embarked on a study to find out exactly what percentage of his ideas were successful over the course of his twenty-three years in practice. He had had a lot of success for a medical academic, with many works published and cited within his field. Nonetheless, many of his ideas failed. His study revealed that 75 percent of the 185 ideas he found in his archives led to no publications. By his own assessment, only 2.7 percent of his ideas met his criteria to be considered “especially good.” The professor told Quartz magazine that despite this number, he considered all the failed ideas to have great value: “The issue here is to recognize that in science (and indeed, perhaps in life as a whole) we have lots of ideas that don’t work out. You cannot tell initially if the idea will work or not—you need to explore it and do some work on it in order to find out. This is a necessary process… we are not wasting our time in exploring ideas that turn out not to work—we are helping to generate good ideas.”

在谈判中，我们的目标之一是尽可能多地提出想法，希望最终找到能够帮助我们实现目标的方案。从事科学领域的人都知道，往往需要经过许多想法——以及许多失败的想法——才能找到一个能够改善人们生活的方案。布里斯托尔大学的风湿病学教授约翰·柯万开展了一项研究，旨在探究在他23年的行医生涯中，究竟有多少想法最终取得了成功。作为一名医学学者，他取得了相当大的成就，发表了许多在医学领域内被广泛引用的著作。然而，他的许多想法最终都以失败告终。他的研究显示，在他整理的185个想法中，有75%最终未能发表。根据他自己的评估，只有2.7%的想法符合他“特别优秀”的标准。这位教授告诉《石英》杂志，尽管失败的想法数量众多，但他认为所有失败的想法都极具价值：“关键在于认识到，在科学领域（实际上，或许在整个生活中也是如此），我们有很多想法最终都行不通。你一开始无法判断一个想法是否可行——你需要探索它，并进行一些研究才能找到答案。这是一个必要的过程……我们并非在浪费时间去探索那些最终被证明行不通的想法——我们是在帮助产生好的想法。”

No matter how many innovative ideas we generate on our own, we can’t assume we know what our negotiation partner thinks about the future, or what ideas they may have. Like in the example of David and Fried Frank above, you might find an idea that meets someone else’s needs while also meeting yours. Some parents I know who have negotiated with their kids over screen use report that their kids have come up with creative ideas, such as setting technology-free zones in the house (like bedrooms and the dining room table), starting “screen-free Saturdays” where the family does an outdoor activity together, or establishing a chore or homework chart to earn time.

无论我们自己想出多少创新点子，都不能想当然地认为我们了解谈判伙伴对未来的看法，或者他们可能有什么想法。就像上面提到的大卫和弗里德·弗兰克的例子一样，你可能会发现一个既能满足他人需求又能满足自身需求的方案。我认识的一些家长在与孩子协商屏幕使用问题时表示，他们的孩子提出了许多富有创意的想法，例如在家中设置无科技区域（比如卧室和餐桌），开始“无屏幕星期六”活动，全家一起进行户外活动，或者制定家务或作业完成表来赚取使用时间。

Even where one side in the negotiation has most or all the expertise needed to come up with a universe of potential options, inviting the other person to contribute can yield benefits for the long-term success of the deal. For example, recent research and teaching shows that when doctors consult with patients on treatment options, it improves patient compliance with treatment as well as health outcomes. In a New York Times article, “Teaching Doctors the Art of Negotiation,” Dr. Dhruv Khullar said, “The medical profession is no longer one in which doctors dictate a given treatment course to patients, who are then expected to follow it. Rather, clinicians and patients deliberate about treatment options, weigh costs and benefits together, and determine the best course of action.” When doctors consult with patients on what steps to take, patients not only feel more satisfaction with the doctor, but are more likely to stick with their decided treatment path, resulting in better outcomes and lower health-care costs.

即使谈判一方拥有提出所有潜在方案所需的大部分或全部专业知识，邀请另一方参与也能为交易的长期成功带来益处。例如，近期研究和教学表明，医生与患者就治疗方案进行磋商，可以提高患者的治疗依从性以及健康结果。在《纽约时报》一篇题为《教医生谈判的艺术》的文章中，德鲁夫·库拉尔博士指出：“医疗行业不再是医生单方面向患者规定治疗方案，然后要求患者照做。相反，临床医生和患者会共同探讨治疗方案，权衡利弊，并确定最佳行动方案。”当医生与患者商讨下一步的治疗步骤时，患者不仅会更加信任医生，而且更有可能坚持既定的治疗方案，从而获得更好的治疗效果并降低医疗成本。

Finally, asking someone to contribute future-focused ideas in negotiation can help with counterpunchers—the term I use for someone who shoots down your ideas without contributing any of their own. Asking this question invites them to participate more productively in the search for a solution.

最后，在谈判中，鼓励对方提出着眼未来的想法，有助于应对那些只会否定你的想法却不贡献任何自己想法的人——我用这个词来形容他们。提出这个问题可以引导他们更积极地参与到解决方案的寻求过程中。

Asking the First Step Benefits the Negotiators

主动提出问题对谈判者有利

Asking the first step also benefits the people in your negotiation. Partnering with someone else in decision-making leads not only to short-term benefits (for example, the idea for an associates’ lounge that costs little and buoys morale) but long-term benefits as well (happier and more engaged associates who have partnered with you in thinking through and solving challenging issues).

主动提出要求对参与谈判的人也有好处。与他人合作决策不仅能带来短期利益（例如，提出建造一个成本低廉且能提升士气的员工休息室的想法），还能带来长期利益（与你合作思考和解决难题的员工会更快乐、更积极投入）。

Even where one person has more subject matter expertise in the negotiation, asking the other person their preferred first step can yield benefits for both parties in the negotiation. Let’s revisit our doctor and patient example. Medical research shows that by presenting the list of possible options to the patient and asking for their thoughts, you benefit both parties in the doctor-patient relationship by increasing the patient’s adherence to whatever treatment option is selected. When patients stick to their treatment plan, the patient saves money associated with relapse and collateral consequences, and the doctor improves statistics while creating savings for the hospital and insurers. In a time when patient noncompliance with treatment is estimated to cost billions of dollars, asking the patient to participate in deciding the course of treatment produces profound benefits for both parties in that negotiation.

即使在谈判中一方拥有更丰富的专业知识，询问另一方他们希望采取的第一步也能使双方受益。让我们再回顾一下医生和病人的例子。医学研究表明，通过向病人列出所有可能的治疗方案并征求他们的想法，可以提高病人对所选治疗方案的依从性，从而使医患关系中的双方都受益。当病人坚持治疗方案时，病人可以节省因复发和并发症而产生的费用，而医生则可以改善统计数据，同时为医院和保险公司节省开支。如今，病人不遵医嘱治疗预计会造成数十亿美元的损失，因此，让病人参与决定治疗方案将为谈判双方带来深远的益处。

Finally, asking someone else for their ideas on first steps benefits the negotiators by benefiting their relationship. This is true not only at work, where people thrive on a feeling of connection with their coworkers, but in relationships outside the workplace. More than ever before, experts are studying what leads to healthy personal relationships, and the answers include qualities like empathy, responsiveness to partners’ concerns, and trust. You increase all those qualities when you ask someone else for their ideas and sincerely listen to their answers.

最后，向他人征求关于初步步骤的意见，对谈判者自身也有益处，因为这有利于彼此的关系。这不仅适用于工作中人们需要与同事建立联系的情况，也适用于工作之外的人际关系。如今，专家们比以往任何时候都更加关注如何建立健康的人际关系，而答案包括同理心、对伴侣关切的回应以及信任等品质。当你征求他人的意见并认真倾听他们的回答时，你就能提升所有这些品质。

Asking an Adversary for Ideas?

向对手征求想法？

When thinking about your approach to a negotiation, it always makes sense to consider to what extent you will need to work with this person once your negotiation is done. Most industries, no matter how large, can end up feeling more like a neighborhood, especially at the top. Gabriel Matus, general counsel of Excel Sports Management, a premier sports agency, told me, “Our industry is surprisingly small. When you manage high-caliber athletes, you see the same people over and over again. In professional services like this, it’s important to maintain good relationships.”

在思考谈判策略时，始终应该考虑谈判结束后你还需要与对方保持何种程度的合作关系。大多数行业，无论规模大小，最终都会感觉更像一个社区，尤其是在高层。顶级体育经纪公司Excel Sports Management的总法律顾问加布里埃尔·马图斯告诉我：“我们这个行业其实很小。当你管理高水平运动员时，你会反复见到同样的人。在这样的专业服务领域，维护良好的人际关系至关重要。”

Asking the other person for their ideas is a sign of respect and collaboration. It’s the final step in building a foundation of trust upon which long, productive, and lucrative partnerships are built. It lets them know that you are interested in them, whether personally or professionally.

征求对方的意见是尊重和合作的表现。这是建立信任基础的最后一步，而信任是建立长期、高效且互惠互利的合作关系的基础。它让对方知道你对他们感兴趣，无论是在个人层面还是职业层面。

Bottom line: asking people for their ideas in negotiation usually costs you nothing, and can benefit you greatly.

总之：在谈判中征求他人的意见通常不会花费你任何成本，却能让你受益匪浅。

One Step at a Time to Solve Problems

一步一步解决问题

Asking for one step can lead to a more comprehensive solution to all the issues on the table. Even if your conversation yields a bunch of ideas, you may want to start in one place, as David did with the associates’ lounge. He knew that that one step would have symbolic benefits that went far beyond simply establishing a place for associates to hang out. It was a physical, tangible reminder that the firm listened to them, and valued what they had to say.

提出一个建议或许就能找到更全面的解决方案，解决所有摆在眼前的问题。即使你们的谈话产生了许多想法，你也应该像大卫那样，从设立员工休息室开始。他知道，这一个步骤的意义远不止于为员工提供一个休闲场所。它以一种切实可见的方式提醒他们，公司倾听他们的意见，重视他们的建议。

But sometimes you need to take solutions one step at a time. Perhaps only one step is feasible at the moment, or there’s one you may want or need to try first before moving on to the others.

但有时候，解决问题需要一步一步来。或许目前只有一步可行，或者在进行其他步骤之前，你可能需要先尝试某一步。

For example: Jamie, a Division I college basketball player with serious back problems—a possible herniated disc that wasn’t getting better with rest— went to the Mayo Clinic for evaluation. She, the doctor, and her family knew there were a couple of possible solutions: they could try the conservative route and do physical therapy, or opt for surgery. The doctor asked the patient and her family what they wanted to do for their first step. Jamie, a sophomore, decided she wanted to try and finish out her sophomore basketball season. She felt that the conservative approach would allow her to do that and also give her the peace of mind to know that they had tried everything before surgery. The doctor supported that choice. Jamie committed to working hard in physical therapy and was able to finish out the year. “I played through the season, and it went relatively well. I had back pain, but I was able to manage it enough to where I could play. The physical therapy really helped me,” she later told the Mayo Clinic. At the end of the season, and after an MRI showed no change in her condition, Jamie opted for the surgery. The physical therapy had helped, but didn’t eliminate her chronic pain. Having taken the conservative first step helped Jamie and her family feel good about knowing the next step to take. The surgery was successful and Jamie returned to the court in the fall.

例如：杰米是一名一级大学篮球队员，她患有严重的背部疾病——可能是椎间盘突出，休息后症状没有好转——于是前往梅奥诊所进行评估。她、医生和她的家人都知道有两种可能的解决方案：一是尝试保守治疗，进行物理疗法；二是选择手术。医生询问患者及其家人，他们想先尝试哪种方案。杰米当时是一名大二学生，她决定尝试完成她的大二篮球赛季。她觉得保守治疗既能让她做到这一点，也能让她安心，因为在考虑手术之前，他们已经尝试了所有可能的治疗方法。医生支持她的选择。杰米坚持努力进行物理治疗，最终完成了赛季。“我打完了整个赛季，情况还算不错。我的背痛一直持续，但我能够控制住疼痛，继续上场比赛。物理治疗真的帮了我很大的忙，”她后来告诉梅奥诊所。赛季结束后，核磁共振成像显示她的病情没有变化，杰米最终选择了手术。物理治疗有所帮助，但并未消除她的慢性疼痛。采取保守的第一步让杰米和她的家人对下一步该怎么做感到安心。手术很成功，杰米在秋季重返赛场。

And sometimes, one step saves lives. About ten years ago, two women accompanied me into a small room in the Bronx and seated themselves on opposite sides of the table. They were residents of the same apartment complex, and ongoing tension between them had spilled over into physical fights. Tension had built to the point where their families, their pastor, and even the police, who had been called to the scene several times, recommended mediation because they were concerned about the prospect of major violence.

有时，一个举动就能挽救生命。大约十年前，两位女士陪我走进布朗克斯区的一间小房间，在桌子两边分别坐下。她们住在同一栋公寓楼里，两人之间长期存在的矛盾已经演变成肢体冲突。矛盾激化到她们的家人、牧师，甚至多次被叫到现场的警察都建议她们进行调解，因为他们担心会发生更严重的暴力事件。

Once seated, the women spoke bravely and candidly about what would happen if they continued on their current path of conflict. One said to the other, “You know, I could hurt you. I’ve thought about that. But I’d go to jail. My kids would get taken away, and I don’t have any relatives to take them. They’d go into foster care, and that’s not happening. So we need another way.” It became evident that there would be no reconciliation, no best friendship or happy embrace. But we asked each of the women to think about what could be their first step toward a future that did not include police involvement or prison time. They considered the question and agreed not to harm each other. We closed the mediation with a prayer from their pastor. Their journey started with one critical, life-changing step.

落座后，两位女士勇敢坦诚地谈论了如果她们继续目前的冲突下去将会发生什么。其中一位对另一位说：“你知道，我可以伤害你。我考虑过。但我会坐牢。我的孩子会被带走，而我没有亲戚可以照顾他们。他们会被送去寄养家庭，但这绝不可能发生。所以我们需要另寻他法。” 很明显，她们之间不可能和解，不可能建立深厚的友谊，也不可能拥抱和解。但我们请每位女士思考，她们可以迈向一个无需报警或牢狱之灾的未来，第一步该如何走。她们认真思考了这个问题，并同意不再伤害彼此。调解结束后，她们的牧师为她们做了祷告。她们的旅程始于这至关重要、改变人生的一步。

Now for the “How”

现在来说说“如何做”。

How do you ask this question effectively? Here are some ways you might formulate this question without narrowing or changing it:

如何有效地提出这个问题？以下是一些无需缩小范围或改变问题本质的提问方式：

  • What’s our first step?
    我们的第一步是什么？
  • What do you see as our first step here?
    你认为我们下一步应该做什么？

If you’re communicating productively with the other side, or have the sense that you may be able to take more than one step, you might try:

如果你与对方沟通顺畅，或者感觉可以采取不止一步的行动，你可以尝试：

  • What ideas do you have for the future?
    你对未来有什么想法？
  • What are your thoughts on how we can move forward?
    您认为我们应该如何推进下一步工作？

In the last sections of this chapter, I’m going to give you some tips to help you ask this question with the greatest success, and then troubleshoot a few issues that might arise.

在本章的最后几节中，我将给你一些建议，帮助你更成功地提出这个问题，然后解决可能出现的一些问题。

Land the Plane

降落飞机

You’ve just asked someone for their ideas. Now wait to hear their answers. This question may yield unexpected and beneficial solutions for you and the other person.

你刚刚征求了别人的意见。现在，请耐心等待他们的回答。这个问题或许会为你和对方带来意想不到的、有益的解决方案。

Enjoy the Silence

享受安静

This is a big question. You are asking the other person to participate with you in designing your future. They may have done their homework already, and have ideas at the ready. Or they may need time. And when I say time, I mean more than two seconds. This is where I have seen many negotiators falter. They ask the question, wait two seconds, and then ask another question, or fill in their own ideas. Example: “What ideas do you have to move forward?… Should we start with the salary piece?” Resist! Even if you’re just tacking on another question, you’re cutting off the discussion and biasing the result. You’ll know if the other person needs help if they ask you for help. Otherwise, stay quiet.

这是一个重要的问题。你是在邀请对方参与你未来的规划。他们可能已经做足了功课，并且已经有了想法。或者他们可能需要一些时间。我说的时间，指的是不止两秒钟。我见过很多谈判者在这方面犯错。他们问完问题，停顿两秒钟，然后又问另一个问题，或者插话补充自己的想法。例如：“你有什么推进计划的想法吗？……我们先从薪资方面谈起吧？” 千万不要这样做！即使你只是在追问，你也会打断讨论，影响最终结果。如果对方主动寻求帮助，你就知道他们是否真的需要。否则，保持沉默。

Follow Up

跟进

If the other person gives you an idea and you need to understand more about it, “Tell me more…” is a great place to start. If the idea is vague, or you’re not sure how to put it into practice—for example, the person says, “I want us to communicate better with our clients”—you could return to the follow-up question from chapter 7 (“What do you need?”) and ask them in response, “What would communicating better with our clients look like?”

如果对方提出了一个想法，而你需要进一步了解，那么“请详细说说……”就是一个很好的切入点。如果这个想法比较模糊，或者你不确定如何付诸实践——例如，对方说：“我希望我们能更好地与客户沟通”——你可以回到第七章的后续问题（“你需要什么？”），并反问对方：“更好地与客户沟通具体会是什么样子？”

And what if you’re dealing with someone who suggests something… unproductive? I once heard about a high-profile legal negotiation in which one of the parties, when asked for settlement ideas, said, “I have an idea. You can ______ my _______.” I won’t fill in the blanks, but suffice it to say he did not suggest that the other person read his proposal or water his plants. This has happened to me more than once. I mediate cases in New York City, where sometimes idle threats are just another day at the office. I once asked a party in Small Claims Court what our first step should be, and in front of the other party, he said, “I’ll give you an idea. I could Taser the ____ out of him!”

如果你遇到的人提出的建议……毫无建设性，该怎么办？我曾经听说过一起备受瞩目的法律谈判，其中一方在被问及和解方案时说：“我有个主意。你可以____我的____。” 我不打算补充细节，但可以肯定的是，他并没有建议对方阅读他的提案或给植物浇水。这种情况我遇到过不止一次。我在纽约市调解案件，在那里，空洞的威胁有时只是日常工作的一部分。我曾经在小额索赔法庭上问一位当事人，我们的第一步应该是什么，他当着对方的面说：“我给你个主意。我可以把他____电击枪打晕！”

I hope you don’t find yourself in this situation, but if you do, here is my suggestion for how to handle it. I simply ask something like, “How does [Tasering him] help us achieve our goals here today?” If I’ve been listening to them, I already know their goals, needs, and concerns. So I can simply repeat what they’ve told me they need, and ask how this new idea will help them achieve it. For example, if they have told me they need to move on with their life, I might say, “You’ve told me your goal here is to settle this so that you can move on with your life. How does Tasering him help you achieve that?”

我希望你不会遇到这种情况，但如果你真的遇到了，以下是我的一些建议。你可以这样问：“用电击枪制服他，对我们今天达成目标有什么帮助？” 如果我一直认真倾听他们的诉求，我就已经了解了他们的目标、需求和顾虑。所以我可以简单地复述他们的需求，然后询问这个新想法如何帮助他们实现目标。例如，如果他们告诉我他们需要继续生活，我可能会说：“你告诉我你的目标是解决这件事，这样你就可以继续你的生活。用电击枪制服他，如何帮助你实现这个目标？”

Sometimes, this follow-up question is enough to produce a more helpful response. If that doesn’t help, I suggest taking a break until we can have more productive discussions.

有时候，这个后续问题足以得到更有帮助的答复。如果还是不行，我建议我们休息一下，等以后再进行更有效的讨论。

Summarize and Ask for Feedback

总结并征求反馈意见

Again, you’ll want to summarize what you hear and ask for feedback. Sometimes in the process of hearing their ideas repeated back to them, people may come to reflect on them and make changes. Hearing David’s summary of the associate lounge plans helped encourage additional problem-solving—and, in turn, helped create a culture of collaboration.

同样，你需要总结你听到的内容并征求反馈意见。有时，在反复听到自己的想法后，人们可能会反思并做出改变。听取大卫对员工休息室计划的总结，有助于鼓励大家进一步解决问题，进而帮助营造协作文化。

Listen for What Is Not Said

倾听言外之意。

As always, you’ll want to be attentive to any non-verbal communication you see during this question. For example, “Correct me if I’m wrong, but it seemed as though you looked doubtful when I asked for your ideas. You may be wondering if I’m sincere in wanting to hear them. I know we haven’t always communicated that well in the past, but I’d like to change that. Your ideas are important. I can’t promise I’ll agree with everything you say, but I absolutely promise to listen.”

和往常一样，在提问过程中，你需要留意对方的任何非语言信息。例如，“如果我没理解错的话，当我问你想法的时候，你似乎有些犹豫。你可能在想我是否真心想听听你的想法。我知道我们过去沟通并不总是很顺畅，但我希望能够改变这种情况。你的想法很重要。我不能保证我会同意你说的每一句话，但我保证会认真倾听。”

Troubleshooting

故障排除

Now that we’ve gone through how to ask this question, let’s talk about how to tackle a few issues you might occasionally face in asking it.

既然我们已经了解了如何提出这个问题，接下来让我们谈谈如何解决你在提问过程中可能偶尔遇到的一些问题。

How Do You Generate Ideas if This Is a Group Negotiation?

如果是小组谈判，你如何产生想法？

If you’re working on a group negotiation, whether it’s among family, colleagues, or nations, you may want to be more deliberate about how you generate ideas than simply asking someone on the spot. For many years, people thought that group brainstorming, a process in which people would get together and shout out as many ideas as came to mind, would produce the best, most innovative results. More recent research, however, shows that group brainstorming often doesn’t work because it can produce shallow or flashy ideas that often don’t hold up under further testing, especially for important or challenging problem-solving. You may want to give people some time to think and then come back with their ideas. Individual work that then gets honed in a group is a much better way to generate ideas. When I help people design their first step in a negotiation, I usually ask them each individually to generate some ideas before we come together and evaluate them.

如果你正在进行集体谈判，无论是在家庭、同事还是国家之间，你可能需要更周密地构思如何产生想法，而不是简单地当场询问。多年来，人们一直认为头脑风暴——即大家聚在一起，尽可能多地提出想法——能够产生最佳、最具创新性的成果。然而，最近的研究表明，头脑风暴往往效果不佳，因为它可能产生肤浅或华而不实的想法，这些想法通常经不起进一步的检验，尤其是在解决重要或棘手的问题时。你或许应该给每个人一些时间思考，然后再提出他们的想法。先由个人独立思考，然后在小组中进行完善，这才是更好的产生想法的方式。当我帮助人们设计谈判的第一步时，我通常会先让他们各自提出一些想法，然后再聚在一起进行评估。

So what does that mean for this question? The good news is that you’re already ahead of many people who come into a negotiation having waited until the group session to start generating their ideas. You’ve already started thinking about possible first steps to take. You’ve done your homework. You’re now asking other people to do the same individual work you did by inviting them to discuss possible first steps. You may just want to allow them some reflection time to do the same work you did.

那么，这对这个问题意味着什么呢？好消息是，你已经领先于许多在谈判中等到小组讨论才开始构思的人。你已经开始思考可能的初步步骤。你已经做好了准备工作。现在，你邀请其他人讨论可能的初步步骤，让他们也像你一样进行个人思考。你或许应该给他们一些思考时间，让他们也进行同样的思考。

What If the Other Person Isn’t Ready?

如果对方还没准备好怎么办？

Be prepared that the other person may not be ready for this question at the moment you ask it. They may want some time to digest the information that came out of the four Window questions you asked and the answers you summarized. If that’s the case, you might ask them for another meeting when they’re ready to discuss, or share with them some of the ideas you generated, and then ask for a follow-up conversation to hear their thoughts.

要做好心理准备，对方可能在你提问时还没有准备好回答这个问题。他们可能需要一些时间来消化你提出的四个“窗口问题”以及你总结的答案。如果是这种情况，你可以约他们在准备好讨论时再见面，或者先与他们分享你产生的一些想法，然后再进行后续沟通，听听他们的想法。

What if the Next Step Seems Automatic?

如果下一步看起来是自动发生的呢？

And what about the opposite scenario, in which the next step seems automatic, or baked into the process? For example, you’ve just finished an introductory interview with HR and you’ve been told the next step is a call-back interview with management. I would still ask, “What more can you tell me about our next steps?” You might be surprised at the additional information you gain, perhaps about the timing of those steps, who the decision-makers will be, or even the likelihood of your application moving forward. Asking the question also makes you look motivated and organized. Bottom line: it’s always better to try for more information.

那么，如果下一步似乎是自动进行的，或者已经包含在流程中呢？例如，你刚刚结束了与人力资源部的初步面试，被告知下一步是与管理层进行复试。我仍然会问：“关于接下来的步骤，您还能告诉我些什么吗？”你可能会惊讶地发现，自己能获得更多信息，比如这些步骤的时间安排、决策者是谁，甚至你的申请通过的可能性。提出这个问题也能让你显得积极主动、做事有条理。总之：多方尝试获取信息总是没错的。

What If You’re the Junior Person in This Negotiation?

如果你是谈判中的资历较浅的人怎么办？

What if you are the more junior person in a boss-subordinate situation in which you are expected professionally to have formulated a plan forward? What if your manager actually turns the question around on you and says, “What’s the first step? Well, shouldn’t you be telling me?” As you’ve done with the previous four questions, you know the first thing you do after the other person speaks is to summarize before you follow up. So here, that might look something like, “Right, you’d like my thoughts. I anticipated that, and so I spent time before this meeting thinking about possible next steps. I have several ideas that I’d be happy to lay out. Or you could share some initial thoughts, so that my ideas will be more responsive. Your choice.”

如果你是上下级关系中资历较浅的一方，却被期望在工作中制定出下一步计划，该怎么办？如果你的经理反过来问你：“第一步是什么？难道不应该是你告诉我吗？” 就像你之前回答的四个问题一样，你知道在对方说完之后，首先要做的是总结，然后再提出自己的观点。所以，你可以这样回答：“好的，您想听听我的想法。我预料到了这一点，所以在这次会议之前，我花了一些时间思考下一步的计划。我有一些想法，很乐意和您分享。或者，您也可以先说说一些初步的想法，这样我的想法会更有针对性。您自己决定吧。”

What If They Can’t Think of Anything?

如果他们什么都想不出来怎么办？

And what if the other person draws a blank when you ask them about a first step? Here are a couple of things I sometimes try. First, if I’m in a position of trust with this other person, I may want to know more about the roadblock so I can help. I might ask, “What makes this question feel challenging to answer?” Giving them the opportunity to talk through their barriers may end up revealing some good ideas.

如果对方一时语塞，不知道该如何着手怎么办？以下是我有时会尝试的几种方法。首先，如果我和对方之间建立了信任关系，我可能会想更多地了解他们遇到的障碍，以便更好地提供帮助。我可能会问：“是什么让这个问题难以回答？” 给他们机会倾诉，或许能让他们找到一些好点子。

And remember, when in doubt, you can always try thinking of the “worst idea.” Tell the other person you have a trick that has helped you generate ideas in the past, and then ask them, “What’s the worst step you/we could take?” Sometimes, knowing what won’t work gives you excellent clues as to what will.

记住，当你犹豫不决时，不妨想想“最糟糕的主意”。告诉对方你过去有个激发灵感的妙招，然后问他们：“你/我们能采取的最糟糕的措施是什么？” 有时候，知道什么行不通反而能为你提供找到有效方法的绝佳线索。

Wrapping Up

总结

Congratulations! You’ve finished all ten questions. You’ve amassed more information than almost any other negotiator out there. And in the process of doing so, you may have even discovered a solution to your negotiation. Now you’re ready to bring it home.

恭喜！您已完成全部十道题。您收集的信息比几乎所有其他谈判者都多。而且，在这个过程中，您甚至可能已经找到了谈判的解决方案。现在，您可以全力以赴了。

#↩

BRING IT HOME: CONCLUDING YOUR NEGOTIATION

谈判收尾：如何结束谈判

Congratulations! You’ve finished Ask for More . By this point, you’ve asked yourself five open questions, listened to the answers, and summarized the internal wisdom you uncovered. You then asked someone else—perhaps a client, friend, spouse, or coworker—five open questions that uncovered a universe of new information. You listened, gave the person room to speak, followed up, and summarized. You worked through roadblocks and steered a relationship forward. You’re in a great place compared to most negotiators—and compared to where you started.

恭喜！您已完成“争取更多”练习。到目前为止，您已经问了自己五个开放式问题，认真倾听了答案，并总结了您从中挖掘出的内在智慧。然后，您又向他人——可能是客户、朋友、配偶或同事——提出了五个开放式问题，从而获得了大量新的信息。您认真倾听，给予对方充分的发言空间，并进行了后续跟进和总结。您克服了重重障碍，推动了关系向前发展。与大多数谈判者相比，您现在的水平非常高——也比您最初的状态要好得多。

You may be wondering: “Okay, I’ve asked the questions. What now?” Now is when you take the next step toward steering your future. The information you’ve learned in Ask for More will help you in any negotiation, whether you’re looking to make a deal, pitch a client, resolve a relationship issue, settle a litigation, or reach a personal career goal.

你或许会想：“好了，问题都问完了，接下来该做什么呢？” 现在正是你迈出下一步，掌控自己未来的关键时刻。无论你是想达成交易、向客户推销、解决人际关系问题、化解诉讼，还是实现个人职业目标，你在《争取更多》一书中学到的知识都将助你一臂之力。
