I wrote this book because I know that asking questions is the best way to create a lifetime of value from every negotiation. But I also wrote it because by listening first, to yourself and then someone else, you equip yourself to ask for more —of yourself and others. I want you to use the tools contained in this book to ask audaciously for what you need, what you dream, what you know will create value for you as well as someone else. How to do that? Read on.

我写这本书是因为我知道，在每一次谈判中，提问都是创造终身价值的最佳途径。但我写这本书的另一个原因是，通过先倾听自己，再倾听他人，你就能更好地为自己和他人争取更多。我希望你能运用本书中的工具，大胆地提出你的需求、你的梦想，以及你认为能够为你和他人创造价值的条件。如何做到这一点？请继续阅读。

Sorting the Information You’ve Gathered

整理你收集到的信息

Ask for More helps you ask the right questions in order to explore the past, make sense of the present, and design a better future in negotiation. Each of the ten questions has a purpose. Now that you’ve completed all of them, the picture in front of you starts to look like this:

《争取更多》这本书能帮助你提出正确的问题，从而在谈判中探究过去、理解现在，并规划更美好的未来。书中的十个问题各有其目的。当你完成所有问题后，你眼前的景象将如下所示：

MIRROR

镜子

WINDOW

窗户

My definition of the problem/goal

我对问题/目标的定义

Their definition of the problem/goal

他们对问题/目标的定义

My needs/what those look like

我的需求/这些需求看起来是什么样的

Their needs/what those look like

他们的需求/这些需求具体表现是什么

My feelings/concerns

我的感受/担忧

Their feelings/concerns

他们的感受/担忧

My previous success

我之前的成功

Their previous success

他们之前的成功

My first steps

我的第一步

Their first steps

他们的第一步

A chart like this can be a helpful place for you to put down the summaries you did at the end of each chapter, or any other information you think might be helpful. I’ve included this as a handout at the end of this book (it’s also available for download at my website, alexcarterasks.com/readerworksheet ).

像这样的表格可以帮助你记录每章末尾的总结，或者你认为可能有用的任何其他信息。我已将此表格作为讲义附在本书末尾（也可以从我的网站 alexcarterasks.com/readerworksheet 下载）。

A lot of us are visual thinkers. Therefore, having a copy of this handout could be useful to actually have in front of you to fill out as you’re negotiating. If you’re in a close relationship with the other person at the table, or you’re trying to build trust after a difficult situation, you might even consider showing them the questions and letting them know that you’re trying a new approach to this conversation. For some people, that very act of transparency itself—visibly sharing your notes and working things out right in front of them—could be an important step toward building trust and moving forward.

我们很多人都是视觉型思考者。因此，手边备一份这份资料，在谈判过程中填写，会很有帮助。如果你和谈判桌旁的对方关系密切，或者你正试图在经历一段艰难时期后重建信任，你甚至可以考虑向对方展示这些问题，并让他们知道你正在尝试一种新的沟通方式。对某些人来说，这种透明的行为本身——当着他们的面分享你的笔记并解决问题——可能是建立信任、推动谈判进展的重要一步。

Use These Questions to Set Successful Aspirations

利用这些问题设定成功目标

We know that negotiators who go into negotiation focused on aspirations tend to be more successful than people who focus on what they can lose. Here’s how you can use the questions and answers in this book to make sure you set your aspirations in the right place.

我们知道，谈判者如果着眼于自身期望，往往比那些只关注可能损失的人更容易成功。本书中的问题和答案将帮助你确保将期望设定在正确的位置。

First, we know that aspirations are based on our needs. At the end of the Mirror section in chapter 5 (“What’s the First Step?”), I asked you to look at your needs from chapter 2 (“What Do I Need?”) and consider which steps would fully and completely satisfy your needs. Now that you’re taking another look at these two answers together, do your steps from chapter 5 fully and completely satisfy your needs? If not, add more or make them higher.

首先，我们知道愿望源于我们的需求。在第五章“镜像”部分的结尾（“第一步是什么？”），我请你们回顾第二章（“我需要什么？”）中提出的需求，并思考哪些步骤能够完全满足这些需求。现在，你们再次将这两个答案结合起来审视，第五章中的步骤是否完全满足了你们的需求？如果没有，请增加一些步骤或提高步骤的优先级。

Next, you’ll need to make sure your aspirations are justifiable—and here’s where the Window questions can help. Where possible, you’ll want to tie your asks to anything objective you can find—for example, looking at comparable homes before you make an offer, or examining the costs of operating your business before setting prices for your products. But looking at the other person’s answers to the five Window questions—their definition of the problem, their needs, emotions, successes, and ideas for the future—also tells you how the other person will think about your proposals. Make sure that your asks, while ambitious, can also be justified under at least one of those answers. If your goal is to raise your compensation by 20 percent, and your boss’s primary goal is to reduce cash burn as much as possible right now while the company is trying to raise money, then you may face hurdles unless you can point to another need that would be satisfied by raising your pay (like reducing turnover), or show him ways in which raising your compensation could be compatible with that short-term financial goal (like hiring fewer staff in a less-needed position or increasing your equity, which gets paid out later).

接下来，你需要确保你的期望是合理的——而“窗口问题”正能帮上忙。尽可能地，你应该将你的要求与你能找到的任何客观信息联系起来——例如，在出价前查看类似的房屋，或者在为产品定价前评估运营成本。但同时，观察对方对五个“窗口问题”的回答——他们对问题的定义、他们的需求、他们的情绪、他们的成功以及他们对未来的想法——也能让你了解对方会如何看待你的提议。确保你的要求虽然雄心勃勃，但至少能从上述五个问题中的一个中找到合理的解释。如果你的目标是将薪酬提高 20%，而你的老板的首要目标是在公司努力筹集资金的同时尽可能减少现金消耗，那么你可能会面临一些障碍，除非你能指出提高薪酬可以满足的其他需求（例如降低员工流动率），或者向他展示提高薪酬如何与该短期财务目标相兼容（例如在不太需要的职位上减少员工人数或增加你的股权，这些股权将在以后支付）。

Framing Your End of the Conversation

构建你最后那部分对话的框架

Once you have figured out your thoughts and goals, you’ll want to frame them for maximum success.

一旦你理清了自己的想法和目标，你就需要将它们组织起来，以求获得最大的成功。

What does “framing” mean? When you frame your thoughts, you’re using a skill that many photographers and artists have used to great success. You’re painting an image with your words that will resonate specifically with the person who’s seeing it. And you can’t frame for your audience unless you have a sense of what kinds of themes, words, and ideas will strike the right chord.

“构图”是什么意思？构图是一种技巧，许多摄影师和艺术家都曾成功地运用过。你用文字描绘出一幅画面，这幅画面能够引起特定读者的共鸣。而如果你不清楚哪些主题、词语和想法能够触动人心，你就无法为你的受众构图。

In other words, you can’t persuade unless you listen first.

换句话说，你不先倾听，就无法说服别人。

Framing is essential. Every negotiator should know and master this critical skill. If you’re making an argument for why your department’s budget should be increased, and you appeal to your manager’s sense of equity across departments, that’s not going to land if what she’s really concerned about is the expected return on investment. If you’re working to convince your child that he should try a new activity where he may not know anyone, persuading him that he can make new friends will not work if what he is concerned about is looking silly when trying something for the first time.

框架构建至关重要。每位谈判者都应该了解并掌握这项关键技能。如果你在争取增加部门预算时，诉诸经理对跨部门公平的理念，而她真正关心的是预期投资回报率，那么你的论点就无法奏效。如果你试图说服孩子尝试一项他可能不认识任何人的新活动，而他担心的是第一次尝试时会显得很傻，那么你告诉他可以结交新朋友也是行不通的。

Briefly, here are three winning strategies for framing in negotiation:

简而言之，以下是谈判中三种有效的框架构建策略：

First, where possible, frame your proposals in such a way that they actually respond to the other person’s definition of the problem, needs, concerns, and ideas, as well as your own. For example, if you’re looking to win a home renovation project and convince the homeowners to pay more for your proposal than their lower competing bid, you’ll want to pick up on their needs for quality, dependability, and durability and let them know how you will meet those needs. If you’re looking to reduce your children’s evening screen time, you could let them know you’ve heard that they are tired in the mornings, and turning off the screens at night will help them feel better as they start their day. Having listened to the other person, you now understand much better how they process information and can pitch your proposals in the best possible way.

首先，尽可能地，在提出方案时，要确保方案能够真正回应对方对问题的定义、需求、顾虑和想法，以及你自己的想法。例如，如果你想赢得一个房屋翻新项目，并说服房主为你的方案支付高于其他报价的价格，那么你需要抓住他们对质量、可靠性和耐用性的需求，并让他们知道你将如何满足这些需求。如果你想减少孩子晚上看屏幕的时间，你可以告诉他们，你了解到他们早上很累，晚上关掉屏幕能让他们精神焕发地开始新的一天。在认真倾听对方之后，你就能更好地了解他们如何处理信息，从而以最佳方式推销你的方案。

Second, focus people on what they can gain rather than what they lose . Studies show that human beings are very loss-avoidant, meaning that we want to avoid a loss even more than we want to achieve a gain—and that focusing on losses can reduce the other person’s flexibility and willingness to compromise in negotiation. So for example, instead of saying to two of your employees, “I know you’re best friends but I need to seat you two apart because I’m trying to reduce the cliques in our office,” you instead could point out, “Each of you has told me you’d like to get to know more people in the department so you can advance in your careers. I’ve chosen seats for you that will allow you to work with some new people who will be important to your future promotion.” Both of these statements are true. One of them is likely to move you back, and the other to move you forward.

其次，要让人们关注他们能获得什么，而不是会失去什么。研究表明，人类非常倾向于规避损失，也就是说，我们想要避免损失的程度甚至超过了获得收益的程度——而关注损失会降低对方在谈判中的灵活性和妥协意愿。例如，与其对两位员工说：“我知道你们是最好的朋友，但我需要把你们分开坐，因为我想减少办公室里的小团体”，不如指出：“你们都告诉我，你们想认识部门里更多的人，这样才能在职业发展中得到提升。我已经为你们安排了座位，这样你们就可以和一些对你们未来晋升很重要的新同事一起工作。” 这两种说法都正确。一种说法可能会让你们的晋升之路受阻，而另一种说法则可能让你们的晋升之路更加顺畅。

Finally, be truthful, clear, and direct. When framing an argument, you want to put your best foot forward, but you also need to be consistent with the facts and situation. Framing involves directing people’s attention to the portion of that picture you want to emphasize. But that doesn’t mean showing people a picture of the White House and telling people they’re looking at the Pyramids of Giza.

最后，务必做到真实、清晰、直接。在构建论点时，你当然要展现自己最好的一面，但同时也要与事实和情况保持一致。构建论点意味着引导人们的注意力集中到你想强调的部分。但这并不意味着给人们看一张白宫的照片，却告诉他们眼前是吉萨金字塔。

Being clear and direct is the best and also the most compassionate way to steer a relationship. A lot of times we mess up conversations by obfuscating how we really feel, or what we really want. Instead of saying, for example, “I feel really defensive when we talk about my spending,” we cover up and play offense: “Well, it’s pretty rich that you’re talking to me about my spending when you’re the one who suggested we take a vacation…” This leads to emotional escalation without getting to the heart of things. The direct route—i.e., stating what you actually mean—usually works best.

清晰直接的沟通方式是维系关系的最佳途径，也是最体贴的方式。很多时候，我们因为含糊其辞而搞砸了对话，掩盖了自己的真实感受或真正想要的东西。例如，与其说“一谈到我的消费，我就感觉很抵触”，我们却会掩饰并采取攻击姿态：“你明明是提议我们去度假的人，现在却来跟我谈我的消费，真是讽刺……” 这样只会让情绪升级，却无法触及问题的核心。直截了当的方式——也就是说出你的真实想法——通常是最有效的。

Transparency creates trust. That’s the magic of the Mirror and the Window, right? You can see yourself and someone else more clearly. When you see clearly, you can speak more clearly. In doing so, you give the person a window into you, too. And you help them understand your proposals better, giving you the best chance for success.

透明创造信任。这就是镜子和窗户的魔力，对吧？你可以更清晰地看到自己和他人。当你看得清楚时，你就能更清晰地表达。这样做，你也给了对方一扇了解你的窗口。你帮助他们更好地理解你的提议，从而最大限度地提高成功的机会。

Timing the Rest of Your Negotiation

谈判剩余阶段的时机安排

So do you make that pitch or proposal on the spot, immediately after working through the questions? Part of determining whether to go forward includes an analysis of things like how much time you have. If this is a rare and precious opportunity, you might want to try to move forward right then and there. I might try to bargain for even a short break to gather your thoughts and organize yourself.

所以，你是会在回答完问题后立即提出方案或建议吗？决定是否继续推进，需要考虑诸多因素，例如你还有多少时间。如果这是一个难得的宝贵机会，你或许应该立即着手推进。我可能会尝试争取哪怕是短暂的休息时间，让你整理思路，做好准备。

If you’re dealing with someone in a long-term relationship, like a coworker, repeat client, or spouse—and you don’t have immediate time pressure—just completing the questions, and obtaining all the data they yield, is enough of a success for one meeting. In fact, you might well want to take time to digest the information you learned and consider your path forward. You could, for example, thank the person for meeting you and sharing more of their concerns. Tell them how much you appreciate this and how it’s given you food for thought. Then set another meeting time and use the information you learned to create a path forward.

如果你面对的是长期关系对象，比如同事、老客户或配偶，而且时间并不紧迫，那么仅仅完成问卷调查并收集到所有信息，对一次会面来说就已经足够成功了。事实上，你完全可以花些时间消化这些信息，思考下一步该怎么做。例如，你可以感谢对方抽出时间与你见面，并分享他们的顾虑。告诉他们你对此非常感激，并表示这些信息给了你很多启发。然后，安排下一次会面，利用这次了解到的信息来制定下一步的计划。

In deciding whether to go forward or take a break, you should also consider whether you’re the type of person who synthesizes things quickly, or whether you need time for reflection before making your next move. And the same is true for the other person in your negotiation. I have worked for both kinds of bosses, one who always said, “Let’s do this!” and one who said, “Thanks for presenting this information, Alex. Let’s set up a time to talk next week.” Knowing this about yourself and the other person will help you make the decision that sets you up for the greatest success.

在决定是继续推进还是暂停谈判时，你还应该考虑自己是那种能迅速整合信息的人，还是需要时间思考后再采取下一步行动。谈判的另一方也一样。我曾为两种类型的上司工作过，一位总是说：“我们开始吧！”另一位则会说：“谢谢你提供这些信息，Alex。我们下周找个时间谈谈。”了解自己和对方的这些特点，将有助于你做出最有利于成功的决定。

You also want to check the other person for signs of fatigue or emotional exhaustion. How long did your conversation last? What kind of topics came up? What was their reaction to these questions, and how did they seem to feel by the end of the conversation? Are they energized, asking, “So what’s next?” Or do they show signs of fatigue? If they are tapping their watch or lapsing into checking email, that might be a sign that the stress of having been away from work for a bit is creeping up, and you’ll want to set another time to make your ask. You want their full attention.

你还需要观察对方是否有疲倦或情绪低落的迹象。你们的谈话持续了多久？都聊了些什么？他们对这些问题的反应如何？谈话结束时，他们的感受如何？他们是否精神抖擞，问“接下来呢？”？还是显露出疲态？如果他们不时看表或开始查看邮件，这可能表明他们暂时离开工作岗位的压力正在逐渐累积，这时你需要另约时间再提出你的请求。你需要他们全神贯注地倾听。

Also, make sure to check yourself for fatigue and emotional exhaustion. Listening like this takes a lot of focus. Depending on how long your conversation lasted and what emotions came up, you may need a break before moving forward. Sometimes my mediations with my students last a full day. When they do, we usually structure the day so that we spend the morning talking about the past and the afternoon talking about the future. And what do we do in the middle? We eat lunch. A break helps all of us regain focus and energy to start problem-solving.

此外，务必留意自己是否感到疲劳和情绪低落。像这样倾听需要高度集中注意力。根据谈话持续时间和所涉及的情绪，你可能需要休息一下才能继续。有时，我和学生的调解会持续一整天。在这种情况下，我们通常会安排上午讨论过去，下午讨论未来。中间做什么呢？我们吃午饭。休息有助于我们所有人恢复精力和注意力，以便更好地解决问题。

If you do decide to reconvene at a later time, here’s what you do to close the meeting. First, start with a summary of the progress you made and the information you shared. Next, thank the person for their time, energy, and openness. If any of you has made promises about doing any work—gathering information or documents, for example—between now and the next meeting, summarize that, too.

如果您决定稍后再次召开会议，以下是会议结束的步骤。首先，总结一下会议取得的进展和分享的信息。其次，感谢对方的时间、精力和坦诚。如果你们中有人承诺在下次会议之前完成任何工作——例如收集信息或文件——也请一并总结。

Where to Start the Discussion

从哪里开始讨论

So let’s say you’ve decided to go forward after finishing these questions. After you ask your Window questions and summarize, the other person may open up and ask you some of the same questions. For example, they may ask you for your needs after you’ve asked theirs. If they do, you’ll be prepared. If they don’t ask you questions and instead seem ready to start talking about the future, you can let them know that you’ve prepared for this conversation so your thoughts and proposals would come from an informed place. You can then share as much of your answers as you like, and use them to frame any proposals you have.

假设你在完成这些问题后决定继续进行下去。在你提出并总结了你的“窗口期”问题后，对方可能会敞开心扉，问你一些相同的问题。例如，在你询问了对方的需求之后，他们可能会问你的需求。如果他们这样做，你就能做好准备。如果他们没有问你问题，而是似乎准备开始谈论未来，你可以告诉他们你已经为这次谈话做好了准备，这样你的想法和建议才会基于充分的信息。然后，你可以分享你认为合适的答案，并用它们来构建你的任何建议。

When you craft your proposals, you have a wealth of information to help you do so more successfully. You might, for example, look at where their needs (chapter 7, “What Do You Need?”) match up with yours (chapter 2, “What Do I Need?”) and use that to design a solution that works for both parties. You can also look at how your vision for the future (chapter 5, “What’s the First Step?”) aligns or complements theirs (chapter 10, “What’s the First Step?”) in deciding what is likely to satisfy each of you. And if you know how they’re feeling (chapter 8, “What Are Your Concerns?”), you can consider your own feelings (chapter 3, “What Do I Feel?”) and consider how to frame your proposal in a way that maximizes your chances for success.

在撰写提案时，您可以利用丰富的信息来提高提案的成功率。例如，您可以查看对方的需求（第7章，“您需要什么？”）与您自身的需求（第2章，“我需要什么？”）的匹配之处，并以此为基础设计一个对双方都适用的解决方案。您还可以考虑您对未来的愿景（第5章，“第一步是什么？”）如何与对方的愿景（第10章，“第一步是什么？”）相契合或互补，从而确定哪些方案最有可能满足双方的需求。如果您了解对方的感受（第8章，“您的顾虑是什么？”），您可以考虑自己的感受（第3章，“我的感受是什么？”），并思考如何调整提案的措辞，以最大限度地提高成功率。

If your conversation brought up multiple issues, which do you tackle first? Here are some ideas:

如果你们的谈话涉及多个问题，你们应该先解决哪个问题？以下是一些建议：

LOW-HANGING FRUIT. If you share any common first steps, that’s great! If you both agreed on something, summarize that and maybe propose it. Or if there’s an issue on which you’re pretty close, you might try narrowing the gap there and generating some momentum.

唾手可得的成果。如果你们有任何共同的初步想法，那就太好了！如果你们都同意某些事情，那就总结一下，然后提出来。或者，如果你们在某个问题上非常接近，可以尝试缩小分歧，并以此为契机推动进展。

In fact, when I’m helping people negotiate, I often build a chart in my notes that looks something like this:

事实上，当我帮助别人谈判时，我经常在笔记中创建一个类似这样的图表：

PERSON 1

人员 1

COMMON

常见的

PERSON 2

第二人

Definition of the problem/goal

问题/目标定义

Definition of the problem/goal

问题/目标定义

Needs/what those look like

需求/它们看起来是什么样的

Needs/what those look like

需求/它们看起来是什么样的

Feelings/concerns

感受/担忧

Feelings/concerns

感受/担忧

Previous success

以往的成功

Previous success

以往的成功

First steps

第一步

First steps

第一步

The center column is where I put down any common information I hear. If the two negotiators agree on any first steps, that can be a great place to start and build momentum.

中间一栏是我记录听到的所有共同信息的地方。如果双方谈判者就任何初步步骤达成一致，这可以成为一个很好的起点，并有助于推进谈判进程。

NEEDS OR FEELINGS IN COMMON. If both of you had one of the same needs or feelings, that too could be a great place to start. You can capture common feelings or concerns in the chart above and start there when finding a path forward.

共同的需求或感受。如果你们双方有相同的需求或感受，这也可以是一个很好的切入点。你们可以在上面的表格中记录共同的感受或担忧，并以此为起点，寻找前进的方向。

Things to watch for and highlight: when you have common interests, feelings, or ideas about the problem but different visions for what to do about them. For example, both you and your department head are concerned that you’re losing employees to a competitor. You think that one step toward retaining employees would be to offer more remote work, while your department head says, “Nothing short of more compensation is going to be effective.” I find it helpful to summarize the common feeling or need, and the different options to meet it. You might decide together to generate some additional ideas (and/or survey employees on what they need) and strategize your solution.

需要注意和强调的事项：当你们对某个问题有共同的兴趣、感受或想法，但对如何解决却有不同的看法时。例如，你和你的部门主管都担心员工流失到竞争对手那里。你认为留住员工的一个方法是提供更多远程办公机会，而你的部门主管则认为“只有提高薪酬才能奏效”。我发现，总结共同的感受或需求以及满足这些感受或需求的不同方案很有帮助。你们可以共同探讨一些其他的想法（和/或调查员工的需求），并制定解决方案的策略。

SHORT-TERM ISSUES. If this is an ongoing negotiation or relationship, you might try something out for a few weeks or months and then set a second date to evaluate the approach and see how it went. For example, if you’re working on communicating better with your partner about when you each need time off from childcare, it may be very helpful to try one approach—a schedule, trade, or even a secret hand signal—and set a time to meet again and talk about how it went. If you’re negotiating with a new product distributor about inventory or shelf placement, you might have more success getting a short-term agreement and then trusting that the quality of your product will resonate with consumers.

短期问题。如果这是一项持续进行的谈判或关系，您可以尝试某种方法几周或几个月，然后安排第二次会面来评估该方法的效果。例如，如果您正在努力与伴侣更好地沟通，以便双方都能抽出时间照顾孩子，那么尝试一种方法——例如制定时间表、交换照看孩子的时间，甚至是使用秘密手势——并安排时间再次见面讨论效果，可能会很有帮助。如果您正在与新产品分销商谈判库存或货架摆放位置，那么达成短期协议，然后相信您的产品质量会受到消费者的欢迎，可能会更容易取得成功。

RECURRING THEMES. If one need or feeling comes up over and over, you might need to work on that before anything else. Try tackling that one and then sequence others later. For example, if your department at work is divided over whether to hire a particular person, and the hiring process has left both sides feeling unheard and left out, you might need to address questions about the process first, before moving to discuss whether to hire. If you’re working with a client on a large web design project and they keep talking about what they see as the lack of communication coming from your firm, you may want to talk about communication first before talking about the substance of the project.

反复出现的主题。如果某种需求或感受反复出现，你可能需要优先处理它。先尝试解决这个问题，然后再按顺序处理其他问题。例如，如果你的部门在是否招聘某个人的问题上存在分歧，而且招聘过程让双方都感到被忽视和被排除在外，那么你可能需要先解决有关招聘流程的问题，然后再讨论是否招聘。如果你正在与客户合作一个大型网站设计项目，而他们一直抱怨你们公司缺乏沟通，那么你可能需要先讨论沟通问题，然后再讨论项目的具体内容。

Troubleshooting

故障排除

As always, here is some advice for any snags you might encounter as you prepare to finish your negotiation.

和往常一样，这里有一些建议，可以帮助你解决在准备完成谈判过程中可能遇到的任何问题。

What If Open Questions Don’t Work?

如果开放式问题行不通怎么办？

Sometimes people aren’t ready to open up when asked an open question. In that case, try to make a connection and find another way in. I’ll never forget the time I took my student, Nona, to mediate a school absence case in New York City between a mom and a teenage son. The mom desperately wanted her son to go to school. The son had been absent to the point where his graduation could be in jeopardy. We sat down in mediation. My student asked the son many open questions, but got nothing but a shrug in return. Not a single word.

有时候，人们面对开放式问题时并不愿意敞开心扉。在这种情况下，试着建立联系，寻找其他切入点。我永远不会忘记，我曾带着我的学生诺娜去纽约市调解一起关于孩子旷课的纠纷，当事人是一位母亲和她十几岁的儿子。母亲迫切希望儿子能去上学。儿子旷课的次数已经多到可能影响他的毕业。我们坐下来进行调解。我的学生问了儿子很多开放式问题，但得到的却只有耸肩的回应。一句话也没说。

Finally, she asked the mom if we could talk to her son alone. The mom immediately packed up and said, “Great, you talk to him! Maybe he’ll actually say something to you!” Then she left us in the room alone with him. My student mediator once again asked him open questions. Nothing.

最后，她问那位妈妈我们是否可以单独和她儿子谈谈。妈妈立刻收拾东西，说：“太好了，你们去跟他谈谈！说不定他会跟你们说点什么呢！”然后就把我们单独留在房间里。我的学生调解员再次问了他一些开放式问题。他什么也没说。

Finally, she turned her chair away from me, and toward him. She leaned in and asked, “So, you’re basically here ’cause you’re forced to be, huh?” Not an open question. But it worked. He looked up, finally, and then shrugged again. But now she had his interest. She continued, “Me too. That’s my professor over there (points at me). She says if I don’t show up here every week, I fail the course.” Brilliant move. The teenager opened up and started talking. When the open questions failed, she found a point of connection and used it to open the door. If you run into a similar roadblock, put these questions to the side. Try to make a human connection with the person across the table. Build some trust. You can always come back to these questions when you’re both ready.

最后，她把椅子转过身，背对着我，转向他。她凑近问道：“所以，你来这儿基本上是被迫的，是吗？” 这并非一个开放式问题，但却奏效了。他终于抬起头，然后又耸了耸肩。但现在她成功引起了他的兴趣。她继续说道：“我也是。那边那位是我的教授（指着我）。她说如果我每周不来，这门课就挂科。” 这招真妙。这位少年敞开了心扉，开始说话。当开放式问题失效时，她找到了一个共同点，并以此打开了话匣子。如果你也遇到类似的障碍，不妨先把这些问题放在一边。试着与对面的人建立起人与人之间的联系，建立一些信任。等到双方都准备好了，你随时可以再回头问这些问题。

“Why Are You Talking Like This?”

你为什么这样说话？

My husband and I started dating after I’d learned the kind of listening we talk about in this book. But what about your relationships where the other person is, ahem, going to notice that you are not exactly talking like yourself? If the person reacts to your new open steering style with a “What have you been drinking?” or a slow blink of disbelief… that’s fine! My advice: Be honest. Tell your loved one what you’re doing and how it will help them as well as you. One way to respond could be: “You’re absolutely right—this isn’t the way I normally talk. I’ve been working on my communication, and listening better to the people around me. I’m going to be trying this from now on.” For the workplace, you might try something like, “I’ve been studying negotiation and what people can do to create better conversations in the workplace. This conversation is important, and I wanted to approach it in the best way for both of us.”

我和我丈夫是在我学会了本书中提到的那种倾听技巧之后才开始约会的。但是，如果你的伴侣注意到你的说话方式和平时不太一样，该怎么办呢？如果对方对你这种全新的开放式沟通方式的反应是“你喝了什么？”或者难以置信地眨眨眼……没关系！我的建议是：坦诚相待。告诉你的爱人你在做什么，以及这样做对他们和你自己有什么好处。你可以这样回应：“你说得对——我平时说话不是这样的。我一直在努力提升沟通技巧，更好地倾听身边的人。从现在开始，我会尝试这种方式。” 如果是在职场，你可以这样说：“我一直在学习谈判技巧，以及如何在职场中创造更好的沟通方式。这次谈话很重要，我想用对我们双方都最有利的方式来进行。”

What If It Doesn’t Work—At All?

如果完全行不通怎么办？

And what if you’re in a situation where these questions can’t get you to your goal? I once had a student in my mediation class who, near the end of the semester, wrote me a weekly journal with a cover note that said, “Here is my weekly journal. Sorry if this is too personal.” By now, I know that means, “Here’s the real reason I took your class.” In her journal, she talked about having a mother with Narcissistic Personality Disorder. She had enrolled in the Mediation Clinic in part because she wanted to learn a skill that might help her in her legal career—but really, what she wanted was to find a way to heal her relationship with her mother. She told me that the open questions and summarizing skills she had learned had been hugely helpful in clarifying her own goals and keeping their interactions more safe, but that she ultimately had not made progress with her mother, who continued to move the goalposts every time my student identified a common need or proposed a way forward. My student felt that her mother continued to find new ways to generate conflict with her. She asked if I had any other ideas for how she could make this better, or if there was something she might be missing.

如果你遇到的情况是，这些问题都无法帮助你达成目标，该怎么办？我曾经有一位调解课的学生，在学期末给我写了一篇周记，附言写道：“这是我的周记。如果内容太私人，请见谅。” 现在我知道，她的意思是：“这就是我选这门课的真正原因。” 在日记里，她谈到了自己患有自恋型人格障碍的母亲。她报名参加调解诊所的部分原因是想学习一项可能对她的法律职业生涯有所帮助的技能——但实际上，她真正想要的是找到修复与母亲关系的方法。她告诉我，她学到的开放式提问和总结技巧对她明确自身目标、让与母亲的互动更加安全非常有帮助，但最终她与母亲的关系并没有取得任何进展。每当她提出共同需求或建议前进的方向时，她的母亲都会不断改变目标。我的学生感觉，她的母亲总能找到新的方式来制造与她的冲突。她问我是否还有其他方法可以改进这件事，或者她是否遗漏了什么。

Gently, I told her I thought she might be asking the wrong question—that perhaps this was not within her control at all. That perhaps her mother needed this conflict in some way, and was resisting efforts to solve or transform it. So maybe my student’s work was to use the Mirror questions to identify her own needs and boundaries, and articulate those in order to keep herself safe.

我温和地告诉她，我觉得她可能问错了问题——也许这件事根本不在她掌控之中。也许她的母亲在某种程度上需要这种冲突，并且抗拒解决或化解它的努力。所以，也许我的学生需要做的，是运用“镜像问题”来识别自己的需求和界限，并清晰地表达出来，从而保护自己。

All this to say: These questions presuppose certain conditions. They assume that the person on the other side is dealing in good faith. That the person does not have a personality disorder, or some reason why they need the conflict to exist. You will still get tremendous value from doing these questions, even in such a situation. For one thing, you will clarify your own sense of the problem—your needs, emotions, prior successes, and ideas for the future. Some of those steps may be within your control, and now you’re on your way to achieving them. You will also have the satisfaction of knowing that you gave this conflict or issue a shot. You can’t know until you try. And if you try and are not successful for one of the reasons I listed above, that is useful information to have. Now you can work toward achieving clarity on a different path forward, one that does not involve a partnership with the other person. In my student’s case, she used these questions to articulate her needs and set a boundary with her mother. It isn’t the relationship she dreamed of, but she feels safer and more accepting of the situation as it is.

总而言之：这些问题都基于一些前提条件。它们假定对方是出于善意，没有性格障碍，或者没有其他需要制造冲突的理由。即便在这种情况下，你仍然能从这些问题中获益匪浅。首先，你会更清晰地了解自己对问题的理解——你的需求、情绪、过往的成功以及对未来的想法。其中一些步骤可能在你掌控之中，而现在你正朝着目标迈进。你也会因为尝试过而感到满足。不尝试就永远不会知道结果。如果你尝试后因为上述原因之一而失败，这本身也是有用的信息。现在你可以努力寻找一条不同的前进道路，一条无需与对方合作的道路。我的学生就运用这些问题来阐明自己的需求，并与母亲划清界限。这并非她梦寐以求的恋爱关系，但她感到更安全，也更能接受现状。

Closing Thoughts

结语

I wrote this book to bring you techniques that you can use to improve any negotiation or relationship in your life. And in doing so, improve your life itself.

我写这本书的目的是为了向你介绍一些技巧，你可以运用这些技巧来改善生活中任何谈判或人际关系。而通过这些技巧，你也能改善自己的人生。

They’ve certainly improved mine. When I first learned the skills you’ve read about in this book, I found that not only did I negotiate better, with myself and with others, but I felt a lot happier. I simultaneously felt more confident and more connected to the people around me. And then I used these skills to find my professional calling as a professor, mediator, and negotiation coach. Today and every day, I wake up knowing that I am doing what I was put on this earth to do. My purpose in writing this book was to help you do, and feel, the same. I love helping people reach their own personal highest and best, and then go on to share what they have learned with others.

它们确实提升了我的能力。当我第一次学习本书中提到的技巧时，我发现自己不仅在与自己和他人谈判时表现得更好了，而且也感到更加快乐。与此同时，我感到更加自信，与周围的人也更加亲近。之后，我运用这些技巧找到了我的职业方向——成为一名教授、调解员和谈判教练。如今，每天醒来，我都确信自己正在做我来到这个世界的使命。我写这本书的目的就是为了帮助你也能做到这一点，并拥有同样的感受。我热爱帮助人们发挥出他们个人的最大潜能，并将他们所学到的知识分享给他人。

In the course of writing this book, I’ve taken you along for some of the highs and lows of my life. In many ways, writing this book has felt like one long look in the Mirror. But I did this for a reason. I wrote this book from the Mirror so that you would feel free to negotiate from yours. I want you to know that when you go out to ask for more, you can do so as your full, authentic self. Not only is it okay, but you’ll be most successful when you do.

在写作这本书的过程中，我带你体验了我人生中的一些高潮和低谷。在很多方面，写作这本书就像是对着镜子长时间地审视自己。但我这样做是有原因的。我以镜子中的视角来写这本书，是为了让你们也能自由地从自己的视角出发去争取。我想让你们知道，当你们想要追求更多的时候，你们可以以完整、真实的自我去表达。这样做不仅可以，而且你们也会因此获得最大的成功。

When people complete negotiation training with me, even if just for a day, I tell them at the end that I consider them my new colleagues. What does that mean? It means you’re now part of a community that is trying to “do good” in their negotiations even as they go out to achieve their goals. It means I want you to consider me your partner in your work from here on, to stay in touch, and tell me what you go on to do with what you have learned. And it means I hope you’ll share some of what you’ve learned with others in your life. When you stay curious in your negotiations and relationships, you’ll see that other people start looking to you as a model, and do the same. In this way, good negotiators become leaders—at home, at work, and in the world.

当人们完成我的谈判培训后，哪怕只是一天，我都会在最后告诉他们，我把他们视为我的新同事。这意味着什么呢？这意味着你现在加入了一个社群，这个社群致力于在谈判中“行善”，同时也努力实现他们的目标。这意味着我希望从今以后，你把我视为工作伙伴，与我保持联系，并告诉我你如何运用所学知识。这也意味着我希望你能与生活中其他人分享你所学到的知识。当你对谈判和人际关系保持好奇心时，你会发现其他人开始以你为榜样，并效仿你。如此一来，优秀的谈判者就能成为领导者——无论是在家庭、工作还是在社会上。

Ask for More: 10 Questions to Negotiate Anything

争取更多：谈判中用到的 10 个问题

BY ALEXANDRA CARTER

作者：亚历山德拉·卡特

THE MIRROR

镜子

THE WINDOW

窗户

My definition of the problem/goal:

我对问题/目标的定义：

What’s the problem I want to solve?

我想解决什么问题？

Their definition of the problem/goal

他们对问题/目标的定义

Tell me…

告诉我…

My needs/what those look like

我的需求/这些需求看起来是什么样的

What do I need?

我需要什么？

Their needs/what those look like

他们的需求/这些需求具体表现是什么

What do you need?

你需要什么？

My feelings/concerns

我的感受/担忧

What do I feel?

我感觉如何？

Their feelings/concerns

他们的感受/担忧

What are your concerns?

您有哪些顾虑？

My previous success

我之前的成功

How have I handled this successfully in the past?

我过去是如何成功处理这类事情的？

Their previous success

他们之前的成功

How have you handled this successfully in the past?

你过去是如何成功处理这类问题的？

My first steps

我的第一步

What’s the first step?

第一步是什么？

Their first steps

他们的第一步

What’s the first step?

第一步是什么？

#↩

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

致谢

This section was the hardest of any to write. From the moment I dreamed up the idea for this book to the moment of its publication, I have been lifted up by a huge community of family, friends, and colleagues. I owe everything to your support. Any errors are mine alone.

这一部分写起来最难。从我萌生写这本书的想法到它出版的那一刻，我始终得到家人、朋友和同事们的鼎力支持。我的一切都归功于你们的支持。如有任何错误，均由我一人承担。

Profound thanks to Carol Liebman, my mentor, who first taught me to fish with a net, and to my community of dispute resolution colleagues across the country.

衷心感谢我的导师卡罗尔·利布曼，她教会了我如何用网捕鱼；还要感谢全国各地的纠纷解决领域的同事们。

To my editor, Stephanie Frerich, who on our first phone call told me this was the negotiation book she’d been waiting for her whole professional life. You’re the intellectual partner I’ve been waiting for all of mine. Thank you to my editing team at Simon & Schuster: editors Kimberly Goldstein and Annie Craig; publisher Jonathan Karp, and editor Emily Simonson. To my artistic team for helping me bring this book to visual and audible life: Lauren Pires, Jackie Seow, and Tom Spain. And to the rest of the team at Simon & Schuster that has enabled this book to empower people across the globe to ask for more: Kayley Hoffman, Alicia Brancato, Marie Florio, and Fritha Saunders.

致我的编辑斯蒂芬妮·弗雷里希，我们第一次通电话时，她就告诉我，这是她整个职业生涯都在等待的谈判书籍。而你，正是我一直以来苦苦寻觅的良师益友。感谢西蒙与舒斯特出版社的编辑团队：编辑金伯利·戈德斯坦和安妮·克雷格；出版人乔纳森·卡普；以及编辑艾米丽·西蒙森。感谢我的艺术团队，是他们帮助我将这本书以视觉和听觉的形式呈现出来：劳伦·皮雷斯、杰基·肖和汤姆·斯佩恩。还要感谢西蒙与舒斯特出版社的其他团队成员，是你们的付出让这本书能够激励世界各地的人们去争取更多：凯莉·霍夫曼、艾丽西亚·布兰卡托、玛丽·弗洛里奥和弗里莎·桑德斯。

To my agents, Esther Newberg and Kristyn Benton. I couldn’t be prouder to be represented by you and by ICM Partners, an agency publicly committed to gender parity at all levels of management.

致我的经纪人埃丝特·纽伯格和克里斯汀·本顿：能由你们以及ICM Partners代理，我感到无比自豪。ICM Partners是一家公开承诺在各个管理层级实现性别平等的经纪公司。

To my graduate, friend, and all-around inspiration, Kristen J. Ferguson, for holding up the mirror and helping me conceptualize this project. If I gave birth to this book, you were my first midwife. Thank you for being the message.

致我的毕业生、朋友，也是我人生中最重要的灵感来源——克里斯汀·J·弗格森，感谢你像一面镜子一样映照出我的内心，并帮助我构思了这个项目。如果说这本书是我孕育的，那么你就是我的第一位助产士。感谢你传递了如此重要的信息。

To my colleagues at Columbia Law School, with special thanks to Dean Gillian Lester, Vice Dean Brett Dignam, and all my clinical faculty colleagues. Thank you to the entire Columbia Law School clinical administrative team: Brenda Eberhart, Michelle Ellis, Elizabeth Gloder, Mirlande Mersier, and Misty Swan. To those who generously spent time reading my book or offering advice and encouragement, including Elizabeth Emens, Michelle Greenberg-Kobrin, Avery Katz, Sarah Knuckey, Gillian Metzger, Colleen Shanahan, Susan Sturm, and Matthew Waxman. Thank you to my mentors, Robert Ferguson and Louis Henkin, for believing in me. I wish you were here to hold this book in your hands, but know that I am holding you in my heart. 致我在哥伦比亚法学院的同事们，特别感谢院长吉莉安·莱斯特、副院长布雷特·迪格纳姆以及所有临床教学同事。感谢哥伦比亚法学院全体临床行政团队成员：布伦达·埃伯哈特、米歇尔·埃利斯、伊丽莎白·格洛德、米兰德·梅西耶和米斯蒂·斯旺。感谢那些慷慨抽出时间阅读我的书或提供建议和鼓励的人们，包括伊丽莎白·埃门斯、米歇尔·格林伯格-科布林、艾弗里·卡茨、莎拉·纳基、吉莉安·梅茨格、科琳·沙纳汉、苏珊·斯特姆和马修·瓦克斯曼。感谢我的导师罗伯特·弗格森和路易斯·亨金，感谢你们对我的信任。我多么希望你们能亲手捧起这本书，但请相信，我永远把你们放在心上。感谢我一生的调解伙伴肖恩·沃茨，你们给予我的恩情远非我能在此一一尽述。

I teach the best students in the world. To my entire Columbia Law School student team, thank you for your ideas, edits, and your unfailing belief in this project: Jennifer Q. Ange, David S. Your expertise, your editorial input, and your hearts are reflected everywhere in this book.

我教的是世界上最优秀的学生。在此，我要感谢我哥伦比亚法学院全体学生团队，感谢你们的创意、修改和对这个项目始终如一的信任：Jennifer Q. Ange、David S. Blackman、Argemira Flórez Feng、Heidi L. To my family, for your support and advice. Special thanks to family authors Bill Carter and Caela Carter for paving the way. Ask for More is just the latest in the bookshelf of Carter volumes. My mother, Vera Carter, for being a role model in the classroom and in life. My father, Richard Carter, for teaching me grit and resilience. My bonus mom, Nikki Carter, for her encouragement. 感谢我的挚友们，感谢你们一路以来对我的鼓励和支持，包括 Dawn Behrmann、Paolo Bowyer、Jennifer Brick、Allison Ciechanover、Shoshana Eisenberg、Deborah Engel、Elyse Epstein、Ruth Hartman、Malia Rulon Herman、Meredith Katz、Reshma Ketkar、Lisa Landers、Marcia LeBeau、Marie McGehee、Laura Mummolo-Collins、Melanie Painvin、Dina Pressel、Rebecca Price 和 Meghan Siket。

For stories, feedback, advice, comments and support, I am indebted to more people than I can capture here, including Kristy Bryce, Kate Buchanan, Autumn Calabrese, Julie China, Lisa Courtney, Ambassador Luis Gallegos, David Greenwald, Jamila Hall, Janet Stone Herman, Art Hinshaw, Kiley Holliday, Mila Jasey, Heather Kasdan, Bonnie Lau, Jodi Lipper, Shuva Mandal, Danielle and Celia Mann, Gabriel Matus, Ben McAdams, Julie Judd McAdams, Jamie Meier, Gray and Suzanne Sexton, Andra Shapiro, Ritu Sharma, Sherri Sparaga, George M. 对于提供故事、反馈、建议、评论和支持的人，我感激不尽，无法在此一一列举，其中包括 Kristy Bryce、Kate Buchanan、Autumn Calabrese、Julie China、Lisa Courtney、Luis Gallegos 大使、David Greenwald、Jamila Hall、Janet Stone Herman、Art Hinshaw、Kiley Holliday、Mila Jasey、Heather Kasdan、Bonnie Lau、Jodi Lipper、Shuva Mandal、Danielle 和 Celia Mann、Gabriel Matus、Ben McAdams、Julie Judd McAdams、Jamie Meier、Gray 和 Suzanne Sexton、Andra Shapiro、Ritu Sharma、Sherri Sparaga、George M. Soneff、Melody Tan、Mary Theroux、Anastasia Tsioulcas、Amy Walsh、Daniel Weitz、Elisha Wiesel、尊敬的 Mark L. Wolf 先生和 Mei Xu。

To my colleagues at the United Nations and UNITAR: Assistant Secretary-General Nikhil Seth, Ambassador Marco Suazo, Pelayo Alvarez, Jones Haertle, Julia Maciel, and all of the hundreds of diplomats who have attended our courses and contributed to this book via their experiences.

致我在联合国和联合国训练研究所的同事们：助理秘书长尼基尔·塞思、大使马尔科·苏亚索、佩拉约·阿尔瓦雷斯、琼斯·哈特尔、朱莉娅·马西埃尔，以及所有参加过我们课程并通过他们的经验为本书做出贡献的数百名外交官。

To my friends and colleagues around the globe for their support. In Japan: Ambassador Ricardo Allicock, President Junko Hibiya of ICU, Michael Kawachi and family, and the rest of my Japan family. In Brazil: my mediation colleague, friend, and Brazilian sister, Professora Lilia Maia de Morais Sales and family; Professor Gustavo Feitosa; and my entire extended family at the University of Fortaleza, including the late Dr. Jose Airton Vidal Queiroz and President Fatima Veras.

感谢全球各地朋友和同事们的支持。在日本：感谢里卡多·阿利科克大使、国际基督教大学校长日比谷纯子、川内迈克尔及其家人，以及我在日本的其他亲人。在巴西：感谢我的调解同事、朋友和巴西姐妹莉莉娅·玛雅·德·莫赖斯·萨莱斯教授及其家人；古斯塔沃·费托萨教授；以及我在福塔莱萨大学的所有亲人，包括已故的何塞·艾尔顿·维达尔·奎罗斯博士和法蒂玛·维拉斯校长。

To Mark Fortier and Melissa Connors, my publicists at Fortier Public Relations, Kenneth Gillett and the team at Target Marketing Digital, as well as Brandi Bernoskie, Elsa Isaac, Tara Lauren, Gregory Patterson, and Rachel Zorel of 7 Layer Studio, for helping me bring this message to the world.

感谢 Fortier Public Relations 的 Mark Fortier 和 Melissa Connors，Target Marketing Digital 的 Kenneth Gillett 和团队，以及 7 Layer Studio 的 Brandi Bernoskie、Elsa Isaac、Tara Lauren、Gregory Patterson 和 Rachel Zorel，感谢他们帮助我将这一信息传递给全世界。

Every word of this book is brought to you by the superlative coffee and carbs found at Liv Breads in Millburn, New Jersey, owned by my friends Elana and Yaniv Livneh.

本书的每一个字都由我的朋友 Elana 和 Yaniv Livneh 在新泽西州米尔本经营的 Liv Breads 提供的顶级咖啡和碳水化合物赞助。

And to my home community of Maplewood, New Jersey, thank you for loving me and my family while I worked to bring this book into being.

感谢我的家乡新泽西州梅普尔伍德社区，感谢你们在我创作这本书的过程中对我和我的家人的爱。

#↩

ABOUT THE AUTHOR

关于作者

© NICK ONKEN

© 尼克·昂肯

ALEXANDRA CARTER is a clinical professor of law and director of the Mediation Clinic at Columbia Law School. She is a negotiation trainer for the United Nations, as well as for Fortune 500 companies, government agencies, non-profits, and more. Carter graduated with honors from Georgetown University, was a Fulbright Scholar in Taiwan, and received her law degree from Columbia Law School. In 2019, Carter was awarded Columbia University’s highest teaching honor. She lives in Maplewood, New Jersey, with her husband and daughter.

亚历山德拉·卡特是哥伦比亚大学法学院的临床法学教授兼调解诊所主任。她为联合国、财富500强企业、政府机构、非营利组织等提供谈判培训。卡特以优异的成绩毕业于乔治城大学，曾获富布赖特奖学金赴台湾深造，并获得哥伦比亚大学法学院的法学学位。2019年，卡特荣获哥伦比亚大学最高教学荣誉。她与丈夫和女儿居住在新泽西州梅普尔伍德。
